LONDON, Aug. 20 Word of Britain's improved July exportimport performance took some pressure off the pound last week briefly. By Friday sterling seemed to have reverted to a slow, steady sag and the reasons were not hard to find.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21--The National Association of Manufacturers endorsed a tax increase today as necessary to reduce an "intolerable" budget deficit that Administration officials have said might go as high as $29-billion.
A 144-year tradition will end tomorrow when the Ambrose Lightship is dismissed from duty as the landmark to the entrance of New York Harbor.
Fifty women arrested on charges of prostitution late Sunday night and early yesterday morning in the Times Square area were arraigned yesterday in Women's Court.

ARLINGTON, Va., Aug. 21 --Mr. and Mrs. A. d'Arcy Harvey have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Gael Harvey, to Charles Edward Yonkers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Rolley Yonkers of Delray Beach, Fla., formerly of Scarsdale, N.Y.
Trading hours returned to normal yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and prices continued a decline that set in last week.
COLLEGE PARK, Md., Aug. 21--The National Student Association approved at its congress today a militant resolution endorsing black power after about 50 Negro delegates had threatened to walk out.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Aug. 22--Planes from the carrier Oriskany bombed the main power plant in Hanoi yesterday during one of the heaviest days of air strikes in the area of the North Vietnamese capital.

H. Rap Brown spent another day in jail yesterday after his lawyers again had failed to convince a United States Commissioner that $25,000 bail was excessive.

LONDON, Aug. 21--The British Government apologized to the United States Embassy today for the machine gunning of the embassy's western side last night, but the police remained baffled in attempts to find the perpetrators.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21-- An official Czechoslovak pathologist concluded today that Charles H. Jordan, senior officer of an American Jewish relief organization, died by drowning after his disappearance in Prague Wednesday night.
QANTARA, United Arab Republic, Aug. 17--The four white jeeps clustered around the signal house at El Firdan railway bridge seemed a natural part of the barren scene.
LIGONIER, Pa., Aug. 21 (AP)--A shoulder ailment cramped Arnold Palmer in the first round today of the 51st Pennsylvania open golf championship as Barry Masick took the-lead with a par 71.
The Consolidated Foods Corporation achieved record profits in the fiscal year ended June 30 and exceeded the $1billion mark in sales for the first time, its annual report disclosed yesterday.
More than a million international travelers passed through the Port of New York last month. It was the first time that a one-month total reached that mark.

FREEHOLD, N. J., Aug. 21 (AP)--Snow Globe, driven by Eddie Cobb and owned by Leon Machiz of Great Neck, L. I., won the $2,500 Matawan purse at Freehold Raceway today.
Wall Street greeted the return to normal trading hours of 10 A.M. to 3:30 P.M. yesterday with a ho-hum attitude. Outwardly, the brokerage community appeared to be moving at a semiholiday pace.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 21-- The main buildings and associated faculties and schools of Catholic University here were returned today to the authorities, marking the end of a 10day occupation by nearly 600 insurgent students. They had refused to leave until their demands for "democratization" were granted.

Eight Americans were decorated last night by President Felix Houphouet-Boigny of the Ivory Coast for contributions to the progress of the West African country and to Africa in general. The National Order of the Ivory Coast and individual citations were conferred in ceremonies at they WaldorfAstoria Hotel.
Steel production turned downward last week after five weeks of increases.

TWIGGY, the 17-year-old model who looks like nothing more than two waiflike profiles glued together with incandescent eyes, returned to New York yesterday in a new guise. She didn't stop traffic at Kennedy International Airport, but she left it in quite a mess.

THE nightly report of Chet Huntley and David Brinkley, a television fixture since October, 1956, underwent a fundamental revision of format last night. WASHINGTON, Aug. 21-- The Treasury bill rate rose substantially for both threemonth and six-month bills at today's auction, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

The cigarette industry's standard response--"inaccurate and misleading" --to the latest scientific report on the health hazards of smoking cigarettes has the hollowness of a cough in a graveyard. For the new study by the United States Public Health Service strengthens the Government's 1964 report on the killing effects of heavy smoking.

George Meany, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., called yesterday for a campaign by labor to seek the nationalization of any business in which workers were not permitted to strike because of the public interest involved.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 21 (UPI) --Charles O. Finley, the owner of the Kansas City Athletics, continued his shake-up of the team today. "New 1880-s $1,000." This was the stamping on a white canvas bag out of which coin dealer Charles Ross spilled yesterday a shining flood of silver dollars atop a desk on the trading floor at the New York Mercantile Exchange.

The upward spiral of industrial prices continued yesterday in steel, photographic film and floor tiling.

THE outer world of the hippies was explored un sparingly last night on the debut of Harry Reasoner's new program, "Who, What, When, Where, Why." Visually the production caught the distinctive environment and wardrobe of the HaightAshbury community in San Francisco, but editorially it was a blunt recital of the perils of lysergic acid diethylamide.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22--A New York University department head who urged Congress to disapprove any health warning in cigarette advertising received $3,200 from the tobacco industry for his services.

HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 22 --Touring golf pros do not wish to outlaw croquet-style putting.

BELTSVILLE, Md.--Dr. Raymon E. Webb cast an appraising eye over the crop of tomatoes. Not bad. Long and with firm flesh, they were perhaps not as sweet as the round plump ones--but were a promising start for what the scientist had in mind.

New York has its own Diana. She's smaller than the bronze huntress that the city lost to the Philadelphia Museum of Art, and she's missing her bow, and she stands next to a sign that says, "Please use elevator for emergency only"--but she's all New York's.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22-- Only 121 companies out of 4,418 replying to a new Government survey cut back their investment last year because of tight money, the Commerce Department disclosed today.

ELLENVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 22--Miss Ann Rachel Regenbogen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Regenbogen, was married this evening to Irwin Bluestein. Rabbi Herman Eisner performed the ceremony at the Nevele Country Club, which was founded by the bride's grandparents, Mrs. Joseph Y. Slutsky and the late Mr. Slutsky. Mr. Bluestein is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Bluestein of East Rockaway, L.I.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 22 --James Demmig of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., Beach Club won his second straight series race on Long Island Sound, off Indian Harbor Yacht Club today. Mr. and Mrs. Walter G. Bunzl of 120 East 81st Street and Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Marjorie Bunzl, to David Charles Belgray, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Belgray of the Bronx.

Batteries are smaller than ever. In many cases, they are more efficient, less expensive and used in a broader range of products.

ALBANY, Aug. 22--The Constitutional Convention spent most of today arguing about provisions for future conventions.
Prices drifted down soon after the opening yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

COLD SPRING, N.Y., Aug. 22--Ray Impellittiere, a heavyweight boxer of the nineteenthirties, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home here. He was 57 years old. Since 1953 he had been president of Impellittiere Motors, Inc., the Ford Motor Company agency here.
For many an ad agency, this is the space age and the space that concerns them is office space. It's harder to find and more expensive than ever.
State Senator Seymour R. Thaler charged yesterday that "there's more rehabilitation in prison" than in the state's new narcotic rehabilitation centers.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 22 (UPI) --The Rev. James E. Groppi and seven members of a militant civil rights group were convicted today of violating the curfew imposed by Mayor Henry Maier during Milwakee's race rioting last month.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22-- Premier Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam told Congress today in a letter that his Government was running a clean election and did not need a lesson in honesty from anyone.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 22 (AP) --Joe Niekro drove in three runs with a bases-loaded double and scattered 11 hits, leading the Chicago Cubs to an 8-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight and snapping the Pirates' five-game winning streak.
LONDON, Aug. 22--"Dad! Let's get a taxi!" says the banner carried by the young woman wearing a culotte, a beret and sunglasses on Oxford Street, the heart of London cabland.

RANCHO SANTA FE, Calif., Aug. 22--Mr. and Mrs. Harry Wills Booth Jr. have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Wills Booth, to Richard Austin Springs 3d, son of Mr. Springs Jr. of Mount Kisco, N.Y., and the late Mrs. Springs.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 22 (AP)--A bill to let Alabama schoolchildren say whether they want white or Negro teachers passed the state Senate despite a filibuster today. A similar measure sailed through the House without a fight.

ATHENS, Aug. 22 (Reuters)--King, Constantine of Greece today pardoned former Foreign Minister Evangelos Averoff-Tossizza, imprisoned for five years by a military court last Wednesday. He was immediately released.

THERE is something about the steel industry that has always attracted Wall Street's security analysts. The industry is vital to the United States economy and represents a substantial amount of invested capital.

OTTAWA, Aug. 22 (AP)-- Peaches Bartkowicz of Hamtramck, Mich., and Vicky Rogers of Rye, N.Y., won thirdround matches by 6-0, 6-0 scores today in the division for girls 18 years old and under at the Canadian junior tennis championships.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 22--The Mandelbaum Gate, the symbol of divided Jerusalem, is being torn down.

SONORA, Calif., Aug. 22 (UPI)--Two 18-year-old boys were arrested here today on suspicion of murdering another boy and wounding his girl friend. They were later reported to have admitted two other murders in Washington and Oregon.

BUCHANAN, N.Y., Aug. 22 --A new zoning law to permit the Georgia-Pacific Corporation to build an $8-million gypsum wallboard factory on the shore of the Hudson River here was adopted unanimously last night by the Village Board.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Aug. 22-- David Deming of the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club, who just got under the wire after three qualifying races with a fifth place finish, led the Junior Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound Midget sailing championship today after two races.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 22 --Charles Pasarell of Puerto Rico and Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., were beaten in the opening round of the United States tennis doubles championship today on the turf at the Longwood Cricket Club.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 22-- Israel today rejected a Jordanian request to permit refugees to return to the occupied west bank after Aug. 31.
Dr. Frank M. Whiting, professor of theater at the University of Minnesota, received the American Educational Theater Association's annual Award of Merit yesterday.

Paperboard production rose 11.9 per cent with 464,000 tons in the week ended Aug. 19, compared with the level in the corresponding 1966 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paperboard Institute reported yesterday.

An Episcopal priest stood outside his church yesterday on a green hill covered with overturned gravestones and thick maple trees. Children sat on the stones and a boy swung from a tree.

The Woodson fiber-glass board operations in Miami, including design, engineering, production and marketing, have been acquired by the Fibre Glass Boat Corporation, one of the Brydon Corporation group of companies, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22-- Two Swiss doctors concurred today in the general findings of an official Czechoslovak pathologist, holding that Charles H. Jordan, American executive of a Jewish refugee relief organization, died in Prague last week by drowning.
OLD LYME, Conn., Aug. 22 --Robert K. Chandler, a retired executive of Standard Oil (New Jersey), died Sunday at his home on Mill Pond Lane. He was 75 years old.

Henry H. Saylor, an editor of architectural publications and author of the first architectural dictionary published in 50 years, died at the Huntington, L.I., Hospital yesterday. He was 87 years old and lived at 38 Russet Lane in Huntington. He had been suffering from anemia.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 22-- Joe O'Brien, fined $200 for having failed to lodge a claim of foul following last Saturday night's $100,000 International Trot, could not be reached today for his reaction to the most severe penalty ever levied against a driver for not reporting interference during a race. O'Brien was training horses at Sportsman's Park in Cicero, Ill., today.

BABYLON, I.L., Aug. 22-- Charles Barthrop of the United States Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, L.I., and Fred H. Miller of the South Shore Sailing Club, San Diego, Calif., tied for first place today after two races in the North American single-handed sailing championship in Great South Bay. Barthrop had a fourth and a third while Miller, the National Finn Class champion, was second and fifth.

New York's foreign exchange market had another quiet day yesterday, with no notable price swings registered.

Gimbel Brothers, Inc., had a net profit of $2,985,731, or 35 cents a share, in the second quarter ended July 31, compared with $2,446,834 or 29 cents a share, in the 1966 quarter Bruce A. Gimbel, president, reported yesterday. against $127,613,730.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug 23-- Mr. and Mrs. Henry' W. McAllister have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sallie Anne McAllister to Donald L. Bennett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Bennett of Brightwaters.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 23 (AP)--Five American planes were shot out of the sky over North Vietnam today, the United States command reported. It also said the raiding jets had shot down two MIG's in dogfights north of Hanoi.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23--A broad program for integrating Chicago schools and improving education of inner-city pupils, including eventual development of large educational parks, was detailed today in a report submitted by Schools' superintendent James F. Redmond and approved by the Board of Education.
Deputy Mayor Timothy W. Costello and Jesse Freidin, a lawyer, were named yesterday by Mayor Lindsay as city representatives on the new Board of Collective Bargaining.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UPI) --The Senate Judiciary Committee, after two weeks of testimony from policemen, turned to two proud, youthful voices of the ghetto today for clues to what caused this summer's race riots.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23-- Maj. Gen. Itzhak Rabin, Israeli Chief of Staff, will be the next Ambassador to Washington, informed sources here said today.

A retired dental technician challenged the constitutionality of the Social Security Act yesterday, contending that Congress unlawfully discriminates by giving women higher retirement benefits than men.
The Salvation Army has opened a cafe on Macdougal Street in Greenwich Village, across from Cafe Freudian Slip and half a block from the Cafe Wha? It is called The Answer.

Charles Mingus, a well-known jazz musician, was arrested with two other persons late last night in a demonstration by a group of 200 hippies outside the Charles Street police station in Greenwich Village.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23-- The A.F.L.-C.I.O. endorsed a tax increase today as a means of averting a new period of high interest rates and of enabling all Americans to "share the sacrifice involved in the war in Vietnam."
THREE teen-agers had three weeks to spend $30,000. They did it.

The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that it had raised the price of six organic specialty chemicals 1 to 25 cents a pound. The company said the increases, effective immediately, reflected increased labor, freight and packaging costs.
Dick Weber almost lost the use of his right hand--the one he uses for bowling--while signing 1,500 autographs (give or take a few) during a recent exhibition of his tenpin skills in Tokyo.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 23-- Two veterinarians agreed today, following examination of Roquepine, that Henri Levesque's 6-year-old French mare was "not 100 per cent fit" when she captured last Saturday's $100,000 International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway.
The National Council on the Arts has recommended that Congress appropriate $139million next year to suport the most extensive Federal arts program in the nation's history.

Vincent Price will make his musical comedy debut in the role of a famous British painter in "Darling of the Day." Costarred with him will be Patricia Routledge, who was commended by critics for her performance in last season's "How's the World Treating You?"

CHICAGO, Aug. 23--The Chicago White Sox increased their lead to one game in the American League tonight as another of Eddie Stanlry's strong, young arms came through-with a little help from the bull pen.

IT could only happen in Manhattan, Mrs. Lilian Cornfeld said recently. She had been in an awful rush, just off a plane from Chicago, and had promised to cook a few Israeli dishes for friends before returning to her home in Tel Aviv.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 23 (Reuters) --Demands increased in the Israeli press today for a full investigation by the Czechoslovak Government of the death in Prague of Charles H. Jordan, an executive of an American Jewish relief agency.

PRAGUE, Aug. 23--A French husband-wife team, using an observing technique of extraordinary sensitivity, has found evidence that in the view of some astronomers means the clouds covering Venus may not be formed of water droplets.

RICHMOND, Aug. 23-- All Saints Episcopal Church was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Virginia Mapes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Maynard Mapes, to Walter Scott Street 3d, son of Mrs. Edgar Lee Robbins and the late Mr. Street.
The stock market made its third straight decline yesterday. But it shaved early-afternoon losses with a modest rally in the final hour of trading.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23--The White House announced today that 20 Americans had accepted an invitation from President Johnson to go to South Vietnam to check on the fairness of the political campaign and elections there.

"If you don't like the weather, just wait a minute," residents of the Berkshires smilingly remark about their variable climate. Tuesday evening, at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Lee, Mass., however, the choreographic sun shone all the time.
Paola Novikova, Russianborn soprano and voice teacher, died Tuesday at her home, 338 West 72d Street. She was 71 years old and the wife of Werner Singer, a concert accompanist.
About 300 teen-agers, mostly girls, gathered outside Shea Stadium yesterday to celebrate the Beatles' appearance there last Aug. 23.

New Jersey's Commissioner of Transportation expressed strong doubt yesterday that Congress would be any more receptive to Senator Clifford P. Case's new bill to expand the interstate highway system than it has been to similar previous bills.
More than 300 former Marines gathered yesterday in the New York Hilton Hotel for the third annual convention of the Montford Point Marine Association.
The advertising chief of United Air Lines and his account man from Leo Burnett took the friendly skies from Chicago to let United's New York sales boys in on fall advertising plans. They're big.

Robert Stein, editor of McCall's magazine, has been named director of editorial development for McCall's, Redbook and Saturday Review. The appointment was announced yesterday by Arthur R. Murphy Jr., president of the McCall Corporation.

A THREE-WAY dead heat finish for first place fea tured the recent Down East Chess Tournament in Portland, Me. Topping a 54-man field in this six-round Swiss system were master John Curdo and experts Alex Keyes and John Morrill, each at 5-1.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 23 (AP) --Mark Hayes, the Oklahoma amateur champion, fired a 2under-par 70 and moved into a triple tie with the first round leaders, Curtis Sifford and Edgar Sneed after two rounds of the 65th Western amateur golf championship today.

FAIR HAVEN, N. J., Aug. 23--The engagement of Miss Norma Louise McCabe to Kostanenos Nick Hronopoulos has been announced by Miss McCabe's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John F. McCabe Jr. Mr. Hronopoulos is the son of Mrs. Nick Hronopoulos of La Jolla, Calif., and the late Mr. Hronopoulbs of Athens.

The Johnson Administration, having implemented its policy of "no wider war" by bombing right up to the Chinese border, now seems to be shedding its remaining inhibitions against dropping bombs in densely populated civilian areas of North Vietnam. Even the center of Hanoi is apparently no longer exempt.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Aug. 23--Mr. and Mrs. Jacques M. Schiffer have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Ann Schiffer, to Richard Brooks, son of Mrs. Lawrence Markowitz of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Dr. Irving Brooks.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy, Democrat of New York, said yesterday that he had, "reser. vations" about President Johnson's proposal to add a 10 per cent surcharge to the income tax.
NEW HAVEN, Aug. 23--After the first night of peace in the streets this week, Mayor Richard C. Lee today relaxed the curfew that had been in effect since Sunday to contain racial violence.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23-- The head of a Presidential board told the railroads and six shopcraft unions today that it was up to them to show why recommendations of an earlier panel should not be imposed to settle their contract dispute.

MONTREAL, Aug. 23--Prime Minister Lester B, Pearson said today that the "considerable increase" in aid that France planned for Quebec was wholly in accord with the treaty between the Paris and Ottawa Governments.
PARIS--French children, who do not often escape their maman or papa, now have their own hotels in the countryside not too far from Paris.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP)--A publication of a fugitive American Negro in Communist China that advocates violence in United States cities and advises Negro G.I.'s to "eliminate" their white comrades in Vietnam has been carried in the mails.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23-- The California Democrats' ultra-liberal fringe, the California Democratic Council, will hold a statewide convention Sept. 30 to choose a 1968 presidential candidate more oriented toward ending the war in Vietnam than Presldent Johnson.

SARATOGA, SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 23--Queen of the Stage contributed her fifth straight flawless performance in winning the $80,375 Spinaway today. Ogden Phipps's undefeated filly turned in the stakes-record time of 1:10 1-5 in beating eight rivals in the six-furlong sprint for 2-year-old fillies.

ATLANTA, Aug. 23--Dr. Anthony Saidy of Los Angeles and Grand Master Pal Benko of New York were tied for first place after the 9th round in the United States Open Chess Championship at the American Hotel here last night. They have each scored eight points out of nine.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 23-- Intrepid put a mile of ruffled water between her lopped-off transom and Columbia's bow today for a spectacular, if inconclusive, stride toward the goal for which she was built--a United States defense of the. America's Cup against Australia.

Dr. and Mrs. Albert J. Ritzmann of Brooklyn Heights and Andover, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Johana Elizabeth Ritzmann, to Colin S. Doyle. He is the son of Mrs. Norbert A. Doyle of Oregon, Ill., and the late Mr. Doyle.
There is a form to be filled out for every moment of the working day, or so it seems.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 23--Three Americans of Greek descent began a 48-hour hunger strike this afternoon, a block south of the United Nations, in anticipation of King Constantine's arrival in New York tomorrow evening.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 (UPI)--The Delaware River Basin Commission proposed today the biggest budget in its seven-year history, asking more than a half-million dol lars to fight water pollution in four Middle Atlantic states.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23-- A 28-year-old newspaper copy boy held a news conference today to recommend to President Johnson that he vacate the White House at the end of his term.

CANTHO, South Vietnam, Aug. 23--While the civilian presidential candidates addressed about 1,000 people alongside the Mekong River in this delta capital, the people of Loivu hamlet, on the outskirts, went about their business.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UPI)--Barry Goldwater said today that President Johnson had played politics with the Detroit race riots and therefore must share the blame for future civil violence.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 23 (AP) --Len Dawson, quarterback, and Otis Taylor, flanker, led a 32point second period bombing for the Kansas City Chiefs, the American Football League champions, and set off a 66-to24 humiliation of the Chicago Bears in an inter-league exhibition tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23--An academic authority on United States foreign policy said today that a Senate resolution intended to limit "national commitments" would have "little or no effect" on the President's authority to define them as he saw fit.

DETROIT, Aug. 23 (AP)-- The United Automobile Workers has summoned its leading officials to Detroit next week to map strategy for a showdown battle with the automobile industry's Big Three on new contracts.

Four teen-aged boys climbed to the top of the Wil1iamsburg Bridge at 2 o'clock yesterday morning to see the city lights. They crawled onto a 30-inch ledge about 600 feet over the East River--then panicked.

DETROIT, Aug. 23 (UPI)-- Two Detroit policemen and a private guard were charged today with beating and intimidating several persons at a motel where three Negro youths were killed during the Detroit riot.

CAIRO, Aug. 23 (Agence France-Presse)--Last week's meeting of Arab finance and oil ministers in Baghdad was limited to listing possible ways to use their oil as a weapon of foreign policy, according to diplomats who took part in the conference.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UPI)--The Senate gave final Congressional approval to a new, $285.6-million G.I. bill covering five million veterans who have served since 1955.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23-- President Johnson told House Democratic leaders privately today that he wanted "every dollar" of the $3.1-billion foreign aid authorization bill now being debated in that body.

WILLMAR, Minn., Aug. 23 --Mr. and Mrs. Russell Renstrom have made known the engagement of Mrs. Renstrom's daughter, Miss Patricia Hovick, to Ens. James McKnight Binger, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Binger of Wayzata.
The J.C. Penney Company, the large merchandise chain, reported yesterday that sales and earnings for the 13 and 26 weeks ended July 29, were the highest in its history.

NASHVILLE, Aug. 23--Mayor Beverly Briley called today for "investigation and clarification" of sedition charges against George W. Ware as the 27-year-old representative of the Student Nonvoilent Coordinating Committee spent his second day in jail.

LIBERTYVILLE, Ill., Aug. 23--Mr. and Mrs. Chedo P. Graham of Libertyville and Camborne, England, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Penelope Graham, to David Addison Walker, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Addison Walker of Greenwich, Conn.

A 44-year-old Great Neck, L.I., insurance man was indicated here yesterday on charges of stealing $338,370 from the Canada Life Assurance Company of Toronto. He had worked for the company as a general agent until he was discharged last April.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 23 (Reuters)--A Danish newspaper answered a Chinese protest note today by quoting the thoughts of Chairman Mao Tse-tung, including one in the little red book that says: "We must try to achieve normal, diplomatic relations based on mutual respect."
TRENTON, Aug. 23--New Jersey has agreed to give the Erie-Lackawanna Railroad a minimum of $80-million over the next five years in exchange for a state role in the line's commuter operations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP)--The two United States Navy bombers that were downed in Communist China on Monday were last seen maneuvering into clouds to escape from North Vietnamese jet fighters, the Pentagon said today.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Thursday, Aug. 24--Costs at Zambia's biggest copper mine have increased 100 ($280) a ton in a year and almost completely offset additional sales proceeds, Harry Oppenheimer, chairman of the Anglo-American Corporation, said here today.
Walter E. Washington, chairman of the city's Housing Authority, was reported last night to be leaving the Lindsay administration to accept a major post in the municipal government of Washington.

Carrier Corporation earnings dropped slightly in the third fiscal quarter while record sales, earnings and orders were booked in the nine months ended July 31, the Syracuse manufacturer of air-conditioners and allied products reported yesterday.
WEDGEPORT, N.S., Aug. 23--Members of the four teams competing in the International Tuna Cup match off this Arcadian village and nearby Cape St. Mary are still seeking to raise their first tuna flag.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23--A special Presidential panel began today an intensive search for ways to provide property and liability insurance to residents and businessmen in riot-torn areas.

LONDON, Aug. 23--Prime Minister Wilson and Foreign Secretary George Brown interrupted their vacations today to take a hard, worried look at Britain's relations with Communist China after the British mission compound was sacked and British diplomats were beaten last night in Peking.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23-- Republican leaders proposed to day a five-point program to help stem migration to troubled cities by rejuvenating rural America.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23-- The American Federation of Teachers voted narrowly today to retain its bar against membership for fascists, Nazis, Communists and others "whose political actions are subject to totalitarian control."

Restoration of the 7 per cent investment tax credit and the two methods of accelerated depreciation on buildings has not produced a spurt in capital investment among the industries that had expected to be hurt the most by their suspension.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24--A group of 113 business executives, many of them heads of the nation's largest corporations, announced their support today for a temporary wartime tax increase of unspecified size.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 24 South Vietnam's militant Buddhist faction today again denounced Lieut. Gen Nguyen Van Thieu's "Machiavellian" policy toward the church, but denied that it was playing politics.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 24 Exactly 65 years ago a 10-year-old native of this town, named Frank Sullivan, slipped through the fence at the Saratoga Race Track to watch the thoroughbreds in action. He wasn't on the grounds long before he was pressed into service, as a water boy for the bookmakers in the betting rine.
Best Co., apparel specialty store chain here, yesterday announced the appointment of two new vice presidents.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) Because of a teen-age fad-wearing sweatshirts inside out-the Government has revised its regulations limiting the sale of clothes that tend to burst into flames.

THE plight of the New York Giants is not quite as bad as one might believe with regard to the defensive unit's ability to field healthy 11 players against the Minnesota Vikings at Yale Bowl in New Haven on Sunday.

AREA A Crabbing excellent in Barnegat Bay with line or trap. These shell fish best in years and moving north making good crabbing at most inlets. Small blues and snappers in bays. Off beaches kingfish and fluke are light. Herring taken on lure off beach. Ling, sea bass and porgies good from boats.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 24 Reinforced patrols of Israeli paratroops and border policemen moved through the twisting streets of the Old City today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UPI) Some Republicans today criticized President Johason's plan to send observers to check on the fairness of the South Vietnamese elections, scheduled for Sept. 3.
Today's advertising news concerns three of the best-known names in the business N. W. Ayer Son; Emerson Foote, and J. Walter Thompson. And there are some firsts involved.

The United States for the last four years has been governed by a leader in perpetual pursuit of a consensus. Yesterday in Washington, however, the nation witnessed the paradox of a consensus searching for a leader.
Industrial stocks continued a moderate advance on the London stock market yesterday in light trading.
James Baldwin, the 43year-old Negro writer, called for a "massive national economic boycott" by American Negroes in a speech in Greenwick Village last night.
HAWORTH, N.J., Aug. 24 Ann Laughlin of the Riverton Country Club won the eighth annual Maureen Orcutt junior golf trophy today over the White Beeches Golf and Country Club.
Two large traps-Atlantic liners North German Lloyd's Bremen and the Italian Line's Michelangelo have new masters.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP)--The State Department said today it was revoking the passport of George Washington Ware, a black power advocate, on the ground that he had made an unauthorized trip to Cuba. Similar action already has been taken against Stokely Carmichael on the same ground.

The engagement of Miss Serina Stephenson and Wade H. Nichols 3d has been announced by her parents, Sgt. Thomas C. Stephenson, R.A.F., and Mrs. Stephenson of Gloucester, England. The future bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wade H. Nichols of Bronxville, N. Y.

LINDENHURST, L. I., Aug. 24 Representatives of the New York State Department of Public Works, following a hearing today on the proposed widening of 6.2 miles of the Montauk Highway, promised a final decision on the project within three months.

Mayor Lindsay confirmed yesterday that Walter E. Washington, chairman of the city's Housing Authority, would accept a leading job in the municipal government of Washington. But the White House insisted yesterday that "no decisions have been made" regarding top posts in the capital's newly reorganized administration.

A program to treat the city's estimated 300,000 alcoholics, without costing the city more than it now spends to treat a tiny fraction of the total, was announced yesterday by Dr. Howard J. Brown, the city's Health Services Administrator.

ONE of the most spectacular performers in the over-the-counter market for the last year has been the stock of Liquidonics Industries, Inc., a maker of hydraulics and telecommunications equipment, based in Westbury, N.Y.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) The House Post Office Committee rejected today an effort to delay the effective date of new higher third-class rates from next January to next July.

The proposal of the Dodge, Manufacturing Corporation to merge into the Reliance Electric Company and thus avoid a takeover by the Emerson Electric Company was approved by a large majority at a special meeting of shareholders yesterday in Mishawaka, Ind.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) The Senate confirmed Townsend W. Hoopes as Under Secretary of the Air Force today despite another protest by Senator Harry F. Byrd Jr. Democrat of Virginia, against the attitude of some high civilian Government officials on the Vietnam war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24--A convocation of more than 800 mayors and business, labor, church and civil rights leaders called on the Government today to "reorder national priorities" and develop "an emergency work program" to provide jobs in the nation's riot-torn cities.
Mrs. Bessie Feldman Yunich, the mother of David L. Yunich, president of Macy's New York, died Wednesday in Villa Mary Immaculate Nursing Home in Albany after a long illness. Her age was 79.

Los ANGELES, Aug. 24 (AP) In an experiment aimed at freeing police officers from routine duties, Los Angeles will put 50 civilians on downtown streets directing traffic and walking beats beginning Nov. 1.
To cope with their increasing success, New York's underground filmmakers will shortly open two more theaters here devoted exclusively to the showing of avant-garde films, both old and new.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 24 King Hussein of Jordan told newsmen here tonight that he was "happy efforts have culminated in the convening of an Arab summit conference," He is here for two days of consultations with Lebanese leaders in advance of the gathering in Khartoum Tuesday.
Mrs. Walter Streich of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Eileen Jutta Streich, to Yuksel Nedim Yalcin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hamdi Yalcin of Mersin, Turkey.

The record of the American public school Establish ment in responding to the storm warnings of both the racial and the urban crisis has been shockingly deficient. Its slowness even to recognize the urgent demands of the hard-pressed cities and their disadvantaged minorities has been in large part a reflection of the schools' domination by the vested interests of professional conservatism and state political machines.
RACHGIA, South Vietnam, Aug. 24 Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Van Thieu, chief of state and the military junta's presidential candidate, failed today to keep a promised date with his civilian rivals.
The American Broadcasting Company is introducing a radical change in radio network operation in order to offer local stations programs for specialized audiences.

A Brooklyn man and his wife were killed yesterday and three children riding with them were injured when their car was struck by another in the Williamsburg section. The other driver was charged with vehicle homicide and drunken driving.

CORTLAND, N. Y., Aug. 24 Mrs. Nicholas Gordon has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Helen Hamilton Gordon, to Robert Francis Matthews of New York. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John N. Matthews of Centre Island, Oyster Bay, L. I.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) Republican members of the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct disagreed sharply today with Representative Ogden R. Reid, who contended that "the American people have lost a measure of confidence in the integrity of the Congress."
Councilman Robert A. Low, author of the city's stringent new air pollution control law, proposed changes yesterday that would allow apartment house owners more time to modernize their incinerators.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 The Food and Drug Administration reported today that a drug known as "68," or "sex juice," said to produce wilder but shorter "trips" than LSD, is really concentrated oil of peppermint and has no hallucinogenic effect.

CHATTANOOGA, Aug. 24 The United Mine Workers of America was found guilty today of charges that it had conspired to violate antitrust laws. As a result, two small Tennessee coal companies were awarded damages that will total $3-million.

Freight handlers, clerks and ticket personnel struck against Pan American World Airways here yesterday. The union said the strike was unauthorized and that the 470 who walked out had refused its pleas to return to work.
Workers are being imported into this country in considerable numbers to fill special jobs and to take up occupations that Americans are reluctant or unable to accept.
A smaller amount of money was committed to future building projects in July than in the record month of June, but the total last month was still 2 per cent above the level of July, 1966.

After seven years of multimillion-dollar, international litigation, Merck Co., Inc., and Robert S. Aries, a chemist who lives in France, have reached a settlement over a poultry drug known as amprolium.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24 (AP) Run-scoring singles by Bob Tolan and Dick Hughes in the ninth inning broke up a scoreless duel between Hughes and Gaylord Perry today and the St. Louis Cardinals beat the San Francisco Giants, 2-0.
A study of New York harbor's water pollution has disclosed a surprising rise in the density of coliform bacteria despite two decades of intensified sewage treatment by the city.
The conservation bill of rights unanimously approved by the Constitutional Convention is a triumph for constructive bipartisanship.
COPENHAGEN, Aug. 24--Probably no company has been so bedeviled in its search for a modern choreographer as the Royal Danish Ballet.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, Aug. 24 A band of Constitutional Convention delegates, on the heels of an appeal by their leaders to start working harder and longer because time is running out, attended an unproductive 35-minute session today and then adjourned to Saratoaa for a day at the races.

DUARTE, Calif., Aug. 24 (AP) Amanda, Randolph, who played the cantankerous, meddling mother-in-law in "Amos 'n Andy" on radio and television, died after a stroke today at Santa Teresita Hospital. She was 65 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 Senator Thruston B. Morton said today that a new cigarette filter introduced last month by Columbia University had been tested and rejected by researchers for a tobacco company as "not worth much."

Directors of Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., the Consolidated Cigar Corporation and the E. W. Bliss Company, approved yesterday the acquisition by Gulf and Western of Consolidated and Bliss. The transaction is subject to the approval of the shareholders of the three companies.
WASHINGTON, Friday, Aug. 25 (AP) Delegates to the American Federation of Teachers convention voted early today; 325 to 106, to take no stand on the Vietnam war at their convention.

PRAGUE, Aug. 24 A politically tinged showdown in naming hundreds of features on new maps of the moon's far side was averted at the last minute here today when Soviet astronomers agreed to a compromise scheme.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -The Federal National Mortgage Association reported today a threefold increase during the second quarter of this year in the number of mortgages offered to it for sale by private bankers.
NEWPORT, R. I. Aug. 24 The interiors of most 12-Meter yachts are as bare as barrels, broken only by unpainted plywood partitions, sail bins, a pipe berth or two an dan exposed head.

GENEVA, Aug. 24 The United States and the Soviet Union submitted to the disarmament conference today separate but identical texts of a draft treaty to prevent the further spread of nuclear weapons. The draft left blank the article on inspection.
Joerg Demus illuminated several of Mozart's piano works in last night's contribution to the Mozart Festival in Philharmonic Hall.

LONDON, Aug. 24 The Home Office warned all Chinese living in Britain today that they might be barred from traveling within the British Isles as well as from leaving this country. They were advised to carry passports.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N. J., Aug. 24 The engagement of Miss Elissa Toinette Lucia, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip F. Lucia, to Lieut. Randolph Rahal, U.S.A. Special Forces, has been announced by the future bride's parents. Her fiance is the son of Lieut. Col. Verdun Rahal, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Rahal of Oklahoma City.
MOSCOW, Aug. 24 (UPI) Soviet astronauts have been practicing sea landings for future space shots, the newspaper Red Star said today.
The Lindsay administration's proposal for cluster zoning was unanimously approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

MOSCOW, Aug. 24 (Reuters) A Correspondent for Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, reported today that American bombing had destroyed almost all the large cities of North Vietnam with the exception of Hanoi and Haiphong.
Seagoing engineer officers have offered to forgo a money increase won in arbitration if other unions will join in putting a stop to the current round of "me too" cost increases.
King Constantine of Greece and Queen Anne-Marie flew into New York yesterday on the first part of a trip that will take them to Canada and then to Washington for a visit with President Johnson.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 President Johnson hailed today the Soviet-American agreement on the draft of a treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons as opening the final stage in the pursuit of "a great gift to those who follow us" on earth.

HUANUNI, Bolivia, Aug. 23 "You must go into the mines," the Bolivian woman said, gesturing up to the distant huddles of adobe and ancient machinery that pock the hills around this chill, forsaken place. "Then you will see why we have guerrillas."
Many of the nation's bank tellers are dipping into the cash drawer these days and coming out with handsome profits -sometimes more than $50 a day and their supervisors don't care.
LONDON, Aug. 24 Unemployment in Britain rose again this month, adding fresh fuel to the debate over the Labor Government's economic and welfare policies.

CANDIA, Crete, Aug. 24 Leaders of the World Council of Churches, representing 223 Protestant, Anglican and Eastern Orthodox churches throughout the world, called on the United States today to reaffirm publicly its commitment to withdraw its troops from Vietnam.
The Book-of-the-Month Club, the oldest and most prestigious of the book clubs, is moving most of its clerical operations from 345 Hudson Street to a cornfield outside Harrisburg, Pa.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy urged the City Council yesterday to approve legislation to control the sale of rifles and shotguns, which he termed "the tools of the urban rioter, the machinery of senseless killing."

Gerald Tsai Jr., whose market success attracted $540-million in net assets to the Manhattan Fund, plans to offer a small, $7.5-million mutual fund whose sole objective will be to seek capital appreciation.
FARMINGDALE, L.I., Aug. 24 (AP) Republic Aviation said today it wanted to give $10,000 each to 12 well-trained men willing to spend 270 consecutive days confined in a simulated space chamber.

BONN, Aug. 24--The secretary of the Government press office called it an "information conversation" this morning when she invited newsmen to the regular Government briefing. But the surprise guests this evening turned out to be four Soviet newsmen.
The election of Willard G. Hampton oP Manhasset, L.I., to the board of the Long Island Trust Company, Garden City, L.I., was announced yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 24 The Ford Motor Company has engineered a collapsing feature into the front end of some of its 1968 cars that lessens the risk of rider injury in accidents, a spokesman said today.

W. Carlton Bernard, president of Berncolors-Poughkeepsie, Inc., manufacturers of textile dyestuffs, died here yesterday in Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases. He was 54 years old and lived in Poughkeepsie.
Eighteen Negroes filed suit yesterday asking that a Federal receiver take over and operate the Newark Police Department on the ground that the police have consistently discriminated against Negroes.
FLINT, Mich., Aug. 24 (AP) City Officials sought an injunction today to end a sleep-in on the lawn of the Flint City Hall by demonstrators protesting the defeat oP a proposed open housing law.
Dollar bills thrown by a band of hippies fluttered down on the floor of the New York "Stock Exchange yesterday, disrupting the normal hectic trading pace.
MOSCOW, Aug. 24 (Reuters) The Soviet Union announced tonight a series of seismic tests next month, during which Soviet planes will drop bombs into two large areas of the Pacific Ocean.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Aug. 25 Air attacks on the Hanoi region Wednesday cost the United States six warplanes, a military spokesman said yesterday, and only one of the 11 crew members on the planes was rescued.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UPI) The National Park Service has issued a directive that sets a limit of 100 on pickets in front of the White House.
ALBANY, Aug. 24 A judges' stand set up for a ladder-raising contest between volunteer fire company teams collapsed today in suburban Colonie, injuring 23 persons two of them seriously.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 24 One by-product of the military defeat of the Arabs by the Israelis in June is a new emphasis in the left-wing Arab nations on the use of women as soldiers and workers.

ADEN, Aug. 24 (Agence France-Presse) Official sources said today that tribal unrest had broken out in the South Arabian state of Audhali, on the Yemeni border. Unconfirmed reports said the state had been taken over by the extremist National Liberation Front.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 24--"One thing we Vietnamese do not lack is touchiness and pride," observed the administrator in charge of South Vietnam's coming election. "We have too much of that "

In hailing the American-Soviet agreement at Geneva on a draft treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons, President Johnson was wise to emphasize the distance yet to be traveled on the road to world nuclear security. Submission of the agreed draft to the seventeen-nation Disarmament Conference is a remarkable achievement, but its full contribution to world security will not be realized unless the next stage of international negotiations proves egually successful.

Miss Deborah Rose Rand, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry I. Rand, was married last evening at their home, 320 West 86th Street, to Richard Mark Wolfe. His parents are George M.D. Wolfe of Washington and Mrs. Lucille S. Wolfe of New York.

TOKYO, Aug. 22--Japanese call them "futenzoku," which means "crazy tribe." Americans, if judging by outward appearance and personal habits only, might identify them as hippies. TRENTON, Aug. 25 (AP)-- The state sent a team of housing inspectors into Atlantic City today in a special drive to enforce the state housing code.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25-- Consumer prices rose substantially in July, a normal experience for the month, the Labor Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25-- Treasury officials confirmed today that they were looking into the possibility that information on the terms of the Treasury's Aug. 17 $2.5-billion cash offering had "leaked" about a half hour before the offering was announced publicly.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 25--A spokesman for Anguilla has suggested that the Caribbean Island become a territory associated with the United Nations under international protection instead of a part of the British Commonwealth.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) --President Johnson said today that Henry J. Kaiser had embodied in his career the best of the nation's traditions.

Ever since the Federal Communications Commission startled Wall Street by lowering American Telephone and Telegraph's permissible rate of return, Telephone has been a dreary performer on the New York Stock Exchange.

HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 25-- All night and morning rains flooded the Westchester Country Club course and washed out the second round of the $250,000 Westchester Golf Classic today. Albert Martin Cohen, a former lawyer and a former Democratic Assemblyman from the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, died yesterday at Coney Island Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 3232 Shore Parkway.

A Greenwich, Conn., woman who sold a Civil War 50-cent coin minted in 1861 for $75 filed suit yesterday in Federal Court for the return of the coin or $40,000. This, she contends, is what the coin is worth.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 25--Mr. and Mrs. Edmund P. Tobin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Constance Mary Tobin, to Lieut. Edward Hughes Stone, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Edward Stone of Port Chester.

NEW YORKERS whose intellectual exuberance starts to sag after mid-evening have a chance these days to keep up with the day's news before surrendering to their cup of warm milk. As part of a larger pursuit of a distinctive character in the competitive New York television market, WNEW (Channel 5) has been offering Bill Jorgensen's thoroughly professional news summary at 10 o'clock, a full hour ahead of its commercial rivals.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I.-- Windmills now stand idle in this New England-style town that was settled by colonists from Connecticut in 1648, but a water mill has just started turning north of the village proper where weathered salt boxes, new and old, line the streets.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 26 (AP)-- The North American Lightning Class sailing championship was won by Bruce Goldsmith of Chicago today as the title series ended at the Cleveland Yachting Club. The fifth and final race was not sailed because of insufficient breeze.

She of course put her finger exactly on what constitutes the outstanding feature of the Bolshoi philosophy. In the West, old-fashioned scenery, where a house is a house and a forest a forest, has largely been discarded.

TWO names in mining history, Klondike and Nome, conjure up hardship almost too painful to think about. WASHINGTON, Aug. 27-- Despite months of sweat--and, for some, a few tears--Congress has failed so far to make significant cuts in President Johnson's huge budget.

Racial disturbances in American cities this summer have demonstrated once more the serious alienation that exists between large numbers of Negroes and the police. FORT BENNING, Ga., Aug. 28--Miss Julia Delafield Swope and Lieut. Herbert Robinson McIlvaine, U.S.A., were married here this afternoon in the United States Army Infantry Center Chapel.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- Esquire, which is always provocative, presents a photographic study of campus boys and girls who are living in simulated wedlock.
Mrs. Lois Stevens Campbell, a partner in Nesbitt-ReynoldsStevens, an advertising agency at 56 West 45th Street, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital after an operation.

GENEVA, Aug. 28--Britain and Poland are expected to give their complete endorsement tomorrow when discussions begin on the United States-Soviet draft of the treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- The Federal Aviation Administration has temporarily halted some efforts to speed modernization of the airways because Congress has not yet approved its current budget.
The Police Department acted yesterday to prohibit a Times Square dance hall from displaying scantily clad dancing girls in its windows.
MOSCOW, Aug. 28--Rumania has returned to the joint military exercises of the Warsaw Pact after three years.
Alan Alda, now appearing on Broadway in "The Apple Tree," has been signed for a major role in "The Night They Raided Minsky's," a United Artists film based on a book by Rowland Barber.
Too much expansion at home and not enough in major export markets such as the United States is giving Japan a recurrence of a familiar headache-- mounting trade and payments deficits.
DETROIT, Aug. 28 (AP)--The tempo of 1968 model production picked up today in United States auto plants as management and labor alike kept close watch on developments in the auto labor talks.

The Federal Trade Commission announced yesterday that it had filed a civil penalty suit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York against the ABC Consolidated Corporation, and its wholly owned subsidiary, the Berlo Vending Company. The F.T.C. has charged the company with violating a commission divestiture order.

Harold Wilson has now answered critics who accused him of essaying an "above the battle" stance while his Chancellor and Economics Minister absorbed the brunt of criticism for Britain's limping economy. By personally taking on the over-all direction of economic policy, the Prime Minister guarantees himself most of the blame--or credit--for what now transpires.

Lawrence Ellman, 41-yearold president of the Cattleman Restaurant, has purchased a major stock participation in the corporate interest held by Irving and Murray Riese in Longchamps restaurants and will become a principal executive of the 10-unit chain. The Riese brothers acquired control of Longchamps two months ago.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 28--Mr. and Mrs. William Edward Neff have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Justine Mitchell Neff, to James Marr Hawley. He is the son of Mrs. Frederick Augustus Strong 3d and, by adoption, of Mr. Strong of Easton, Conn.
HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 28 --Dan Sikes scored 62 for a course record as the $250,000 Westchester Golf Classic was finally resumed today.

WEST HARTFORD, Aug. 28 --The engagement of Miss Roberta Ann Ryter to Ens. John Connery Heffernan, U.S.N., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Francis Ryter, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Connery Heffernan of Bronxville, N.Y.

NASSAU, The Bahamas, Aug. 28--The United Bahamian party, for decades the political machine of Nassau's white merchants and bankers, today retained its Nassau seat in the Bahamian General Assembly in a significant special election.
AJACCIO, Corsica, Aug. 28 (Reuters)--The Gaullist candidate won a disputed seat in the French National Assembly, it was announced today.

When Tom Stoppard's "Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead" opened at the Old Vic last April, British drama critics called it the most brilliant new play of the decade and its author the finest young playwright since John Osborne or Harold Pinter.
OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 28 (AP)--Hundreds attended a funeral service for Henry J. Kaiser today at the First Congregational Church of Oakland.
Charles B. Darrow, who became a millionaire by inventing the game Monopoly, died at his Bucks County, Pa., home yesterday at the age of 78.

DU QUOIN, Ill., Aug. 28-- A group of harness horesemen was sitting around prior to today's start of the Annual Grand Circuit racing at the Du Quoin State Fair Grounds, the site of Wednesday's 42d edition of the Hambletonian. One would guess that the conversation would be about the probable outcome of the classic trotting race that is the sulky sport's showcase event.
KITCHAWAN, N.Y., Aug. 28 --The rising cost of road construction is reflected in a new state ceiling of $18-million on redeveloping a 3.37-mile stretch of the Taconic State Parkway here.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28--A group of Republican House members said today that poor people were being victimized by organized crime and that the Administration was doing almost nothing about it.
The Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation announced yesterday that its directors would consider a possible split of the concern's common stock at their regular meeting Thursday.

Demand for sterling was brisk yesterday on New York's foreign exchange market, and the pound climbed by 16 points in the spot rate against the dollar, to $2.7860 in comparison with Friday's closing quotation of $2.7844.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) --The House Post Office Committee restored today the rate increases asked by the Johnson Administration for books and educational materials. A sub committee had reduced the increases by $2.3-million.

HUE, South Vietnam, Aug. 28 --Shouts of "Down with the cowboy leader!" and "Down with the hooligan!" greeted Premier Nguyen Cao Ky today as he made his first campaign appearance with Vietnam's Civilian presidential and vice-presidential candidates.

FLINT, Mich., Aug. 28-- Floyd J. McCree, the first Negro Mayor of this city of 210,000, announced today that the was withdrawing his oral resignation. He had offered it two weeks ago after the Flint City Commission failed to pass ...

ALGIERS, Aug. 28 (UPI)-- The Algiers radio announced tonight that the city airport would be closed for 10 hours tomorrow. The announcement led to speculation that former Premier Moise Tshombe of the Congo was about to be extradited to face a Congolese death sentence.

MONTREAL, Aug. 28 (Canadian Press)--The hopes for a settlement of the 11-day-old Canadian inland shipping strike dimmed today when company officials refused to consider the issue of the size of crews, which the union has called "paramount."
The United States and Canadian Government, have extended for an additional year, to March 31, 1969, their approval of the fares agreement on North Atlantic routes that came into effect last April 1.
American churches are "in danger of losing their souls" because "the people who need their ministry most are not getting it," Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff said yesterday.

Franz Cardinal Konig, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Vienna, described here yesterday how the Austrian church was trying to eliminate references in religious textbooks that would foster anti-Semitic feelings.

TORONTO, Aug. 28--The Canadian economy is continuing to expand at only a modest rate this summer. Industrial layoffs and capital market pressures are unsettling, and there is disagreement over whether any pickup in activity is in sight.
Opponents of the war in Vietnam announced plans yesterday for a huge two-day demonstration in Washington next month to "shut down the Pentagon."
Tomorrow may be more than a day away for Forest Lee Ward, who is being billed as the Joe Louis or Cassius Clay of tomorrow.
BRIGHTON, England, Aug. 28 (AP)--Maurice Elvey, British film director and producer, died today in a nursing home. He was 79 years old.

Third round of 72 holes of stroke play begins today and tournament continues through tomorrow. One 18-hole round will be played daily. In event of a tie for first, a sudden-death playoff will follow immediately.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- The Senate Appropriations Committee approved today President Johnson's request for $40-million to operate the controversial rent-supplement program in the current fiscal year.
HONG KONG, Tuesday, Aug. 29 (UPI)--A Hong Kong court convicted three leftist newspaper officials today of publishing seditious material and sentenced each to three years in jail.

PASSAIC, N.J., Aug. 28 (AP) --Three men were arrested here today and charged with bank robbery shortly after three men took more than $22,337 from the New Jersey Bank and Trust Company office in Clifton.
Issues on the American Stock Exchange ended narrowly irregular yesterday in quiet trading.
PLAYERS who object to post-mortem discussions sometimes miss the best part of the hand.
LUSAKA, Zambia, Aug. 28-- Central African Airways, jointly owned by Zambia, Rhodesia and Malawi, will cease operations on Dec. 31, a Government statement said today.
A program to train 570 men from poverty areas as truck drivers and warehousemen was begun yesterday by Mayor Lindsay in a corner of the former Brooklyn Navy Yard.
The stock market yesterday greeted the last week before Labor Day indecisively in a session marked by dull and listless trading.
DENVER, Aug. 28--New York City's Finance Administrator, Roy M. Goodman, proposed today the repeal of all state and local cigarette taxes and the enactment of a single Federal tax of 20 cents a pack.
Sea water has been moving further upstream in the Hudson River, a Federal agency reported yesterday.

ATLIT, Israel, Aug. 28-- On the narrow coastal plain south of Haifa, between the shimmering Mediterranean and the mottled, gray-green Carmel Hills, 4,600 Egyptians are whiling away their days doing nothing.
The purchase of Rice, Unruh Co., Philadelphia steamship agency, was announced yesterday by the Luckenbach Steamship Company, Inc.
CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Aug. 28 (UPI)--Allison Danzig of The New York Times, the dean of the world's tennis writers, was honored today at the Longwood Cricket Club.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 28-- Three men out on bail on Federal charges of running a Mafia-controlled gambling operation in Mamaroneck have been arrested again on new gambling charges by the White Plains Police.

Heavy United States air attacks on Hanoi are reported to have caused much suffering and enormous difficulties in maintaining the life of the city, at the same time stiffening the North Vietnamese will to fight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- Several of the nation's major business organizations collided head-on before the House Ways and Means Committee today over the wisdom of enacting a tax increase now.

YESTERDAY was one of tension in the pro football training camps as the coaches sifted through their rosters and trimmed their squads. The National Football League requires its 16 teams to be down to 49 players today and the American Football League limit is 43.
HOUSTON, Aug. 28 (AP)-- Dr. Edgar Altenburg, a Rice University professor who did early genetic research, was found dead at his home here Sunday. He was 79 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- More than a thousand welfare recipients conducted a mass lobby of heavily policed buildings on Capitol Hill today and picketed the Health, Education and Welfare Department building.

Donaldson, Lufkin Jenrette, Inc., which provides management services to corporations and institutional investors, announced yesterday the election of Edward R. Hintz Jr. and Carl B. Menges as vice presidents and voting stockholders.

Koret of California, an apparel producer and parent of Koratron Company, Inc., hopes to achieve sales of more than $100-million by 1971, Jere N. Helfat, president, told the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday. Koret, which became publicly owned in 1966, last year had sales of $26,381,524.

PRAGUE, Aug. 28--The peculiar radio emissions from the Milky Way that seem to meet many criteria for signals of intelligent origin may be coming from stars in the process of birth, is was suggested here today.
OSAGE BEACH, Mo., Aug. 28--Gov. George Romney said today that he would postpone a foreign policy fact-finding trip to Europe to devote several weeks to a tour of the nation's urban slums.

"I intended to raise a few jarring notes, and seem to have brought out a whole philharmonic," Jerzy Skolimowski, the 31-year-old Polish film director said here yesterday. He smiled, then added: "It's a question of too much sound."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- The companion issues of Treasury bills rose again at this week's auction.
MOSCOW, Aug. 28--Is it a crime for Soviet farm officials to show initiative and bring a degree of prosperity to backward villages by organizing small, semiprivate factories?
WCBS radio went back on the air with its new AM broadcasting operations at 9:17 last night.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28--Ronald Salmon Crane, one of the founders of the Chicago School of literary criticism, which for three decades had emphasized humanism over verbalism in its appraisal of books, died yesterday at his home, 5536 Dorchester Avenue, after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) --A New Jersey antipoverty worker said today that shortsighted policies and outdated obstructionism by certain forces provided powerful support for the perpetuation of poverty among migrant farm workers.

LIVERPOOL, England, Aug. 28 (AP)--The police removed pills from the home of the Beatles' manager, Brian Epstein, for laboratory analysis today in an effort to determine whether they, with liquor he drank at a party Saturday night, could have caused his death.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) --President and Mrs. Johnson are going to put on an oldfashioned country fair at the White House Sept. 12 for children and grandchildren of top officials in the Government.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 (AP)--The medical director of a Massachusetts sanitarium said here today that at least one million women in the United States were alcoholics.

"Package-goods companies will have to look outside the grocery store to achieve the same growth rates of the last decade," said Andrall E. Pearson, a director of McKinsey Co., management consultants, to a visitor who had asked him to look over the marketing horizon.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 28--The United Nations asked South Africa today to propose measures to "facilitate the transfer" of South-West Africa to United Nations Administration.

BATON ROUGE, La., Aug. 28 (AP)--State Conservation Commissioner J.M. Menefee said today he would halt on Sept. 1 emergency overproduction of Louisiana's oil wells, a move authorized after the Middle East crisis developed.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 29 (AP)--Douglas Russell, a 21year-old University of Texas student from Midland, Tex., shattered a world swimming record for the second time in two days at the World University Games today when he won a heat in the 100-meter butterfly in 56.5 seconds.

SEATTLE, Aug. 28--The nation's civilian space program "no longer has a very high priority" and if it is to continue it must show taxpayers more practical results, a Representative told space scientists here today.

In a tale of two old warriors, there were cheers for Elston Howard and concern for Mickey Mantle as the Boston Red Sox resumed their aspirations for the American League pennant with a 3-0 victory over the New York Yankees last night at Yankee Stadium.
HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 28 --The Westchester Golf Classic's final round on Wednesday will be televised.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) --The Pentagon announced tonight that the slain American Nazi party leader, George Lincoln Rockwell, could be buried in a national cemetery but that uniformed party members could not attend the interment.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 28 (AP) --A Federal judge ruled today that a television newsman, Walter Sheridan, did not have to appear (county) before the Orleans Parish grand jury helping District Attorney Jim Garrison in his Kennedy assassination conspiracy investigation.

Canned elephant meat, instant juices in powder form, chocolate candy with cheesebased centers, gold-colored lumpfish caviar, sea scallop bisque, packaged liquid espresso coffee, and Turkish figs in rum.
ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 28 (AP)--Lenny Green drove in four runs and Mickey Lolich pitched a five-hitter as the Detroit Tigers defeated the California Angels, 10-0, tonight.
ASSISI, Italy, Aug. 28 (AP)-- A leading Vatican administrator declared tonight that the Vatican has trouble finding the money to balance its budget.

WEST END, N.J., Aug. 28 --Miss Rosemary Katherine Ilvento and Carmen Michael Penta were married here this afternoon in St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Charles K. Ilvento of West End and Mr. and Mrs. Carmen Penta of Long Branch.
LONDON, Aug. 28--Prime Minister Wilson announced today, as part of a major shuffle of his Government, that he was assuming over-all responsibility for Britain's economic affairs.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 28 (AP)-- John Callison's home run and a bases-loaded balk by Gerry Arrigo in the sixth inning carried the Philadelphia Phillies to a 3-2 triumph over the Cincinnati Reds tonight. It was the Phils' eighth straight victory and it put them in second place in the National League.
TEL AVIV, Aug. 28--A military court in Gaza imposed the heaviest sentence since the Middle East war when it gave a 22-year-old student a 15-year prison term.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Aug. 28 (AP)--A group of United States Marines and a group of Puerto Ricans threw rocks and bottles at each other on Vieques Island over the weekend. A local judge said today that the marines were Negroes who had chanted "Black power."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UPI) --Legislation was introduced today to establish a Federal reinsurance corporation to guarantee riot insurance to homes and businesses in central urban areas.
EDGEWOOD, N.M., Aug. 28 (AP)--A man shot to death yesterday in an exchange of gun fire with a state policeman was identified today as Jay Stanley Weinberger, 31 years old, of Forest Hills. N.Y.

The last section of the tollfree Adirondack Northway, the state's 176-mile Albany-toCanada highway, will be opened Thursday at 5 P.M. Barriers will be rolled away at all entrances to the 30-mile stretch between Underwood and Keeseville in Essex County.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UPI)--House members voted today to start officially a 10day Labor Day recess on Friday. So many lawmakers had left early that there were barely enough on hand to pass the resolution.
TRENTON, Aug. 28--Five South Jersey farmers were officially warned by the state today to clean up their migrant labor camps by the end of the week or face a move in court to have them closed.
TORONTO, Aug. 28 (AP)-- Michel Briand of France finished first today in the opening race of the second World Dragon Class sailing championships.
"Dorothy and Red," a new play about the embattled marriage of Sinclair Lewis, the novelist, and Dorothy Thompson, the columnist, is scheduled for Broadway production this season.

Public support of United States participation in the Vietnam war dropped from 72 to 61 per cent within the last six weeks, according to a survey by Louis Harris published in yesterday's New York Post.
Schenley Industries, Inc., the distiller, announced here yesterday the election of Sylvan Oestreicher as a director.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Aug. 28--The engagement of Miss Rona Elissa Meyer and Lawrence Henry Ross has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Meyer, parents of the future bride. Her fiance's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Rosenbaum of New York.
Genesco, Inc., a manufacturer of footwear and apparel, achieved record sales and earnings in fiscal 1967 for the seventh consecutive year, it was announced here yesterday.

FRESH purple plums go by several names; they are called prune plums, Italian plums or Italian, prunes. But whatever they are called, the small, dark plums with the silver bloom are ideal for serving as is, with bel paese or gorgonzola cheese, or for making pies, breads, cobblers, jams and chutneys.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy accused "reputable banks and department stores" yesterday of advertising loan and credit plans with "phraseology intended to deceive rather than to inform."
Production of steel by the nation's mills turned upward last week.
