A MIDDLE-AGED man asked for an orange flower to cover his bald head. A model in a low-cut dress wanted a butterfly to hover above her cleavage. A hippie chose the word "LUV" printed across his forehead. Lydia Saltzman, a 24-year-old brunette, granted their requests one night recently ...

LUFKIN, Tex., Aug. 28-- Mrs. Elizabeth M. Slater has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Slater, to Capt. Barry Nathan Beck, U.S.M.C., son of Col. Donald Macauley Beck, U.S.M.C., and Mrs. Beck of Quantico, Va. Miss Slater is the daughter also of the late Surrey Winfred Slater.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 28--The North Vietnamese shelled three United States Marine bases near the demilitarized zone and a Marine airfield near Danang today, killing 10 marines and wounding 116, an American spokesman announced.
The National Gypsum Company and Congoleum-Nairn, Inc., announced yesterday agreement on a proposal to merge Congoleum into National Gypsum in a $70-million deal.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) --The American Medical Association opposed today any move to set up a standard fee schedule for physicians' services under the Medicare program.

SEOUL, South Korea, Tuesday, Aug. 29 (Reuters)--North Korean troops killed an American soldier and two South Koreans yesterday in an attack just below the demilitarized zone between North and South Korea, the United Nations command announced today.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 28--An alleged burglar who chose to kiss a sleeping woman in preference to stealing more material things was shot by a policeman today after fleeing from a home here pursued by an angry husband.
Kenneth Schermerhorn, music director of the American Ballet Theater and the New Jersey Symphony, began his stint as Mozart Festival conductor at Philharmonic Hall last night.

ATLANTA, Aug. 28 (UPI)-- Roberto Clemente, the National League's batting leader, hit his second home run of the game in the 10th inning tonight, giving the Pittsburgh Pirates a 4-3 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

FOR the longest while Fenway Park in Boston was generally regarded as the country club of the American League and the the Red Sox were scathingly characterized as the spoiled darlings of an overly generous and doting parent, Tom Yawkey, owner of the team. But Dick Williams put an end to that nonsense when he assumed the managerial controls this year.

ATLANTA, Aug. 28 (UPI)-- Roberto Clemente, the National League's batting leader, hit his second home run of the game in the 10th inning tonight, giving the Pittsburgh Pirates a 4-3 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 28--"Everywhere I look," said Tran Van Huong, widely regarded as the leading civilian candidate for president of South Vietnam, "the prospects look promising, at least on the surface."
BERLIN, Aug. 28 (UPI)-- Mahalia Jackson, the gospel singer, canceled a concert tonight and was taken to a hospital for treatment of a cold and fever.

A group of young women who will be presented at this year's 11th Mistletoe Debutante Ball are being honored today in a luncheon at Stoneleigh, the home of Mrs. Horace J. McAfee, honorary chairman of the ball, in Irvington, N.Y.

SEATTLE, Aug. 28 (UPI)-- A series of lightning storms touched off more than 125 new forest fires in Oregon tonight while fires in British Columbia burned through acres of trees in the Pacific Northwest's worst forest fire season in many years.
TWO sets of earnings figures will appear in many corporate annual reports covering 1967 and they may have an impact on share prices.
Eleven women fled yesterday from the addict rehabilitation center at 10th Avenue and 4lst Street in the second escape from the center within half a month.

HAMPSTEAD, Md., Aug. 28 --O.H. Hoffman Jr., who was general manager of the InterState Milk Producers Cooperative in its Philadelphia headquarters from 1938 to 1963, died Saturday in Union Memorial Hospital, Baltimore. He was 72 years old.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 28--Denmark came to the rescue of the United States tonight at the Edinburgh Festival, where the New York City Ballet was making its first appearance in Scotland in 15 years. An emergency ...
The Queen Mary's final voyage will be a 39-day cruise with stops on three continents and a passage around Cape Horn.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- president Johnson hailed the weekend agreement in London on world monetary reform today, saying it "advances the welfare of all Americans."

DALLAS, Aug. 28 (AP)-- Zeke Bratkowski, the backup quarterback, stepped in for injured Bart Starr tonight and sparked the world champion Green Bay Packers to a 20-3 exhibition-game victory over the Dallas Cowboys.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28-- The Rev. Robert J. Welsh was named president of Villanova University today. He succeeds the Rev. Joseph A. Flaherty, who held the position for two years and resigned because of ill health.
Mayor Lindsay broke ground yesterday for a $2.3-million combination convention hall and indoor ice-skating rink in Coney Island.
The big store opened yesterday, and the trade was brisk as expected. After 24 racing days at Saratoga, the thoroughbreds returned to Aqueduct, and were greeted by a crowd of 30,578 customers.
WIMBLEDON, England, Aug. 28 (AP)--Rod Laver defeated Ken Rosewall, 6-2, 6-2, 12-10, today in the final of the first professional tennis tournament ever staged at Wimbledon.
GENEVA, Aug. 28--James H. Lewis of Washington has been appointed assistant director for trade policy and intelligence to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, it was announced today.
PARIS, Aug. 28--HenriGeorges Adam, a sculptor, died yesterday in Brittany, where he was vacationing, it was reported here today. He was 63 years old.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 28 (AP) --Max Alvis hit a two-run homer in the 11th inning to night to give the Cleveland Indians an 8-7 victory over the Kansas City Athletics.
MOSCOW, Aug. 28 (Reuters)--The Soviet Union appointed Sergei A. Vinogradov today as its Ambassador to the United Arab Republic, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) --An Interstate Commerce Commission hearing examiner recommended today that a subsidiary of Pepsico, Inc., owner of the soft drink company, Pepsi-Cola, be allowed to acquire North American Van Lines Inc.

MINEOLA, L,I., Aug. 28-- A proposed new charter that would triple the size of the Nassau County Board of Supervisors and a law that would create the nation's first ombudsman, or public protector, were approved today by the Board of Supervisors.

VIENNA, Aug. 28--Relations between Austria and Czechoslovakia were strained today after Czech border guards killed one of four young East Germans yesterday. The Germans were shot at while swimming into Austria across the March River.
More sellers than buyers appeared to be on vacation yesterday as the bond market plodded through another slow session. Most Government and corporate issues advanced only slightly.

WEST HARTFORD, Aug. 28 --Mr. and Mrs. Henry S. Robinson Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Constance Brainard Robinson, to Roberto Joseph Ancis, son of Dr. and Mrs. Arturo Ancis of Florence, Italy. The engaged couple plan to marry in the late autumn.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 28-- Gerald N. Hill, president of the California Democratic Council, rejected today a suggestion by the state's Democratic National Committeeman that the 33,000member organization disband.

Stockholders of the ErieLackawanna Railroad voted yesterday at a special meeting here to accept the terms presented by the Interstate Commerce Commission for the inclusion of their line in the Norfolk Western Railway system.

OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 28 (AP)--Curtis Cokes, the welterweight champion, signed today to defend his World Boxing Association title against Charles Shipes, the No. 1 challenger, on Oct. 2 in the Oakland Arena.
CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (UPI)-- Adolfo Phillips scored, the deciding run on a wild pitch in the sixth inning today as the Chicago Cubs registered a 6-5 victory over the Houston Astros.
A MIXTURE of matinee fatuity and well-inten tioned reportage marked the opening yesterday of WNEWTV's marathon afternoon attraction called "The New Yorkers."
The National Educational Television has won out over the three commercial networks to conduct an hour-long interview with Svetlana Alliluyeva.

The appointment of Clarence W. Vandegrift as assistant general counsel of United States Freight Company was announced yesterday by G. Russell Moir, chairman of the board of the concern, the nation's largest freight forwarding company.

HURON, Ohio, Aug. 28 (AP) --The Coast Guard began dragging Lake Erie today for the bodies of 14 missing sky divers, 24 hours after they vanished in the worst accident in the history of the jumping sport.

Chief Federal Judge Sidney Sugarman returned to work yesterday after a rainy vacation to be greeted by an overdue notice for him to qualify as a Federal juror and the haunting taunt by his wife: "Doesn't anyone know you're chief judge?"

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) --Legislation to prohibit the issuance by banks of unsolicited "open end" credit cards was introduced today by Representative Wright Patman, chairman of the House Banking Committee.

A CZECHOSLOVAK writer, Ladislav Mnacko, came prominently to the attention of the West only recently when he left his country and denounced its government for blindly following the Russian line in the Arab-Israeli dispute and for not allowing the Israeli side of the war to be told.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 29 (UPI)--Intrepid, the America's Cup defender, is undergoing a week of overhauling at the Newport Shipyard.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 (UPI)--A Pennsylvania insurance company has announced it has canceled 40 to 50 "poorrisk" policies covering property in the riot-torn area of Detroit.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 29 (UPI)--Gov. Lurleen B. Wallace has signed a resolution asking state-supported colleges and universities to fly the Confederate flag and to play "Dixie" at football games, her office said today.

Some years ago, Max Ernst, the artist, met Sigmund Freud at a party in London and is reported to have said: "Dr. Freud, I would like you to know that what all the surrealists have done is due to you and I want you to know how grateful we are."

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29 (AP)--Hal Lanier drove in five runs with a triple, two singles and a groundnut and Joe Gibbon pitched a three-hitter tonight as the San Francisco Giants crushed the Los Angeles Dodgers, 11-1.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 29--Calvin Koonce, the only self-confessed spitball pitcher in baseball, pitched the New York Mets to a 2-0 victory over the leagueleading St. Louis Cardinals tonight.
The Cigarette Advertising Code, which has had a major effect in tempering cigarette advertising since it went into effect Jan. 1, 1965, lost one of its most important members yesterday.

Two men--one from the Advertising Council, the other from the Treasury--arrived in the board room of the Advertising Research Foundation yesterday morning to discuss the A.R.F.'s volunteer contribution to Savings Bond sales.

AN area of card-play theory that many players find difficult to understand is the one usually described as "restricted choice." The general idea is that a player who drops an honor card in defense is more likely to have done so involuntarily than to have exercised a choice between equal honors.
Prices on the New York Stock Exchange moved up yesterday with trading continuing at a subdued pace.

ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 29 (UPI)--The Detroit Tigers capitalized on nine walks in the first six innings and Dick McAuliffe's timely hit for a 4-2 victory over the California Angels tonight as Denny McLain hurled a three-hitter for his 17th victory.
MALAGA, Spain, Aug. 29 (AP)--Santos of Brazil decided today to suspend its European tour because of injuries suffered by Pele and Silva, two star players.

Millions of Americans are expected to join a nationwide discussion of such issues as atomic energy and the artificial creation of life under a program developed jointly by the National Council of Churches and the Columbia Broadcasting System.
Several offerings of common stock were marketed yesterday and most were oversubscribed.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 29 --John Newcombe and Tony Roche of Australia are the new tennis doubles champions of the United States and Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., and Rosemary Casals of San Francisco are the women's titleholders.
OTTAWA, Aug. 29 (Canadian Press)--Proceedings to bring Hal C. Banks, a former union leader, back from the United States on a charge of perjury were started yesterday at a secret court hearing.
The Control Data Corporation--considered about a year ago as a prime candidate for corporate "last rites"--gave further evidence yesterday that it is very much alive.
The American alligator may become extinct in this country.
HARTFORD, Aug. 29--Mrs. Dorothy Welles Stilson has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Barbara Welles Stilson, to Robert A. Myers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Myers of New York.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29-- President Gamal Abdel Nasser has apparently foiled a plot to overthrow him from within the Egyptian armed forces by arresting about 150 senior officers, including some of his closest followers, reliable diplo-- matic sources reported tonight.

PINE BROOK, N.J., Aug. 29 --The man who built the New York World's Fair, Brig. Gen. William Whipple Jr., is working now on a much smaller, but possibly more important project. The United Network, a television chain that opened with entertainment programing in May and closed in June, hopes to return to the air with news and public affairs shows. Robert R. Pauley, who recently resigned as president of the American Broadcasting Company's radio network, is expected to head the new operations.

COOLIN, Idaho, Aug. 30 (AP) --A rapidly moving forest fire that had been threatening this small, north Idaho resort community, was halted today within a mile and a half of the edge of town. CENTREVILLE, Del., Aug. 30 (UPI)--Mrs. Katherine Thompson wood, 74 years old, a wealthy society matron and sister of James H. W. Thompson, the missing Thailand silk industrialist, was found beaten to death this morning. she lived alone.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30--The United States lost $33-million in gold in July, bringing the loss for the year to a comparatively modest $99-million, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

DETROIT, Aug. 30--Leaders of the United Automobile Workers rejected today the automobile industry's new contract offer, calling it "entirely inadequate." The union also... began preparing the machineery for a strike, which Could begin next Wednesday night if there is no settlement.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 30--The Vietcong struck a number of United States and South Vietnamese bases today and, in the most daring raid, freed 977 prisoners from a provincial jail. Four hundred were reported recaptured.
OSAGE BEACH, Mo., Aug. 30--President Johnson sent his regrets to the Midwestern Governors today for not having attended their conference.
STUART GREET, a British decorator who has been here for seven years, has opened at 967 Lexington Avenue (between 70th and 71st Streets) what might be called an all-purpose decorating shop.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 30--Two weeks ago, on the day that the 10 civilian presidential candidates finally got their campaign rolling, Dr. Hoang Co Binh turned up in Bienhoa prepared to deliver an impassioned and closely reasoned one-hour speech.

GREENVILLE JUNCTION, Me., Aug. 30--It is almost axiomatic that when a ski enthusiast decides to become a lodge operator so that he can enjoy more of the sport, he usually becomes too busy with guests to enjoy the sport at all.

THE Red Sox and the Yankees, feeling much like disembodied zombies dragged themselves onto the diamond yesterday at the Stadium for the fourth and final game of their spectacular series. It had been an exhausting operation with Tuesday's twilight-night double-header beginning at 5 P.M. and ending minutes before 2 o'clock Wednesday morning. It had been an emotional and physical strain as the Yanks edged out the Bosox in the 20th inning, 4 to 3.
PARIS, Aug. 30--The publication of Andre Malraux's memoirs has been advance because a local newspaper, France-Soir, printed excerpts totaling about 3,500 words without authorization.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30-- Despite the tough tone of recent public statements from Hanoi, American officials report continuing signs that North Vietnam is suffering from morale problems.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 30 (Reuters)--A commercial court here has agreed to the sale of the Intra Bank branch in Rome toi the Milan branch of the First National City Bank.
The long-standing debate over Federal maritime policy has been pushed off dead center by an agreement worked out this week by members of Congress and the Department of Transportation.

TOKYO, Aug. 30--The Bank of Japan is scheduled to raise the official discount rate early in September to cope with the deterioration of the country's international balance of payments and to prevent overheating of the Japanese economy.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 30--Like Tom Sawyer and Huckleberry Finn--whom they often have been accused of resembling--Stan Musial and Red Schoendienst are putting the finishing touches on the Great New Adventure they started along the banks of the Mississippi last spring.

The victory of John Bell Williams in Tuesday's Democratic runoff primary for Governor of Mississippi marks a revival of power for the arch-segregationists who have given that state its pre-eminence as a symbol of Deep South resistance to equal rights for Negroes.
ITALIAN history balances bloodshed with art. In so doing, as we know, say, from the Roman and the Renaissance stories, it gives a haunting glitter to violence, and produces infinitudes of books.

TOKYO, Aug. 30 (AP)--John Ferris, an 18-year-old entering Stanford this fall, slashed the world record for the 200-meter butterfly to 2 minutes 6 seconds in leading the all-winning United States swimming and diving team to a sweep of seven gold medals tonight in the World University Games.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Aug. 30 (UPI)--Rains and bone-chilling 53-degree temperatures washed out the opening round of the 67th United States Amateur golf chamnionship today.

THE story of the schooner America, which took the measure of British sailing vessels in the celebrated race around the Isle of Wight in August, 1851, was re-enacted in a film documentary last night. The program also turned out to have a strong peripheral commercial purpose.

The Federal Reserve Board announced yesterday a revision in its measure of the nation's money supply. This shows that money circulating in the economy has risen to a higher level, and is increasing at a more rapid rate than had been supposed earlier.
The electricity index, a component of The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activity, fell to 542.9 from 544.4. A year earlier it was 521.6.
Soybeans were on the march yesterday. Following the leader, corn and wheat also advanced in price.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI) --The Federal Communications Commission issued today a brief stay of its order directing the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to reduce its rates by $120-million a year.

The United States rowing team, a 36-man contingent that included oarsmen, coxswains, alternates, coaches, a boat rigger, manager and team doctor, left last night for Vichy, France, and the European championships.

Miss Eulalia Meyer is going back to work. She will climb the dark stairs of crumbling West Side tenements and knock on doors in shabby hotels, seeking out elderly people who need help. Miss Meyer is 76 years old.

The Socialist Workers party announced its 1968 ticket yesterday, with Fred Halstead, a 40-year-old cloth cutter, its candidate for President and Paul Boutelle, 35, a Negro cab driver, for Vice President. It opposes the war in Vietnam...
Three common stock offerings were successfully marketed yesterday and a fourth was registered for future sale.

ROME, Aug. 30--Pope Paul VI expressed great concern today over the continuation of the war in Vietnam. His concern was echoed by the Vatican's weekly review, which stressed the dangers of bombings of North Vietnam close to Communist China.
Should you trade in commodity futures? Probably not, unless you are a seasoned investor and have a certain mental attitude.

SAYVILLE, L.I., Aug. 30-- Barring any breakdowns on the final two days, Fred H. Miller should finish well ahead of the 57 other skippers competing in Great South Bay off here for the Finn Class national championship.
As a result of the new divorce law effective today, New York is expected to lose its standing as the state with the lowest divorce rate in the country.
TEL AVIV, Aug. 31 Two tractors of the Saad communal farm in the Northern Negev were damaged by land mines today. One driver was injured.

The net income of ACF Industries, Inc., for the first fiscal quarter to July 31 was $5,755,000, or $1 a share, down from $6,829,000, or $1.16 a share, in the corresponding period last year, John F. Burditt, chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.
SAIGON, Aug. 31 A United States command spokesman said 125 Americans were killed and 1,078 wounded in Vietnam last week, a slight rise from the previous week, when 108 were killed and 883 wounded.

RIO GRANDE CITY, Tex., Aug. 31 (UPI) The rainswollen Rio Grande swept out of its banks and poured over hundreds of acres of lower Rio Grande Valley croplands on the Texas side today, sending scores of persons fleeing from its path. No injuries were reported.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Aug. 31 Abdullah al-Salal, the President of Yemen, reacted today to the agreement between Egypt and Saudi Arabia to halt the war in his country with a statement denouncing "interference in our internal affairs."

Sammy Mosberg, 1920 Olympic lightweight boxing champion, died on Wednesday after suffering a heart attack in the rooftop pool at 370 East 76th Street, where he was visiting a friend. He was 70 years old and lived at 160 Columbia Heights in Brooklyn.
CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 31 (Reuters)--Australia today made it illegal to import lysergic acid, the main ingredient for the hallucinatory drug LSD.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 31 (AP) Officers of a minority conservative party were arrested today on charges of having defamed President Eduardo Frei Montalva's Government by issuing a statement that criticized Chile's handling of foreign affairs.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Aug. 31 The Rev. Lawrence Munns Upton of 326 Grove Street, housing expert of the United Church of Christ, died Tuesday of a heart attack while vacationing at Hillsboro, N. H. He was 52 years old.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Sept. 1 (Reuters)--Vietcong or North Vietnamese forces today mortared the United States northern Marine headquarters, killing four marines and wounding 41 in a 30-minute barrage, an American military spokesman said.

MADRID, Aug. 31 The chief public health officer of Spain today denounced "illegitimate" interests, mainly in Anglo-Saxon countries, which he said were behind birth-control programs and promotion of contraceptive devices.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The Senate Preparedness Investigation Subcommittee urged President Johnson today to widen the air war against North Vietnam and abandon his policy of "carefully controlled" bombing.

LONDON, Aug. 31 The Foreign Office said today that Britain's Ambassador in Israel, Michael Hadow, had been urging the Israeli Government to extend the time limit for the return of refugees from the east bank of the Jordan.

The Rev. Gommar A. De Pauw, leader of the Catholic Traditionalist Movement, said yesterday that he was prepared to carry his protest against "modernist" tendencies in the Roman Catholic Church to the point of schism, if necessary.

Serious issues of civilian vs. military control of defense and diplomatic policy are raised by the public campaign of some of the nation's top generals for an extension of the bombing of North Vietnam a campaign that has now brought them an initial Senate victory.

TOKYO, Aug. 31 (AP) A Japanese youth slipped into the United States Embassy compound today, tossed a bucketful of gasoline on three embassy cars, set them afire and escaped. No one was hurt. The Chief Cabinet Secretary, Toshio Kimura, expressed the Government's "sincerest regret and apologies."
SPRING LAKE, N. J., Aug. 31 William J. Duffy Sr., chairman of the board of the Haven Savings and Loan Association of Hoboken, died last night at his home here.

When a passenger hops a commercial plane to get from here to there quickly, he soon discovers that man does not live by one means of transportation alone. The Labor Day weekend congestion and peril underscores the point.
DETROIT, Aug. 31 (AP) United States auto production surged near the 140,000 mark this week in what could be the last full week of production before an auto strike.

MIAMI, Aug. 31 (UPI) The hurricane season's first tropical storm weakened today and was moving northward away from land areas after it collided with a mass of cold air over the mid-Atlantic that sapped its strength.

This man is not a new executive at either Lever Brothers or Procter Gamble, but you're close. C. W. (Red) Barnard is regional sales manager for the Calgon Corporation and on Sept. 14 he'll be the sudsy star of a commercial.

MONTREAL, Aug. 31 (Canadian Press) John Dane of New Orleans clinched the North American junior sailing championships today to win the Sears Cup. Scoring 48 points, he beat his nearest rival by only 1 points after winning the eighth and final race of the series.

MANY women who probably couldn't afford it were thinking mink in Union Square Park yesterday as eight perspiring models paraded up and down a blue runway in $44,444 worth of furs from S. Klein. Was it a Happening? Was it an In? No, it was a "Mink-Out," so...
Alexander M. White Jr., Joseph J. Gal and James R. Morse were admitted yesterday as general partners of White, Weld Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange.

UNTTED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 31 Yugoslavia's Foreign Minister said here today that he was encouraged by the reception given at the United Nations and in Washington to President Tito's latest proposals for easing tension between Israel and the Arab countries.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) Senator Robert F. Kennedy, Challenged today the conten tion of Gen. Wallace M. Greene Jr., Marine Corps commandant, that Vietnam is more important than the plight of United States cities.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 31 Belgium, The Netherlands and Luxembourg are discussing steps to push their integration beyond the field of economics, hoping that this will also encourage the European Community, of which France, West Germany and Italy are the other three members, to follow suit.

MOSCOW, Aug. 31 (Reuters) Three young Soviet writers, members of an underground literary society, were hustled out of a courtroom and into a waiting police truck tonight with the expectation they will be sentenced tomorrow for organizing an illegal demonstration in January.

Seated yesterday among fellow hay fever sufferers on 13 trolley-like benches in the main room at the allergy clinic of the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital was a man to whom sneezing has virtually become a way of life.
A flurry of last-minute statements from rival airlines came with today's deadline for filing written briefs in the 10-yearold Pacific air route case before the Civil Aeronautics Board.
MIAMI, Aug. 31 Mrs. Hannah Troy, the New York fashion designer, was married here yesterday to Max Meyer of Fall River, Mass., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., in a civil ceremony at City Hall.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 31 The headquarters of Gen. William C. Westmoreland, the United States commander in South Vietnam, accused North Vietnam today of flagrant lying about the results of enemy military operations.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 31 (AP) Clay L. Shaw, charged with conspiring to murder President Kennedy, lost his fight today to have testimony taken by deposition from Mrs. Lillie Mae McMaines, a former friend of the state's main witness, Perry Raymond Russo.

UNDER the title "Take a Deep, Deadly Breath," the American Broadcasting company documentary series "Summer Focus" offered last night a summing up of the problem of air pollution. The program was a useful if routine review of the blight of contaminated air; what the hour had to say was worth saying but it neither charted any new ground nor was provocatively detailed.
TOKYO, Aug. 31 Premier Eisaku Sato is expected to leave generous gifts in the developing countries of Southeast Asia that he will visit during a month-long tour program beginning Sept. 20.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 31 The five top Communist leaders in Thailand and 25 suspected Communists were arrested at dawn today, the police said. The police director general, Prasert Ruchirawong, said four of the leaders had been trained in China.
GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Colonialism Continued debate on Gibraltar.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Revenue freight traffic gen-, erated by carloadings on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended Aug. 26 were both below the volume in the corresponding week of 1966.
TAYLORVILLE, Ill., Aug. 31 (AP) Harry B. Hershey, former Justice of the Illinois Supreme Court, died last night in St. Vincent's Hospital here. He was 82 years old.

The John's Bargain Stores Corporation, which over the last 12 years expanded its sales of low-priced merchandise from 40 to 474 retail variety stores, filed a voluntary bankruptcy petition in the Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday.
The Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation reported here yesterday a 25 per cent increase in profits for the six months ended July 1.

BOSTON, Aug. 31 The Chicago White Sox, who usually employ reckless base-running to score, used a rare gait for them tonight, the home-run trot, in a 4-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox that tightened the four-team American League pennant race.
The Weather Bureau predicted yesterday that the opening days of the Labor Day weekend would be mostly sunny and cool.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 President Johnson signed today a new veterans Bill of Rights extending to about five million veterans increased educational, job training and other benefits.
Highway construction at nine points in the metropolitan area is expected to cause traffic delays over the long Labor Day weekend.

HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 31 (UPI) Audrey Hepburn and Mel Ferrer, married for 13 years, have separated, a spokesman for the couple announced today. No reason was given. The spokesman said they had no plans for an immediate divorce. Mr. Ferrer, an actor and director, is in Paris preparing a new movie. Miss Hepburn is staying in the family home in Switzerland with their son, Sean, 7.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 31 At the sixth annual St. Vincent Debutante Ball at the Apawamis Club here tonight 17 young women from Westchester and Fairfield Counties made their formal bows to society. They were presented to Francis Cardinal Spellman in the club's ballroom.
JERICHO, Jordan, Aug. 31 Israel today closed the Jordan River bridges that refugees have been using to return to west-bank areas occupied in the brief June war.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 31 The self-styled peace candidate in South Viet nam's presidential elections gets up every morning at 5 o'clock. He lifts barbells for 30 minutes. He reads Jean-Paul Sartre or Henri Bergson for an hour. And then he meditates.

The American Broadcasting Company and the National Broadcasting Company last night submitted what they called "final" contract proposals to the National Association of Broadcast Employes and Technicians in an effort to prevent a strike today.

WHEN Homer Jones of the Giants caught his fifth forward pass of the game last Sunday, he was slammed out of bounds by Earsell Mackbee of the Vikings. They rose to their feet and started to toss punches at each other. For this gross breach of etiquette they were given the heave by the officials.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara said today that the Pentagon had blacklisted a company in Mineola, L.I., that had charged the Government $33,000 for 130 knobs that could have been bought for $210.60.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 31 Gov. Robert E. McNair said today that he expected Negro delegates to be elected to the National Democratic Convention by the state convention in South Carolina next year.
The police are searching for 11 boys who escaped from Youth House in the Bronx and for a member of Mayor Lindsay's Summer Youth Council who is helping them to avoid recapture.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican republic, Aug. 31 (Reuters) The Dominican Republic closed its border with Haiti to land travelers last night, alleging that subversive elements were crossing it to disturb the peace in both countries.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 31 (UPI) The Alabama Legislature refused late today to let Gov. Lurleen B. Wallace put strings on an appropriation to a Negro college.
The SCM Corporation, a manufacturer of office equipment, announced here yesterday a realignment of the company into four major divisions.
BOSTON, Aug. 31 (AP) The American Legion condemned President de Gaulle of France today for his "disdain" for the United States and called for "diplomatic and economic retaliation" against France.
Net income of the Union Pacific Railroad for July plummeted by more than 30 per cent, the carrier announced yesterday.

Sears, Roebuck Co., the nation's largest retailing company, reported yesterday record sales for the first fiscal half ended July 31, but said that net income for the period was 4 per cent below the record total for the same period last year.

ROME, Aug. 31 (Reuters) The police throughout Italy were today ordered to watch but for about 4 pounds of stolen cheese that contains deadly cyanide poison. It was being shipped to France for use as rat bait.
TORONTO, Aug. 31 (Canadian Press) Inter of Milan and Olympiakos, the 1967 soccer champions of Greece, played a 2-2 tie tonight before a crowd of 23,000.

A son was born on Wednesday to Mr. and Mrs. David Love of Forest Hills, Queens, at the Long Island Jewish Hospital, New Hyde Park, L.I. Mrs. Love is the former Miss Judy Axelrod. The child, whose father is director of the Mayor's Action Center at City Hall, has been named Lawrence Lindsay.
LONDON, Aug. 31 After playing in London a month, "America Hurrah" three oneact plays by Jean-Claude van Itallie has been banned for public exhibition.
MONTREAL, Aug. 31 (AP) Two armed men overpowered a worker in a baggage car on a Canadian National Railways passenger train en route from Halifax to Montreal today and escaped with about $80,000.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Friday, Sept. 1 The Arab chiefs of state agreed yesterday to establish a fund of 140-million, or $392-million, to aid Jordan and the United Arab Republic, the countries that suffered the greatest losses in the war with Israel in June.

The city's teachers union rejected the Board of Education's latest salary offer yesterday and submitted a new proposal of its own as efforts to settle the school contract dispute moved into the critical stage.
Litton Industries, Inc., announced here yesterday a preliminary agreement to acquire the Landis Tool Company for about $130-million in stock. Charles B. Thornton, chair-...

BERLIN, Aug. 31 (UP) Mahalia Jackson today called off her European tour because of illness. She announced that she would leave West Berlin's Westend Hospital next week and fly back to Chicago. She entered the hospital Monday. West Berlin was her first appearance on a tour scheduled to take her to West Germany, Britain, Switzerland and Italy.

After absorbing one of the earliest defeats in their history, the New York Yankees announced yesterday that Whitey Ford would be their first base coach in 1968, with Jim Turner remaining active as the pitching coach.

The Vienna Philharmonic will give a concert benefiting the pension fund of the New York Philharmonic at Philharmonic Hall on Oct. 3. It will also cele brate the 125th anniversary years for both orchestras, which were founded in 1842.

TORONTO, Aug. 31 Golfers representing 15 nations, including a weary contingent that arrived from the prolonged Westchester Classic that ended in Harrison, N.Y., yesterday, stood attentively at a colorful flag-raising ceremony this afternoon.

HANOI, Aug. 31 Stokely Carmichael, the American black power militant, told a meeting here that he was a revolutionary who wanted to change the "American regime," according to reports in the Hanoi press today.
Orvis Brothers Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday the appointment of Paterson Bond as managing partner.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) Three field goals by Lou Michaels in the second half provided the margin tonight as the Baltimore Colts defeated the Washington Redskins, 23-17, in a National Football League exhibition game.
WASHINGTON, Aug 31 (AP) The United States Office of Education took a first step today that could lead to termination of Federal financial assistance to the Lowndes, Ga., school system.

JOAO PESSOA, Brazil, Aug. 31 (UPI)--The last of the quintuples born near here last week has died despite all efforts of medical teams, doctors sold today. The mother, Maria Santos, gave birth to four boys and a girl in Campinas Grande. Doctors said the babies were born prematurely.

KINSHASA, The Congo, Aug. 31 (UPI) White mercenary soldiers beat back Congolese army attacks and inflicted heavy losses, diplomatic sources reported today. The sources said the Congolese made several attacks yesterday on the mercenaries and their Katangese allies, who hold the town of Bukavu.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) Maria Tallchief was chosen today to receive the 1967 Indian Achievement Award presented annually since 1933.

The marriage of Miss Flower Zoloto, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman L. Zoloto of 44 East 67th Street, to C. Martin Goldenberg took place at the Regency last evening. The bridegroom is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Max Goldenberg of Los Angeles. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Arthur Schneier, assisted by Cantor David Kusevitsky.

The American Broadcasting Company has acquired exclusive television rights to the world middleweight championship bout Sept. 28 between Nino Benvenuti and Emile Griffith. The network will tape the fight at Shea Stadium here and broadcast it on "A.B.C.'s Wide World of Sports" on Saturday, Sept. 30 at 5 P.M.
THE Knickerbocker Championships, a sectional tournament organized by the Greater New York Bridge Association, begin this afternoon at the New York Hilton.
A strike threatened for this morning by 5,000 workers at about 90 nursing homes here was averted yesterday.

The Shoreside Supervisors Union, now engaged in an effort to organize some 1,000 hiring agents and pier superintendents in the Port of New York, is seeking to enlist the help of the New York Port Council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Maritime Trades Department.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 31 (Reuters) The Shah of Iran returned tonight after a 10-day trip to the United States, Canada and France. While in North America, he met President Johnson and attended Expo 67 in Montreal.

CLEARWATER, Fla., Aug. 31 (UPI) The Pinellas County Teachers Association announced today that it had come to agreement in a dispute over pay with the county school board and would withdraw members' resignation and return to classes tomorrow.

With the Wimbledon titleholder, John Newcombe of Australia, awaiting his turn to play today and nursing a pinched nerve in his back, Roy Emerson of Australia was a party to the main action in the stadium yesterday as the 86th United States grass court singles championships started at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.

SOPHIE is a gentle blond designer who always manages to emerge un scathed from fashion's continuous storm. Her umbrella at Saks Fifth Avenue shelters a good number of women each season, all of whom are buffeted by the winds of change but refuse to acknowledge it.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 31 Miss Carolyn Ferris White and Second Lieut. Gerald Raymond Wheaton, U.S.A, were married here this afternoon in the Presbyterian Church of the Covenant. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. John Travers White of Shaker Heights and Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Wheaton of Corning, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Donald C. Clokey.
MOSCOW, Aug. 31 A fervent plea for Christianity in Soviet public life, particularly in education, was put before the readers of a national youth newspaper today.

WCBS and WNBC radio began sharing a temporary 200foot transmitting tower on High Island in the Bronx yesterday morning in a move to increase the stricken stations' broadcast range in the New York area.

BOSTON, Aug. 31 Miss Alice Elizabeth Keidan and Arthur Van Cleve Lanckton were married here this afternoon in the chapel of Temple Israel by Rabbi Harvey Fields. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Baer Keidan of Detroit and Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Lanckton of New York and Rowayton, Conn.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP)--Gen. Harold K. Johnson, the Army Chief of Staff, has said the United States may be able to consider withdrawing troops from South Vietnam in 18 months if the present rate of progress is maintained.

Power was shut off on the Eighth Avenue IND subway from 1:50 to 2:40 P.M. yesterday from 145th to 207th Street after a woman was discovered on the tracks near the 159th Street emergency exit. The woman, identified as Mrs. Patricia Black, 22 years old, of Newark, told the police she had been shoved from a moving train. Mrs. Black was treated at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center for bruises and released.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) The Senate passed without debate today a bill increasing the number of trips that members of the House may make to their home districts each year at the taxpayers' expense.
DALLAS, Aug. 31 (UPI) The loyalty oath required of state employes in Texas was ruled unconstitutional today by a special three-judge Federal panel.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 31 Gov. Ronald Reagan's eightmonth campaign to inaugurate a tuition fee at the University of California met defeat today by a 14-to-7 vote of his fellow members on the university Board of Regents.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday that it had obtained consent judgments in connection with two suits it had filed last year against David M. Milton, former chairman and chief executive of the Equity Corporation, a closed-end investment company.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 31 (AP) Jorge Velasquez, the nation's leading rider, and Steve Brooks, another experienced jockey, suffered injuries in the same race today at Atlantic City race track and were sent to the Atlantic City Hospital for X-rays and observation.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.

Madison Square Garden and WOR TV announced yesterday they had signed a three-year contract for televising games involving the New York Rangers of the National Hockey League and the New York Knickerbockers of the National Basketball Association.

BALDWIN, L.I., Aug. 31--A Negro high school teacher who has been accused of molesting a 16-year-old white girl student was characterized by school officials at a public hearing today as a "very good" teacher and an "excellent" human being.
Variety, apparel, discount and department store chains may well double their space in New York City over the next five years, a survey of leading chain operations indicates.

LEEDS, England, Aug. 31 (Reuters) A woman scientist whose pacifist stand as a Quaker led to prison during World War II has been elected the first woman president of the British Association for the Advancement of Science. She is Dame Kathleen Lonsdale, 64 years old, one of the world's greatest experts in the study of crystals by X-rays.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Following is the text of a report issued today by the Senate Preparedness Investigation Subcommittes on the air war against North Vietnam.

In the comments it has filed with the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, the American Association of Advertising Agencies says that the proposed regulations of the Food and Drug Administration on ethical drug advertising would seriously hamper the effectiveness of that type of advertising.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 31 Mrs. Renee Millicent Hecht and Dr. Michael Allan Sperber were married here this evening in the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Chapel by the Rev. Arthur B. Jellis, Unitarian, of Concord.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange rose again to a new high for the year yesterday, but tended to ease toward the close of trading.

MURRAY HILL, N. J., Aug. 31 Miss Susan Jean Hagen, daughter of Mrs. Stanley J. Hagen of Summit and the late Lieutenant Hagen, Army Air Forces, was married here tonight to David Hays Cavanaugh, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Thomas Cavanaugh of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Russell E. Swanson performed the ceremony in Faith Lutheran Church.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 31--Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson said today that he would not pay a bill for $1.79-million from the Metropolitan Commuter Transportation Authority for the upkeep of 60 stations of the Long Island Rail Road. The bill is due tomorrow.

OXFORD, N.Y., Aug. 31 (UPI) A small plane crashed on a farm near this Chenango County community during a violent electrical storm last night, killing two men. The state police identified the two victims as William A. Culberson, 39 years old, of East Point, Ga., apparently the pilot, and Bruce MacLean, 38, of Basking Ridge, N. J.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 31 (UPI) Rich Reese, a pinchhitter, blasted a two-run homer today with one out in the ninth inning and carried the Minnesota Twins to a 10-9 triumph over the Baltimore Orioles, the victory enabled the Twins to retain second place in the American League.

Nearly five years have gone by since a panel of experts on mental health appointed by President John F. Kennedy urged that mental retardation be recognized as a major national problem calling for legal and moral commitment at all levels. New Federal programs now provide $400 million a year in this field and twice as much more is spent by state local and private agencies.
Ad Reinhardt, a prominent figure in the development of "minimal art" in painting, died of a heart attack Wednesday night at his studio at 732 Broadway. His age was 53.
Take two apprentice jockeys (one of whom had never won in New York), put them aboard claiming horses whose recent form shouted "stay away!" and what do you get? Simple: a daily double of $1,800,20.
John Nuveen Co., investment banking firm, confirmed yesterday it had contracted to acquire for an undisclosed sum the business of Arthur Wiesenberger Co.

TOKYO, Aug. 31 (AP) Charlie Hickcox and Mike Burton led an American assault on three more world records tonight in leading the formidable swimming and diving team to four more championships in the World University Games.
A drive is under way to floodlight the city's public schools to reduce vandalism and loitering.
HONG KONG, Aug. 31 (Reu ters) Premier Dong praised both the Soviet Union and China in his speech celebrating North Vietnam's anniversary, the Hanoi press agency reported today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 31 Mrs. Margaret J. Irvine Wilson, an account executive for Reach, McClinton Co., Inc., advertising agency at 505 Park Avenue in New York, died yesterday in New Rochelle Hospital. She was 54 years old and lived at the Chatsworth Garden Apartments here.

Eureka, Ill., was in the minds of the actors of the National Shakespeare Company yesterday and so was Gorham, Me., Selma, Ala.; San Jose, Calif., and Calgary, B.C. The company was rehearsing for an eight-month tour of 99 towns in 27 states and Canada.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 Officials of New York City were surprised to learn today that they were competing with Phiiadelphia in seeking to acquire the aircraft carrier Tarawa for use as a school.

ALBANY, Aug. 31 The Democratic-controlled Constitutional Convention pushed through late tonight a proposal requiring the Legislature to establish and define a system of free higher education for all New Yorkers.

New legal machinery for the peaceful resolution of labor disputes in the civil service becomes effective in both city and state today. The common aim of the state's new Taylor Law named after Prof. George W. Taylor of the University of Pennsylvania, chairman of the committee of experts that drafted it and of the city's new Office of Collective Bargaining is to end strikes of public employes by eliminating any necessity for them.
HONG KONG, Aug. 31 The Canton radio early today reported the formation of a "revolutionary joint committee" of workers professing allegiance to Mao Tse-tung, Chairman of the Chinese Communist party.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 31 (UPI) President Tito dispatched a fourth envoy yesterday, this time to Latin America, to seek support for his peace plan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The United States, backing away from a confrontation with the Soviet Union over Arctic navigation rights, has delivered a strong protest accusing the Russians of violating a freedom-of-the-seas convention, the the State Department said today.
MANILA, Aug. 31 (AP) Sixty publishers and editors organized the Press Foundation of Asia today to "encourage regional cooperation" and "a rapid growth of the press" in this part of the world.
The McDonnell Douglas Corporation announced yesterday receipts of military and commercial contracts totaling more than $117-million.
Columbia will name one of its senior scientists to take charge of tests on the Strickman cigarette filter, of which it owns slightly more than 50 per cent interest.
The bankrupt New Haven Railroad has been offered a $25-million loan that should permit it to keep its trains running for three years more, or longer.
The stock market shook the doldrums yesterday as price advanced decisively in an increased trading pace.

The dedication of modern dancers to their craft is legendary but few go so far as to paint the hall that they are to perform in. The gothic-style gymnasium of Calvary Episcopal Church on Park Avenue South received a new coat of paint from the performers last night and made a start to becoming a home for the blossoming world of dance.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Aug. 31 (AP) The chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission proposed today that the International Atomic Energy Agency provide the "effective international safeguards" needed under a treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons.

BONN, Aug. 31 (AP) A medical bulletin said today that Defense Minister Gerhard Schroder was in good condition after having suffered a disturbance of his heart rhythm Tuesday while vacationing in the island of Sylt. He is being treated at the Hamburg University hospital. The bulletin said that there was no sign of a stroke, heart attack or brain hemorrhage.
Leon Lauterstein, senior member of the law firm of Lauterstein Lauterstein, died yesterday at Boothbay Harbor, Me., while on a vacation. He was 84 years old.

OBERLIN, Ohio, Aug. 31--The pilot of a converted B-25 from which 16 out of 18 sports parachutists who leaped into Lake Erie Sunday are presumed dead testified today that just after the jump he had an uneasy feeling he was in the wrong place.
Harlan P. Kleiman, co-founder of New Haven's Long Wharf Theater, has resigned as executive director, effective Sept. 10.
DAR SAAD, Lahej Sultanate, South Arabia, Aug. 31--Rebel tribesmen today proclaimed that they had captured this key market town at the gates of Aden.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara said today that about 85 per cent of American servicemen wounded in Vietnam were later returned to duty.

Miss. Megan Harris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rich ard L. Harris of 535 Park Avenue and Southampton, L. I., was married here yesterday afternoon to D. Sean Murphy, son of Dr. and Mrs. Donal G. Murphy of Greens Farms, Conn. The ceremony, was performed in St. Vincent Ferrer, Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Edward Rooney.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 31 The Rhodesian Government announced today that three men who have been in the death cells for nearly two years would be hanged shortly.
The American Stock Exchange continued to bounce back yesterday, after almost two weeks of declining prices, to rack up good gains in active trading.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Aug. 31--The Stanford Repertory Theater will open its third season Nov. 29 with Jean Anouilh's "The Cavern."
AREA A Small bluefish being taken along the beaches in Barnegat Light area by trollers. Small weakfish in same area responding to jigging. Sea bass and ling...

BAY SHORE, L. I., Aug. 31 The marriage of Miss Anne Baxter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Byrne Baxter, to Anthony Joseph Cigarran, son of Mr. and Mrs. Avelardo Manuel Cigarran of Waverly, Pa., took place here today in St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church. Msgr. Myron J. Purick performed the ceremony.

HAMDEN, Conn., Aug. 31 Mr. and Mrs. Eben Brown Haskell have announced the engagement of Mr. Haskell's daughter, Miss Judith Brown Haskell, to John Hutchison Kress, son of Mrs. Rush Harrison Kress of New York and the late Mr. Kress.
ALBANY, Aug. 31 (AP) A resident of Cohoes accused of murdering a Jewish salesman was indicted today by a grand jury on a charge of first degree murder.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Mrs. J. Borden Harriman, Minister to Norway at the beginning of World War II and an early crusader for social rights, died at her Georgetown home here today. She was 97 years old.

Mrs. Beatrice Straus Levy, wife of Dr. Robert L. Levy, a noted cardiologist, died yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after a long illness. She was 69 years old and lived at 720 Park Avenue.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 31 (AP) A persistent blanket of hot, stifling smog draped itself across Los Angeles today as desperate residents sought relief.
Development of an experimental television camera for viewing the insides of the human body in color was announced yesterday by C.B.S. Laboratories.

SKOPJE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 31 Bobby Fischer, the 24-yearold eight-time United States chess champion, triumphed in the Tournament of Solidarity when he defeated the Yugoslav master, Jovan Sofrevski, in the 17th and final round here last night. Fischer posted a 13 -3 winning score, with 12 victories, three draws and two losses.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 A New York City Congressman made public today 82 reports of near-misses between aircraft over his area in two and a half years. He called for a ban on flights by small planes near large cities.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Manufacturers' inventories rose almost $300-million in July after their decline in June, the Commerce Department reported today.

TOKYO, Aug. 31 (AP) Authorities reported today that floods in Niigata and Yamagata prefectures this week killed 53 people and left 82 missing and 34 injured. They said 133 houses had been destroyed and 602 damaged.
THE nation should face up to the dangers of infla tion immediately, the First National City Bank urges in its monthly economic letter, issued today.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Aug. 31 (UPI) The British Amateur golf champion, Bob Dickson, on leave from the Army and wrapped up like a mummy against the cold, rain and fog, took the early first-round lead in the 67th United States Amateur golf tournament today with a one-over-par 35, 36-71.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) John R. McDonough, 48 years old, long-time law professor at Stanford University, was appointed today as assistant to the Deputy Attorney General.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 The district attorney's office obtained warrants for five men today on charges of murder and conspiracy in the slaying Robert A. DeGeorge, a member of Local 107, International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
The Nederlander family, which controls theaters here and on the road, has added the new Garden State Arts Center in New Jersey to its string.
JANSSEN'S, Lexington Avenue and 44th Street, Opera scenes from Verdi's "La Traviata," with Maida Testa and Bob Gregori; Riccardo Bertoni, continental singer.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 The engagement of Miss Bette Ellen Egnal to Gerald Allan Rabie has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Michael H. Egnal. Her fiance's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Dan Rabie of Capetown.
TORONTO, Aug. 31 (Canadian Press) A new challenger rose out of the swell to threaten the leadership of a pair of New Orleans skippers today in the world Dragon Class sailing championship.
The Federal Reserve may have decided to slow, just a bit,, its push toward easy money, banking statistics released yesterday indicated.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he was considering conducting a personal campaign urging voters to turn down the new state Constitution because convention delegates had rejected proposals to expand the taxing powers of cities.

The world's oldest ants have been found in New Jersey, preserved in a lump of amber. The discovery of the fossils dates the origin of the earth's first social insect to 100 million years ago, a time when dinosaurs were becoming extinct.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) The United States Naval Academy has 200,000 pounds of dirty laundry every week and cannot find anyone who wants to help wash it.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 31 (UPI)--Orlando Cepeda drove in two runs with his 24th homer and a sacrifice fly and scored another on a wild pitch tonight as the St. Louis Cardinals whipped the Houston Astros, 5-1.

JUAREZ, Mexico, Aug. 31 Officials of the three divorce courts here issued more than 1,000 divorces today to residents of New York State seeking Mexican decrees before New York's new divorce law goes into effect tomorrow.

ARLINGTON, Va., Aug. 31 (UPI) A county judge refused today to commit John C. Patler, accused of slaying George Lincoln Rockwell, to a mental institution despite a 10-yearold psychiatric report branding the suspect "a potential murderer."

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Aug. 31 D. W. Rajapatherane, governor of the Central Bank (Reserve Bank) of Ceylon, was removed from office today, apparently because of illness. He will be succeeded by William Tennekoon Seniro, deputy governor of the Central Bank.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Aug. 31 (AP) A dynamite blast early today wrecked the front of a building used as an office by Robert DePugh, leader of the ring-wing Minutemen, and as a headquarters by the Patriotic party, the Minutemen's political arm.

Retail buyers continued yesterday to take recent corporate issues from Wall Street hands. Prices staged their best advance in several weeks. The Federal Reserve System stepped into the Government Securities market with purchases of Treasury bills and of coupon issues maturing from November, 1968; and later.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) Barbee Miss, without a victory in 10 previous starts, closed strong today to win the $15,000 Prairie Belle purse before a crowd of 13,295 at Arlington Park.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 31 Jerry Silverman, the Riverdale man who discovered, recommended the purchase of and developed Romeo Hanover into one of the world's outstanding pacers, resigned today as trainer of the 4-year-old horse.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) The names of 14 men killed in action in the Vietnam war were made public by the Defense Department today. Among them was Sgt. Farrell R. Carew of Highland Lakes, N. J., an Army man.

MAPLEWOOD, N. J., Aug. 31 Marshall Crowley, a lawyer and former Essex County counsel, died yesterday at Presbyterian Hospital in Newark after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage in his office at 810 Broad Street, Newark. He was 59 years old and lived at 80 Claremont Avenue here.
A proposed new program of merchant marine development will probably be put into legislative form by the end of this month, sources close to the Federal planners said in Washington yesterday.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 31 Hank Jotz, a 29-yearold San Francisco sailmaker, successfully defended his Flying Junior Class national sailing championship today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31--Some 2,000 American radicals began organizing a campaign here today to defeat President Johnson in 1968 and ultimately forge a new political "third force" in the nation.
Mayor Lindsay accused the Public Service Commission yesterday of not exercising sufficient control over the utilities that serve the city.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31 The accent was on youth appeal today as the Chrysler Corporation unwrapped its 1968 Chrysler-Plymouth models at its preview here.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 31 The Rev. James E. Groppi and at least 150 of his civil rights followers were arrested here tonight for defying Mayor Henry Maier's "state of emergency" ban on protest marches.

A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Harold Sheehan of 4 East 89th Street on Monday in the New York Hospital. Mrs. Sheehan is the former Miss Yvonne Ouvrard of Nice, France. The child, whose father is a vice president of Barnard Relin Associates, has been named Odile.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) The Senate approved today a resolution authorizing the expenditure of $35,000 by its Labor and Education committee for a study of the education and related problems of Indian children.
New York State's new divorce law goes into effect today, discouraging the speedy Mexican divorce and prolonging for as much as two years the time it takes to end a marriage in the state.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 31 (AP) H. Rap Brown, chairman of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committe predicted today in an interview on the Havana radio that when trained Negro troops returned to the United States from Vietnam "they will use their skills to liberate the Negro people."

Mayor Lindsay, who has turned the campaign-style walking tour into a weekly occurrence, went strolling again last night. He turned up unannounced at the Mall in Central Park where a musical show was in progress and was greeted with cheers. Later, he was driven to the Bronx and went for a walk near 170th Street and Jerome Avenue where there were cheers and some scattered jeers.

TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 1 (AP) Premier Pham Van Dong of North Vietnam said today that a halt of United States air raids over his country was a prerequisite to peace talks and that the United States had no right to demand reciprocity.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Administration officials said today that the amount of Federal aid to the states for highway construction would probably remain level or at slightly less than $5-billion annually over the next five years.
In a day of quiet trading and little news, rumors can have a significant effect on some commodities in futures trading.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I. Aug. 31 Miss Leslie Susan Sarafan and Eric Lloyd Merahn were married here this evening in the Central Synagogue. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Bertram D. Sarafan and Mr. and Mrs. Harold R. Merahn. Rabbi George B. Lieberman performed the ceremony.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31--The Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today that it was investigating recent market activity in a "large number" of stocks to determine whether their prices had been manipulated.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., Aug. 31 The New York Giants are practicing Fran Tarkenton's scramble play and that is something new and different for pro football.
The public relations blunder of the week is the current Moscow trial of three young Soviet writers who dared organize a small public protest demonstration in that city last January.
GENEVA, Aug. 31 Sweden submitted to the disarmament conference today her version of an article on inspection for inclusion in the treaty to halt the proliferation of nuclear weapons.

Three suspects in a supermarket holdup, pursued by the police in a high-speed chase across Brooklyn, were seized in Rockaway yesterday when their car struck another auto. A fourth suspect escaped after the crash.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 96.2 on Wednesday from 96.4 on Tuesday.

SALT LAKE CITY The newest plant in Utah occupies only 20,000 square feet of leased space, employs just two-dozen persons and will have a yearly payroll of less than $250,000 scarcely an industrial plum by big city standards.
LONDON, Aug. 31 (UPI) New demonstrations flared today outside the British mission in Peking, reports reaching the Foreign Office said.

The Brick Presbyterian Church was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the wedding of Miss Ann Cornell Hess, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Hess of 170 West 73d Street, to John Kraus Urice. He is the son of Mrs. Michael Rogers of Wilmington, Del., and Silver Bay, N.Y., and Leonard H. Kraus of Beverly Hills, Calif.

TRENTON, Aug. 31 The Canadian police and officials of Montreal's Expo 67 reported to authorities here today that they had not seen Dr. James T. Dodge and his 65-foot converted shrimp boat at the fair's marina.

THE PRESIDENT Met with Senators Monroney and Harris, both Oklahoma Democrats, and Jayne Monroe, Miss America, who has just returned from entertaining troops in Vietnam; signed the veterans' benefits bill; met with Secretary of State Rusk and Defense Secretary McNamara.
SAIGON, Aug. 31 A Vietcong mortar atack today on the provincial capital of Phanthiet, 96 miles east of Saigon, left a child dead and 11 civilians wounded, a South Vietnamese military spokesman said.
Philip Johnson, the architect, told a conference on religion and architecture yesterday that the delegates apparently did not believe great architecture was necessary for modern religion.

MONTREAL, Aug. 31 (Canadian Press) Clifford Campbell of Beechwood, N.J., won the Mallory Cup today by placing better than Eddie Botterell of Montreal in the eighth and final race of the North American senior sailing championship.

MOUNT VERNON, Aug. 31 Hardy Bumpers, who represented South Side Negroes in recent negotiations over a job program, has been sentenced to 30 days in the Westchester County rail. The $60-a-week chemical worker pleaded guilty to a charge of disorderly conduct for refusing to obey a policeman's order Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Dr, Russell Shank, an associate professor in Columbia University's School of Library Service, has been appointed director of the Smithsonian Institution libraries. The 42-year-old resident of Hillsdale, N. J., will head the operations of the central library and 10 branches.
Sidney Harth helped to close the extensive Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts last night as soloist in the Concerto No. 4 for Volin and Orchestra (K. 218).

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Aug. 31 A man who holds degrees as an architectural engineer and as a lawyer has perhaps the ideal training for putting together the delicate structure of an agreement between ideologically antagonistic Arab states.

Miss Jill Ann Hoffman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Myron B. Hoffman of 21 East 87th Street, was married here yesterday evening in the Terrace Room of the Plaza to Allan E. Shore Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Shore of Scarsdale, N. Y. The Rev. Dr. Nathan A. Perilman of Temple Emanu-El performed the ceremony.

DEAL, N.J., Aug. 31 Stan Mosel of Essex Fells shot rounds of 68 and 69 for 137 today to lead the New Jersey qualifiers for the $150,000 Thunderbird, which will be held Sept. 21 through 24 at the Upper Montclair Country Club.

PHUCUONG, South Vietnam, Aug. 31--Whitney M. Young Jr. picked up a flimsy ballot box in a polling place in a hamlet outside this provincial capital 25 miles north of Saigon today. "Hey, it's got a real bottom in it," he said.
TOKYO, Aug. 31 With her booming economy heading for trouble, Japan has again taken the key deflationary step that has halted downward slides in the past.

KEEWATIN, Minn., Aug. 31 The iron ore pellet plant built by the National Steel Corporation at a cost of $74-million is approaching capacity operations of 2.4 million tons of iron ore pellets a year, George A. Stinson, president, said today.

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 31 (AP) Dr. Fager, a trim bay colt with a record of blazing speed but untried at 1 miles, heads a field of five 3-year-olds named today for the fourth running of the $250,000 added New Hampshire Sweepstakes Classic at Rockingham Park on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The United States Steel Corporation rejected a Government appeal today and raised prices on one line of steel products. The action followed by only a few hours a statement by Gardner Ackley, chairman of President Johnson's Council of Economic Advisers, that called

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) The Senate Commerce Committee reported today that it had found no need at present for laws to change the current election system because of a possible impact on voting by the use of computers by networks to forecast election results.
Mayor Lindsay's summer task force, charged last spring with keeping this summer a peaceful one in the city, will be retained on a year-round basis, the Mayor announced yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 31 (AP)--Chief Akpan Bassey of Biafra, the former Eastern Region that seceded from Nigeria in May, praised the United States and condemned Britain today for their attitudes toward the Nigerian-Biafran war.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) Capitol Hill's latest architectural curiosity is a gleaming white marble balustrade being constructed for $150,000 on the roof of the Cannon House Office Building.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art found itself yesterday with a funeral wreath for one of its statues.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31 The Chicago Cubs defeated the New York Mets, 2-1, today in an 11-inning battle of wits between Leo Durocher and Wes Westrum that was decided by a midget single behind third base.
Dr. H. Houston Merritt, dean of the College of Physicians and Surgeons here, was elected a director of the Chock Full o' Nuts Corporation yesterday at a special meeting of the board of directors.
ROUNDSTONE, Ireland, Aug. 31 (Reuters) Two Canadians in a wooden canoe set out today on their third attempt to cross the Atlantic the way they believe St. Brendan did 1,400 years ago.

SAYVILLE, L.I., Aug. 31 The competition for the Finn Class national championship continued today with two races and Fred H. Miller of the South Shore Sailing Club, Newport Beach, Calif., remained in the lead. The defending champion took today's first event and then finished 13th in the second, which was sailed in light air.

DETROIT, Aug. 31 Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, accused the General Motors Corporation today of conspiring to close down the auto industry in the event of a strike against one car manufacturer. Contracts between the union and General Motors, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation expire Wednesday night. Mr. Reuther promised to strike one of the three if no agreement was reached.
OBERLIN, Ohio, Aug. 31 (UPI) The Coast Guard recovered today the body of Michael Theim of Springfield, one of the 14 missing sky divers.
Several hundred family-size pies will be the order of the day when the village of The Springs, East Hampton, L.I., celebrates its annual Clam Pie Festival tomorrow.
percentage, the best achieved by any major league pitcher since 1900 with that many decisions. He also won 10 World Series games, a record.
ATLANTA, Aug. 31 (AP) Rico Carty drove in two runs tonight with a pinch-double in the bottom of the eighth inning, that gave the Atlanta Braves a 5-4 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

The two men whose policies toward Yemen really count President Nasser of Egypt and King Faisal of Saudi Arabia have reached agreement on ending the Yemeni conflict. Of the two other figures involved, President al-Salal of the republican faction in the civil war is protesting, while the nominal leader on the royalist side, Imam Mohamad al-Badr, is silent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The election year 1968 is beginning to look like 1948 in more ways than one. President Johnson almost surely faces a third party on the right, headed by George Wallace, and probably a fourth party on the left, possibly with Martin Luther King as its candidate.

WELCOME WAGON International, now in its 40th year of greeting newcomers in communities across the nation, has run into trouble in New York. It seems the newcomers don't make the hostesses feel very welcome.
MOBILE, Ala., Aug. 31 The New York Jets beat the Buffalo Bills in every way tonight except the only way that really counted.

LANSING, Mich., Aug. 31 (UPI) The Michigan National Guard withdrew today its request to hold a mock riot here for training purpose. It did so because there were warnings that it could cause a real riot.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
HAMPTON, England, Aug. 31 (AP) Dennis Washington paid $4,200 for gates operated by remote control, and at those prices he thinks they shouldn't be swinging open for 50 to 60 jet fighters a day.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 31 One of the leading figures in the presidential campaign offered voters tonight a primer in cheating at the ballot box.
LONDON, Aug. 31 Prime Minister Wilson ruled out again tonight the possibility that a Labor government would devalue the pound or impose import controls to spur Britain's economy.
TRENTON, Aug. 31 A state official said tonight that the Saturday deadline given to five South Jersey farmers to clean up their migrant labor camps or close them down would be extended nearly a week.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Aug. 31 A bitter clash pitting Paraguay, Ecuador and Bolivia against the rest of the nations of the Latin American Free Trade Association threatened tonight to block further progress toward the establishment of a Latin American common market.

VIETNAM. By Mary McCarthy, 106 pages. Harcourt, Brace World Paper, $1.95. LAST winter The New York Review of Books sent the esteemed American author and critic, Mary McCarthy, to South Vietnam to report on what she calls the American invasion and occupation of that country.

A two-year "market basket" survey conducted in 25 cities by the Food and Drug Administration has indicated that the daily intake of pesticide chemicals in a well-balanced American diet is "substantially below" acceptable "safe" limits.

"People think I'm swinging with money but I'm not," said Mrs. Maria Trapp, the former Baroness Maria von Trapp of Austria, whose life story became 'The Sound of Music," one of Broadway's longest-running musicals (3 years; $30 million worldwide gross), which was turned into the biggest money-maker in firm history ($180-million in 29 countries) and led to a best-selling album (8 million copies of the movie's sound track, list price, $6.79 each).

LONDON, Aug. 31 A leading British genealogist and expert in dynastic law has called for formal recognition of the Duchess of Windsor as the "consort of a royal prince," which would entitle her to be called "Her Royal Highness."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP)--The National Transportation Safety Board said today it had used "truth drugs" often--and hypnosis once--to restore the memory of persons involved in aircraft accidents.
Committee on Colonialism Adopted Four-Power resolution on Gibraltar.
ATLANTA, Sept. 1 (AP) Al Ferarra's fifth-inning home run, the third of the game for Los Angeles, snapped a 4-4 tie and sent the Dodgers to a 6-4 victory tonight over the Atlanta Braves.
LONDON, Sept. 1 Anthony M. Lund of London and 50 East 72d Street, New York, a partner in the banking concern of Kuhn, Loeb Co., married Mrs. Sophie Anstey here today at the Chelsea Registry Office.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 ; is easier to make people stop, smoking by threatening the pocketbooks than by stressing the threat to health, according, to a study by two Dartmouth College psychologists.

Efforts to resolve the school contract dispute were suspended last midnight by Mayor Lindsay's special mediation panel as prospects for averting a threatened mass resignation of teachers became bleaker than ever.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 1 Lear, Siegler, Inc., a diversified company with headquarters in Los Angeles, has purchased the assets of the Rochester Business Institute for an undisclosed amount of Lear, Siegler stock, it was announced today.
Peter Ottley, president of Local 144, Nursing Home Division, Building Service Employes Union, yesterday announced ratification of a new contract by nonmedical employes of about 90 nursing homes.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) Thurgood Marshall was sworn in today as a Justice of the Supreme Court and was presented with a Bible by Justice Hugo L. Black, who officiated at the ceremony.
BUCHAREST, Sept. 1 (AP) Two United States wrestlers lost opening bouts today in the 16th world Greco-Roman wrestling championships.
Wall Street's summer ended yesterday on an upward tick with the Dow-Jones industrial average remaining narrowly above the 900 level.
Leading market, indicators were mixed. The Dow fell 0.14 to 901.18, after being on the minus side all day. It was off as much as 1.21 points during the session.

Steamship lines and railroads are studying the possibility of a major shift in ship cargo routing in the container age the transcontinental transport by rail of container shipments for and from the Far East.

WESTPORT, Conn., Sept. 1 Noble Savage, who once had a tryout with the United States Equestrian Team, captured two classes today to take the lead for the large junior working hunter championship at the opening session of the Fairfield Farm's junior horse show.
WAYZATA, Minn., Sept. 1 Miss Barbara Ann Burgh and Frederick Pierson Liebert were married here this afternoon in St. Edward's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Jerry M. Wilcox.
A husband and wife received prison sentences, yesterday in Federal Court for conspiring to smuggle hashish into this country from Turkey.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 1 No matter who wins the presidential and senatorial elections Sunday, the seeds of tension and discord will have been sown in South Vietnam.

Seven of the 12 boys who escaped. from Youth House in the Bronx Wednesday were returned to Family Court yesterday by Linda Cusamano, the member, of the Mayor's summer youth council who had kept them hidden since early Thursday morning.
Silver markets were firm yesterday despite prospects that prices at the Government's, auction after the close of, trading were expected to continue the decline of the last four weeks.
