It has the qualities of good narrative history. Yet it provides the stimulus to the mind generated by the dialectical play of ideas.
Brownsville residents have nominated for principal of an experimental school a Negro educator charged with plotting the murder of two moderate civil rights leaders.
CHICAGO The computer, now firmly entrenched as an essential tool of corporate management, is starting to take hold down on the farm.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 An emotionally charged division between Negro and white delegates threatened today to destroy the effectiveness of the radical convention called by the National Conference on the New Politics.
The wholesale commodity price index fell 0.3, to 95.9 on Thursday from 96.2 on Wednesday.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 1 Foreign Minister Abba Eban today rejected the Yugoslav peace proposal for the Middle East as "one-sided and unauthorized." He also said that Israel "will not allow her rights or interests to be affected in any way by proposals or initiatives from Yugoslavia."

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 Clear in the cool September morn, the Mets awoke today realizing that this could be The Day the day they might be eliminated, for the sixth straight year, from the National League pennant race. Sure enough, it was.

PLEASANTVILLE, N Y., Sept. 1 Dr. Norman Henry Rose, medical superintendent of the Sydney (Australia) Hospital, died of a heart attack here Wednesday at the age of 54. He was visiting Dr. Milton P. Hunter of 329 Bedford Road.

The engagement of Miss Margaret Lillian Sealy to Thomas Carlton Newton has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Sealy of Brooklyn. Her fiance's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Newton of Delray Beach, Fla.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 1 (AP) A preliminary audit at Liberty National Life Insurance Company disclosed at least $980,000 was misappropriated during the last seven years, the company's president said today.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 1 Policemen fired repeatedly with tear gas guns tonight to disperse civil rights marchers who were throwing rocks and bottles at them.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 President Johnson said today that he regretted very much the decision of major steel companies to raise prices on steel bars but made clear that he was not planning to do anything about it.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 Two questions were left unresolved today when President Johnson denied that there was a "deep division" between him and the Joint Chiefs of Staff on the bombing of North Vietnam.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Sept 1 Mrs. Martha Whitwell Gravel, a former teacher and textbook editor, died yesterday in Valley Hospital. Her age was 69 and her home was at 160 Bellair Road. She was the wife of Eugene O. Gravel, a retired printer.
SALEM, N.H., Sept. 1 Considering the circumstances, it seemed cruel to cut off Barbs Delight from his daily ration of wine today.
COME Back When You Grow Up" groan Bobby Vee and the Strangers over jukeboxes and stereo speakers in college shops all over town.

YONKERS, Sept. 1 (AP) A family of nine that has been living in a motel for the last six months at the expense of the Westchester County Welfare Department moved into a nine-room house today.
MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Sept. 1 Miss Susan Jane Laskey and Eric C.P. van Ginkel were married here this afternoon at Redtops, the Laskey home.
New Yorkers have been splashing through their rainiest summer in 25 years, the Weather Bureau reported yesterday.
JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 1 (UPI) The trial of 18 white men in the slaying of three civil rights workers in 1964 near Philadelphia, Miss., was set today for Oct. 9 by Federal District Judge Harold Cox.
The management and 51 backers of the stage production of "The Sound of Music" will share an arbitration award of more than $1-million from sales of the recording of the film version soundtrack.
Two allergists in Washington have found evidence that an allergy to cockroaches may be a cause of asthma and other allergic reactions.
During this summer we have witnessed one of the most astonishing feats of arms of our century, the brief IsraeliArab war.

MARLBORO, N.H., Sept. 1 (UPI) F. Nelson Blount, a millionaire industrialist, was killed today when his single-engine plane smashed into a tree as he was trying to land in field. He was pronounced dead at the scene by Dr. Walter H. Lacey. He was alone in the plane, a Maule Rocket.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 1 The Stamford Yacht Club's Vineyard Haven race, since 1932 traditionally the Long Island Sound season's last venture into blue water, began for the 33d time this afternoon under near ideal sailing conditions with a starting fleet of 115.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Sept. 1 The New York Giants closed their summer training camp today at Fairfield University where rapid development was made during the last two weeks. The team moved down to Princeton, N. J., where the Philadelphia Eagles will be the opposition in Palmer Stadium tomorrow.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 1 Bernard Rubinstein, national vice president of the United Synagogue of America, died Wednesday. He was 76 years old and owned a lumber company here.

In a departure from the traditional Labor Day appeals for reconciliation between workers and management, three of the nation's leading Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish organizations issued separate messages yesterday citing race as the paramount issue facing America today.
THE word "preferred" is often a misnomer before the title of a stock issue because, in many instances, few people orally would prefer it to common shares.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) Senator Mike Mansfield of Montana, the Senate Democratic leader, has passed the word to President Johnson to order lobbyists for Government agencies to "keep their distance" from the Senate.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Sept. 1 The 17-year-old son of Suffolk County Health Commissioner Dr. George E. Leone was arrested last night on charges of selling narcotics to an undercover man who was working with the police.
Tender offers for some $15.1million of natural-gas pipeline common stocks were announced yesterday.

The Public Service Commission said yesterday that Senator Robert F. Kennedy's recent charge that a Consolidated Edison Company rate increase was "arbitrarily" imposed on the city was "totally out of place."

MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 1 The New York Jets may have lost the battle, but they think they can win the war.

The trustees of the New Haven Railroad filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday a plan that for the first time tells how proceeds from the sale of the bankrupt line's assets to a merged Pennsylvania-New York Central Railroad should be disbursed to creditors.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board approved today the merger of Frontier Airlines and Central Airlines.

DARLINGTON, S.C., Sept. 1 (AP) A field of cars and drivers that shapes up as the fastest ever for the Southern 500-mile stock car race on Monday neared completion today as eight more places in the 44-ear line-up were filled.
A maritime arbitrator yesterday denied increases in money benefits demanded by a radiomen's union from 61 steamship companies operating about 250 ships.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 1 Several members of the 22-man American observer team today praised South Vietnam's preparations for the national elections Sunday, but others were guarded in their comments.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 1 (AP) Woody Fryman pitched a threehitter and struck out 15 batters tonight in hurling the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 3-0 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) The Defense Department today identified 24 men killed in action in the Vietnam war. They included Pfc. John J. Pinder of Bellerose, Queens, of the Army, Construction Mechanic 1/C. Jack W. Wilkinson of East Islip, L.I., of the Navy, and a Marine Cpl. Frank C. Fisher of Patchogue, L.I.
New York City's hopes for a floating classroom went aground for the second time in six weeks yesterday.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 1 (AP) Minnesota capitalized on four Detroit errors to hand Jim Kaat a three-run lead in the early innings, as the big left-hander hurled the Twins to a 5-4 victory over the Tigers tonight.

A drive to reduce the number of Negro re-enlistments in the armed services has been started by the National Urban League. It said many Negro servicemen feel they "have no choice" between the certainties of military life and the belief that civilian life offers them no opportunities.

Physical affliction struck another headliner from the lists in the United States grass court singles championships yesterday for a toll perhaps the greatest at the outset of the tournament at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.

The Constitutional Convention's proposal that New York set up "a system of free higher education for all the people of the state, encompassing both public and non-public institutions," is a demagogic bid for political popularity, adopted in total disregard of sound educational principle.

YONKERS, Sept. 1 Factories of the Otis Elevator Company here and in Harrison, N.J., were shut down today by a strike of more than 2,000 members of the International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers.

Gamely, William Haggin Perry's home-bred star, will head the field in the Gazelle Handicap at Aqueduct today. The winner of four of her ten starts this year, Gamely will be the strong favorite in the 1 1/8-mile test for 3-year-old fillies.
TOKYO, Saturday, Sept. 2 (AP) The Vietcong, in a major bid for support on the eve of South Vietnam's election, announced today a broad political and economic program.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 1 (AP) A protest against the city's school desegregation plan developed into a sit-in at the Providence School Administration Building today.

City and Federal agents seized two men in Lindenhurst, L.I., yesterday in what was described as an attempt to extort $15,000 from a Manhattan factoring agent in exchange for company books stolen in a hoax.

CAPE MAY COURTHOUSE, N.J., Sept. 1 Raymond A. Neff resigned today as health coordinator of Cape May County in the wake of a controversy over his disclosures about a supposedly new mind-expanding drug found in the area.

LAFAYETTE, Ga., Sept. 1 (AP) M. Neil Andrews, who helped prosecute Nazis at the Nuremberg War Crimes trials in Germany, died at a hospital in Chattanooga yesterday after a long illness. He was 72 years old.
MIAMI, Sept. 1 (UPI) The first tropical storm of the season missed Bermuda today and moved toward the North Atlantic with 55-mile-an-hour winds.

MOSCOW, Sept. 1 (Reuters) Two American officials at the United States Embassy here were ordered out of the Soviet Union today, apparently in reprisal for the barring of two Soviet diplomats from the United States last week.
ADEN, Sept. 1 Being a British official in this sandblown little remnant of the British Empire is largely a thankless task.

Held an impromptu news conference; saw Lawson Knott Jr., General Services administrator; saw Senator Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin; saw Farris Bryant, director of the Office of Emergency Planning; met with Treasury Secretary Fowler.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 1 A South Jersey farmer told a state migrant labor hearing here today that his Millville farm had been virtually taken over for a time this summer by Negro migrant farm workers whom he described as a "gang of thieves, murderers, convicts and drunks."

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 1 In the Anabel Taylor Chapel of Cornell University this morning; Miss Jane Frances Rea was married to Paul Austin Crotty. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Clyde woodrow Rea of Troy and Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Crotty of Buffalo.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Sept. 1 (AP) Bob Dickson, the Oklahoma cowboy who is the British Amateur champion, roped and tied the Broadmoor West course today with a second 71 and held a three-stroke lead at the half-way point in the 1967 United Sates Amateur golf championship.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 1 The tempo of Vietcong terrorism and shellings quickened today as South Vietnam's presidential election neared.

William Westcott Black, a researcher who had specialized in food marketing and processing, died of a stroke here Thursday at the Veterans Administration Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 185 West End Avenue.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., Sept. 1 Joe Bennett, a vaudeville headliner early in the century whose specialty was eccentric dancing, died yesterday at the Our Lady of Consolation Residence here. He was 78 years old.

TRENTON, Sept. 1 Miss Marcia Tabram Philips and Russell Allen Eliason were married here this evening in Grace Baptist Church. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Alexander Philips of Trenton and Mr. and Mrs. Walter Joseph Eliason of Minneapolis.
CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Sept. 1 An experiment in ecumenism the thrust toward Christian unity is under way here at the level of future Roman Catholic priests and Protestant ministers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) President Johnson said today he planned to spend the Labor Day weekend in the Washington area and saw nothing unusual about it.

Some positive notes were struck at the fourth Arab summit conference in Khartoum despite the usual incandescent oratory and the final communique's rejection of negotiations with Israel. This may have been the most realistic discussion the Arab leaders have ever held; they may even have taken a modest first step toward peace in the Middle East.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 1 Gov. Ronald Reagan of California appeared today to have supplanted Barry Goldwater as the national hero of the Young Americans for Freedom, a conservative, 30,000-member organization that played an important role in the successful Goldwater nomination drive of 1964.

THE best country auction to be held in a long time will take place on Thursday, Friday and Saturday, at Candle Light Farm, Westbrook, Conn., when 2,000 objects, mainly 17th and 18th century Americana, in the collection of the late Katherine Prentis Murphy will be sold.
Arvid Anderson, a commissioner of the Wisconsin Employment Relations Commission, was named yesterday as the $35,000-a-year chairman of the city's new Board of Collective Bargaining.
ATHENS, Sept. 1 A ban on unauthorized gatherings of more than five persons was eased tonight to allow Greeks to hold parties, weddings and funerals without permission.
HONOLULU, Sept. 1 (AP) Beginning Sept. 11, The Honolulu Star-Bulletin will publish The New York Times Weekly. Review as a special four-page supplement every Monday.

Of all the complex and contradictory fates shaped by the Russian Revolution of 1917, none was more fantastic than that of Ilya Ehrenburg. The skeptical young intellectual gibing at Communist illusions, the middle-aged cynic prostituting his literary talents to Stalin's whim, and the elderly crusader frantically using every remaining minute to reunite his grandchildren's generation with their own almost forgotten cultural past, all these were chapters of this strange life.

BONN, Sept. 1 A Munich court rejected today a complaint by the extreme right-wing newspaper Deutsche National Zeitung und Soldaten-Zeitung against the confiscation of its July 19 issue, which carried a picture of Hitler alongside one of Defense Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel on its front page.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 President Johnson defended today his policy of controlled bombing of North Vietnam and denied the existence of any serious rift between his military aid civilian advisers.
Dr. Srul Pieczenik, senior clinical assistant in arthritis and rheumatism at Mount Sinai Hospital, died on Thursday in his home at 515 West End Avenue. His age was 55.
PARIS, Sept 1 (Reuters) Pabio Picasso had his telephone cut off today so that he could mourn in private the death of Ilya Ehrenburg.
The bond market staged another advance yesterday, extending a rally that began on Wednesday. From midweek on, interest rates were steadily driven down from what in some cases were record levels.

Michael T. Fitzmaurice, an actor who delivered many radio and television commercials, died Thursday of lymphoma in Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases. He was 59 years old and lived at 1160 Fifth Avenue.
The lumber index, a component of the New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activity, rose to 103.1 from 96.5. A year earlier it was 99.8.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 The Pentagon announced today the award of a $25,871,701 contract to Colt Industries for 242,716 more M-16 rifles.
Luggage-laden travelers swarmed yesterday into bus, plane and train terminals here to begin a last fling of summer pleasure on the Labor Day weekend that ends Monday night.

The scene looked wintry on Madison Avenue, between 57th and 58th Streets, yesterday. Flurries of what seemed to be snowflakes fell on the area from between the 25th and 30th floors of the General Motors Building, which is nearing completion on the site of the former Savoy Plaza Hotel.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 1 (AP) Stockholders of the Gannett Company, Inc., approved today recapitalization of the newspaper publishing and broadcasting company, one month after the plan won approval of the directors.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 1 The Special Committee on Colonialism declared today that a referendum on the political future of Gibraltar would be a violation of United Nations decisions and basic principles. Britain plans to conduct the referendum Sept. 10.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 The Government proposed today to extend airplane speed zones far beyond airports, where they now apply, in an attempt to reduce the chances of mid-air collisions.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 1 (AP) Lou Brock hit a homer and scored two runs and Nelson Briles scattered eight hits tonight in leading the St. Louis Cardinals to a 5-0 victory over the Houston Astros.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 (UPI) Another Nell, one of two supplementary entries in the field of 14, was the early favorite today for the $175,000 Lassie, to be run tomorrow at Arlington Park in the 6 -furlong ton Park. The 6 -furlong race is for 2-year-old fillies.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 1 Israel gave details on anti-Israel and anti-Jewish teachings in Arab textbooks to the United Nations today.

THE Greater New York Bridge Association's Knickerbocker Championships continue today at the New York Hilton. The qualifying session of the Open Pair event is scheduled at 1:30 P.M. and the final at 7:30 P.M., while the tournament will continue through Monday night.
The new Jacob and Ethel Sincoff Gallery of the Jewish Museum will be dedicated Oct. 15. The gallery was endowed by Mrs. Sincoff, whose husband died in 1965.
Two stabiles by Alexander Calder will be displayed on a Harlem street in October during a month-long, exhibition, and the sculptor said yesterday that he would like the community to keep the works.

"Thank you for making reading an enjoyable pastime once more. I have not been able to read ordinary print these last 10 years." This statement of a book borrower is considered by New York Public Library administrators both reason and reward for their year-old large-' print project.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 1. William W. Cox, who retired in 1954 as vice president of the Delaware Hudson Railroad Corporation, died on Wednesday in the Manhasset Medical Center Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 73 Summit Road.
SHORT HILLS, N.J., Sept. 1 Oscar A. Shann, a former engineer at Bell Telephone Laboratories, died yesterday in his home at 29 Elmwood Place. He was 81 years old.
Retail business here barreled along during August, giving the city's major department stores their second big monthly increase in a row and their largest gains since last January.
HARTFORD, Sept. 1 (AP) Gov. John N. Dempsey of Connecticut was designated today to head a National Governors Conference committee to explore racial disorders.
RYE, N.Y. Arthur and Kathryn Murray do most of their stepping these days on the vinyl floor of their his-and-hers kitchen here.

NASSAU, The Bahamas, Sept. 1 Louis A. Chesler, a Canadian gambler and investor, testified today at an inquiry by a royal commission that he was positive that the United States underworld had never had any connection with casino gambling in the Bahama Islands.

Mrs. Esther Alperstein Rothenberg, former financial secretary of the Beth Abraham Hospital, 612 Allerton Avenue, the Bronx, founded in 1920 by her mother, the late Mrs. Bertha Alperstein as the Beth Abraham Home for Incurables, died of a heart attack Wednesday at her home, 59 West 71st Street. Her age was' 75 and she was the widow of Sheftel Rothenberg.
The Dow Chemical Company, the nation's largest producer of chlorine, announced yesterday an immediate price increase of $2 a ton on tank car sales of liquid chlorine.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 1 (UPI) Delmar Heinelt of Memphis, 32 years old, was killed today when his supercharged 1967 Mustang went out of control at more than 169 miles an hour at the 13th annual national championship drag races.
OBERLIN, Ohio, Sept. 1 Four sky divers who took part last Sunday in the fatal skydiving flight near Lake Erie related their experiences today at an official inquiry.
DETROIT, Sept. 1 The United Automobile Workers picked the Ford Motor Company today to set a new contract pattern for the automobile industry.
The East 55th Street Conservative Synagogue announced yesterday the appointment of Rabbi Reuven Siegel, president of the New York chapter, Military Chaplains Association, as its rabbi.

LONDON, Sept. 1 New economic and political problems for the Labor Government cropped up today with the announcement by Britain's nationalized power industry of a 10.5 per cent increase in electricity prices on Oct. 1.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 1 (UPI) Bob Lee walked Dick Groat with the bases filled and one out in the 21st inning tonight to end a record-equaling scoreless deadlock and give the San Francisco Giants a 1-0 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

ALBANY, Sept. 1 The Constitutional Convention today approved a watered-down version of a proposition that was originally designed to limit the powers of existing public authorities and to slow the creation of new ones.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Sept. 1 The Foreign Ministers of 11 member nations of the Latin American Free Trade Association appeared today to have solved one of their most difficult problems how to deal fairly with the group's underdeveloped countries.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 Consumer installment credit rose $225-million in July, less than in June but more than in other recent months, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) Gen. Harold K. Johnson, Army Chief of Staff, will hold a conference at the Pentagon Tuesday with about 20 National Guard generals from throughout the nation to discuss the latest Reserve reorganization plan.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) President Johnson approved today the shipment of a million tons of American wheat to combat the threat of starvation in India.

LOS ANGELES (AP) The Los Angeles Rams, outplayed and trailing by 11 points at half-time, exploded for three touchdowns in the third period tonight and went on to defeat the Kansas City Chiefs, 44-24, before a capacity crowd of 73,990 in the Coliseum.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 1 (AP) Two of the three men convicted of stealing the Star of India sapphire in New York City three years ago have been arrested in Los Angeles for investigation of jewelry burglaries in this area.

DETROIT, Sept. 1 The auto replaced the horse long ago, but there's still a good deal of haggling over harnesses.

OCEANSIDE, L.I., Sept. 1 Mr. and Mrs. Donald Chapman Logan have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Leslie Chapman Logan, to Daniel Maynard Parks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maynard Eugene Parks of St. Louis. A December wedding is planned.
SADDLE BROOK, N. J., Sept. 1 (AP) A toll collector on the Garden State Parkway has filed a complaint with the police here charging that he was shot in the chest with a quarter.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 1 Gov. Lurleen B. Wallace raised a new doubt today over whether Tuskegee Institute, a private college for Negroes, would continue to receive financial support from the state.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara swore in Paul R. Ignatius today as Secretary of the Navy.
SKOVSHOVED, Denmark, Sept. 1 (AP) Paul Elvstroem of Denmark retained the Star Class world sailing championship today by placing fourth in the fifth and final race.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 1 President Gustave Diaz Ordaz cautioned the Mexican people today against excessively fast economic growth that might bring uncontrollable inflation.
BOSTON, Sept. 1 Patience is a virtue, except for a baseball manager whose pitcher is being strafed by line drives.

Dr. and Mrs. William Dunaway of 655 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gwendolyn Ford Dunaway, to Robert O. J. Streuber of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward Nielson Streuber of Erie, Pa. An October wedding is planned.
CHICAGO, Sept. 1 The Chrysler Corporation has begun a $1-million program to train qualified Negroes who are now in secondary jobs in the automotive business as new-car dealers.
The Hat Corporation of America announced here yesterday the election of Edward Mann as executive vice president for clothing and shirts. He was also elected a director.

Herman T. Stichman, the former State Commissioner of Housing who served as Governor Rockefeller's special investigator on corruption in public life, was found dead yesterday in his suite at the Croydon Hotel, 12 East 86th Street. He was 65 years old.
Mrs. Sibyl Emma Hubbard Darlington, widow of Herbert S. Darlington, a Philadelphia merchant, died Thursday in her home, 139 East 79th Street. She was 90 years old.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Sept. 1 Arab chiefs of state resolved today to seek a nonmilitary solution of their impasse with Israel.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 1 Sister Marie Theresa Charles of the Roman Catholic Order of St. Ursula, chairman of the theology department of the College of New Rochelle, died yesterday at the convent infirmary, after a brief illness. She was 64 years old.
The National Association of Broadcast Employes and Technicians last night angrily rejected what two television networks had called their final proposal to avoid a strike by the union.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 1 The two points at which Jordanian refugees have been returning to the Israeli-held west bank were closed yesterday, but the flow of Jordanians in the opposite direction was as heavy as ever today.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 1 A Negro police sergeant refused to accept an appointment as acting police captain here today. His appointment as a permanent police captain had been one of 39 demands made by Negro militants to city officials.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) President Johnson said today that the Administration was not considering Invoking the Taft-Hartley raw to stop a strike that has shut off most of the nation's copper production.

A 62-year-old dentist who delayed his weekend departure to give emergency help to a "patient" who had complained, "My tooth is killing me, doc," was rewarded with a pistol shot in the side and a blow on the head yesterday.
Four detectives who hid their identity under the hard hats of construction workers at the World Trade Center site moved in yesterday to pull the plug on a suspected telephone gambling operation.
TORONTO, Sept. 1 R. H. Sikes led the opening round of the $200,000 Carling world golf tournament today with a 68 as most of the 150 contestants were puzzled by the severely contoured greens.
If Fritz Peterson got the feeling that he was surrounded by assassins at Yankee Stadium last night, it would have been perfectly understandable.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 The Treasury bill rate fell back at today's auction from the high levels reached at the auction held on Monday, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

HONG KONG, Sept. 1 The Municipal Revolutionary Committee that rules Shanghai instructed army units there today to confiscate the arms of Maoist revolutionary organizations "from other parts of the country" that have not been authorized by the Communist party's Central Committee to carry guns.
WARSAW, Sept. 1 The scream of air raid sirens reminded Warsaw's citizens today that this was the 28th anniversary of Hitler's invasion of Poland and the beginning of World War II.
Becton, Dickinson Co. reached an agreement in principle yesterday to acquire Univis, Inc., through an exchange of shares valued at an estimated $35-million.

TOKYO, Sept. 1 (UPI) RaNae Bair prevented a United States shutout in the World University Games today when she accounted for her country's only gold medal of the day by winning the women's javelin competition with a throw of 173 feet 10 inches.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 Mike Mansfield, the Senate majority leader, said today that the campaign he had been leading in the Senate to get the United Nations Security Council to take up the issue of the Vietnam war had the full support and cooperation of President Johnson.
Prices on the London Stock market were firm yesterday, close to the new high levels for the year reached earlier in the week.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 1 Nigeria's leading playwright, Wole Soyinka, is being detained by security officials here, allegedly for questioning about a statement he published last month advocating a cease-fire in the eight-week-old civil war.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 1 George V. Doerr, who retired in 1954 as first vice president of McKesson Robbins, Inc., manufacturers of pharmaceuticals, died yesterday at the age of 83.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 1 Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Van Thieu, the chief of state and Premier Nguyen Cao Ky did not appear this evening at a final rally for South Vietnam's presidential ticket before Sunday's election.

MOSCOW, Sept. 1 Vladimir Bukovsky, a 25-year-old writer, was sentenced tonight to three years' imprisonment for having organized a demonstration in downtown Moscow protesting the arrest of the editors of a clandestine literary magazine.

Bartol of New York. The wedding . took place Wednesday in Juarez, Mexico.

BONN. Sept. 1 Neckermann-Versand, West Germany's most aggressive mail order company, has entered a new field: Today it began selling mutual funds by mail order or fat retail counters in its 47 branch stores throughout West Germany.

LONDON--The sun was shining in Britain last week as it is seldom supposed to shine. People were bronzed after their vacations and they never looked happier, better dressed, better fed or better off.

THE immigration forms previously required of United States citizens leaving and returning to this country have been discontinued for the remainder of the year. The decision was made by the Department of Justice.
BONNERS FERRY, Idaho, Sept. 2 (AP)--An army of men waged losing warfare in assaults today against forest fires throughout the Pacific Northwest. Weather forecasters predicted mostly more drought.

WESTPORT, Conn., Sept. 2-- The Irishman, who isn't from Ireland at all, waited until almost the end of the season before hitting his stride and won the amateur-owner hunter championship today at the Fairfield County Hunt Club junior horse show.

Mickey Mantle, who may or may not be being groomed for a new career behind a microphone, showed again last night why no one is in a hurry to have him abandon his old one too soon. He hit a pinch-hit home run in the eighth inning to give the New York Yankees and Mel Stottlemyre a 2-1 victory over the Washington Senators at Yankee Stadium.

PRAGUE, Aug. 31--New discoveries relating to the peculiar celestial objects known as quasars were disclosed during the 10-day assembly of the International Astronomical Union here. The talks underlined the fact that no other problem in science is so enormous in scope, yet so perplexing in detail.

MADISON, Wis.--A remote, primitively beautiful national park is in the making in Wisconsin's northland. The proposal, made by the Department of the Interior, drew overwhelming bipartisan support at the hearings.

TO THE EDITOR: AFTER a year of planning (and saving), we arrived in Paris waitting th be skinned alive by her natives, as our friends said we would. New Jersey's Commissioner of Transportation, David Goldberg, suggested yesterday that Philadelphia might share with his state in the development of a new jetport.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 3 Dennis Viollet, an assistant coach of the Baltimore Bays by way of the Manchester United Team of England, proved the hero in Baltimore's 1-0 triumph today over the Oakland Clippers in the opening contest of the National Professional Soccer League's championship playoff series at Memorial Stadium.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Sept. 3 (AP) Kathy Whitworth shot a par on the first hole of a sudden-death playoff with Carol Mann today and won the $10,000 first prize in the $32,000 Ladies' World Series of golf.

PANAMA CITY, Sept. 3 (Reuters)--President Marco A. Robles has ruled out an early signing of a new canal treaty between Panama and the United States and has said his Government will seek changes in the treaty language.
LONDON, Sept. 3 (Reuters) Robert Bradshaw, Prime Minister of the three-island Caribbean state of St. KittsNevis-Anguilla, called today for British military action against breakaway Anguilla.
BLOCKER, Okla., Sept. 3 (UPI) A midair collision of two small planes near here today killed four Missourians, including a county official.
Eyeglasses that darken outdoors and then return to a lightly-tinted state indoors or after sundown, are being widely accepted in overseas markets, according to Corning Glass Works.

The odd double standard that governs the approach of Big Labor and Big Industry to the bargaining table has never been more evident than in the pained reaction of Walter P. Reuther to the possibility that the automotive Big Three might undertake a collective defense this year against the "divide and conquer" tactics traditionally used by the United Auto Workers.
It was a lovely day for baseball yesterday at Yankee Stadium, but only the Washington Senators really enjoyed it, as they defeated the New York Yankees, 6-3.

Joe Garagiola is leaving the New York Yankee broadcasting team at the end of this season because of the pressure of other opportunities, but Jerry Coleman and Phil Rizzuto will continue to describe Yankee games on radio and television next year.
THE Open Team event concludes the Knickerbocker Championships at the New York Hilton today at 1 P.M. and 7 P.M.

Joe Garagiola is leaving the New York Yankee broadcasting team at the end of this season because of the pressure of other opportunities, but Jerry Coleman and Phil Rizzuto will continue to describe Yankee games on radio and television next year.
At one corner of the park yesterday, 14-year-old John Keller shot baskets and allowed that the other game was all right, but basketball was better.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 3 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Van Horne Upjohn of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sydney Van Horne Upjohn, to Dr. Gary Salenger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Salenger of Los Angeles.
MIAMI, Sept. 3 (UPI) The first hurricane of the 1967 season gained in size and speed but lost some of its punch today as it moved further out into the North Atlantic.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Sept. 3 Hartwell (Bucky) Moore, in a Star; Ted Kaiser, in a Flying Dutchman; Scott Perry, in a Lightning, and Skip Oliver, in an OK Dinghy, emerged as triple winners today at the annual three-race Labor Day series conducted by the Northport Yacht Club.

The voting in the South Vietnam election provides a politically viable basis for a peace settlement. One of the prerequisites for successful negotiations has been a Government in the South that has both constitutional legitimacy and demonstrable popular support. A long step in that direction has now been taken.
JAMES KNOX and his wife, Nancy, have been hooked on remodeling ever since they began tinkering with their apartment in a converted Air Force barracks 20 years ago.

An uninhabited jungle on the island of New Britain in the United Nations trust territory of Papua and New Guinea is destined for transformation into a 2,500-acre palm oil plantation within the next four years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 An inspector for the Office of Economic Opportunity has concluded that a sedition charge against Joseph Mulloy, a poverty worker in the mountains around Pikeville, Ky., is based entirely on local issues.
Taxpayers' revolts against rising school costs have cast a shadow over many suburban school systems as they prepare to reopen this week.
LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 3 State Fair time is the traditional period for the start of political campaigns in Nebraska.
A key committee of the New York Academy of Medicine is threatened with dissolution as a result of attempts to end its 25-year role as a pioneer in medical-social problems.

ATLANTA, Sept. 3 (UPI) Phil Niekro pitched a six-hitter and Hank Aaron and Mack Jones crashed home runs today as the Atlanta Braves routed the Los Angeles Dodgers, 7-1. It was Niekro's 11th triumph against seven losses.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 3 Any Navy football player unwilling to give his all for the cause this season may be dropped from the squad at the request of his team captain. No dogging will be tolerated on a team that is tired of losing, a trend Navy does not want to continue.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Sept. 4 Outside a polling station at suburban Bienhoa yesterday, an elderly Vietnamese woman grew tired of waiting in line to vote for six of the 48 tickets of 10 men each in the election for South Vietnam's Senate.
OAK HARBOR, Wash., Sept. 3 (AP) Exhaustion and exposure apparently killed seven mountain climbers during a storm on Mount McKinley in Alaska ldast Aug. 5.
The holiday traffic death toll edged upward yesterday, passing 330 last night, according to The Associated Press, but remained behind the rate that led to last Labor Day's record of 636 deaths.
The primary immediate imperative for this city's school system is to prevent the threatened mass "resignations" of teachers so that classes can begin on time.
James Dunn, the film actor whose expression of slightly battered wistfulness became his trademark, died yesterday in Santa Monica, Calif. His age was 61.

ALEXANDRIA BAY, N.Y., Sept. 3 (AP) A twin-engined seaplane collided with a motorboat while landing in the St. Lawrence River today, the state police said. One occupant of the boat was missing and presumed drowned.
The holiday traffic death toll edged upward yesterday, passing 330 last night, according to The Associated Press, but remained behind the rate that led to last Labor Day's record of 636 deaths.
The primary immediate imperative for this city's school system is to prevent the threatened mass "resignations" of teachers so that classes can begin on time.
James Dunn, the film actor whose expression of slightly battered wistfulness became his trademark, died yesterday in Santa Monica, Calif. His age was 61.

Mr. Ratliff denied last night in a telephone interview from Pikeville, Ky., that he was conducting a campaign "to run anybody out of Kentucky" and that his actions in the case against Mr. Mulloy were influenced either by political considerations or by the coal interests.

RICHMOND, Sept. 3 (AP) The score was Richmond 105, Savannah 0 in a UnitedAmerican Professional Football League game here last night. Incredible? Well, maybe, says Dick James, the winning coach especially for a team that prides itself mainly on its defense.
DETROIT, Sept. 4 Gov. George Romney believes he was subjected to "brainwashing" during a visit to Vietnam.
MIAMI, Sept. 4 (AP) Adam Clayton Powell's estranged wife, Yvette, has offered to let the Congressman see their son "any place in the United States," a lawyer for Mrs. Powell said today.
PARIS, Sept. 4 It was not the Eiffel Tower, the Louvre, Notre Dame Cathedral or the Arc de Triomphe that attracted the most visitors, French and foreign, in Paris this summer.
LONDON, Sept. 4 Britain is apparently prepared to begin talks at once to establish a new Government in the South Arabia Federation under the National Liberation Front.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 4 (AP) Doug Millward, the coach of the Baltimore Bays said today he had been dismissed and would not return next season even if the Bays win the National Professional Soccer League championship next Saturday.

TOKYO, Sept. 9 (AP) Madeline Manning of Tennessee State won the women's 800meter run today as the United States capped a successful campaign with a top score of 32 gold medals in the fifth World University Games.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 The United States today acclaimed the South Vietnamese election as a "major step forward."

AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 4 (AP) Mexican-American marchers seeking a state minimum wage law charged a "sellout" by some of their own leaders today as they staged a Labor Day rally at the Capitol for the second straight year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 In mid-August the airfield at Ka- no, in northern Nigeria, was suddenly closed to commercial flights by the Nigerian federal authorities. The reason became clear during the next several days when 15 Soviet Antonov12 transports landed there and ground crews unloaded crates from the four-engine cargo planes.
The London stock market advanced in light trading yesterday.

The Chicago White Sox, pursuing the American League pennant in their own quaint fashion, forced one game upon the harm less New York Yankees yester- day, but found their offer of the second disdained by their hosts at Yankee Stadium. Eventually, the White Sox won the finale, 3-2, in 10 innings, after losing the first by the same score in 8 .
DETROIT, Sept. 4 (AP) Dick Green's second three-run homer of the day gave the Kansas City Athletics a 4-2 victory over the fourth-place Detroit Tigers and a split in their double-header today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (UPI) The National Conference on New Politics adopted a resolution today demanding abolition of the draft, the Reserve Officers Training Corps and military recruiting at high schools.

The Board of Education has made known that it is prepared to risk a mass resignation by teachers next Monday rather than drop its attempt to obtain greater freedom over teacher assignments and the use of teacher time.

As a document that pulls together and simplifies many aspects of criminal justice, the new New York State penal law is a welcome codification of rules and laws that have seen no general revision since 1881. As a document that shows imagination in the area of social crimes, however, the new law is conservative and undistinguished.
ATLANTA, Sept. 4 (UPI) Gov. Lester G. Maddox today named to a judgeship the lawyer who represented him in his bitter legal fight with the Federal Government over the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

TO PEOPLE who are with it, Joyce Oates's new novel will appear highly unfashionable. It is told in strict chronological order, the environment is solid and recognizable, each of the three parts of the novel has its own protagonist and therefore a distinct point of view. The novel is neither outrageously funny nor brutal nor shocking.

Temple Rodeph Sholom here was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Miss Karen Jane Freeman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur R. Freeman of New York and Atlantic Beach, L.I., to John Andrew Lowe. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Lowe, also of New York and Atlantic Beach.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Sept. 4 Miss Cynthia Gay Baker and Robert Lewis Stone were married here this afternoon in St. Paul's Episcopal Church. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Horace Edward Baker and Mrs. Leon Lewis Stone of Hudson, Mass., and the late Mr. Stone. The Rev. John C.W. Linsley performed the ceremony.
ROME, Sept. 4 Pope Paul VI has canceled audiences at least through Wednesday and a trip to a sanctuary scheduled for Friday because of illness, the Vatican reported tonight.

Negotiations between a broadcast technicians' union and two television networks were recessed last night with the negotiations deadlocked. The union declared it would notify its locals at noon today to initiate strike action.
In their six-week trial, the city's new air-conditioned subway cars have proved a blessing for hay fever sufferers and a joy for transit buffs.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 4 (UPI) Fred Whitfield's disputed run-scoring infield single in the 10th inning tonight gave the Cleveland Indians a 2-1 victory over the league-leading Minnesota Twins and a split in their double-header.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 4 Deputy Premiers of the Soviet Union and other East European nations met here today to discuss economic assistance to the Arab countries that suffered losses in the recent fighting with Israel.

LONDON, Sept. 4 Anglican and Roman Catholic Theologians discussed the common use of their churches and the need for a common text in prayers during four days of talks at Taplow, near London that ended yesterday.

TEL AVIV, Sept. 4 Egyptian and Israeli forces exchanged fire across the Suez Canal for eight hours today and an Egyptian torpedo boat was sunk by Israeli guns in the Gulf of Suez, according to a statement issued here.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Sept. 4 (UPI) The wife of a Florida businessman and Republican party leader was charged today with aggravated assault in the shooting of her husband, William T. Wakeman.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 In this last stronghold of competing morning and afternoon newspapers, four metropolitan dailies are waging a desperate fight to recapture the 330,000 readers they have lost in the last ten years.

The agreement on monetary reform worked out by the ten major industrial nations is an important step forward in international financial cooperation, but its very substantial merits hardly justify the Johnson Administration's excessive praise.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 Organized labor's political arm has begun an effort to follow the migration of blue collar workers from the cities to the suburbs.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 4 Mrs. Lyda Womelsdorf Barclay, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Lefevre B. Womelsdorf of Cartersville, Ga., was married here this afternoon in her home to Randolph F. Hall, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Glenn Hall of Chicago and Rye, N.Y.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 4 In the Unitarian Church of Princeton today, Miss Linda Jean Meyers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Macknet Meyers, was married to Robert Eric Crootof. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Crootof of Manhasset Hills, L.I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Howard Middleton.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Tuesday Sept. 5 Fifty-four United States marines were killed and 84 wounded in a 15hour coastal battle in which they killed 143 North Vietnamese regulars and captured 25, a United States Military spokesman said here today.

BALDWIN, L.I., Sept. 4 Charges by the Board of Education that a high school teacher had molested a 16-year-old girl student has caused concern, uncertainty and bewilderment among the residents of this normally placid South Shore community.

Angry Negroes hurled bottles and stones at the police last night after a detective shot and killed a 14-year-old boy who had allegedly participated in the mugging of an elderly man on a Brooklyn street.

DETROIT, Sept. 4 (UPI) A union representing Detroit's 11,000 public school teachers rejected a mediator's plea for binding arbitration today and prepared for a strike that would postpone Wednesday's scheduled opening of school for 300,000 children.
MACY's likes the Mediterranean this year, and when the 34th Street giant likes something, it goes all out.

TOKYO, Sept. 4 (UPI) Chief Justice Earl Warren predicted today that more restrictions would be placed on public officials in the United States to protect the rights of persons accused of crimes and curtail sensational coverage of trials.

LONDON, Sept. 4 The Bank of England has been ex- ploring with foreign and merchant banks a new approach to limiting their lending in time of economic boom. Something like American-style reserve requirements may be the result.
LONDON, Sept, 1 The head of Britain's biggest labor organization said today that "the trade union movement is not prepared to accept the discipline of unemployment."
Their tails going like windshield wipers, 46 dachshunds were special guests at the Riverside Plaza Hotel yesterday afternoon.
The Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., announced yesterday the appointment of Raymond J. Klemmer as vice president for planning.
Benjamin Britten and his contributions to the Aldeburgh Festival in England will be the subject of a "Bell Telephone Hour" on Nov. 3 at 10 P.M. over the National Broadcasting Company network.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Sept. 4 Mrs. Charles S. Rodgers has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Virginia Anne Rodgers, to John Wayne Silbersack, son of Mrs. Mowry E. Goetz of Darien, Conn., and the late Walter F. Silbersack, former president of the American Home Products Corporation.

DEL MAR, Calif., Sept. 4 (UPI) Native Diver, racing in top form at the age of 8, breezed to victory by 3 lengths today as he equaled the Del Mar track record for 1 1/8 miles in winning the $43,150 Del Mar Handicap.

PARIS, Sept. 4 Lord Chalfont, chief spokesman for Britain's effort to get into the Common Market, said here today that his country's entry would give France "easier access to a market of 52-million consumers."
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 4 The formation of P.P.G. IndustriesEurope, with headquarters in Brussels, was announced today. It will be a subsidiary of P.P.G. Industries.

Mr. and Mrs. William Ward Foshay of 720 Park Avenue and Fishers Island, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Briggs Foshay, to Anthony Drexel Duke Jr. He is the son of Mrs. Marshall J. Dodge of New Haven and Fishers Island and of Mr. Duke of New York and East Hampton, L.I.
The question of whether a 326-foot submarine rammed a 30-foot racing sloop and left without offering assistance was directed yesterday to a Naval board of investigation.
The Budd Company announced yesterday the appointment of Aaron J. Gellman, a transportation planner and economist, to the new post of vice president for planning.

THORPE BAY, England, Sept. 4 (UPI) Lady Helsman of Britain won the third race in the International Catamaran Trophy Series the little America's Cup at Thorpe Bay today and now leads, 3-0, in the four-of seven series.
THE mother who wants to move her family from a city apartment to a house in the country may well be thinking of green grass, fresh air and the good of the children.
John Diebold, one of the world's leading evangelists of the computer and its potential, announced today the formation of his first operating company in the data-processing field.

The appointment of Arthur A. Chase to the newly created position of general-freight sales manager of American President Lines, was announced over the weekend by Raymond W. Ickes, president of the San Francisco-based company.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Sept. 4 At the meeting of the Western Hemisphere's chiefs of state last April, President Johnson called for urgency in the establishment of a Latin-American common market. The other presidents echoed him.

Lawyers for Cameo-Parkway Records, Inc., and for Allen Klein and Abbey Butler, investors, have filed a motion in Federal district Court, Southern District of New York, to dismiss a civil suit alleging conspiracy brought against them and nine others by Lucarelli Enterprises, Inc., and Emanuel Lester.
The Board of Estimate has been confronted with the problem of deciding whether new structures in the Brooklyn Heights Historic District must be limited to heights of 50 feet.

William F. Buckley Jr. said yesterday that he had written leaders of a draft-Buckley citizens committee and the Conservative party that "for personal reasons it is not possible for me to run" against Senator Jacob K. Javits in 1968.

DARLINGTON, S.C., Sept. 4 Richard Petty for President. The bumper stickers are proliferating in the Carolinas for the 30-year-old stock-car driving star from Randleman, N.C. And no wonder, for Petty won the prestigious Southern 500 today the one important title that had eluded him.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 It is of "great importance" that industrial countries such as the United States and West Germany that have been stagnating this year "achieve an early resumption of economic growth," the International Monetary Fund said today.

ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept. 4 (AP)?Bob Rodgers's bases-loaded sacrifice fly in the 12th inning scored two runs tonight when Rick Reichardt raced home from second as Brooks Robinson let the throw from the oufield get past him at third base, giving the California Angels a 5-4 victory over the Baltimore Orioles for a split of their double-header.

The Consolidated Edison Company yesterday rejected criticism by conservationists who have contended that the utility's proposed hydroelectric plant on Storm King Mountain would destroy the area's natural beauty.
Reuters, the leading British foreign news agency, plans a major expansion of its coverage of the United States and in its service to American newspapers and broadcasters.

LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 4 (AP) Bill Wiles of Kansas City recorded the second fastest straightaway speed in pleasureboat racing today as the threeday international championships ended at Capitol Beach Lake.

The Bowery Savings Bank announced yesterday that James A. Drayton has been appointed an assistant treasurer in charge of the bank's economics and statistics department. His responsibilities will include basic economic and statistical research in banking.

AT a time when legislators, state fish and game offi cials, police authorities and other groups are directing their fire at the pros and cons of gun laws, along comes a fascinating history of firearms by Harold L. Peterson, which is sure to create more interest in the metamorphosis of the gun.
HOUSTON, Sept. 4 (AP) Jim Hart drove in two runs and Mike McCormick recorded his 19th pitching victory as the San Francisco Giants topped the Houston Astros today, 4-3.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 4 Harry Bridges has accused the Volkswagen Company, in effect, of trying to wreck the union - employer agreement covering automation of the West Coast waterfront.

William Bowrey hit six of the most gorgeous backhands imaginable in a single game, and Nicola Pilic must have known he had met his master before the end of the third set of their match in the United States tennis championships at Forest Hills, Queens.
DETROIT, Sept. 4 (AP) Most of the 43 deaths during the Detroit riot could have been prevented, The Detroit Free Press has concluded.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 4 County Judge Christ Seraphim sat with his golden retriever, Holly, on the porch of his Spanish-style house on a pleasant East Side street this afternoon and made some acerbic comments on 1,000 civil rights demonstrators who jived and strutted past his front lawn.
Negro social workers have formed their own association to combat the discrimination they charge exists in "a subtle yet significant fashion" throughout the New York social work community.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 The Securities and Exchange Com- mission has attacked, as based on "false assumptions," a study of the costs of owning mutual fund shares that was prepared by Arthur D. Little, Inc., management consulting firm.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 4 Nineteen-year-old Gary Nolan, with an eighth-inning assist from Ted Abernathy, beat the New York Mets for the fourth straight time in pitching the Cincinnati Reds to a 2-1 victory tonight.
STOCKHOLM, Sept. 4 Fewer than the normal number of automobile traffic accidents on the right-hand side of the road occurred today on the second day of driving in Sweden.
Honeywell, Inc., has appointed David C. Gerrish as Washington vice president, with corporate-wide responsibilities, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) The Voice of America has completed a survey of its global audience and concluded that about 43 million listeners tune in on its overseas broadcasts each week.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 About 100 college students will receive $600 each during the coming school year under a union-financed scholarship program without consideration of the applicant's grades or class work.

NEWQUAY, England, Sept. 1 The Labor Government's economic squeeze, not oil from the wrecked tanker Torrey Canyon, is blamed along the winding coast of Cornwall for a slowdown this summer in the tourist trade.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 4 (AP) Road At Sea, the 9-2 favorite in the $29,925 Ventnor, Handicap, took the one-mile grass test today by three- quarters of a length over the fast-closing Out The Window.
LIME ROCK, Conn., Sept. 4 George Alderman of Newark, Del., captured the feature event at the sports car races today at Lime Rock Park.

THE sign was freshly painted although it seemed badly outdated. It read: "Welcome Robin Roberts and the Phillies" and a tourist blinked unbelievingly on seeing it a couple of months ago in an unlikely place: Waterbury, Conn. It produced a slow double-take, but eventually the greeting made sense. Although this was the same Robin Roberts, the Phillies were the Philadelphia farm club at Reading in the Eastern League.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 4 Yesterday's national election in South Vietnam was "reasonably efficient, reasonably free and reasonably honest," Prof. Richard M. Scammon
RUIDOSO DOWNS, N.M. (AP) Laico Bird won the $486,593 All American Quarter Horse Futurity at Ruidoso Downs today, sprinting away from challengers in the last 120 yards of the 400-yard race.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 4 Gov. Tom McCall has been dealt a major setback by a group of conservationists organized by the man he defeated for the governorship last year, State Treasurer Robert Straub, a Democrat.

If former Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama runs in the 1968 Presidential election, a poll indicates that he will take away votes from the Republican nominee and insure a victory for President Johnson.
BONN, Sept. 4 The Ambassadors of Britain, France and the United States delivered an unusually sharp rebuff today to a Soviet charge that a piece of pending West German legislation was illegal.

NASSAU, The Bahamas, Sept. 4 (AP) The chairman of the ruling Progressive Liberal party accused the British colonial authorities today of tapping telephones, opening mail and otherwise spying on members of the Bahamian Government.

TORONTO, Sept. 4 Billy Casper won the Carling world golf tournament today at the first hole of a sudden-death playoff. After he rallied with a 69 to tie Al Geiberger with a 72-hole aggregate of 281, Casper beat his fellow professional from California by one stroke on a par 4 to a bogey 5.
WILDWOOD, N.J., Sept. 4 A four-man band was arrested here early this morning on charges of providing afterhours accompaniment to a large crowd dancing on the main street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 The Boston Red Sox, still struggling to regain the power hitting that made them pennant contenders, divided a double-header with the Washington Senators today before 32,- 355 persons.

CALCUTTA, India, Sept. 4 Urban intellectuals who have broken with the left Communist party here are excitedly talking up the idea of agrarian revolution.
Joseph Gabriel Taracido, a lawyer and insurance executive, died Saturday at his home at 2 Mitchel Place. His age was 38.

TOKYO, Sept. 4 Officials here hope that Premier Eisaku Sato, when he visits South Vietnam for the first time next month, will be met by a counterpart in the new Saigon Government, who is a civilian and not a military man.
ATHENS, Sept. 4 The Government put on display today the composer Mikis Theodorakis to counter rumors that the former left-wing deputy was tortured or beaten to death after his arrest two weeks ago.

A group of American authorities on international law and world politics called yesterday for a United Nations study of the potential threat to individual freedom posed by computers, wiretap and eavesdropping devices and genetic controls.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 4 Eugenio Schettini, a retired colonel, resigned as Mayor of Buenos Aires tonight. His tenure in office had been threatened since an argument with President Juan Carlos Ongania's brother-in-law more than nine months ago.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) The funeral of Mrs. J. Borden (Daisy) Harriman will take place tomorrow at the National Cathedral. Vice President Humphrey will lead the mourners.

MOSCOW, Sept. 4 The Soviet Union's IL-62 jet airliner, undergoing tests for service on routes to Montreal and New York, was declared here today, to have the ability to fly safely through the most violent turbulence.

TEANECK, N.J., Sept. 4 Temple Beth Sholom here was the setting this evening for the wedding of Miss Susan Binder to Pfc. Rabbi Barry Schaffer performed the ceremony.
City Licenses Commissioners Joel J. Tyler urged parking-lot and garage operators yesterday to lower the rates for motorcycles and scooters.

TORONTO, Sept. 4 (Canadian Press) England won the Canada-England-France junior track and field meet today with a 3-point margin over Canada. The English team scored 164 points during the 23-event competition. Canada had 161 points and France 154.
ATHENS, Sept. 4 When a group of fervently anti Communist army officers seized power in Greece on April 21, few known Communists evaded their net.
MOSCOW, Sept. 4 (AP) Thousands of solemn Russians attended the funeral today of Ilya G. Ehrenburg, considered one of the Soviet Union's greatest writers.

Alexander Calder, Leonard Baskin, Edward Steichen, Ben Shahn and Dwight Macdonald are among 14 United States artists, writers and photographers who have agreed to judge a "No More War!" international poster contest, sponsored by Avant-Garde magazine. The publication is edited by Ralph Ginzburg.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 4 (AP) A lawyer for the Federal Power Commission predicted today that natural gas pipeline companies would ask for rate increases in the near future.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 4 Arab teachers throughout the northern part of the west-bank area of Jordan refused today to teach in the public schools.
Harrison A. Hartman Jr. has been appointed general manager of the Summit Hotel.

Sonia Molday, a violinist and authority on recorded music, died Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital of injuries suffered on Aug. 20 when struck by an automobile near her home. She was 62 years old and lived at 152 East 84th Street.

SAIGON, Sept. 4 American and South Vietnamese troops, which had spent most of the week trying to prevent Vietcong terrorism and to protect voters, returned to patrols seeking the enemy today.
Labor Day weekend came and went without rain, the first weekend to do so since June 10 and 11. The fact was noted with glee around the city.
WATER MILL, L.I., Sept. 4 (AP) An employe was injured in an explosion and fire today at a fuel oil company in this eastern Suffolk community.

DU QUOIN, Ill., Sept. 4 (AP) A.J. Foyt of Houston scored the 35th national championship victory of his career today, winning the United States Auto Club's 100-mile Ted Horn Memorial national championship race at the Du Quoin State Fair.

When the first play of the new theater season opens in three weeks, it will follow a juggling act as intricate as any that ever wowed them at the Palace.

ATLANTA, Sept 4 (UPI) Clete Boyer and Woody Woodward singled in two runs each to highlight a six-run first inning tonight that sent Atlanta on to an 8-1 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies after the Braves had won a day game, 8-2.

In a move unusual for the apparel industry, one of its leading companies, Koret of California, Inc., plans to enter the field of home furnishings, with a coordinated line of furniture, carpets, and draperies.

WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 4 Loyalties in Hollywood and its dormitory, Beverly Hills, are ever-shifting, and this week the "in" crowd found a new place to play: "The Factory," a private discotheque in a cavernous two-story structure where sheet metal was once produced.
ST. IGNACE, Mich., Sept. 4 (AP) Gov. George Romney, who is trying to be a frontrunner, proved today that he was also a fast walker.

A survey of selected retail districts in Manhattan and the Bronx shows that current store vacancies are lower than last year, averaging 2.3 per cent of the available properties. A year ago a similar survey found the vacancy rate to be 3 per cent.
TRENTON, Fla., Sept 4 (UPI) The body of Cecil Davis was recovered today from a sinkhole he fell into 16 days ago while looking for stray ponies.
SEATTLE, Sept. 4(AP) Thousands of firefighters battled smoke and flames in Northwest forests yesterday, including a pair of rugged fires in northern Idaho timberland.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 4 (UPI) Bill Mazeroski drove in three runs in the second game after Manny Mota and Maury Wills had driven in three runs apiece in the opener today as the Pittsburgh Pirates won two games from the league-leading St. Louis Cardinals, 10-8 and 9-3.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 4 (AP) Pittsburgh's three-time championship team moved into the title game of the 15th National American Softball Association's men's open slow-pitch tournament by beating Long Island, 6-5, today.
LONDON, Sept. 4 (UPI) Two aviation students confessed tonight that they had built a flotilla of whirring, bleeping "flying saucers."
Edward Albee, Richard Barr and Clinton Wilder, stage producing partners, have formed a nonprofit Broadway repertory theater and plan to begin a six-week season Dec. 25 at the Billy Rose Theater.

CHERRY HILL, N.J., Sept. 4 Miss Arlene Bonnie Singer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Singer of Philadelphia, was married today at the Cherry Hill Inn to Dr. Lenard E. Jacobson. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis S. Jacobson of Woodbridge, N.J. and New York.
The fifth New York Film Festival, to run from Sept. 20 to 30, will pay tribute to Abel Gance, the French film director, with the showing of nine of his works.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 4 Michael E. Gluhareff, who helped Igor I. Sikorsky develop the helicopter, died today in Bridgeport Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at Hoyden Hill Road in Fairfield.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UPI) Factory layoffs increased in July, and hiring declined, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
Medicaid and Medicare fail to provide incentives for efficient health care, or penalties against waste, the city's first deputy health services administrator said yesterday.

"The creative wind toward reform and progress that has swept the country and the Government in Greece since the April revolution..." So begins a Greek Embassy press handout about the National Tourist Organization. The truth in Greece, four months after the seizure of power by a clique of Army officers, is somewhat different.

Time at summer camp is often squandered in beating out uselessly shallow copper ashtrays for Father or being treated for poison ivy at the infirmary. The 17 boys and girls who performed at Judson Memorial Church last night in "Dances From Indian Hill," however, obviously spent their time more profitably.

CAIRO, Sept. 4 Former Vice President Abdel Hakim Amer, who was dismissed as deputy supreme commander of the United Arab Republic's armed forces after the defeat by Israel in June, may be courtmartialed for "attempting to stage a military comeback."
CHESTER, N.J., Sept. 4 John Y.G. Walker rode Bankers Trust to the open working hunter championship today at the Chester Rotary Horse Show.
MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Sept. 4 The discovery of an important chemical relic of life from more than 3 billion years ago indicates that the basic chemicals of life then were similar to those of today.

Orient Overseas Line, one of the companies in the C.Y. Tung group of shipping concerns, is about to become the only steamship line to offer passenger service between the Far East and the Atlantic and Gulf coasts of the United States.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 4 -- Defeated civilian candidates in South Vietnam's presidential elections today assailed the victory of Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Van Thieu, the armed forces nominee.

Damascus had no trouble in the $106,800 Aqueduct Stakes yesterday. Mrs. Edith Bancroft's splendid 3-year-old colt thrilled an exuberant crowd of 67,878 fans by taking the 1 1/8-mile event by two lengths over George D. Widener's Ring Twice, with Mrs. Ethel Jacobs's Straight Deal next in the field of five.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Sept. 5 Three 10man tickets were running strongly today in early returns from South Vietnam's Senate election Sunday.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 4 Miss Susan Maxine Reicher and Ronald William Filante were married here this afternoon at the Tappan Hill Inn. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Leon Reicher of Jamaica, Queens, and Mr. and Mrs. William Filante of Jackson Heights Queens.
PARIS, Sept. 4 Gerard Bauer, a member of the jury of the Prix Goncourt, died today of a cerebral hemorrhage at his home on the Left Bank. He would have been 79 years old on Oct. 8.
WOODVILLE, Miss., Sept. 4 (AP) Highway patrolmen broke up a Negro march that was seeking the ouster of Negro school teachers today.
CLINTON, B.C., Sept. 4 (UPI) About 50 motorcyclists invaded this town of 500 late yesterday. A 40-man mounted police contingent had to be called in to get the cyclists out of the area.

METUCHEN, N.J., Sept. 4 The greyhound, an ancient breed that was a favorite of royalty in Egypt, proved to be the favorite in the judging today as Shalfleet Starlight of Foxden was named best in a field of 746 dogs at the New Brunswick Kennel Club show in Roosevelt Park.

The weather was soft and balmy last night but the music was not on the Central Park Mall, where the Naumburg Symphony Orchestra offered a concert version of Bizet's "Les Pecheurs de Perles."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 After twenty-seven years of retirement from the silver screen, Ducky Lucky grew bored with sitting by his swimming pool and appearing at testimonial dinners at the farmyard Chinese Theater to be hailed as "a living monument," and so he decided to become President.

Louis Hinrichs, financial writer here for The Times of London since 1916, died Sunday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived at 19 West 12th Street.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (AP) Wes Parker's two-run double was the key blow today in a five-run uprising in the ninth inning that gave the Los Angeles Dodgers an 8-6 triumph over the Cubs, after Chicago had taken the opener of a double-header, 2-1, on Ernie Banks's 11th-inning homer.
NASHVILLE, Sept. 4 (UPI) The "jailhouse lawyer" at the Tennessee Penitentiary is out of business.
KINSHASA, the Congo, Sept. 4 (AP) President Joseph D. Mobutu of the Congo called today for more effective measures, including the use of force, to bring down Rhodesia's whiteminority regime.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) Senator Strom Thurmond said today that some people believed that work "is an oldfashioned idea," doomed to extinction by the growth of computer technology and laboreliminating devices.
CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (UPI) Fusilier Boy, a 22-1 shot, moved out of the field of 15 at the head of the stretch today to win the $118,100 Benjamin F. Lindheimer Handicap by 4 lengths.

A SLAPSTICK version of "The Emperor's New Clothes" was offered with indifferent results by the Prince Street Players in last night's taped version of their stage production over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.

As soon as more manpower is available, around-the-clock Criminal Court arraignments will be reinstituted in the city, Presiding Justice Bernard Botein of the Appellate Division's First Department said yesterday.
A practical form of aid for developing countries showing how to get more for a dollar is being successfully applied by an unusual organization here, the Afro-American Purchasing Center.

A Civil Court judge has ruled that Samuel Weinberg, a Brooklyn resident, cannot change the surname of his two sons from Weinberg to Lansing. The name of the judge: Jacob Weinberg.

WINNIPEG, Man., Sept. 4 (AP) A record-shattering performance by Ray Rogers, the world champion from Muskogee, Okla., helped the United States clinch the Ambassadors' Cup team trophy yesterday in the North American archery championships.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 4 The Vietcong today denounced the victory of Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Van Thieu in the South Vietnamese presidential election and said it meant an intensification of the war.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 4 J. William Atherton, a New York advertising executive, died Saturday in New Rochelle Hospital of a heart attack.

George MacCall of Los Angeles, the Davis Cup captain for three years, is to be the new executive director for the professional tennis players, according to a report circulated yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 4 (AP)?Golden Money Maker tied a national season's best time for 2-year-old pacers today and captured a straight-heat victory in the $67,000 Fox Stake.

With justice, African leaders accuse outsiders of exaggerating "tribalism" as a catch-all explanation for political and economic ills besetting their struggling new nations. With less reason, some simply deny that tribal differences are any longer a major problem despite the current agony of Nigeria.
