The waiting is over the Sinclair Refining Company is going to Cunningham Walsh. After 26 years with Geyer, Morey, Ballard and its predecessor agencies, the account moves out on Jan. 1.
NEWTON, Mass. Old D.D.U. has almost no dropouts and very few failures. And while Harvard, in another suburb of Boston, is in summer recess, D.D.U. is in full session.
Sidewalk superintendents, long accustomed to peering through holes in construction fences, have more comfortable vantage points for two of the city's biggest building projects.

An 11-year-old boy was electrocuted and his brother and a playmate were seriously injured yesterday when they touched an 11,000-volt, overhead power line in the New Haven Railroad's Oak Point rail yard in the Bronx.
LONDON, Sept. 4 The Treasury said today that Britain's reserves of gold and for- eign exchange declined by 12- million ($33.6-million) in Au- gust to 985-million ($2,758000,000).

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 4 (AP) Negro demonstrators, apparently in a maneuver to tax police resources to the fullest, split into two groups tonight and resumed their marches. One group was led by Mr. Gregory, the other by Father Groppi.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Sept. 4 Spanish artifacts will decorate many of the windows of the stores on the Mall here Saturday, Sept. 23, for the gala champagne preview of an exhibition of work by Salvador Dali called "Art-inJewels."

PITTSBURGH, Sept.4 An interfaith committee of Christian and Jewish clergy announced here today that it would initiate "Project Equality," a nationwide campaign against job discrimination, in the Pittsburgh area.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 5 (AP) --An open space treaty with all nations "for the more orderly use of the sea" was proposed by Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Sept. 5 (AP)--William Wakeman, financier, was reported partly paralyzed today by a bullet in the back. The police said it had been fired by his millionairess wife.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 5-- Miss Diane Jane Starr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Zoltan Starr, was married today to Peter Brintnall Cooper, son of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Cooper of Woodbridge, Conn. The Rev. Francis John Moore performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Starr home.

Beyond doubt, the most impressive single aspect of South Vietnam's election was the showing of Truong Dinh Dzu, who came out of obscurity to poll more than 800,000 votes and finish second in the presidential contest.
The lawyer for Mrs. Hunting ton Hartford said yesterday that he would begin divorce action today under the state's new divorce law, which went into effect Sept. 1.

The marriage of Miss Barbara Elizabeth Lawrence, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel B. Lawrence of Orlando, Fla., to Theodore Bruce Alfond, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Alfond of Waterville, and Belgrade Lakes, Me., took place yesterday at the Plaza.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass,, Sept. 5 (AP)--Lieut. Gen. James Gavin said today he had been invited to visit Vietnam, and would make the trip in late October or early November.

Originala, Inc., New York, and Selincourt Sons, Ltd., of London, announced here yesterday that their subsidiaries have agreed to establish a joint venture company in England to produce women's coats, suits and dresses for the British and Continental markets.
FILMS "A Man for All Seasons" at the Fine Arts Theater. "Enter Laughing" at Cinema I.

Sleeping potato futures came to life yesterday with a burst of activity that took brokers by surprise. Trading was suspended from 10:08 A.M. to 10:15 to give floor brokers time to catch up on their orders.

BONN, Sept. 5--In a large European business office, the morning mail usually passes through the hands of three or four senior officials before it reaches the clerks who must actually answer individual letters.
Thomas P.F. Hoving, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, resigned yesterday from the editorial policy board of the Public Broadcast Laboratory of National Educational Television.

ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Sept. 5 (Reuters)--The United States Export-Import Bank is providing $10-million for a project to help people in East and West Pakistan--separated by 1,000 miles of Indian territory--to talk to each other through space.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5-- Norway and the United States are cooperating in rocket launchings to measure electric fields associated with the northern lights, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.
The British Government is advertising to explain to the world shipping industry why Parliament passed the law under which offshore piratical radio stations were closed down on Aug. 15.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) --The Justice Department's Community Relations Service is studying reports of news coverage of the summer riots in Detroit, Newark and Buffalo, a spokesman said today.
RUMSON, N.J., Sept. 5-- Six young women were presented at the annual Rumson Debutante Ball tonight at the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club.

Mrs. Frances T. Evans McQuade, wife of Edward A. McQuade, vice president and a director of the Central Securities Corporation, died Monday of a heart attack in the Harkness Pavilion. She was 61 years old and lived at 162 East 80th Street.
NEW DELHI, Sept 5--Foreign Minister M.C. Chagla has resigned in protest against a Government move to replace the teaching of English with Indian regional languages in five years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) --The Government agency investigating the collision of two planes over Ohio last March 9 in which 26 persons were killed called today for a survey of the sun visors used on light aircraft.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5--A lawyer in the Office of Legal Counsel, Department of Justice, said tonight: "You don't actually have to put a paper in a person's hand to serve it. If you do something reasonably calculated to reach the person intended to be served, that is adequate."
PLATTSBURGH, N.Y., Sept. 5 (AP)--Three masked men held up a branch of the Marine Midland Bank this morning on the city's outskirts and escaped with $36,872 in cash.
BALDWIN, L.I., Sept. 5--A second girl student at Baldwin High School testified at a public hearing today that she had been molested by Maurice C. McNeill, the 36-year-old biology teacher.
Name performers, folk singers, satirists, comedians and jazz combinations will be the key ingredients in the presentation of New York night spots this fall.

DAVID STRASBERG of New York, Pedro Cabral of Greenwich, Conn., Charles Lamprey of White Plains and Henry Bethe of Ithaca, N.Y., won the open team championship, which closed the Knickerbocker Sectional Tournament on Monday at the New York Hilton.
WARSAW, Sept. 5--President de Gaulle's plans for his visit to Poland have been criticized on two scores.

KINSHASA, the Congo, Sept. 5 (Reuters)--Diallo Telli, Secretary General of the Organization of African Unity, said today that current troubles in the continent were weakening the cause of unity and development.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 5--Gov. Ronald Reagan disclosed today plans for a half dozen more major speeches --most of them at Republican fund-raising affairs--across the nation in October.
CAPE MAY POINT, N.J., Sept. 5 (UPI)--A pre-dawn fire today destroyed a historic three-story mansion that had served for years as the home of the commander of the old Cape May Naval Base.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5-- American officials consider it likely that the new Government in South Vietnam will take a new interest in peace maneuvers as a result of the strong peace sentiments expressed during the presidential election.
CARLSBAD, N.M., Sept. 5 (UPI)--An Army officer was found dead tonight after being trapped for nearly 24 hours in a newly discovered "wild cave" in the Lincoln National Forest.
CUERNAVACA, Mexico, Sept. 5--An experiment in psychoanalysis that caused a deep stir within the Roman Catholic Church has come to an end with the official closing of a Benedictine monastery here.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 5 (AP)--Science can be a powerful ally of the church in determining the true direction of human progress, B.D. Thomas, president of the Battelle Memorial Institute, Columbus, told 1,800 delegates to a national church consultation here tonight.

FARMINGTON, Conn., Sept. 5--Miss Barbara Nichols and Pieter Stroeve were married this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Edward Nichols. Mr. Stroeve is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Antonie Stroeve of Orinda, Calif., formerly of The Hague.

The program of the Allied Picture Corporation to settle its debts has been upset by they unsuccessful attempt to buy control of the film distributor by D. Kaltman Co., George D. Burrows, Allied's president, said in an interview yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) --Representative Joseph Y. Resnick, Democrat of upstate New York, accused the American Farm Bureau Federation today of deliberate deception on a call for the House Agriculture Committee to investigate the activities of the bureau and other major farm groups.

GENEVA, Sept. 5--The International Commission of Jurists denounced today what it describes as the violation of human rights by Dr. Francois Duvalier, President of Haiti, and said there were "obvious signs of the growing instability of the regime."
MOSCOW, Sept. 5 (UPI)-- Anatoly Makarov set a national record today in winning a 5,000meter event in 13 minutes 34.8 seconds, it was reported by Tass, the Soviet Press Agency.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) --Sponsors of the annual Westinghouse science talent search announced today that the fund would offer twice as many scholarships and add more money to them.

Representatives of eight Brooklyn antipoverty and community organizations demanded yesterday that residents of the slum neighborhoods around the Brooklyn Navy Yard be given a controlling voice in planning its development as an industrial park.
SAGINAW, Mich., Wednesday, Sept. 5 (AP)--All the firemen in this city of 100,000 population in central lower Michigan walked off their jobs last night but returned about three hours later.
ONCE in a while, the makers of various food products come up with inexpensive booklets that seem uncommonly worthwhile for home cooks.
ALBANY, Sept. 5--The Constitutional Convention voted 125 to 48 today to reject efforts to curb the Legislature in mandating higher expenses on local governments such as New York City.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 5-- The Riverhead Town Board amended the town zoning ordinance today to permit youngsters to build tree houses without permits or approved plans.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 5--Foreign Minister Abba Eban said today that Israel had "looked in vain" for any signs of moderation in the resolutions adopted last week by the Arab summit conference at Khartoum.
Douglas Gibbons-Hollyday Ives, Inc., has elected Edward S. Elliman as its vice president.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 5--The engagement of Miss Louise Marie Demarest and Francois J. Thunin has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Demarest, Mr. Thunin is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jean Thunin of Salon-de-Provence, France.

NASSAU, The Bahamas, Sept. 5 (AP)--The Bahamian Police Commissioner denied today that his officers had been involved in tapping the telephones or tampering with the mail of Premier Lynden O. Pindling or members of his Government.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 5 --Former Gov. George C. Wallace refused Today in behalf of his wife, Gov. Lurleen B. Wallace, to accept notice of a Federal court order blocking a new state law that would let parents decide whether their children's teachers were to be white or Negro.

TRENTON, Sept. 5 (AP)-- The New Jersey Supreme Court adopted today new rules extending constitutional guarantees to juveniles accused of serious crimes. The major effect requires that lawyers be furnished for indigent juveniles in cases where conviction could lead to confinement.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 5-- Rufus Crosby Kemper Sr. stepped down today as chairman of the board of the City National Bank and Trust Company, which he had guided for the last 48 years.

Chairman Edwin B. Dooley of the State Athletic Commission said yesterday the commission still recognized Joe Frazier as the top-ranking heavyweight contender, despite last Friday's decision by the World Boxing Association to drop him from second to ninth place in its ratings.

BRIGHTON, England, Sept. 5 (AP)--Ignoring the advice of its ruling Council, the convention of Britain's powerful Trades Union Congress called upon the Laborite Government today to disown United States policy in Vietnam and demanded withdrawal of American forces.
Auchincloss, Parker Redpath, members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday the admission of Graham Bell as a general partner.
SCRANTON, Pa., Sept. 5-- John Durkan, former Mayor of Scranton and an undertaker here for more than 60 years, died today at his home in West Scranton of a heart attack. Ne was 92 years old.
Net income of the H.J. Heinz Company rose 22 per cent to a record of $5,244,000 in the first fiscal quarter ended Aug. 2, it was reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5-- North Vietnam has quadrupled its surface-to-air missile sites within the last year, Pentagon sources reported today.

Mayor Lindsay's special mediation panel on the schools has come forward with a generous but essentially sound formula for resolving the dispute between the Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers before the scheduled opening of classes next Monday.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 5 (AP) --John W. Irwin, whose conviction in the 1963 kidnapping of Frank Sinatra Jr. was overturned by a court, pleaded guilty today to renewed charges rather than face a new trial.

LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 5 (AP) --A three-way merger of the Lincoln (Neb.) Life and Casualty Company, the National Insurance Company of America in Grand Forks, N.D., and the Empire Life Insurance Company of America, with headquarters in Dallas, is being proposed to stockholders of the three companies.

PEKING, Sept. 5 (Agence France-Presse)--Two Russians walked out of a press conference given by South Vietnam's National Liberation Front today when charges of collusion between the Soviet Union and the United States were made by a representative of the Chinese Red Cross.

ATHENS, Sept. 5--Greece and Turkey have agreed to tackle their prolonged dispute over Cyprus at a two-day meeting of their Premiers in Thrace over the weekend. An official announcement is to be made by the two Governments tomorrow.
"The Americanization of Emily," a movie that was issued three years ago, is coming back with a new name but with an old purpose: to cash in on "hot" box office names.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (UPI) --A House bill to end Federal supervision over the Seneca Nation of Indians of New York and Pennsylvania has been introduced in Congress, the Interior Department announced today.

Late in the evening of Aug. 6, James Callaghan, the British Chancellor of the Exchequer--"looking bronzed and fit from his holiday in the Isle of Wight," according to one British newspaper-- came out from behind closed doors in Lancaster House, London, to announce an agreement for overhaul of the monetary machinery of the non-Communist world.
The National Horse Show will be held--for the last time in the present Madison Square Garden--from Oct. 31 through Nov. 7.
DETROIT, Sept. 5 (AP)--Joe Sparma beat the Kansas City Athletics on two hits for his fifth shutout of the season and pitched the Detroit Tigers to a 4-0 victory tonight.
Rent controls will be removed from all New York City apartments that were renting at $250 a month or more in April, 1965, City Rent Administrator Frederic S. Berman said yesterday.

The National Broadcasting Company last night settled its contract dispute with the National Association of Broadcast Employes. The union did not reach agreement with the American Broadcasting Company, but said that A.B.C.'s final proposal for a new contract would be submitted to its membership for consideration.

Prices during the 1967-68 season at the Vivian Beaumont Theater in Lincoln Center will go up 50 cents a ticket for all performances, both subscription and nonsubscription. The new rate is expected to bring in an additional $118,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (UPI)--Negotiators in the eight-week-old strike against the copper industry were summoned to Washington today in an effort by the Administration to head off possible damage to the nation's war effort. The initial meetings with the four big copper companies were not scheduled as negotiating sessions, but contract talks were expected to move to Washington later.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 5--The official Czecho slovak press agency denounced as a "manifest fabrication" today a manifesto attributed to Czech writers that was published by The Sunday Times of London. A report on the statement was published in The New York Times yesterday.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Sept. 5 (AP)--A union official says that industry is headed toward Government ownership "when the Federal government starts to regulate the wages of workers."

THERE were 111 fewer jobs in pro football yesterday after the 25 teams trimmed their rosters to the required limits--43 players for the National Football League's 16 clubs and 40 for the American League's nine.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) --Gen. Harold K. Johnson, Army Chief of Staff, listened today to the views of 21 National Guard generals on a Pentagon plan to streamline the Guard and the Army Reserve.
The Neighborhood Youth Corps summer program, which put 42,000 local youngsters to work at $1.50 an hour, was credited yesterday with a major role in easing tensions in the slums.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Sept. 6--Tran Van Don, a retired Major General who organized the 1963 coup against President Ngo Dinh Diem, led his military ticket to victory today in still-incomplete returns from the Senate elections Sunday.
CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (AP)-- The Labor Day weekend traffic death toll was lower than the record for the holiday set last year, but exceeded the estimate forecast by safety experts.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 5--An Iranian proposal to create a United Nations international space agency was turned down by the scientific and technical subcommittee on the peaceful uses of outer space.
Plans for Smith Industries International, Inc., to acquire Drilco Oil Tools, Inc., for stock worth about $16-million were announced yesterday.
A spokesman for the Navy insisted yesterday that a submarine that collided Saturday with a racing sloop in Block Island Sound had come to a dead stop when the accident occurred.
Governor Rockefeller recommended yesterday that the planned November balloting on the projected new State Constitution provide for separate votes on "major policy, questions."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5-- Ramparts magazine reported today that two Greek citizens, described as key Government witnesses in the impending treason trial of Andreas Papandreou, had fled to the United States and had retracted their "totally fabricated" testimony.
A WAVE of change is sweeping over Seventh Avenue. Designers are switching from a preoccupation with strict, military lines to a concern for curves.

The Art Dealers Association of America is considering forming panels of experts to determine the authenticity of works of art for collectors throughout the country.
The Barden Corporation, a producer of ball bearings, announced yesterday the appointment of Charles A. Durakis to the new post of administrative vice president.

Neulander of the Bayswater Jewish Center in Far Rockaway, Queens. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Elias I. NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 5-- Members of the Norwalk Teachers Association this afternoon accepted recommendation of its professional committee for acceptance of a new contract on the eve of the opening of school tomorrow.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Sept. 5--The architect of a $2.06-million elementary school under construction here has complained to the Board of Education and the builder about structural irregularities in the foundation.
Late profit taking trimmed some of the earlier gains on the American Stock Exchange yesterday, but the list managed to end the session in the plus column.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 5--Arab agitation to close all schools on the Israeli occupied West Bank area of Jordan was reported here today.

Although a special threejudge court here is scheduled to hold a final hearing on Sept. 18 on the Pennsy-Central rail merger, several railroads asked the court yesterday to continue indefinitely an injunction preventing that merger.

ASPEN. Colo.--Herbert Hoover, not a lucky President, was nevertheless wise and, incidentally, one of the few intellectuals since Thomas Jefferson to inhabit the White House. He is the only Chief Executive to have translated a Latin classic into English.
Two groups opposed to the war in Vietnam are seeking separate referendums in the city's November elections to poll New Yorkers' feelings about the war.

RICHMOND, Sept. 5--Virginia authorities rejected today arguments that H. Rap Brown, 23-year-old chairman of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, faced a "lega lynching" in Maryland but deferred action on the extradition of the black power advocate.

Dr. Means, emeritus professor of clinical medicine at Harvard Medical School and former chief of medical services at Massachusetts General Hospital, was a pioneer in using radioactive iodine as an aid in diagnosing thyroid disease.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 5-- In a sailing game in which a hush-hush policy on design features is the rule, the Australian perpetrators of a secret weapon were as baffled today as those from whom information was being withheld.

S. Roger Tyler Jr. of Washington and Mrs. Zora Cheever Gross of San Francisco and Shaw Island, Wash., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Zora Tyler, to Malcolm Clark Mills, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Henry Mills of Burlington, Vt.

TEL AVIV, Sept. 5--An Israeli Army spokesman said that Jordanian troops on the eastern bank of the Jordan River opened fire today on an Israeli jeep moving on the west bank, wounding three of the Israeli soldiers in the vehicle.

The Constitutional Convention seems bent on adopting a new Judiciary Article that will disappoint supporters of true court reform. Neither the proposition backed by the majority of the Judiciary Committee nor the amendments to it supported by most of its Republican minority are at all adequate to the state's needs.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) --President Johnson added a lawyer to his special assistants today. He is Ernest Goldstein, who is leaving Coudert Brothers, a firm with offices in New York and Paris.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 5-- Lester Pence Barlow, inventor of some of the first aerial bombs and torpedoes used in World War I, died today at Stamford Hospital after a brief illness. He was 80 years old and lived on Cedar Heights Road, Stamford.

POMPTON PLAINS, N.J., Sept. 5--Mr. and Mrs. James W. Campbell have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Ellen Campbell, to Robert Pearson Grim, son of Mrs. Allan K. Grim of Kutztown, Pa., and the late Federal Court Judge Grim.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Sept. 5 (Reuters)--A state of siege will be imposed here and in the eastern departments of Itapua and Alto Parana tomorrow, the Paraguayan Interior Ministry announced here tonight.

PARIS, Sept. 5--President de Gaulle leaves tomorrow for Poland on what for any conventional chief of state would appear to be a conventional state visit. Instead, Frenchmen are waiting with growing fascination, partly pleasurable, partly apprehensive, for what their leader may do.
Stock prices rose yesterday in more active trading as investors returned from the long Labor Day weekend in an optimistic mood.

Quiet August is over now, and the Sales Executives Club is preparing to enter its 35th winter with its youngest president ever--John Emery Jr., 43-year-old executive vice president of Emery Air Freight. And he's got some ideas.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Sept. 5--Bob Ward has become the third head football coach at the University of Maryland in three years. But Ward is eager to remain and he seems to have the credentials for a long tenure with the Terrapins in a winning way.

The 1967 edition of the American Hotel and Motel Association's directory of hotel and motel systems contains information on 170 chains having a total of 4,120 lodging establishments in the United States and abroad. The directory lists organizations operating three or more establishments, as well as firms that specialize in referrals.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 5--The parents of 46 white children on Pittsburgh's North Side refused today to let them attend the newly opened Columbus School, where the Board of Education is seeking to achieve a balance between Negro and white students.

DETROIT, Sept. 5 (UPI)-- Militant teachers, holding firm to a "no contract, no work" rallying cry, began strike action today in 34 Michigan cities. More than 500,000 students were faced with school lockouts.
GANDER, Nfld., Sept. 5 (UPI)--A Soviet-built Czechoslovak airliner with 69 persons aboard crashed and burned early today while taking off for Havana. Thirty-four persons were killed.

Michael Calabrese, once described as a central figure in an investigation of police payoffs, was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld to 18 months in prison for conspiring to falsify bank records.
The Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers charged yesterday that the Long Island Rail Road was operating unsafe equipment, but a public relations spokesman for the railroad quickly denied the charge.

Production of steel last week--compared with that of the previous week--continued the general upward trend of the last two months, but output could be curtailed if an expected strike in the automotive industry is called tonight.

DETROIT, Sept. 5--Malcolm Lawrence Denise comes close to hating the limelight. But twice daily the Ford Motor Company's chief labor negotiator steps in front of a bank of bright lights and television cameras and is seen by thousands of Ford workers, many of ...

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 5 (UPI)--Rich Rollins hit a triple with the bases filled in a first-inning assault against Sam McDowell and the league-leading Minnesota Twins went on to rout the Cleveland Indians, 9-2, for Jim Kaat's 11th pitching victory.
Before the first race, John Jacobs told Willie Shoemaker that Led Astray's sore shins weren't hurtine her anymore.

THE season's first new show, "Garrison's Goril las," is very likely going to be the season's first popular hit; it is a ready-mix narrative for the mass audience, a sure-fire blend of the underworld and the underground.

GOOD MORNING, WORLD," the Colum bia Broadcasting System's new series about the adventures of a pair of early morning disk jockeys on a New York radio station, apparently discovered the awful truth early in the game. Instead of shooting for the funnybone, its producers decided instead to rely on the doubtful security of canned laughter. As it turned out, it was a piece of worldly wisdom.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) --The Democratic national chairman, John M. Bailey, said today that Gev. George Romney of Michigan "has insulted the integrity of two dedicated and honorable men" in saying he was brainwashed during a trip to Vietnam in 1965.
Four destroyers--members of Japan's first training squadron to visit the city since 1936-- sailed into New York Harbor yesterday for a four-day stay.
DURHAM, N.C., Sept. 5 (UPI) --Integration came today to a formerly all-white residential section here.

WESTBSURY, L.I, Sept. 5-- The field for the $50,000 Nassau Pace at 1 miles at Roosevelt Raceway Saturday begar to take shape today. Helen R. Buck's Overcall, who faded in last week's National Pacing Derby, won't be entered in the 16th edition of the Nassau Raceway officials said today
TOKYO, Sept. 5--Japanese and American trading interests clashed on two fronts today, with spokesmen for each side urging the other to modify its barriers to free trade.
DENVER, Sept. 5 (UPI)--Two baby girls were in fair condition today at Colorado General Hospital after liver transplant operations.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 5 (AP) --Three human skeletons more than 40,000 years old have been discovered by a French archeological expedition in a cave near Nazareth, it was announced today.

United States universities and colleges are enrolling more than 7,000 African students this year to help meet Africa's urgent need for trained manpower in government, education, agriculture and industry.
Two thousand tourists, most of whom earned their sealegs on the Staten Island ferry, jammed the Queen Mary yesterday for a last look at the symbol of trans-Atlantic speed and luxury.
CAIRO, Sept. 5 (Reuters)-- The head of Egyptian military intelligence, Salah Nasr, was dismissed in the wake of a farreaching purge of officers, it was disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5-- Self-administered medications may soon end a legal controversy by making abortion a matter of private decision, a Princeton theologian said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) --The appointment of Francis M. Bator, a former White House aide, as special consultant to the Secretary of the Treasury was announced today by Secretary Henry H. Fowler.
LONDON, Sept. 5 (Reuters)-- At least seven persons were killed today and dozens injured in gales that swept across Britain.

James P. Kepple, president of Paper Handlers Union I, said yesterday that members had voted to seek strike sanction from the parent international in their dispute with newspaper publishers in New York City.
Directors of National Service Industries, Inc., proposed yesterday in Atlanta a four-forthree split of the common shares, to be followed by an increased quarterly dividend on the new stock.
Policemen were pelted with stones and bottles for the second straight night yesterday by bands of angry Negroes milling through the streets of the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Sept. 5 (AP)--Chet Gladchuk, an AllAmerican football player at Boston College in 1940, died last night in Cooley Dickinson Hospital after a long illness. He was 50 years old.
The rise in bond prices and decline in interest rates that began last week continued yesterday.

When Special Markets, Inc., was formed in 1955, some members of the Wall Street community scoffed at the idea of setting up a brokerage house to cater to Negro investors. The Negro with sufficient means to become a stock market investor was thought to be a rarity.
PARIS, Sept. 5--Britain's chief negotiator on entry into the Common Market met France's Foreign Minister today and, according to informed sources, received no encouragement.

SEOUL, South Korea, Sept 5 --Having almost used up $150million in United States development loans committed to South Korea three years ago, the Seoul Government intends to ask for another $150-million in loans to help finance the nation's second five-year economic plan.
Czechoslovakia has canceled plans to observe the 1,000th anniversary of her Jewish community.
Peter Darmohraj is a student at City College, but he has been spending a lot of time this summer at Queens College--counting trees, among other things.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 5--The Rev. James E. Groppi heard himself denounced as a "preacher of hatred" at City Hall today while his civil rights followers groaned and booed and shouted "hypocrite" at his accuser.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 5--A three-judge Federal Court ordered Alabama school authorities today not to enforce a new state law that would permit parents to choose the race of their children's teachers.
Warren Caro, executive director of the Theater GuildAmerican Theater Society outof-town subscription group for 20 years, has resigned to join the Shubert organization.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) --The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that J.P. Stevens Co. unlawfully dismissed 18 employes for engaging in union activity.
NEW HAVEN, Sept. 5--A company spearheaded by professional theater people who will double as classroom teachers is taking shape at the Yale School of Drama.
A man walked into a Bronx tavern yesterday, shot a woman and two men, one fatally, and then escaped, the police reported.

The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday the election of Wilbert A. Walker as executive vice president for accounting. He was formerly administrative vice president and continues as controller.
Floyd B. McKissick, national director of the Congress of Racial Equality, said yesterday that CORE would soon announce a plan "to develop a black community from the ground up."
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 5--The bitterest fighting in two months broke out yesterday and today from the Mekong Delta to the northern provinces.

CALIFORNIA, Md., Sept. 5 --Lieut. Comdr. Henry J. Weseloh, U.S.N., and Mrs. Weseloh have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Weseloh, to Raymond Arthur Ilg 3d. He is the son of Mrs. William C. Mercer of Darien, Conn., and the late Mr. Ilg Jr.

A threatened strike against Gimbels department store outlets in the New York area was averted last night with the announcement of a tentative contract settlement with a union representing 150 cleaners and maintenance workers.

Physicians are staging a mass protest against Medicaid and are refusing to treat patients because they are not being paid their fees, the chairman of the Citizens Committee for Medicaid said yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 5----Truong Dinh Dzu, the peace candidate who was the surprise runner-up in the presidential election Sunday, said today that he would try in the Constituent Assembly to upset the vote.
ROCKAWAY, N.J. Sept. 5 (AP)--A safe containing about $40,000 was stolen over the weekend from the Shop-Rite supermarket on Route 46 here.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 5--Federal Customs agents announced today the arrest of a Japanese scientist here and the recovery of three crates containing missing information on a United States space project.

LAKESIDE, Conn., Sept. 5-- John Burns, the versatile senior who played every backfield position and also did some punting and place-kicking in his two previous varsity years, has been lost to the 1967 Columbia football squad.
The appointment of Ronuald P. Holubowicz as a vice president of the Ingalls Shipbuilding Corporation, a division of Litton Industries, was announced yesterday.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 5 (AP)--Go Lite won his 12th race of the year today when he gained a 1 -length victory in the Neptune Purse at Atlantic City.

HANOI, North Vietnam, Sept. 5 (Agence France-Presse)-- North Vietnam indicated today that it would reject any attempt to launch a new United States peace offensive via South Vietnam's newly elected President, Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Van Thieu, and its Vice President, Air Vice Marshal Nguyen Cao Ky.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP)--A greater percentage of American babies are surviving infancy than ever before, the United States Public Health Service reported today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) --Gen. Earle G. Wheeler, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, is being treated at Walter Reed Army Hospital for what the Pentagon described as "minor heart damage."

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 4-- Recruitment of police officers has become a major effort of this city, with results that so far fall short of the goal set by Police Chief Tom Reddin. Additional efforts have been initiated to relieve the shortage.
PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 5-- Dick Colman, the Princeton football coach, wore bright, red trousers at an Ivy League meeting two years ago.

HONG KONG, Sept. 5--Political observers of affairs in China who have evaluated recent reports from Canton describe the Kwangtung provincial capital, 90 miles up the Pearl River from Hong Kong, as one of the world's most lawless, violence-ridden cities.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) --The airline pilot who brought his passenger-filled jet down at the wrong Columbus, Ohio, airport last July 4 was grounded for two weeks for his mistake, Federal Aviation Administration records showed today.

Directors of the First National City Bank voted yesterday to raise the bank's quarterly dividend rate to 50 cents, from 45 cents. This was the second increase in the dividend rate in a little more than a year. In June, 1966, the payout was raised to 45 cents from 40 cents.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5--A conservative political organization said today that freshmen Republicans in the House had generated a strong swing to the right in Congress this year.
KEESEVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 5 --Like clever showmen, the men who built the Northway saved their most spectacular effect until the last.
Added protection against lightning-caused fuel tank explosions in yet transports has been ordered by the Federal Aviation Administration.
Mayor Lindsay made public yesterday the recommendations of his school mediation panel, which proposed a $125-million compromise package.
Prices on the London stock market advanced to new high levels for the year in active trading yesterday.

The executive committee of the Bangor Punta Corporation at a special meeting here yesterday approved in principle a plan under which that holding company could receive a "substantial" interest in a new holding company to be formed by the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) --Gen. Earle G. Wheeler, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, is being treated at Walter Reed Army Hospital for what the Pentagon described as "minor heart damage."

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 4-- Recruitment of police officers has become a major effort of this city, with results that so far fall short of the goal set by Police Chief Tom Reddin. Additional efforts have been initiated to relieve the shortage.
PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 5-- Dick Colman, the Princeton football coach, wore bright, red trousers at an Ivy League meeting two years ago.

ADEN, Sept. 5--Sir Humphrey Trevelyan, the British High Commissioner, put an official seal today on the end of the federal Government of the South Arabian Federation with a broadcast recognizing "the nationalist forces as representatives of the people."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5-- Perhaps 20 million Americans think they have heart disease but, in fact, do not, a professor from Hofstra University said today.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. 5 --Almost 2,400 public school teachers in Broward County (Fort Lauderdale) resigned today in support of a continuing fight for higher teacher salaries.

A parade in Washington Oct. 21 in support of United States servicemen in Vietnam was called off yesterday to avoid any possible clash with antiwar demonstrators planning to throng the nation's capital that weekend.
Robert Dickson of McAlester, Okla., the recent winner of the United States Amateur golf championship, has been named to the Americas Cup team, the United States Golf Association announced yesterday.

Charles Pasarell of Puerto Rico lost a match that he appeared to have won beyond any question with an electrifying burst of tennis, and Rosemary Casals of San Francisco was beaten, too, in a sensational finish in the United States grass court championships yesterday at Forest Hills, Queens.
ROME, Sept. 5--Pope Paul VI apparently is on the mend today after a mild illness but has accepted his doctor's recommendation to take a few days of complete rest.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4--Carl Yastrzemski needed a rest and almost was given tonight off. But he elected to play, then hit two home runs and a single and led the Boston Red Sox to an 8-2 victory over the Washington Senators.

Domestic consumption of natural gas should "approximately double" within the next 20 years, Howard Boyd, chairman of the El Paso Natural Gas Company, told a press conference yesterday at San Francisco, Calif. He had just been elected president of the Independent Natural Gas Association of America at its annual meeting in that city.

Four community nominees for principals in the experimental Ocean Hill-Brownsville district in Brooklyn won approval of the school system last night. But a fifth--a Negro fighting a murder conspiracy charge--was left without action.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 --Business has again revised slightly downward its plans to invest in plant and equipment this year but still plans to spend more in the second half than in the first, the Commerce Department reported today.

ERIC DE JUAN, Cuban designer who was jailed six times by Fidel Castro and then fled the country, showed his first custom collection at Bergdorf Goodman yesterday. The reaction of the spectators--many of them Cuban friends of the designer --was a rousing "Ole!"
CLEVELAND, Sept. 5 (UPI) --The sale of Don Demeter, an outfielder, from the Cleveland Indians to the Detroit Tigers was canceled today, because Demeter has a heart condition.
The spot rate on the British pound dipped 2 points to $2,7846 in quiet trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.
The New York Mets perchased Amos Otis, a 20-yearold infielder and outfielder, from their Jacksonville farm yesterday. To make room for Otis, the club released outright Phil Linz to Jacksonville.
PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 5-- Public and private power agencies in the Northwest have started discussions about joining in the construction of the proposed High Mountain Sheep Dam on the Snake River.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art opened the 1967-68 art season yesterday by taking the wraps off a major acquisition, a 7-foot-high Carrara marble sculpture of the hero Perseus holding aloft the severed head of the Gorgon Medusa.

EAST ST. LOUIS. Ill., Sept. 5 (UPI)--The president of the the American Federation of Teachers Local 1220 said today that the nonunion teachers keeping the city's 42 schools open during a wage dispute were "not competent to handle the students safely."
PROVIDENCE, R.I. Sept. 5 (AP)--David Cornel DeJong, poet and novelist, died today in Jane Brown Hospital after a long illness. He was 62 years old.
HAMEENLINNA, Finland, Sept. 5 (UPI)--Jochen Rindt of Austria, driving a Brabham Repco, won a Formula Two race for grand prix pilots today, covering the 20 laps in 27 minutes 5.53 seconds.

Joaquin P. Rodriguez, who retired in 1961 as senior officer of Rodriguez Sons Company, steamship brokers at 39 Broadway, died Monday at Great Barrington, Mass., where he was visiting friends. He was 69 years old and was a resident of Larchmont, N.Y.
For the last six weeks a bus line has been running in Queens without a franchise. And the city, although it has threatened to stop the operation, has not yet put it out of business.
A second Prudential Insurance Company tower will be added to the 33-acre Prudential Center, a city-within-a-city in Boston.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 5--Willard H. Cobb, a retired vice president and director of the United States Rubber company, now Uniroyal, Inc., died yesterday in his home here at 3 Bellegrove Drive after a long illness. He was 81 years old.
Prices of 1968-model refrigerators, freezers and room air conditioners are going up.

Tony Conigliaro will undergo a series of medical tests Wednesday in Boston that may determine whether he can play again this season. The 22-year-old Red Sox outfielder was injured severely on Aug. 18, when struck on the cheek by a ball pitched by Jack Hamilton of California.
ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept. 5 (AP)--Bubba Morton drove in eight runs, four in each game, today as the California Angels swept a twilight-night doubleheader from the Baltimore Orioles, 7-2 and 11-4.

With strikes and strike threats again chilling the economy, a strong voice has been raised inside organized labor for voluntary union-management action to insure industrial peace without Government intervention.

The gradual removal of rent controls from some city apartments is increasing the flight of middle-income residents to the suburbs, three City Council Democrats asserted yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 President Johnson confirmed today his intention to nominate Walter E. Washington as commissioner, or head, of this city's municipal government.
TRENTON, Sept. 6 (AP) The State Board of Education ruled unanimously today that local school boards cannot tell students how long they can wear their hair.

ALBANY, Sept. 6 The State Attorney General is holding up and may reject contracts for a special $100,000 state chair at Fordham University, which is already filled by Dr. Marshall McLuhan, the communications theorist.

State and city officials agreed yesterday that Federal programs would never be large enough to alleviate the plight of slum dwellers and that private enterprise would have to be enticed to do the job through economic incentives.

DETROIT, Sept. 6 Strikes by teachers delayed the start of school for more than 500,000 Michigan students in 36 communities today, including 300,000 in Detroit. The Detroit Board of Education said it was closing its schools "until further notice." A spokesman for the Michigan Education Association said its teacher members would "sit it out until Christmas if necessary" to obtain higher wages and smaller classes.

GIVEN the conceit that a man frozen inside a gla cier 67 years could be defrosted and returned to the present as a lusty 33-yearold, "The Second Hundred Years" may give the American Broadcasting Company one of the season's comedy this. Accept the silly premise, and what follows takes on a balmy logic of its own.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 6 (AP) A suit has been filed in United States District Court contending that there is "a pattern of purposeful discrimination" in selection of juries for the Baltimore Circuit Court.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 6 Dame Pattie, the challenger for the America's Cup, and Columbia, beaten by Intrepid for the defense role, sailed upwind and down for three hours today in the first approximation of a real duel between the Australian yacht and a top American 12-Meter.

GENEVA, Sept. 6 Eric Wyndham White, Director General of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, disclosed today that he had proposed a meeting of its 72 members at the ministerial level this fall to "survey the principal trade problems still requiring further international consultation following the conclusion of the Kennedy round."
Salesmen for FM radio stations are beginning to break down the resistance of agency men toward their medium.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 6 The elan and stamina of the Rev. James E. Groppi's civil rights demonstrators, some of whom have trudged well over 100 miles through Milwaukee streets in the last five days, appeared to have weakened this afternoon when only about 50 marchers appeared in the downtown area.

A lending institution designed to provide "a more equitable and dependable" source of financing for real estate developers and builders has been formed by William J. Levitt Jr., president of Levitt Properties, Inc.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. 6 Leaders of Florida's public school teachers said today that they would step up a campaign to urge the Democraticcontrolled State Legislature to call itself into session for a vote on higher teacher salaries.
WILTON, Conn., Sept. 6 George Mitchell, an actor who turned sculptor in recent years, died yesterday at Trumbull. He was 93 years old and resided here.

WASHINGTON. Sept. 6 There was a terrible scene the other night at the Charles Darnays' house. Young Sidney, who had been a delegate to the convention of "New Left" politicians in Chicago, came home and cut off his beard.
BETH and Herbert Levine, who were voted a Special Coty Award this year for their shoe designs, have taken a giant step in the stretch boot sweepstakes.

THE Asbury Park Regional Championships that begin this afternoon at the Convention Hall will attract many New York players who took part in the Labor Day sectional tournament in Manhattan. Some players had only a one-day break, for a two-day trial to determine a representative. New York team began at Asbury Park yesterday.
WARSAW, Sept. 6 President de Gaulle suggested tonight that France and Poland might cooperate in helping to end the war in Vietnam.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Sept. 5 The cash grants to Egypt and Jordan that the Arab chiefs of state granted in Khartoum last week total $378-million and will amount to about 20 per cent of the annual oil revenues of the three contributors the great Arab oil-producing kingdoms of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait

DETROIT, Sept. 7 Labor experts here regard the strike at the Ford Motor Company as the prelude to months of labor strife in the automobile industry. Even if most of the economic issues are cleared up in a few days and this is all but impossible the strike will probably drag on for a month any
