ARLINGTON, Va., Sept. 6 (AP) A $10,000 reduction in bond, from $50,000 to $40,000, was ordered today for John Patler, 29 years old, charged with the sniper slaying of George Lincoln Rockwell, American Nazi party leader.

GENEVA, Sept. 6 Following is the partial text of a study by Dr. Raul Prebisch, Secretary General of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development. Earlier paragraphs, omitted here, are devoted to comments affecting developed countries. The sections printed below summarize the effects of the Kennedy round tariff reductions on major product categories of interest to developing countries.
The city's 4,000 new teachers went to classes yesterday to learn about their schools, their students and the communities in which they will work.
The appointment by President Johnson of Walter E. Washington as the first "Mayor" Washington has had in this century does honor to both men.

DETROIT, Thursday, Sept. 7 The Ford Motor Company was struck by the United Automobile Workers last night. The strike began at midnight after the company rejected a union offer to submit their differences on pay and fringe benefits to binding arbitration.
WAKE ISLAND, Sept. 6 (UPI) A Navy tug and a Coast Guard cutter were to rendezvous here today to assist a Standard Oil Company tanker that was aground on a reef and leaking fuel.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. (AP) Federal court order blocking enforcement of a new Alabama law on teacher choice was left by a United States marshal on the desk of the legal adviser to Gov.Lurleen B. Wallace.

The Ford Motor Company, with $500-million in cash and marketable securities and total assets of $8-billion, as of last June 30. The United Automobile Workers union with a strike fund of $67-million. Ford employs 159,816 U.A.W, members in plants and parts depots in 25 states, including 79,187 in Michigan, 7,371 in New Jersey and 4,671 in New York State.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 6 (AP) Pinch hitter Ron Hunt, hit in the face by the ball when he tried to bunt, stayed in the game and hit a tie-breaking single in a four-run eighth inning that gave the Los Angeles Dodgers a 6-3 victory over the Chicago Cubs tonight.
Don Marshall, the New York Rangers' left winger returned his signed contract yesterday, becoming the second player in the fold. Harry Howell, the defenseman, signed last week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 Gov. George Romney of Michigan today stood by his statement that he had been "brainwashed" on the Vietnam war and added that the Johnson Administration had not been telling the people the truth about the conflict.
CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (AP) Ken Berry laced a run-scoring double in the 13th inning tonight, giving the Chicago White Sox a 3-2 victory over the California Angels.

MOSCOW, Sept. 6 The Soviet literary leadership, breaking a silence on a quarrel with Andrei A. Voznesensky, ac- cused him today of "coarse tactlessness" toward officials of the Union of Soviet Writers.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 6 The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled today that amusement parks that offer no public shows are not covered by the Civil Rights Act of 1964.
Governor Rockefeller will ask the Constitutional Convention today to authorize the creation of a new state fund to guarantee private loans to businessmen in slum areas.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 (AP) Jim Bunning pitched a sixhitter tonight in gaining his fifth shutout this season and 38th of his career as the Philadelphia Phils routed the Cincinnati Reds, 9-0.
Mrs. Huntington Hartford, wife of the heir to the A. P. grocery chain fortune, filed suit for divorce here yesterday on the ground of cruel and inhuman treatment.

Derald H. Ruttenberg, the 51-year-old financier who arranged the pending merger of the Studebaker Corporation and the Worthington Corporation, was elected yesterday to the new post of chairman of the I-T-E Circuit Breaker Company.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Sept. 6 James Crane, the defending champion from the Noroton Yacht Club, won the first race of the 19th annual Long Island Sound Junior Yacht Racing Association championship regatta for the Jesse A.B. Smith Trophy today.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 6 The Fairmount Presbyterian Church in Cleveland Heights was the setting tonight for the marriage of Miss Susan Van Vleck Shaffer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Hixon Shaffer of Chevy Chase, Md., to Airman Arthur James Robinson 2d, U.S.A.F. His parents are Dr. and Mrs. Harold Arthur Robinson of Elyria.

The engagement of Miss Wendy Lehman to Stephen Sycle Lash has been announced by her stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. Richard Kaye Korn of 898 Park Avenue. Mr. Lash is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel George Lash of Brookline, Mass.

THORPE BAY, England, Sept. 6 (UPI) The Australian challenger, Quest III, won her first race in the international Catamaran Trophy series today when the British defender, Lady Helmsman, sprung a leak and had to return to shore on one hull.

SENIOR MASTER DR. ANthony Saidy of Los An geles, a sharp tactician, scored 10 -1 in the recent United States Open at Atlanta, capturing second place, a half point under the winner, Grand Master Pal Benko of New York.
ALBANY, Sept. 6 The state's Republican and Democratic parties, in an expected show of harmony, gave bipartisan endorsement today to two nominees for vacancies on the State Court of Appeals.
Sonny Werblin, the president of the New York Jets, said yesterday at the club's opening luncheon of the year in Shea Stadium, "This is the season we hope to get it all."

LUSAKA, Zambia, Sept. 6 Fifteen whites were declared prohibited immigrants today by the Zambian Government. One of them was Mrs. Doreen Fleming, who was named as a Rhodesian spy at a tribunal in June. She was expected to leave for London Sunday.

BALDWIN,L.I., Sept. 6 A science teacher testified tonight that he "heard no noise or distraction of any sore" from an office in which Maurice C. McNeill was alleged to have molested a 16-year-old girl student.

ALBANY, Sept. 6 The Constitutional Convention approved tonight a proposed local reapportionment article that critics said could affect the 10 Councilmen at Large in New York City and possibly even the Board of Estimate.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 7 Eight of ten unsuccessful civilian candidates for President lodged formal protests today against what they called fraud in the election last Sunday.
Investors continued to accentuate the positive yesterday and stock prices notched another modest advance in active trading.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 6 The United Arab Republic has accused Israel of causing a heavy exchange of gunfire on Monday at the south end of the Suez Canal by trying to force a passage into the canal.
ROME, Sept.7 Pope Paul VI suffered a renewed illness last night and returned to the Vatican from his summer retreat at Castel Gandolfo. He had a slight fever, according to a Vatican announcement.
A teen-age girl lies huddled in her bed, clutching the blankets around her, refusing to move.
Coming along on the outside in the stretch, Politely of the Bohemia Stable registered a thrilling victory over Norman Bate's Triple Brook in the $28,750 Maskette Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.
Issues on the American Stock Exchange continued to advance yesterday although some late profit taking for the second consecutive session reduced some of the earlier gains.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 6 The engagement of Miss Ellen Merigo Carroll to Lieut. Anthony Peter Chianese, U.S.A., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Kennedy Carroll. Lieutenant Chianese is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore Chianese of the Bronx and Candlewood Isle, Conn.

LONDON, Sept. 6 A 19year-old Brooklyn student, who stabbed to death the 20-yearold daughter of the American author Edmund G. Love here in June, was sentenced to life imprisonment today at the Old Bailey, London's central criminal court.
Growing numbers of motorists, including many firsttime renters, are being put in the driver's seat these days by car-rental companies.

BOSTON, Sept. 6 Ernest Sheraton Corporation of America, one of the world's largest operators of hotels, died today at Massachusetts General Hospital. He had been stricken with a heart attack Tuesday morning at his summer home in Dublin, N.H. He was 70 years old and lived at 8 Louisburg Square on Beacon Hill in Boston.

BRIDGETON, N.J., Sept. 6 The state staged a series of predawn inspections of migrant labor camps at five South Jersey farms near here this morning and announced afterward that all of the farmers had complied with an ultimatum to clean up their camps.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 The Administration said today that its forecast of "a strong economic expansion" in the second half of this year and on into 1968 had been confirmed by "every recent piece of eco- nomic information."
LONDON, Sept. 6 The Trades Union Congress overrode its leader's advice today and adopted a resolution criticizing the Labor Government's economic policies.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 6 The United States has proposed to its Western allies a course of action by the Security Council to obtain a cease-fire and peace negotiations in Vietnam.

City Councilman Matthew J. Troy, has filed a resolution calling on Mayor Lindsay to "reconsider his decision" to serve as vice chairman of President Johnson's advisory commission on civil disorders and to devote all his energies to his city responsibilities.
Prices edged forward in moderate trading yesterday on the London stock exchange.
DETROIT, Sept. 6 General Motors opened its 1968 preview season today by showing its new Pontiacs. They feature a styling theme dominated by the division's hallmark, a bold front-end design.

Recently a pedestrian sauntering by John's Bargain Store on West 34th Street near Eighth Avenue, in Manhattan, reached into one of the store's sidewalk counters, grabbed a fistful of scarves and began running toward the nearby subway entrance.

LA JOLIA, Calif., Sept. 6 Life in the Amazon Basin does not yield its secrets in sweeping portions. But international teams of scientists probing the basin's mysteries have made a series of striking discoveries in recent weeks.
About 10O Negro teen-agers demonstrated at City Hall yesterday to protest the end of the city's paid summer-job programs.
Mr. Finnegan was the first of more than 30 Federal tax officials to resign under fire in a nationwide corruption scandal involving more than 10 Internal Revenue offices from Boston to San Francisco.

A gray-haired con artist who dupes his victims by pretending to be Hirsch Jacobs, the famous horse trainer, has stepped up his activities in recent days. Harry, as the glib-tongued imposter sometimes calls himself, thrives by exploiting a long-held suspicion: in the heart of every horseplayer lurks a little larceny.

TOKYO, Sept. 6 (AP) Two "counterrevolutionaries" were sentenced to death and executed publicly before cheering thousands in Shanghai Aug. 28, according to a Shanghai radio report received in Tokyo today.
NEWARK, Sept. 6 The Teaneck Board of Education, five of its nine members and three Bergen County taxpayers filed suit today, challenging the
PEEKSKILL, N.Y. The bosky dell was sheltered with hemlocks and ironwood trees. There were fern and moss, a dappled brook and nearby a rose of Sharon in bloom.
Some American servicemen serving in Vietnam have attempted to smuggle marijuana home in packages to the United States, Federal Customs officials reported yesterday.

NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., Sept. 6 The State Supreme Court ordered today that a 16 year-old Negro honor student from Virginia be admitted to the high school here after he was not allowed to enroll because he was a nonresident.
New efforts to avert a mass resignation of teachers next Monday collapsed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 The State Department, disturbed at what it views as recent regressive moves by the military junta in Athens, is opposed to immediate resumption of full-scale military aid to Greece, department officials reported today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 An automobile strike limited to the Ford Motor Company would "somewhat dampen current activity" in the economy but would result in a further speedup later on, President Johnson was told today.

The Philco-Ford Corporation has come up with still another version of recorded music for teen-agers. And it has dewed a special, lightweight radio-phonograph to play them on. The new products were shown to the press for the first time yesterday in Hampshire House.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Sept. 5 The construction director of the architectural concern that designed a $2.06-million elementary school here said today that he would send a special inspector tomorrow to determine if ordered repairs had been made on the foundation.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 6 Standing on the east bank of the Suez Canal, Premier Levi Eshkol said today that the Arabs' refusal to negotiate left Israel no choice but to hold the lines reached by her soldiers.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 6 The Roman Catholic Church made a smashing political comeback in Sunday's na- tional elections, winning a powerful and perhaps dominant role in the new Senate.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UPI) A New York psychologist said today he believed that romance was not lasting and that to keep a marriage together adultery might be a good thing for some couples.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6--The Early Bird communications satellite was tested today as a device to be used to expedite the clearance of passengers and cargo through airports when jumbo jet aircraft are put in service in 1970.

The General Foods Corporation announced yesterday the election of Magnus R. Bohm as group vice president for operations. He will be succeeded as president of General Foods International by George Bremser Jr., who was vice president of the unit.
The United Shoe Machinery Corporation and United-Carr, Inc. announced yesterday they were discussing plans for merging.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 6 On a steep hillside overlooking the scenic Tarrytown lakes and the Rockefeller estates, Marymount College has just completed an unusual octagonal library.
Ronald Barnes of Brazil gained his most prized victory in the United States grass-court tennis championship yesterday since he defeated Dennis Ralston in the 1963 quarter-finals.
A 15-year-old girl was raped in Central Park early yesterday by two men who so severely stomped her 19-year-old escort that he may die, according to the police.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 6 (AP) Olympia You, a 7-1 shot, won the Brennan Purse today, beating Arabian Legend by 1 lengths. King's Palace finished third.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 President Johnson's novel exercise of having prominent Americans observe South Vietnam's election ended in a flow of warm tributes and fine food at the White House today.

The United Federation of Teachers is making a great point of its determination to improve the city's public schools, not just get more money for its members. But the cavalier rejection the union has given to the carefully drafted recommendations of Mayor Lindsay's mediation panel indicates its belief that the most useful contribution the U.F.T. can make to better education is to keep the schools from opening at all.

The capital markets got back into full swing yesterday as more than $400-million of new fixed income securities were offered or announced. It was too early to tell, however, how interest rates were moving.

Herman Frasch Whiton, a prominent yachtsman and retired business executive, died yesterday at his New York home, 680 Madison Avenue. He was 63 years old and had been in failing health for several months. He also maintained a home at Cove Neck, L.I.
THIS is the time of year when many youngsters lucky enough to live close to the ocean near bays, inlets and creeks begin yearning to play hookey from chores.

WASHINGTON, Sept 6 In Gov. George Romney of Michigan, the treacherous issue of Vietnam may already have claimed its first victim in national politics. This issue has haunted him from the day he emerged, after the 1966 elections, as a leading possibility for the Republican Presidential nomination, and his attempts to deal with it have displayed not only intellectual futility but perhaps worse political ineptitude.
AMSTERDAM Isador S. 1962, Memories that become more cherished with each passing year of a beloved husband, a devoted adored Dad and a loving "Pa".
NEW DELHI, Sept. 6 (AP) Prime Minister Indira Gandhi took over the post of Planning Minister today. She now holds four Cabinet posts.

DAYTON, Ohio, Thursday, Sept.7(AP) Some 12,000 workers struck the General Motors Corporation's two huge Frigidaire Division plants here at midnight last night when their contract expired, a union spokesman said.
A round of price increase appears to be in the making for the shoe industry, following upward trends in color television and a variety of products notably household appliances using steel and copper.

ANTONIO VIVALDI wrote a great deal of music, and it seems as though the City Center audience would be glad to see Gerald Arpino take the City Center Joffrey Ballet and choreograph all of it. Last night Mr. Arpino tried to match his earlier success, "Viva Vivaldi!," with a new work, "Cello Concerto," and he came extraordinarily close to his target.

Sidney Lanier, a former Episcopalian minister and one of the founders of the successful American Place Theater, will make his Broadway acting debut opposite Jean Arthur in "The Freaking Out of Stephanic Blake."
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 6 "They seem to sense that something important is going on. They know there are people here who do not only have many things to teach, but who are determined to teach them."

SUEZ, United Arab Republic, Sept. 6 Egyptian authorities charged today that Israeli tanks and mortars fired deliberately into densely populated sections of the town of Suez Monday killing 44 persons and wounding 161.

JOHN MILLS, the British performer, has succumbed to the tempting reward that goes with doing a weekly American television series. In last night's premiere of his vehicle, "Dundee and the Culhane," it seemed altogether possible that he may remember the pleaures of his annuity longer than the screen credit.

Five of the 13 partners of Bernard Geis Associates are reported to have surrendered their interests in the publishing venture because they do not like its editorial policy. Mr. Geis has recently concentrated on sexy novels in which the characters resemble actual celebrities.
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Sept. 6 A leading water carrier executive urged here today that railroads and barge lines be allowed to invest in each other's business.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 6 (UPI) Al McBean pitched a sixhitter and drove in three runs to give the Pittsburgh Pirates a 4-1 victory over Atlanta in the second game of a twilight-night double-header today after the Braves had won the opener, 4-1.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 6 Nigeria today entered the third month of her civil war in a flurry of claims and counterclaims of air victories.
A panel of experts in human genetics advised yesterday that no one in his or her reproductive years should take the hallucinogenic drug LSD unless there was a very good medical reason for doing so.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 Medical science may soon be able to detect many mental defects in fetuses before birth, a chief pediatrician at the Johns Hopkins University medical center, Baltimore, said today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 6 (AP) Gaylord Perry extended his scoreless pitching streak to 34 innings with a three-hit shutout today as he led the San Francisco Giants to a 2.0 victory over the Astros.

MONTREAL, Sept. 6 Transportation was challenged today by John W. Pickersgill, Canada's Minister of Transport, to come up with some of the answers needed to enable society to develop an economic, efficient and adequate transportation system.

The Board of Education moved yesterday to reassign aides from headquarters and district staffs and to accept assistance from parents to keep public schools open Monday in the face of threatened mass resignations teachers in a labor dispute.
The police yesterday arrested Vito Thomas D'Angelo, 23 years old,of 1615 Kenelworth Place, the Bronx, and charged him with the rifle slaying of a man Tuesday night in a Bronx tavern.

For a while yesterday, wheat futures could be described as a swinging market. Early in the day, prices dropped 2 to 3 cents a bushel but late in the session some large commercial buyers entered. As prices advanced, holders of short posittions entered along the way with buy orders to even out. By the time the flurry was over, the final prices ran 1/8 to of a cent a bushel above Tuesday's close.

RED SCHOENDIENST was assigned a suite in the tower of his hotel when he brought his St. Louis Cardinals to New York for last night's game with the Mets. If he is the only manager in either league to rate so lofty a distinction, it figures. Not only does he have a panoramic view of New York, but also the entire National League is spread out far below his Redbirds.
A STOCK with a jawbreaker of a name, Re sponsive Environments Corporation, made its debut on Wall Street yesterday as another hot new issue.
CRAWFORDSVILLE, Ind., Sept. 6 (AP) Two figures of American auto racing died to day in the flaming crash of a two-engine private plane.

TEN years ago when Albert Shanker was teaching junior high school arithmetic, he sometimes posed questions this way: If it takes four ounces of poison to kill a person, how many ounces would it take to kill your mother, your father, your sister and your brother?
CAN the lumbering turtle be nudging the sharp toothed alligator out of first place in fashion snob appeal?
Ballots for the biennial election of officers of Local 88, International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, are being mailed out to the membership this week.
PURCHASE, N.Y., Sept. 6 The Old Oaks Country Club was the setting this evening for the wedding of Miss Margot Siris and Kenneth Helphand.
CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (UPI) The nation's New Left Movement has been invaded by right wing spies in hippie clothing, it was reported today.
NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 6 Five kerosene fire bombs were thrown in the business section early today in the first serious Rockland County racial disturbance.

Miss Elizabeth A. Goodman, a leader in Brooklyn Roman Catholic, charitable and civic affairs, died Monday in the Methodist Hospital of Brooklyn. She was 76 years old and lived at 652 East 18th Street, Brooklyn.
Arthur Hays Sulzberger, chairman of the board of The New York Times, received an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws yesterday from Chungang University in Seoul, Korea.

For students of the approaching World Series form charts, the St. Louis Cardinals displayed a dangerous weakness a center fielder who can't throw in their 3-1 victory over the New York Mets last night at Shea Stadium.

An apparent attempt to make South Vietnam's Senate a rubber stamp through use of a bewildering electoral system seems to have backfired. Far from being servile, the newly chosen Senate gives more signs of becoming an acrimonious reflection of an acute division within Vietnamese society and within the military junta whose slate topped the presidential balloting.
LIMA,Peru,Sept.6(Reuters) The Cabinet of President Fernando Belaunde Terry has resigned in an economic crisis, informed sources said today.

Aaron Copland's "Inscape," one of 18 works commissioned by the New York Philharmonic in observance of its 125th anniversary year, 1967-68, will be given its premiere by the orchestra at the University of Michigan next Wednesday.

Louis E. Wolfson, the millionaire industrialist, went on trial in Federal court here yesterday on charges that he and several associates had conspired to sell 690,000 unregistered shares of Continental Enterprises, Inc., valued at $3.5million.
MAHWAH, N.J., Sept. 6 The entire night shift of 1,900 workers at the Ford Motor Company assembly plant here jumped the strike deadline tonight and walked off their jobs at 8:30.
William Francis Gibbs, one of the world's outstanding naval architects and marine engineers, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

A Negro assistant principal accused of conspiracy to commit murder has charged in a petition for the City Commission on Human Rights that "prejudice" has led to his suspension from the school sys etm.

LONDON, Sept. 6 Sir Robert Thompson, who headed Britain's Advisory Mission in Saigon for three and a half years, says that recent United States military measures in South Vietnam "smack more of desperation" than of the reso lution needed to win the war.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 6 James B. Moore Jr., representing the club that originally donated the trophy in 1903, won the opening race of the 43d Manhasset Bay Challenge Cup regatta on Long Island Sound off Larchmont Yacht Club today.
STANLEY J. HALLE, celebrating his 50th year in the dog show world, will name the best of 3,422 entries at the 50th Westchester Kennel Club fixture on Sunday.

The riot-torn cities and their quiet, comfortable suburbs often seem separated by invisible but impenetrable walls of apathy and indifference. But much that appears to be apathy is really ignorance. Many genuinely,well-motivated persons are at a loss to know what they can do in an immediate, personal way to reach the slum child or the violence-prone teen-ager or the family in the city that is of another color and another cultural background.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 6 (AP) Fred Stolle of Australia defeated Andres Gimeno of Spain, 6-1, 6-2, tonight in the final of the $14,000, Transvaal Province professional tennis chamnionship.

BONN, Sept. 6 Chancellors Kurt Georg Kiesinger told the West German Bundestag, or lower house of Parliament, today how his Governments planned to eliminate a $16billion federal budget deficit and at the same time revive the somewhat limp national economy.

GENEVA, Sept. 6 UNCTAD, the champion of the poor countries, and GATT, which some of them consider an agency of the rich, announced today their plans to join in promoting the exports of the underdeveloped regions of the world. They made their announcements at a meeting of the United Nations Trade Board in the Palais des Nations, which houses the rival agencies.
ADEN, Sept. 6 (Reuters) At least 20 persons were reported killed in heavy fighting during the last three days between the two Arab nationalist groups vying for power in South Arabia.

MONTREAL, Sept. 6 Now it is the turn of the Vienna State Opera in Montreal. This famous company, appearing for the first time in the Western Hemisphere, opened its run last night at the Salle Wilfrid Pelletier as part of the Expo 67 entertainments.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 6 Senator Robert F. Kennedy flew here from his Cape Cod summer home today to take a look at some of the problems that generated two nights of disturbances in late July.

Cedok, the Czechoslovak Government's travel bureau, said yesterday that it would continue to run its regular tours to sites of historic Jewish interest in Czechoslovakia during the next year's 1,000th anniversary of Judaism in that country.
Sporadic incidents of bottle throwing erupted again last night in the tense Brownsville section of Brooklyn.

Kathrene Pinkerton, who wrote high-spirited stories about life in the North Woods and venturesome cruises in a 50-foot boat, in addition to a dozen children's books, died yesterday of cancer at the New York Infirmary. She was 80 years old and lived at 626 East 20th Street.

VICHY, France, Sept 6 After late-summer weeks of a campaign unusual in Harvard rowing history, and after a couple of defeats, the Crimson eight-oared varsity is here for its most important contest since the four-mile race with Yale in June.

Earnings of the Firestone fire and Rubber Company fell sharply in the three-month and pre-month periods ended July ,it was reported yesterday Akron, Ohio. Firestone attributed the de nes to a 91-day strike which shut down most of the com any's domestic plants. The dis ite began April 21 and ended July 20.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 6 The engagement of Miss Mary Ann Harrold to Ens. Malcolm Davis Johnson, U.S.N.R., has been announced by her parents, Mrs. Johnson Harrold and Frank W. Harrold. Ensign Johnson is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Johnson.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 6 Rutgers staged its first spring practice drills in 13 years when the Scarlet Knights spent eight days in two-a-day workouts last June. Players and coaches feel that this has put the team well ahead of schedule during the current preseason practice sessions.

DETROIT, Sept. 6 (UPI) Earl Wilson hit a two-run homer in the seventh inning that enabled him to become the first 20-game winner in the major leagues tonight as the Detroit Tigers won the second game to sweep a double-header from the Kansas City Athletics, 8-5 and 6-3.

GANDER, Nfld., Sept. 6 (AP) The 36 survivors of the crash of a Czechoslovak airliner were reported to be in serious condition today in hospitals in Gander, Montreal and Halifax. Investigators were searching the wreckage for clues to the cause of the crash, Gander's worst air disaster.
The appointment of Gustave L. Bowen as vice president in charge of passenger sales and promotion for the Incres Line was announced yesterday.
The world's two largest electric-power-equipment makers said yesterday they planned to build two large plants in South Carolina at a total cost of $60million.

Robert V. Roosa, former Under Secretary of the Treasury for monetary affairs in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, cautiously endorsed yesterday the plan for international monetary reform agreed on two weeks ago in London.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 The engagement of Miss Ellen Hauge Abelson to John Charles Cherniavsky has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Philip Hauge Abelson of Philadelphia and Washington. Mr. Cherniavsky is the son of Dr. and Mrs. John Cherniavsky of Milford, Conn.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 6 Rumania's continuing refusal to label Israel an aggressor delayed for more than 18 hours a joint communiqu after a conference of Eastern European leaders that ended here today.

TOKYO, Sept. 6 "Fiddler on the Roof" received an enthusiastic welcome here today, although some purists in the audience may have thought that the original Yiddish expressions lost something in translation.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 The Federal Government's first series of grants to strictly experimental theater was announced today by the National Endowment for the Arts.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 6 (UPI) James P. Finnegan, former Collector of Revenue here, died today of a heart ailment. He was 66 years old.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Sept. 7 Major fight- ing erupted again last night and this morning in the Queson Valley, south of Danang, where United States marines have been battling North Vietnamese regulars.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 6 (UPI) Crowds cheered as the champaign bottle swung, by Lady Erskin crashed against the Myrina, the largest ship ever built in Europe.

The St. Louis Cardinals and the top four teams in the American League Minnesota, Boston, Chicago and Detroit received permission yesterday to print World Series tickets. Authority was given by William D. Eckert, the commissioner of baseball.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UPI) The Administration in a surprise move sought today resumption of negotiations in the eight-week strike against the nation's major copper producers.

DAHIRIYA, Jordan, Sept. 6 One of the busiest spots in the Middle East today is a temporary police checkpoint on the edge of this rocky garrison town near the border of occupied Jordan. From early morning until dusk a procession of taxis, trucks and buses stops, here, bulging with residents of the Gaza Strip.
In some of the harshest language he has used against the Federal Government, Mayor Lindsay accused it yesterday of not providing sufficient aid to the nation's cities.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 7--New information gathered by intelligence officials indicates that enemy military strength in South Vietnam is much below the figure of 297,000 men heretofore thought to be in the country.
TRENTON, Sept. 7--A member of Gov. Richard J. Hughes's Migrant Labor Task Force disputed today the official approval given to migrant labor camps by state inspectors.
A number of price rises were announced yesterday on several widely used chemicals.
Dr. James A. Perkins, president of Cornell University, has been elected to the board of the Chase Manhattan Bank.

THE girls in their American summer dresses dropped in at Bergdorf Goodman yesterday to see the store's fall imports. The second-floor salon is one of the last remaining places in the United States that reproduces couture imports line for line, seam for seam and price for price at the custom-made ...

PACIFIC PALISADES, Calif., Sept. 7--Henry Miller, whose literary reputation rests largely on books he wrote when he lived on the poor side of Paris in the 1930's, plans to return to the Left Bank this month--as a painter and as a bridegroom for the fifth time.

The Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday a rise of 17 per cent in per-share earnings for the second quarter, making it the largest second quarter in the company's history.

The rise in world sugar future prices continued yesterday. On the way up customers of commission houses bought, apparently to even out short positions. Based mostly on the strength in sugar futures, the spot price was raised yesterday to 1.65 cents a pound, up about 8 points from Wednesday level of 1.57. There was a bid at that level for a cargo, but no transaction was announced.
Pennsylvania sold $75-million of bonds yesterday in a financing regarded as the key to tax-exempt bond market trends this week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7--Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said today that the Pentagon's campaign to end housing discrimination against Negro servicemen was being expanded to cover the entire nation.

Fifteen hundred nonteaching members of the school system are being directed to report to district superintendents for schoool assignments Monday in case of a mass "resignation" which the teachers' union says will involve 31,000 of 55,000 teachers.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 7 (UPI)--President Johnson said today he hoped for a "prompt and satisfactory" settlement of the United Automobile Workers strike against the Ford Motor Company. But he stayed out of the dispute.
Harris, Upham Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday the election of Howard C. Gorst and John H. Libaire as vice presidents and directors.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 7--Fourteen young women were presented tonight at the fourth annual Debutante Ball of the Junior League of Greenwich at Mr. and Mrs. Julius Manger's home here. Mrs. Thomas F. Hodgeman and Mrs. George Hardin Brown were chairman and vice chairman, respectively, for the event, a benefit for the league's Community Trust Fund.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7--The Nixon for President forces openly attacked Gov. George Romney of Michigan today for "a lack of ability to handle some of the issues he has encountered" in foreign and domestic affairs.

LONDON, Sept. 7--The Labor Government, committed to seek British entry into the European Common Market, was spared today the possible embarrassment of having the Trades Union Congress come out against the bid to join the Con- tinent.

Perhaps the chief benefit to be hoped from the antiinfiltration wall the United States plans to build across the top of South Vietnam is that it will cause President Johnson to abandon the futile bombing of the North and thus improve the chances for a negotiated peace.
MOST interior designers have known for the be ginning that they wanted to be in that field or one fairly close to it, such as textiles, furniture or architecture.
Msgr. Edward R. Martin, former chief chaplain of the First Army who was twice decorated, for heroism and meritorious service, died Wednesday at the age of 74 after suffering a series of strokes.

The thousands of companies that supply the Ford Motor Company with parts and materials are facing varying degrees of difficulties in the wake of the strike against the nation's second largest car maker.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 7--Mrs. John Parmenter Cluett has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Amanda Rockwell Cluett to Robert Bowen Fry of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Edward Fry of Radnor, Pa.
TEL AVIN, Sept. 7--Israeli troops exchanged fire with Jordanian Arab Legionnaires in two incidents across the Jordan River this morning, according to a statement issued here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7--Administration officials see little prospect of getting the United Nations Security Council to call for a cease-fire in the war in Vietnam and a peace conference on Southeast Asia.

RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 7-- State Representative Arthur H. Jones of Charlotte said today that the suggestions of Father Drinian and Mr. Young were "as far from the truth as it is possible to get."
Some 150 Negro policemen were deployed last night on the streets of a Brownsville neighborhood that had been shaken by sporadic incidents of violence since Monday night.
The appointment of Julio O. Mello as vice president for operations of American Export Isbrandtsen Lines was announced yesterday.

BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., Sept. 7--An arsonist who specializes in setting fire to houses along the Chestnut Ridge path of interstate Highway 87, now under construction, is causing deep concern among residents of the towns of Bedford and North Castle.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 7 (UPI)--The merger of the United Soccer Association and the National Professional Soccer League is expected to be announced tomorrow, following a meeting of the two rival leagues's boards of directors in Chicago.
DENVER, Sept. 7 (UPI)--The Western Athletic Conference, expanded to eight schools today with the admission of Colorado State University and the University of Texas at El Paso.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Sept. 7--Informed delegates were generally skeptical today that the United Nations could promote an international peace conference on Vietnam along the lines suggested here by the United States.

The Hunter College concert bureau, which sponsors more than 100 events a season, will set aside five per cent of the seats in its Assembly Hall and Playhouse for sale only on the day of a performance.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 7--The agenda of the 22d General Assembly, which is scheduled to open on Sept. 19, was made public here today.
The Georgia-Pacific Corporation, a producer of forest products, announced yesterday the election of John F. Watlington Jr. as a director.
The strike of 160,000 Ford workers has begun without any real exercise by either side of the process known as collective bargaining.

EATONTOWN, N.J., Sept. 7 --James E. Powers, a public relations man and a former reporter for The New York Times, died at the Jersey Shore Medical Center yesterday after a long illness. He was 68 years old and lived on Route 35, Eatontown.
The electricity index, a component of The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activity, fell to 529.9 on Thursday from 542.9 a week earlier. A year earlier it was 529.8.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP)--The United States trade surplus with the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe increased to $18.2-million during the first quarter of this year. A record level of imports was more than offset by a 20 per cent jump in exports.
WARSAW, Sept. 7--Presi dent de Gaulle heaped praise on Poland today and exhorted her to play a greater role in helping solve European problems.
NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 7-- Joseph E. Gagan, a Haverstraw lawyer, died today at the Veterans Hospital in Castle Point. He was 48 years old and lived at 18 Brookside Avenue in South Nyack.
ADEN, Sept. 7--The Britishtrained army of the Federation of South Arabia acted today to enforce its demand for a truce between two rival nationalist groups.

HONG KONG, Sept. 7 --Western analysts of Chinese political affairs think that decisions reached by the leadership of the Cultural Revolution in Peking during the last week mean a protracted continuation of Mao Tse-tung's campaign to purge China of revisionist policies, ideas and officials.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Sept. 7--Encircled United States marines, wearing gas masks against a barrage of tear gas shells, turned back a North Vietnamese bayonet charge early today as the battle near a hamlet 32 miles south of here entered its fourth day.
Whatever happened to Arnold Zenker? That question has been asked since the end of the 13day television strike in April Now, there's an answer.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7-- American officials reported today a slight thaw in United States relations with the Arab world growing out of the Arab conference at Khartoum last Week.

CARLISLE, Pa., Sept. 7--A Pennsylvania judge dismissed today the controversial libel suit of Miss Helen Clay Frick against a noted historian. Miss Frick had accused the historian of defaming the memory of her late father, the Pittsburgh "coke king" and art collector, Henry Clay Frick.
The identity of the 19-yearold hippie who was badly beaten in Central Park Wednesday and whose 15-year-old "wife" was raped was still undetermined last night.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 7--Mr. and Mrs. Franz Schager of New York, Oyster Bay and Sagaponack gave a dinner dance tonight at their Oyster Bay home, Eckartsau, in honor of their debutante daughter, Miss Francesca Florence Waring Schager.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Sept. 7 (UPI)--A biological research laboratory carrying thousands of insects and plants soared into orbit today on a three-day flight to see what biological risks men may take on long journeys into space.

Rafael Osuna made his exit from the United States grass court tennis championships yesterday, a parting sorrowful for the 7,000 in the Forest Hills Stadium who saw the graceful Mexican touch-artist's comeback from far behind founder in the fifth set against the greater might of Owen Davidson.
DETROIT, Sept. 7--A chrome-swept silhouette that was a styling favorite 10 years ago has been revived by the Buick division of General Motors for some of its 1968 models.

BOSTON, Sept. 7--Jim Lonborg pitched the Boston Red Sox into second place tonight in the game of musical chairs being played by the four American League pennant contenders. He held the New York Yankees to three hits and scored his 19th victory of the season, 3-1.

A dozen New Rochelle mothers, wheeling infants in strollers while they played detective, helped in tracking and exposing "Westchester's largest and most sophisticated policy ring." United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau said yesterday.

GENEVA, Sept. 7--The 55member board of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development gave its unanimous approval tonight to the agenda of the conference to be held in New Delhi next February for the benefit of the developing countries.
The city antipoverty program intends to expand its family planning efforts in the hope of eventually reaching 100,000 women a year.
The wholesale commodity price index maintained on Wednesday the level it reached on Tuesday, which was 96.1.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7--A Federal judge changed his mind today on a school decision in time to let 255 students attend the schools of their choice on opening day tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) --The Internal Revenue Service will indirectly help businessmen, home owners and insurance companies cover part of their losses from riot damages this year.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 7San Francisco was designated yesterday as the permanent home of the American Conservatory Theater.
HARTSDALE, N.Y., Sept. 7 --Voters in two racially unbalanced school districts elected a single merged board of education tonight--15 years after merger talks began.

Vincent D. McDonnell, State Mediation Board chairman, disclosed yesterday that cleaners and maintenance employes at Gimbals department store outlets in the metropolitan New York area had unanimously rejected a tentative contract agreement.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 7--The marriage of Miss Eden Force, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Force of New York, to Robert H. Eskin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Eskin of Hewlett, L.I., took place this afternoon. Rabbi Barry H. Greene of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun of Essex County performed the ceremony in the South Orange Chapel of the Congregation.
Nine girls, 11 to 15 years old have escaped from Youth House detention facilities in the Bronx.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 7-- A sparkling afternoon of bright skies and 15-knot southwesterly wind was enjoyed today on Rhode Island Sound by half a dozen 12-Meter yachts, all bent on improving themselves for serious conflict ahead.
F. LEE BAILEY, the defense lawyer who has not been adverse to trying his cases on television, crossed the line last night that separates the competent inquisitor from the bland in terviewer.
Twenty-five hundred members of the delegate assembly of the United Federation of Teachers voted last night to reject a contract settlement proposed by the Board of Education.

LIMA, Peru, Sept. 7 (Reuters) --president Fernando Belaunde Terry swore in a new Cabinet today in an attempt to heal growing dissension in his Popular Action party and strengthen hiS Government in the face of mounting opposition.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7--Intercity truck tonnage in the week ended Sept. 2 was 4.8 per cent below the volume in the corresponding week of 1966.

Mrs. Spencer R. Hershey of Bloomfield Village, Mich., and Thomas A. Rogers of Pompano Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gayle Rogers, to Joseph E. Thompson of New York, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward Charles Thompson of Champaign, Ill.

The Packard-Bell Electronics Corporation yesterday in Los Angeles reached an agreement in principle to merge with the Telex Corporation, a producer of hearing aids, phonographs and electronic components.
The city will curtail its offpeak Staten Island ferry schedule and put other economies into effect beginning Sept. 17 to offset part of the expected increase in the service's annual deficit.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7(UPI) --A new weekly newspaper, The Washington Examiner, printed its first edition today.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Sept. 7--Jim Miller and his 1966 Boston College Eagles had expected a fine football season. The squad was big, deep and talented, but the Eagles floundered to a 4-6 won-lost mark, the first losing season in Miller's coaching career.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (UPI) --The Johnson Administration admitted complete failure today in attempts to revive negotiations in the eight-week strike against the big four copper producers. Labor Secretary W. Willard Wirtz said both sides were "deplorably far apart."
ALBANY, Sept. 7--A small ray of sunshine has pierced the gloom shrouding the state lottery as early returns from August ticket sales indicate a distinct improvement over the July performance. A sur

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.
Dr. Leslie A. Fiedler, the novelist and critic who was arrested on a narcotics charge in his Buffalo home last May, could lose the house as a result of the case, his lawyer said yesterday.

A former state secretary of the Communist party has paid for ah advertisement contending that the party's national committee has "adopted a resolution completely withdrawing the charges used as a basis for my expulsion from the party three years ago."

AUBURN, Ala., Sept. 7 (UPI) --A spurned suitor was accused of killing three girls and wounding the mother of his former girl friend early today. The police said that the accused slayer, identified as Edward Albert Seibold 21 years old, fled from the House.
Too Bald bounced back into the victory column yesterday, winning Aqueduct's feature race of 11-16 miles on the turf by five lengths over Forty Merry's of the North Forty Stable.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 7-- Dr. Nureddin al-Attassi, the Syrian head of state, was reported here to have been reelected secretary general of the ruling Socialist Baath party.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 7 (UPI)--Soviet-built jet planes bombed the suspected headquarters of rebel forces in the breakaway Eastern region today a Government spokesman said.
The case of the reluctant angels will be playing backstage all over Broadway this season as new musicals start out with the grudging financial support of record companies.

BALDWIN, L.I. Sept. 7--A biology teacher at Baldwin Senior High School accused of molesting a girl student took a lie detector test and "answered all relevant questions truthfully and honestly" in denial of the charges, a defense lawyer said today.
ALBANY, Sept. 7--The state failed today to sell $46.6-million in State University construction.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Sept. 8--Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Van Thieu said today that he would offer North Vietnam a bombing pause after officially assuming office as President of South Vietnam about Oct. 1. He stressed that there would be no pause unless Hanoi showed some sign of reciprocation.
SOME players fail to make sufficient allowance for the fact that their partners have bid "under pressure." This occurs most often after jump overcall, as in the diagramed auction.

BONN, Sept. 7--The Government sharply reduced its subsidies to West German newspapers and periodicals during the first eight months of the coalition Government's rule, a senior official reported today.
TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 7-- The Iranian Constituent Assembly designated Empress Farah today to rule over Iran as regent if the Shah, her husband, should die.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 7 (AP)-- Tony Oliva hit a tie-breaking double in the eighth inning and scored on Bob Allison's single, carrying the Minnesota Twins to a 4-2 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight.
Removal of rent controls from apartments renting at $250 a month or more will not begin until the autumn of 1968, at the earliest, City Rent Administrator Frederic S. Berman announced yesterday.

DETROIT, Sept. 7 (AP)--A nationwide strike of the Ford Motor Company and the Labor Day holiday cut auto producthis week to 115,585, the trade publication Automotive News said today. Last week's production was more than 24,000 higher.
Twenty-three top-echelon jobs, in addition to the $35,000a-year Administrator, were formally created yesterday by Mayor Lindsay to operate the new Housing and Development Administration.

SANTAGO, Chile, Sept. 7-- Chile has not experienced a military coup d'etat in 40 years, and virtually all Chileans are proud of it. But the Government of President Eduardo Frei Montalva argued for the second day yesterday before the Chilean Supreme Court that the right-wing National party last month seditiously tried to set the stage for one.
Money continued to be easy during the week ended Wednesday, banking statistics issued yesterday indicated, but there was a suspicion that the pace of monetary expansion might be slowing down a bit.
The 26-story Beverly Hotel at 557 Lexington Avenue, northeast corner of the avenue and 50th Street has been purchased by Frederick Dreier, hotel operator.
Two 700-pound female whales captured in Hudson Bay Aug. 28 by a team from the Bronx Zoo arrived here last night in a chartered C-46 transport plane.

Then there's the story of the Italian photographer on the tug sailing down the bay to meet the world middleweight champion. A light plane with rudder painted red, white and green was circling the Italian liner Raffaello with a BENVENUTO BENVENUTI banner in tow.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7-- Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara announced a decision today to Construct a barrier of barbed wire, mines and electronic devices along the northern border of South Vietnam.

Edgar N. Bronfman, whose purchase of 420,000 shares last month of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc. may make him the key figure in the company, outlined yesterday a few of his plans for the future and related some of the details regarding his entry into the motion picture industry.

THE Columbia Broadcasting system had a pretty good half-hour "adult" Western on "Cimarron Strip" last night. Unfortunately, the new series runs 90 minutes and this particular episode was notably short on plot.
Earnings of Holiday Inns of America, Inc., in fiscal 1967 were 41 per cent higher on a 32 per cent increase in revenues, it was announced yesterday in Memphis, Tenn.
The American Stock Exchange ended on the fence yesterday in active trading.
DETROIT, Sept. 7--Negotiators strove without success today to settle teachers strikes that have delayed the opening of school for nearly 500,000 Michigan students.
A $1,679,940 program to restore a number of rundown areas of Prospect Park is beginning to take shape, one year after the park's centennial celebration.
SAIGON, South Vietnam Sept. 7--Two American soldiers were executed by the Vietcong after their squad was ambushed 26 miles east of Saigon Tuesday, a United States military spokesman said today.

LAKESIDE, Conn., Sept. 7-- A series of minor injuries, some of which kept players out of practice, hit Columbia's team in preseason training today, but most of the injured are expected to be back in action by the weekend.
The spot rate on the British pound gained three points to $2.7850 in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.
MAHWAH, N.J., Sept. 7-- Automobile workers who went on strike last night at the Ford Motor Company plant here will receive their weekly pay checks from the company tomorrow.

VICHY, France, Sept. 7 (AP) --Larry Hough and Tony Johnson, a pairs combination from the Potomac Boat Club, scored the only victory for the American forces today as the Harvard eight finished second to West Germany in the heats of the European rowing championships.
THE crated bathtub weighed a bulky 175 pounds. The workmen couldn't budge it, to the annoyance of Bob Brown who decided to move it inside his new home himself.

MONTREAL, Sept. 7--United States railroads could get along with 200,000 fewer employes and save $2-billion a year if they applied automation to their management and operations, a railroad executive said today.

Paid lobbyists who appear before the City Council, the Board of Estimate, the City planning Commission and the Mayor would have to be registered with the city under a bill filed by a Councilman with the Council Clerk yesterday.
Twelve of the nation's leading chain stores sharply increased sales in August--half of them to record levels--according to figures released yesterday.
Rear Adm. Ralph E. Westbrook U.S.N., retired, died of cancer Wednesday in the Naval Hospital in St. Albans, Queens. He was 62 years old and lived at 450 East 63d Street.
Allan Schmelz, wearing his brand-new Mets' uniform, walked onto the mound and into the record books at Shea Stadium yesterday.
NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 7 (AP) --Thomas W. Young, a publisher here, died of a heart attack yesterday in a Norfolk hospital. He was 58 years old.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (UPI) --The Office of Economic Opportunity Said today its own investigation of recent rioting showed that antipoverty workers heled stop, not start, trouble in the cities.
The appointment of James H. Biggart as a vice president of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., has been announced by the real estate company.
A 36-year-old law that requires entertainers in cabarets and dance halls to carry official identification cards seems likely to be repealed by the City Council when it meets Tuesday.
A disgruntled man's challenge of the constitutonality of the Social Security Act, because it appeared to him to favor women, was dismissed yesterday.

The textile industry, which was recently suffering from heavy inventories and fluttering prices, is emerging from its own private recession, according to Robert A. Bendheim, president of M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc.
RICHMOND, Sept. 7--Gov. Mills E. Godwin Jr. today ordered the extradition to Maryland of H. Rap Brown, youthful black power leader indicted there on charges of arson and inciting a riot.

THE program with an instant box-office title, "The Flying Nun," looks headed for a downdraft. The idea of doing a situation comedy about a sprightly novice in and around a Puerto Rican convent is strong on novelty value and not without considerable possibilities for obtaining winning qualities of amusement and charm; these potential values are still there.

Paper Handlers Local 1 and the Publishers Association of New York City reached agreement last night on a new threeyear contract, making the union the fifth of the 10 newspaper unions to settle with the association.

The Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Katherine Quittner Manheim, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Joseph Manheim of 2 East 88th Street and Redding Ridge, Conn., to Christopher Worrall Ryan. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fortune Peter Ryan of New York and Murray Bay, Que., and a greatgrandson of the late Thomas Fortune Ryan, the financier.
The Boy Scout Councils of Greater New York have announced the appointment of David L. Yunich, president of Macy's, as general chairman of the 1968 fund drive.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 7-- Thomas D'Alesandro 3d won the Democratic nomination for Mayor tonight by a landslide over Peter G. Angelos, his major opponent.
The Metropolitan Opera hash added to this season's roster nine more singers who have not appeared with the company before.
PANAMA, Sept. 7--Vociferous opposition to new treaties between the United States and Panama regarding the Panama Canal has caused considerable delay in signing and ratifying them.

The Congress of Racial Equal ity chapter in Brooklyn announced yesterday it would stop fighting the traditional civil rights-type battles in which the organization has been engaged for several years and "shall in the near future retire to the positions of our forefathers--back to the soil."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7-- About 150 white mercenaries in the Congo were reported today to have seized the abandoned United States consulate building in Bukavu, the mercenary stronghold on the eastern border.
A team that will be called the New Jersey Americans, playing home games in the 5,000-seat Teaneck Armory, will be the metropolitan area's entrant in the new 11-team American Basketball Association.
DETROIT, Sept. 7--The Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers prepared for a long and costly battle as pickets marched today at 101 Ford plants and parts depots in 25 states.

Yeshiva University announced yesterday that it is offering a new master's degree program this fall to train teachers for Jewish secondary schools. The program will be conducted by the religious education department of the university's Ferkauf Graduate School of Humanities and Social Sciences.
The Hamilton Watch Company of Lancaster, Pa., announced yesterday that its board had approved a plan to sell 320,000 of its common shares to the Bush Terminal Company.
DOWNERS GROVE, Ill., Sept. 7 (AP)--Ten persons, including five children, were killed tonight in the fiery collision of a station wagon and a car just west of this village in northeast, Illinois.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 7--Pat Mucci of Preakness Hills Hills and William McCracken of Suburban took the lead today in the New Jersey State Golf Association's ninth annual senior and pre-senior championships at the Rock Spring Club.
STONY BROOK, L.I., Sept. 7--Members of the United States Equestrian Team scored victories in the first two jumping event s as the North Shore Horse Show opened today.

WHEN Japan's Premier, Eisaku Sato, was a child, his mother, Moyo Sato, a strong-minded woman proud of her family traditions, made it clear to him and his two brothers that she expected more than mediocrity from them. "Never forget," she told them, "that we are of samurai

NAPLES, Italy, Sept. 7 (AP) --Willy Kuhweide of West Germany won the fourth race in the six-event Finn Class European sailing championships and took the lead today in the standing with a low score of 15.7 points.
IN the frothiness of recent cross-currents in the stock market, the odd-lotter has remained remarkably consistent by selling more stock than he is buying in lots of under 100 shares.

The Democratic judicial convention for Brooklyn and Staten Island is reported likely to nominate Representative Abraham J. Multer today for the vacancy on the Supreme Court bench left by the death of Justice Victor Anfuso. His nomination would be deplorable.

A woman died--apparently of heart failure--and 30 others were injured yesterday when a Transit Authority bus swerved to avoid hitting a boy and crashed into the rear of a truck parked in south Brooklyn.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Sept. 7--Mayor Anthony B. Flask declared a state of emergency today in this northeastern Ohio steel city of 170,000 persons when 90 per cent of the police and firemen refused to report for work.

Richard J. Mulhern, president of the Boston Maine Corporation, was reassured yesterday that for the present at least there will be no change in the top management of that holding company or of the B. M. Railroad, which it owns.
ROME, Sept. 7--Pope Paul VI was reported to be resting today in his Vatican apartment, his temperature back to normal. He suddenly returned from his summer residence last night with a slight fever.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Sept. 7-- Mrs. William Mudge and George Gennity of Nassau Country Club scored a 37, 35--72 today and won the low gross award in the Women's Cross County Golf Association's 18th annual charity tournament. The contest was played over the par-72, 6,460-yard North Shore Country Club course.
After months of planning and waiting, the Economic Development Council's ad campaign to sell New York to New Yorkers and then to the rest of the world breaks Monday.
Senator Jacob K. Javits proposed yesterday the creation of a 21-member national commission, including 10 members of Congress, to re-evaluate the position of the United States in Vietnam.

AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 7-- Major international oil companies urged the Texas Railroad Commission today to cut back September oil production because of the easing of the Arab embargo on shipments to the United States and Britain, and the commission trimmed back 180,500 barrels a day, backdated to Sept. 1.

Dr. Abraham Geltzer, a dentist here for 44 years, died of a pulmonary infection in his home in Riverdale, the Bronx, Tuesday. He was 68 years old and lived at 3530 Henry Hudson Parkway. His office was at 30 East 42d Street.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy, asserting that a "maze of loopholes" was permitting too many Americans to "escape their fair share of the cost of shaping our nation's destiny," called last night for total reform of the Federal tax system.
Miss Silvia E. Tortorelli Valente and John Gilbert Ogilvie have made plans to be married this November in Rio de Janeiro.
Exporters using the Port of New York will no longer be able to use its more than 350 piers as cost-free warehouses, the New York Terminal Conference announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7--A leading Roman Catholic opponent of liberalizing abortion laws suggested today that some recent legislation in that direction might have had racial overtones.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 7--The marriage of Miss Joyce Lampell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andr Lampell of New York, to Daniel Kurz took place here this evening. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Israel Kurz of White Plains.
ALBANY, Sept. 7--The Constitutional Convention gave final approval today to a proposed suffrage article that gives the Legislature power to lower the voting age to as low as 18 in future years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7--A panel of Presidential advisers called today for the creation of an educational opportunity bank to permit students to finance the full cost of their college education against a pledge to repay out of their future earnings over a period of 40 years.

DETROIT, Sept. 7--A veteran of 24 years with the Ford Motor Company stood today outside a plant gate at nearby Dearborn today and gestured defiantly at the company's 400block Rouge manufacturing complex behind him.

CALCUTTA, India, Sept. 6-- Mr. and Mrs. Kishan Babu and their two children live at a respectable address on Central Avenue here, the site of a middle-class apartment house. But they would not normally be considered either respectable or middle-class, for they live outside, on the sidewalk.

PERHAPS the time has come to shed a compassionate tear for Vince Lombardi, the maestro of the Green Bay Packers and the supposed lord of all he surveys. Vince's invincibles will conclude their exhibition season in Green Bay tomorrow by playing the slightly vincible New York Giants.

WASHINGTON, Sept, 7 (Reuters)--An Australian admirer of George Lincoln Rockwell, the American Nazi leader who was slain last month, was ordered deported today after saying thahe illegally took a job her while on a visitor's visa to fight "the corrupt system" in the United States.
The NATO Secretariat has concluded a discreet but intensive study of defense preparations to insure that no allied defense plan could, if misused, facilitate an internal coupd d'etat.
MADRID, Sept. 7--The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development has cautioned Spain that the cost of living in this country is rising at "an unacceptably high rate."
NEW HAVEN, Sept. 7--Wells H. Barnett Jr., a radio advertising executive, died here yesterday morning at Yale New Haven Hospital. He was 50 years old and had been ill with cancer for more than a year.

Benefits amounting to nearly $15-million were paid to members of the National Maritime Union in 1966.

Stock prices traced an irregular course yesterday as investors tried to gauge the impact of the strike against the Ford Motor Company and a renewed call by the Johnson Administration for an increase in income taxes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7--The Justice Department asked the Court of Appeals today to prohibit the merger of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., on the ground that there was no way for the Government to insure the independence of A.B.C. News after the merger.

Dr. Charles J. Walsh, a member of the Fordham University faculty for more than 30 years and chairman of the economics department from 1960 to 1966, died yesterday in his home at 184 Concord. Drive in River Edge, N.J. He was 58 Years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7--The chairman of the Securities and Exchange commission warned the New York Stock Exchange today that it was "already pushing to the danger point" its ability to handle an everincreasing volume of stock trading.

LONDON, Sept. 7--Despite Prime Minister Wilson's economic pyrotechnics last week--his making himself the Cabinet's economic overlord and the relaxation of installment credit--the Government is bracing itself for what one policy maker calls "a bit of misery this winter."

Alger Hiss will deliver a series of four two-hour lectures on "The New Deal: A Lost Era" beginning Oct. 5 at the New School for Social Research. Announcement of the lectures was contained in an advertisement this week.

Some of the Busby Berkeley film musicals that were shown at the Gallery of Modern Art in November of 1965 will return for a 12-day engagement starting Wednesday. Screenings will be given at 3 and 5:30 P.M. Tuesday through Saturday and at 2 end 4 P.M. on Sunday.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Sept. 7 --James Crane of the Noroton Yacht Club won the 19th annual associate member championship of the Junior Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound today for the second straight year.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 7 (AP) --Dr. C.D. Pettaway, president of the National Baptist Convention of America for a decade, unexpectedly resigned today.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 7--About 75 militant Negro youths invaded and vandalized the reception room of Mayor Henry W. Maier this afternoon.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 7 (AP)-- President Joaquin Balaguer dismissed the commanders of the air force and national police today after denying rumors that rightist groups were plotting a coup d'etat against his Government.

NEWARK, Sept. 7--Newark's police director, its police chief and two patrolmen filed a $16.5-million slander suit in Federal District Court today against John W. Smith, the Negro taxicab driver whose arrest on July 12 helped set off five days of riots.

Arnold Cohan, radio and television consultant for former Mayor Wagner and public relations director for the Uniformed Firemen's Association, died of a heart attack yesterday in his home. He was 56 years old and lived at 170 East 77th Street.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7-- The Tariff Commission, by a split 2-2 decision, found today that a domestic industry was being injured by dumped imports of castiron soil pipe from Poland.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7-- Research into the ground obstacles and other devices to be used in an anti-infiltration barrier in Vietnam has been carried out by many organizations for a number of years.

PLANDOME, L.I., Sept. 7-- Dr. Robert W. Culbert, the director of the Bureau of School Health of the New York City Health Department since the bureau's inception in 1948, died yesterday in his home here at 39 North Drive after several months' illness. A pediatrician, he was 69 years old. His office was at 125 Worth Street, New York.
BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Sept. 7 --Two teams tied for the medal today in the qualifying round of the state pro-ladies golf championship at the Forest Hills Field Club.

WESTBROOK, Conn., Sept. 7 --All of the 500 buyers and would-be buyers at today's auction of the Early American collection of the late Katherine Prentis Murphy wanted some token from it, inexpensive or not. So prices were on the high side.

ROCKFORD, Ill. Sept. 7 (AP) --T. Barney Thompson, editor emeritus of The Rockford Register-Republic and The Rockford Morning Star, died today in Rockford Memorial Hospital. His age was 91. He had become ill, apparently from a heart attack, in his office on Aug. 29.
DETROIT, Sept. 7 (UPI)-- The Detroit Pistons signed Sonny Dove, a former St. John's star, to a three-year contract today.
AREA A--Bluefish, up to 15 pounds, began appearing in large numbers Tuesday night on a stretch from the Mud Hole eastward for about six miles. Anglers chummed and drifted to take them.

Congress, now in recess, will resume work next Monday, but for the House Interior Committee this year's session has already ended. As is his peremptory custom, Representative Wayne Aspinall, Democrat of Colorado, and the crusty, long-time chairman of the committee, has announced that the committee will report out no further legislatiion this year.

HAMBURG, Germany, Sept. 7 (AP)--Gunter Grass, the West German novelist, appealed to President Antonin Novotny of Czechoslovakia, in an open letter published today, to "grant freedom of thought" to writers.
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, Ill., Sept. 8--The Arlington-Washington Futurity will be the cornucopia distributing $371,750 among thoroughbred horsemen tomorrow.
LONDON, Sept. 8--The trustees of the Aberfan Disas ter Fund decided today to give 5,000 ($14,000) to the parents of each of the 116 children killed in the disaster last Oct. 21.
CHICAGO, Sept. 8--The Detroit Tigers won the sixth game in their last seven tonight and muscled their way into a tie for first place in the American League by defeating the Chicago White Sox, 4-1.

In his first news conference in six weeks, Secretary of State Rusk said yesterday that he could not offer any "gold-plated guarantees" that Communist China would not interfere in the Vietnam war in retaliation against stepped-up American air attacks.

In 1964, when the Veterans Administration decided to establish a psychiatric research center specializing in the problems of aging, it sought and secured Dr. Cameron to set up and direct the laboratories.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 8-- Democratic leaders of the five counties in the Ninth Judicial District made a strategically strong bid today to elect a Democrat as a State Supreme Court justice, something they have succeeded in doing only once in the last 50 years.
Michael Harrington, the author and social critic, yesterday called proposals to entice privale business into the construction of ghetto housing through government subsidies "illusory."'
Government bond prices declined yesterday, with some intermediate-maturity issues falling as much as half a point.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that both Israel and the Arab states were beginning to recognize "some of the realities" of the situation in the Middle East.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) --The 22 shotguns allocated to Iran under the military assistance program are for riot control, not hunting or shooting clay pigeons, United States officials insist.
AT the New York City Center last night, the City Center Joffrey Ballet gave the first performance of its new production of George Balanchine's "Pas de Dix."
Major capital investment programs were announced by three companies yesterday.
DETROIT, Sept. 8--Pressure mounted on Gov. George Romney today to act in the most widespread teacher strikes ever to grip Michigan.
The smallest cotton crop since 1921 is expected this year, according to the Department of Agriculture. It estimated that the 1967 production ...
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 8-- Flamboyant, who went offstride at the start and forfeited about 15 lengths, rallied to win the $6,000 Class A one-mile trot that topped tonight's card at Roosevelt Raceway.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8--A system that was pat ented this week for the space agency may be used to test the surface of Mars or Venus.
The conductor Bruno Amaducci will make his Metropolitan Opera debut Thursday, Oct. 5, in the sesson's first performance of Verdi's "Falstaff," it was announced yesterday.
The City Housing Authority is withdrawing a request to have a 25-acre industrial site in Middle Village, Queens, rezoned for a mixed-income public housing development.
