Roman Catholic and Protestant spiritual leaders donned skull caps along with their Jewish colleagues yesterday at a special religious service marking the dedication of the International Synagogue at Kennedy International Airport.
Two of the season's debutantes, the Misses Victoria Villa Hamilton and Barbara Briggs Waterman, were honored yesterday.
Members of the United Federation of Teachers voted overwhelmingly yesterday to reject a proposed contract that the city had hoped would avert a threatened mass teacher resignation this morning.

TORONTO, Sept. 10--Robert Lorne Stanfield, the 53-year-old Premier of Nova Scotia, maintained his political batting average of 1,000 last night as he was elected leader of the opposition Progressive Conservative party of Canada.

Miss Elizabeth Flescher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Flescher of 161 West 75th Street, was married here yesterday afternoon to Earl Palay, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Palay of Milwaukee. Rabbi Edward E. Klein performed the ceremony in his Study at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 10 --King Constantine II of Greece, here to see the America's Cup match that starts on Tuesday, made his debut as a 12-Meter helmsman today and the first time out had a chance to match strides with Dame Pattie, the Australian challenger.
BURKETON, Va., Sept. 10 (AP)--A Delaware youth was rescued today from a 50-foot cave shaft near this Augusta County community. He fell down the shaft last night.

The assorted telephone companies of the nation will earn money from the 16 teams of the National Football League today as the clubs make their final roster cuts to 40 players and deal with one another to fill out weaknesses. The New York Giants, faced with a depletion of their linebacking corps, will be up front among the dealing teams.

Perry Robinson, a rarity among jazz musicians today because he devotes himself to the clarinet, introduced his new Uni-Trio on Saturday night in two concerts at the Arts Elast Gallery Theater, 99 East 2d Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10-- Two hundred sixty economists from universities across the nation, including mostly liberals with a sprinkling of conservatives, urged Congress today to act promptly to raise taxes.
ADEN, Sept. 10 (Reuters)-- Rival Arab nationalists used mortars and bazookas today in fighting through the streets of the Sheik Othman suburb of this British colony.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 10--The police fired more than 100 rounds of tear gas at white crowds on the South Side tonight after the largest civil rights march in the city's history.
The Antidefamation League Of B'nai B'rith, in a study made public yesterday, reported that state legislatures achieved a substantial record in civil rights legislation during this year.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 10--"Jack Nicklaus, he too good," said Roberto de Vicenzo of Argentina, the British Open champion, shortly after Nicklaus holed out for a winning score of 144 today in the World Series of golf.
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Monday, Sept. 11 (UPI)--Striking policemen and firemen voted overwhelmingly early today to reject a pay rise proposal described by city officials as their "final offer."
DANZIG, Poland, Sept. 10 president de Gaulle today stepped up his efforts to persuade his Polish hosts to show more independence from the Soviet Union.

LONDON, Sept. 10--The four young music-makers known as the Beatles, objects of Britain's idolatry and scorn in almost equal parts, have postponed the next stage of what they describe as their search for meaning in life.

ALBANY, Sept. 10 (AP)--Edward N. Scheiberling, a former national commander of the American Legion and member of its national legislative committee, died here today at St. Peter's Hospital. He was 79 years old.
VICHY, France, Sept. 10 (AP) --A pair of Virginians stroked to a gold medal and the Harvard eight-oared crew picked up a silver medal today in the European rowing championships.

IF one can easily overlook inept acting, poor direction and incredibly bad writing, then one might be forced to admit that the National Broadcasting Company has something going for it in its new Sunday night Western series, "The High Chaparral." Those who cannot overlook such failings should tune in anyway for an evening of high camp on "The High Chaparral."
AT ANY given moment of the day, William Scach ter may he found weighing feathers, making quilts, custom-blending pillows, discussing the psychology of sleep or sweeping the floor.

Four men were taken into custody at the Coney Island precinct yesterday after four persons had been wounded by rifle fire from a passing car as they stood at West 25th Street and Mermaid Avenue. A fifth man was being sought in the shooting.
Teachers who went to Singer Bowl in Flushing Meadows Park early yesterday afternoon were confronted by a huge sign over the entrance that read, "Strike for Better Schools!"
RICHMOND, Sept. 10 (AP)-- Richard Petty sped to victory today in a rain-threatened running of the Capital City 300 stock car race, but a scoring, muddle held up the final results.

Two United States steamship lines and Brazil's national flag carrier will be the principal defendants in a $72.9-million antitrust suit to begin in the United States District Court in New York tomorrow.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 10 (Reuters)--The provisional National Assembly will investigate 15 complaints made by voters and unsuccessful candidates after the election last Sunday, it was announced today.

The formation of a new concern to deal in the securities of the United States Government and its agencies, the first such action in at least 10 years, was announced yesterday by Philip V. Mohan, founder and president of the new company.
OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 10 (AP)--The Oakland Raiders, in a reversal of form, crushed the Denver Broncos, 51-0, in opening their American Football League season today.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 10--Mr. and Mrs. James S. Robb said tonight that their son, Capt. Charles S. Robb, called from Washington a month ago and told them:

Tug McGraw, the 23-year-old wonder of other years, made his first appearance of 1967 as a Met yesterday after a season of maturation in the minors. For three innings his maturity was untouchable, then the Cincinnati Reds broke through, and eventually won, 5-2.

A knife blade sticking from a man's pocket led two detectives on a routine burglary investigation last night to seize what they described as $50,000 worth of heroin and cocaine and make nine narcotics arrests.

City Council President Frank D. O'Connor said yesterday he was opposed to sending the proposed new State Constitution to the voters in a single package. Instead he called for putting the major controversial issues on the November ballot as separate items.

FORT LEE, N.J., Sept. 10-- Pleasure-boat racing on the Hudson River leaped to new heights today when a 16-foot outboard won the first roundtrip running of the Hudson River marathon at an average speed of 49.1 miles an hour.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 10--The steel recovery was threatened last week by strikes in the automobile industry.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 10 (AP) --Maury Wills drove home two runs with a triple in a four-run eighth inning today and then scored the winning run as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the National League leading St. Louis Cardinals, 8-7.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10--A shiny new $11-million Greyhound terminal was put into operation today to serve longdistance bus riders.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 10 (AP)-- Dave Boswell pitched a fivehitter to give the Minnesota Twins sole possession of first place in the American League today with a 4-2 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

CALCUTTA, India, Sept. 6-- West Bengal's unstable United Front government, in which the left-wing Communists are the most powerful force, is surviving from day to day despite the worst food crisis in recent years.

Without a pause, the New York Cotton Exchange switches to a new trading floor this morning. Workmen over the weekend put finishing touches on its new headquarters at 37 Wall Street, also known by its sidedoor entrance at 43 Exchange Place. The Exchange is one flight up.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 10--Members of the Cleveland Orchestra plan to picket instead of play tomorrow at Severance Hall, the orchestra's home. The 109-player group is expected to refuse to start rehearsals for the season's opening scheduled on Sept. 25.
Take a machine making parts for machines and put it under the direction of a computer console board.
GIBRALTAR, Sept. 10--The people of Gibraltar voted nearly unanimously today to retain their link with Britain rather than return to Spanish sovereignty.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Sept. 10 --Clarence W. Higbee, who retired in 1960 as assistant general manager of the electrical conductor division of Kaiser Aluminum Chemical Corporation, died yesterday in his home, 162 Brite Avenue. His age was 73.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 10 --A greater commitment toward solving the problems of the cities, perhaps patterned after what has been done for the farms, was urged on the nation's universities today.

Physicists make discoveries every now and then which make them wonder whether a perverse nature isn't deliberately confounding their expectations. An outstanding example is the recent creation of mendelevium 258. This is not only the heaviest atom ever definitely identified but also a veritable Methuselah among the newest transuranium elements.
An Arctic anthropologist, once a fullback for Harvard, has captured 15 rare musk ox calves with which he hopes to transform the economy of the poverty-stricken Eskimos of northern Canada.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10--Joe Horlen pitched a no-hit game today as the Chicago White Sox posted a pair of shutouts over the Detroit Tigers and further snarled the four-team race for the American League pennant.
PARIS, Sept. 10--At Notre Dame, the Arc de Triomphe and airfields throughout France this weekend, French airmen saluted the memory of their knight nonpareil of the skies, Georges Guynemer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10-- Gov. George Romney will turn his unannounced campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination toward domestic issues tomorrow as he begins a 19-day tour of the nation's urban slums.

BOSTON, Sept. 10--In businesslike fashion, the Boston Red Sox maintained their position in the middle of the American League's stretch run by battering the New York Yankees, 9-1, at Fenway Park today.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 10 --Ralph L. Evans Jr.'s Escales, a Tripp-30 class yawl out of Norwalk Y.C., was belatedly credited with a victory today in the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's annual cruising race for the Whitmore Trophy. The trophy race was held yesterday on Long Island Sound.
Strains of deep discord are the hidden issue in the school contract dispute here.

John Newcombe of Australia and Mrs. Billie Jean King of Berkeley, Calif., added the United States championship to their Wimbledon titles yesterday and stand indisputably as the monarchs of amateur tennis the world over.
LEWISBURG, Pa., Sept. 10-- The Rev. Dr. Charles M. Bond, emeritus professor of religion at Bucknell University, died today of a cerebral hemorrhage. His age was 78.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Sept. 10-- President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia left today for the conference of the Organization of African Unity at Kinshasa, the Congo, still faced with the danger of resignations from his new Cabinet.

GENEVA, Sept. 10--The success of the Kennedy round assault on trade barriers has raised hopes for a narrowing of the split between Western Europe's rival trade blocs, the European Free Trade Association said today.

The Middle East war last June triggered massive movements of funds in the international money market and equally vigorous countermeasures by central banks to protect the dollar and the pound from attack, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday.

AN extraordinary primer on the way of life of an en tire continent--fascinating and contradictory Africa-- was presented last night by the American Broadcasting Company in a dimension without parallel in television.

Miss Barbara Hemley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Hemley of Woodmere, L.I., was married here yesterday afternoon to Daniel Wohl Rosenn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Rosenn of Kingston, Pa. Rabbi Joseph I. Weiss, the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony at the Plaza.
The New York Metropolitan Council recommended yesterday that the General Post Office be moved from trafficclogged midtown to Harlem.

EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., Sept. 10 (AP)--H. Rap Brown, the black power advocate, told more than 1,000 persons today that they should respond to a call for black nationalism because "we're on the eve of a Negro revolution."

VENICE, Italy, Sept. 10-- Clare Boothe Luce was caught in a traffic jam of motorboats on the Grand Canal last night so she arrived, like most people, more than an hour late for the masked ball at the 17thcentury Palazzo Rezzonico.
MIAMI, Sept. 10--Thousands of men and women are being chosen throughout Cuba to occupy the new posts of "delegates to local administrations."
THE Lightner slam double, requested an unusual lead, has proved its value over and over again since Theodore Lightner of New York introduced it in 1929.
WESTBROOK, Conn., Sept. 10--The antiques collection of the late Mrs. Katherine Prentis Murphy was auctioned last week for $211,400.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Sept. 10 --This summer was Shakespeare's best season on the West Coast, which has never been noted for its enthusiasm for his plays.
RAFAELA, Argentina, Sept. 10 (Reuters)--Eight persons were killed and at least 20 others injured today in three separate accidents during a stock car racing championship.

STANDING lean, relaxed and without serious chal lenge atop the world of amateur tennis at the age of 23, John Newcombe is the newest of Australia's seemingly unending string of court titans who have dominated the sport since the early 1950's.
JUNCTION CITY, Ore., Sept. 10 (AP)--Clifford Ann Creed, hitting into a heavy wind all day, won the Pacific Ladies' Golf Classic by six shots today with a 74 for a five-under-par 211 for the 54 holes.

Weston Merchandising has signed an exclusive 10-year agreement with the Major League Baseball Players Association to the "names, likenesses and signatures of virtually every professional ball player in the National and American Leagues."
The housewife left the supermarket, walked to the family car and, like countless other motorists, found a deep gash in one of the fenders.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 (AP)--Cookie Rojas of the Philadelphia Philiies hit the first grand-slam home run of his six-season career today as the Phillies beat the Atlanta Braves, 10-5.
Pan American World Airways has reported that the number of "no-shows" on its service to San Juan, P.R., was reduced by 33 per cent as a result of a new reservations procedure for that city.
EVERYBODY goes to Hana at Kenneth's," said a woman who gets to many of the parties where "everybody" goes.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 10 (Reuters)--Prime Minister Balthazar J. Vorster announced tonight that South Africa and Malawi would establish diplomatic relations in December.

LAKESIDE, Conn., Sept. 10-- Buff Donelli, Columbia University's cheerful football coach, always has looked at the bright side of the gridiron picture. This season Donelli has some bright prospects to back up his opinions.

District Attorney Jim Garrison of New Orleans, expanding on his earlier charges that former employes of the Central Intelligence Agency were involved in the killing of President Kennedy, has raised to at least seven the number of men he says took a direct part in the assassination.
STONY BROOK, L.I., Sept. 10--Rod Jenkins, the slender professional horseman from Orange, Va., rode two national champions to division titles at the North Shore Horse Show today.

BUFFALO, Sept. 10--The Buffalo Bills beat the New York Jets, 20-17, today when Mike Mercer kicked a 43-yard field goal with nine seconds remaining. That provided a stunning ending to a game in which the Jets turned from the sublime to the near ridiculous, and though this was their season opener, their title hopes in the American Football League's Eastern Division were hit hard.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 10 (AP) Sal Bando drove in two runs with a single and squeeze bunt in leading the Kansas City Athletics to a 5-2 victory over the Cleveland Indians today in the second game of a double-header. The Indians had won the first game, 1-0, on John O'Donoghue's three-hitter.

State Controller Arthur Levitt said yesterday that the manufacturer of three tranquilizing drugs used extensively in the state's mental institutions had agreed to cut the price of the drugs 7 per cent.
Underwriting activity in the corporate bond market will decrease this week, but sales of tax-exempt bonds and Federal agency securities will take up the slack.

ROME, Sept. 10--Pope Paul VI, his face slightly drawn and his voice weaker than usual as a result of his current illness, made his regular Sunday appearance at his palace window at midday today. He blessed thousands in St. Peter's Square below.

DOES television talk too much? Those who might feel that way struck it rich with an hour of virtuoso silence on WOR-TV last night. Marcel Marceau filled the entire hour with his dazzling pantomime, which is great no matter how many times you have seen it before.

HARRISON, N.Y., Sept. 10 --Miss Barbro Sonja Ingrid Juthberg and Stephen Kirschenbaum were married here this evening in the Jewish Community Center of Harrison. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Kerstin Juthberg of Borlange, Sweden, and Erik Juthberg of Stockholm. The bridegroom, whose father was a state assemblyman, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Kirschenbaum of Harrison and New York.
The National Broadcasting Company said last night it had been informed of the imprisonment in Syria of President Nureddin al-Attassi.
Botany Industries, Inc., announced over the weekend the appointment of Henry Schwartz as president of Weber Heilbroner, Inc., a retail division.
Rex Stewart, the jazz cornetist who was a star of Duke Ellington's orchestra for 10 years, died of a heart attack Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 60 years old.
HONG KONG, Sept. 10--Reports from Communist China indicate spreading violence and disorder in the political struggle growing out of Mao Tsetung's Cultural Revolution.

Britain has bowed to the inevitable by officially ending the existence of the Federal Government in South Arabia and recognizing "the nationalist forces" as representatives of the federation's 800,000 inhabitants. WASHINGTON, Sept. 10-- The Senate Antitrust and Monopoly Subcommittee has decided to expand its investigation of the newspaper industry into four specific areas: exclusivity of syndicated features and columns, pricing practices of the wire services, newsprint costs and the demise of The New York World Journal Tribune.
Miss Debra Dene Barnes of Moran, Kan., who had never been east of Chicago before last week, arrived in New York last evening and gaped at the buildings on the midtown skyline.

Mrs. Ann Haydon Jones had been hobbling on her left leg from early in the first set and now, in the fourth game of the second set, she lunged for a shot behind her baseline. Unable to reach it, she collapsed in pain.
ALBANY, Sept. 10--A hearing on the newly effective state statute restricting the use of guns by the police will be held in New York City Sept. 21.

HIGHLAND MILLS, N.Y., Sept. 10--The 21st national convention of the Farband-Labor-Zionist order, which ended today, re-elected Samuel Bonchek as president and Jacob Katzman as national secretary. Both are of New York City.

AN expose of the Mafia and an artfully detailed documentation of the misdeeds of evil men are featured in the latest issue of Life magazine. But the brush that properly smeared them improperly splattered a recent folk hero in sports, Bob Cousy.

TOKYO, Sept. 10--After transferring his activities from the halls of state to the board rooms of worldwide corporations, George Wildman Ball remains very much involved in international relations on the business level.
S. Klein Department Stores, Inc., substantially reduced its deficit in the six months ended July 31, 1967, it was disclosed yesterday by Samuel Neaman, chairman of S. Klein.

DETROIT, Sept. 11--More powerful engines and a wider selection of the higher-priced models of intermediate size were shown today as the Oldsmobile Division of General Motors staged a press preview of its 1968 models.
John Newcombe of Australia, the winner of the United States championship Sunday and holder of the Wimbledon title, received the Martini and Rossi award yesterday as the tennis player of the year.

PEKING, Sept. 11 (Agence France-Press) China delivered "a most serious protest" to India tonight over "criminal armed aggression" against Chinese frontier guards today by Indian troops, Hsinhua, the official press agency reported.

MOSCOW, Sept. 11 Twenty-three years after they were rounded up at gunpoint and herded into exile in Central Asia, half a million Crimean Tatars have been exonerated of a wartime accusation that the entire population collaborated with the Nazi invaders.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 11 A five-day strike by 200 plumbers, electricians and other skilled workers at the University of Michigan has tied up $75-million in campus construction.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy charged the cigarette industry yesterday with "peddling a deadly weapon ... for financial gain." He said he would introduce three bills in Congress today to make up for what he called the industry's ineffective attempts at selfregulation.
The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation unveiled the first design entry yesterday in the American competition to sell the airlines a jumbo, medium-range jet known as an airbus.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Sept 11 Four players, including Pat Schwab of Crestmont the New Jersey open champion, tied for the first-round lead today in the State Professional Golfers' Association championship at the Essex Fells Country Club.
SUMMIT, N.J., Sept. 11 William A. Knoop, a retired Bell Telephone Laboratories engineer, died today in his home at 27 Windsor Road. His age was 76.

DENVER, Sept. 11 The president of the American Mining Congress criticized today a Johnson Administration study proposing legislation to control the surface mining industry. He said the report was "unrealistic and wasteful."
NEW DELHI, Sept. 11--Dr. Triguna Sen, the Education Minister, denied today that the Government was seeking to weaken English as a national language in India.

High winds and waves battered a 42-foot motor-sailboat adirfft in the Atlantic during the night, but the Coast Guard said early today that an Italian tanker had reached the scene and that the five persons aboard were in no immediate danger.

At Joan of Arc Junior High School on Manhattan's West Side a girl student rode an elevator to the sixth floor yesterday morning and said, "Thank you" to the attendant.
The owner of an East Side Italian restaurant was sentenced yesterday to pay $40,000 in fines for income-tax evasion from 1959 through 1962.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Sept. 11 Msgr. Francis J. Williams, administrator of St. Agnes Roman Catholic Cathedral, died last night in the rectory. He was 51 years old.

The first plant to make calcined petroleum coke in Japan will be built at a cost of about $17-million by the Continental Oil Company and two Japanese concerns.

DETROIT, Sept. 11 (AP)--Ford production lines remained idle today because of a strike while General Motors, Chrysler and American Motors were busy turning out 1968 models as debut time for the new cars neared.

CHADDS FORD, Pa., Sept. 11 Mr. and Mrs. Ford B. Draper have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katharine Reeve Draper, to Charles Porter Schutt Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Porter Schutt of Greenville, Del.
ALBANY, Sept. 11 The Democratic leadership of the Constitutional Convention has introduced a proposition that would delay any new constitution from going into effect for a full year.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 11 How many Americans have heard of a remarkable, questing American citizen named Alexander Bryan Johnson, who died in this city 100 years ago at the age of 81? How many scholars know his name, writings and ideas? The answer to both questions: Very few.

At 10 A.M. yesterday, a tall sun-tanned man in a gray business suit appeared on the rostrum above the trading floor of the New York Stock Exchange. He rang the gong as applause burst out on the floor, then he raised his arms in greeting.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 11 Israel sent 354 Egyptian nationals home today.

ADEN, Sept. 11 (Reuters) The two rival Arab nationalist groups struggling for power here agreed tonight to a ceasefire in the Sheik Othman and Mansoura districts of Aden. Their leaders also pledged not to renew fighting in any part of South Arabia.

Lieut. Gen. James M. Gavin, conferred with another prominent Republican yesterday in his campaign to swing the party's Presidential nomination to a candidate committed to de-escalation of the war in Vietnam.
DETROIT, Sept. 11 Resumption of negotiations between the Ford Motor Company and the striking United Automobile Workers Union was put off today until Friday.
NEW HAVEN, Sept. 11 Kingman Brewster Jr., the president of Yale University, urged the freshman class today "to repudiate oversimplification and renom from the left."
MIAMI, Sept. 11 Hurricane Beulah struck the Dominican Republic and then raked southern Haiti with torrents of water and winds up to 105 miles an hour today.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Sept. 11 Mr. and Mrs. Hubert Locke Jackson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Ann Jackson, to David W. Brumbaugh Jr., son of Mr. Brumbaugh of Scarsdale and Pinehurst, N.C., and the late Mrs. Dorothy Seay Brumbaugh. A late fall wedding is planned.

Price rises were posted or planned yesterday by producers of many types of products. Some were following action taken by others in appliances, steel, chemicals and floor coverings. But one, in the field of batteries, was new.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 11 Northeasterly 30-knot winds and big seas chopped up partly by the force of distant Hurricane Doria posed a threat for a while today to tomorrow's start of the world's most distinguished sailing competition a match for the America's Cup.

MUSCLE SHOALS, Ala., Sept. 11 (AP) At least three persons were reported dead tonight in an explosion that trapped an unknown number of persons in the Reynolds Metals Alloys Cast House No. 10 here, company officials said.

Mr. McBee is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Cunliffe McBee of Greenwood.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI) The Supreme Court was asked asked today to decide whether a broadcaster may be compelled to grant free time to persons attacked over his station.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Sept. 11 Colgate's football forces developed a strong and efficient defense in recent, seasons as much through necessity as anything else. Coach Hal Lahar never had the players capable of a strong offense, so defense became the Red Raiders' big weapon.

OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 11 (UPI) Rick Barry, the National Basketball Association's leading scorer last season who jumped to the new American Basketball Association, announced today that he would sit out the 196768 season.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 11 A year ago, in a preseason poll, Harvard was picked to finish in the second division of the Ivy League. That estimation of John Yovicsin's Crimson proved to be a mistake. Harvard won eight of nine games and tied Dartmouth and Princeton for the league title.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (AP) Minnesota Mac, making his first stakes start, rallied in the stretch today to defeat the favored Diplomat Way by a neck in the $78,200 Chicagoan Handicap before a closing-day crowd of 18,446 at Arlington Park.

YOU could almost feel the shock ripples at Bergdorf Goodman yester day when models wearing clothes by Fernando Sanchez pranced about with thin black lines running up the backs of their legs. As far as Mr. Sanchez is concerned, it seems that stockings with seams are back.
DETROIT, Sept. 11 Air conditioners will be standard equipment on 1968 Ambassador automobiles, the American Motors Corporation said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 Retail sales continued their steady advance in August and exceeded $27-billion for the first time, the Commerce Department reported today.
EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., Sept. 11 (AP) The teachers union and the East St. Louis school board reached agreement tonight and a call was issued for pupils to report to the classroom in the morning.

ROME, Sept. 11 (AP) The Vatican announced today that Pope Paul VI, ailing from an inflammation of the urinary system, spent a peaceful night and that his temperature continued normal.
Next week, newspapers throughout North America are going to blossom with ads designed to convince the consumer of the beauties of the American marketing system.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 11 (UPI) Frank Sinatra walked out on his contract with the Sands Hotel here last night because the management "cut off his credit," a spokesman for the singer said today.

The executive board of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People yesterday reaffirmed its support of the Milwaukee N.A.A.C.P Youth Council in its efforts to secure open housing legislation in that city," said Henry Lee Moon, the organization's director of public relations.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 11 Prince Norodom Sihanouk removed two pro-Peking Cabinet ministers today in a crackdown on Communist elements in Cambodia. The Chief of State also suspended all privately operated newspapers, about half of them pro-Chinese.

Louis B. Lundborg, chairman of the board of the Bank of America, said here yesterday that the world hunger problem could be overcome if small farmers in developing countries were shown how to make a profit.

FOR several weeks now, uncertainty about the eco nomic outlook has been mirrored in an indecisive see-saw in stock prices. Just about everybody thinks that business is getting better, that profits ought to turn upward and that consumer spending is on the rise.

Mrs. Helen Rentschler Waldon, widow of Sidney Dunn Waldon, former vice president and general manager of the Packard Motor Car Company who helped design the Liberty airplane motor in World War I, died yesterday in her home at Hamilton, Ohio. Her age was 77.

Captains of industry, labor leaders and an array of United Nations representatives and officials will gather in the Waldorf-Astoria next Tuesday for a black-tie dinner. The sponsor is U.N. We Believe, an organization that seeks commitment from business, industry and labor to the principles of the international organization.
MY mother's ancestry and the whole environment in which her childhood was spent determined most of her personality.

The Norwich Pharmacal Company, maker of pharmaceuticals and proprietary products such as Pepto-Bismol, Unguentine and Nebs, is planning to add liquid detergents and other household chemcials to its business through the acquisition of Texize Chemicals, Inc.
CHICAGO, Sept. 11 A nuclear physicist told a convention of chemists today that it might be possible to create a new group of enormously heavy and perhaps stable artificial elements.
The General Aniline and Film Corporation announced here yesterday the election of Thomas H. Dermody as a vice president.

HONG KONG, Tuesday, Sept. 12 (UPI) Red Guard publications received in Hong Kong today said the leader of the Chinese Communist Army in Canton organized an ambush last month in which more than 150 supporters of Mao Tse-tung, the Communist party chairman, were killed.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 11 The University of Notre Dame, which has been preeminent in undergraduate work and football during its 125-year history, has embarked on a large-scale development of its graduate and research departments.

SADDLE RIVER, N.J., Sept. 11 Mr. and Mrs. Merton Sage Neill have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Campbell Neill, to John Edward Nanorta Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Nanorta of WilkesBarre, Pa.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Sept. 11 Robert M. Raymond of the Whippoorwill Club took a onestroke lead in the Westchester Seniors Golf Association's 33d annual championship today by scoring 37, 38-75 at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club.

The New York Giants dropped five players yesterday and added three defensive men one of them a notable acquisition as the teams of the National Football League collectively cut their rosters for the last time to 40 players apiece.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 King Constantine of Greece called on President Johnson and other high officials today and was urged to help steer his country back toward constitutional procedures.
Carl A. Ilgenfritz, former vice president-purchasing of the United States Steel Corporation, died Saturday in Pittsburgh at the age of 75.
A 62-year-old token seller was shot yesterday evening as two men held him up in his booth in Brooklyn and fled with $78. Five minutes earlier, a cashier in Queens was held up.
Steel production changes were practically nonexistent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) A bill to bring futures trading in coffee and sugar under Federal jurisdiction poses a threat to the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, its president said today.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 11 (AP) Maury Wills's error with the bases loaded and a run-scoring single by Pete Rose in the ninth inning tonight gave the Cincinnati Reds a 4-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 11 Ending a summer of speculation about his intentions, Lieut. Gov. Thomas F. Eagleton announced at a news conference at the Sheraton-Jefferson Hotel here today that he would challenge United States Senator Edward V. Long in the Democratic primary elections next August.

CAMP PENDLETON, Calif. Sept. 11 (AP) Twenty-six marines here were wounded today when a grenade exploded in a grass fire, the Marine Corps said.

A replacement for the $25 frequency crystal whose theft put radio station WBAI off the air over the weekend, arrived here by plane shortly before midnight. It was to be installed as soon as possible, but it was not known when the outlet would be back on the air.

A nonprofit theater program to give actors a grounding in early American plays and to encourage audience interest in them got under way last night with a performance of George Henry Boker's "Francesca da Rimini." It was given at the Library and Museum of the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center.
TRENTON, Sept. 11 Gov. Richard J. Hughes today announced a series of major reforms aimed at eliminating much of the squalor and deprivation in migrant farm worker camps.

Chau Seng's rise to prominence in Cambodia began in 1963, when the country's foreign policy veered sharply to the left. By 1965, the sharpeyed, ambitious psychologist had become the most prominent left-winger and one of the more powerful men in the country.

CAROL BURNETT, whose new show made its debut on the Columbia Broadcasting System last night (Channel 2 at 10 P.M.), is luckier than most of her brothers and sisters in the new situation comedy series. She can, if she so chooses, escape from the cage of banality her Hollywood-based writers have prepared for her.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission today ordered the suspension of overthe-counter trading in the common stock of Jodmar Industries, Inc., of Brooklyn through Sept. 20.

The United Federation of Teachers has demonstrated that it can indeed bring this city's school system "to a grinding halt." Its leaders boast of the union's effectiveness in strangling education at a time when every school day lost aggravates the already tragic handicaps of hundreds of thousands of children.

The son of a former United States Senator and former Governor of Kentucky testified in Federal court here yesterday that he bought substantial amounts of stock in Continental Enterprises, Inc., after being "romanced" by a close business associate of Louis Wolfson.

MONTREAL, Sept. 11 (Canadian Press)--Carl Geiger of Austria won today's race in the week-long series for the world Flying Dutchman sailing championships, with Geoff Smale of New Zealand second and Renaldo Conrad of Brazil third.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 11 The poice prevented a head-on clash between white and Negro marchers tonight, but not without a heated exchange of shouted insults and a windowsnashing barrage of bricks and botles.
LONDON, Sept. 11 (UPI) The International Coffee Council, ending a marathon session today, generally agreed that the four-year-old coffee agreement would be renewed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) President Johnson submitted to the Senate today his nomination of Walter E. Washington, chairman of New York City's housing authority, as Commissioner of the District of Columbia.
LINCOLN, R.I., Sept. 11 (AP) Breaking alertly from the starting gate; Ultra Quick scored a length victory in the Narragansett Pier Purse today at Lincoln Downs.

LONDON, Sept. 11 Anthony Perrinott Lysberg Barber has an attribute that should stand him in good stead as chairman of the Conservative party. He knows from experience how to wrest a marginal constituency from the Laborites.

The practice floor was too slippery, there was no soap in the shower and the laundry dryer wasn't working.

Three hundred youths from Harlem and the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn who have worked in a Government-sponsored program this summer, demonstrated yesterday in front of the United States Parcel Post Building, 341 Ninth Avenue, between 29th and 30th Streets, demanding year-round jobs.
A Criminal Court judge dismissed criminal charges against a Manhattan housewife yesterday arrested for selling antiVietnam war flags, literature and buttons from a sidewalk table.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 11--Chinese troops in Tibet opened artillery fire today across a Himalayan pass on Indian Army positions in Sikkim, according to a Government announcement.

For school opening yesterday, Arthur Crozier was scheduled to start for the first time as a community coordinator for the Board of Education. His task: explaining the schools to the people and reflecting community views back to the board.
The Western railroads currently are in the midst of "a real recession" in their business, according to Jervis Langdon Jr., chairman and president of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad.
TRENTON, Sept. 11 (AP) New Jerseyans go to the polls tomorrow to choose candidates for 120 legislative seats in the November elections.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 There is growing interest in Congress for tax reform as an alternative to the Administration's proposed tax increase.

Marking a new, and more exhausting, era in baseball's player-owner relations, the "prehearing hearing" conducted by Commissioner William D. Eckert yesterday on the Kansas City controversy was adjourned at 9:41 P.M. after nearly 12 hours of discussion. The hearing will be resumed today.
Four of five persons questioned in a Louis Harris survey think that Ronald Reagan is doing a good job as Governor of California, according to a report published in The New York Post yesterday.
ALBANY, Sept. 11 Governor Rockefeller urged the Constitutional Convention today to revise its proposed legislative and Congressional reapportionment system because of "a number of serious defects."

The bell that should have rung loudly at the opening buzzed faintly and the gavel that should have produced a mere whack gave an over-loud boom yesterday. Otherwise trading began as planned in the new quarters of the New York Cotton Exchange at 37 Wall Street.

EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., Sept. 11 (UPI) Negroes smashed windows and hurled firebombs tonight in the second night of unrest that followed a speech last night by H. Rap Brown, the black power advocate.

WHEN Jocko Conlan was an outfielder on the Toledo Mud Hens in 1930, his manager was Casey Stengel, al ready a master of marathon monologues. Day after day in clubhouse meetings Casey would rumble along for three and four hours at a clip. Not only did he entertain his ballplayers but he also instructed them, using gestures and pantomime to demonstrate hitting, fielding, pitching, baserunning and everything else.

Canada's Progressive Conservative party has chosen a new leader who is the very antithesis of his predecessor, John G. Diefenbaker, the colorful, rambunctious, battlescarred veteran of the political wars. At 71, "Dief the Chief" had hoped to retain power and make a dramatic comeback in the next election against the Liberals, but his dreams were decisively shattered by the party rank and file whom he had led so long.
Prices turned down on the London stock market yesterday as a run of selling reversed the recent sustained advance to new high levels for the year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 A three-judge Federal District Court rebuffed today an attempt by the American Civil Liberties Union to have the House Committee on Un-American Activities declared unconstitutional.
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio Sept. 11 (UPI) This steel city's 500 striking policemen and firemen voted today to accept a new wage proposal and end their five-day work stoppage.

MASTIC, L.I., Sept. 11 In this high-geared era of expensive sport fishing boats, elaborate rigged baits, sonar fish finders, multicolored lures and ultrafancy rods and reels, the old rowboat fleet on Moriches Bay still flourishes.

About 275 policemen have taken jobs as taxi drivers in their off-duty hours this summer and, perhaps not just coincidentally, the number of assaults on cabdrivers was reported to have declined 40 per cent.

PRAGUE, Sept. 11 The people here are the best dressed and probably the best fed of any in Eastern Europe and certainly this is the most intellectually stimulating of the capitals. These days it is also one of the most depressed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11(AP) The Pentagon is seeking to assess a penalty of $1.5-million against the contractor for the Navy's F-111B interceptor on the ground that the plane is overweight, Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat of Arkansas, said today.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 11 Two persons were killed and scores injured when the police fired on demonstrators in three widely separated cities of India today.
GIBRALTAR, Sept. 11--A British-Dutch naval task force of 13 ships quietly anchored off Gibraltar at dawn today, hours after this colony had nearly unanimously voted to retain its links with Britain.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 11 (AP) A group of sign-carrying members of the Cleveland Orchestra picketed today at Severance Hall and passed out handbills declaring that the orchestra members are on strike.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI) The Department of Agriculture today estimated the 1967 corn crop at a record of 4,693,917,000 bushels. It also predicted record crops of soybeans and wheat.

Borough President Mario J. Cariello of Queens told the City Planning Commission yesterday that no new housing should be erected in that borough until it had another subway, more paved streets and improved sanitation and police protection.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 The International Monetary Fund published today the text of the outline plan for creation of a new type of international monetary reserve asset, as agreed upon last month in London by the Group of Ten, made up of leading financial nations.

WARSAW, Sept. 11 Wladyslaw Gomulka, head of the Polish Communist party, rebulked President de Gaulle today for his efforts to persuade Poland to assert herself more with the Soviet Union and to accept reconciliation with West Germany.
The spot rate on the British pound rose one point, to $2.7842, in quiet trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) Capt. Charles S. Robb and his fiancee, Lynda Bird Johnson, said today their plans were largely undecided.

DETROIT, Sept. 11 Gov. George Romney said today that "there will be no additional funds from the state either directly or indirectly" for use in settling the strike of Detroit's public school teachers.
KINSHASA, the Congo, Sept. 11 President Joseph D. Mobutu convened a meeting of the Organization of African Unity in his capital city today.

Charles Butwin, one of the founders of the Associated Health Foundation, Inc., died Sunday at sea. He was 64 years old.
THE Asbury Park Regional Championships, which ended Sunday, broke all attendance records by totaling more than 1,800 tables to become the biggest four-day regional ever held.

About 80,000 commuters were left stranded or were forced to find other transportation yesterday morning after a wildcat stoppage by the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers forced a drastic slowdown of the Long Island Rail Road.

The American Broadcasting Company's four-hour documentary on Africa Sunday night not only drew critical applause around the country but also held its own in the ratings against more glamorous offerings by the other networks.

RAHWAY, N.J., Sept. 11 Walter E. Orvis, a retired vice president of the former Empire Trust Company of New York, died Saturday in Rahway Memorial Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 1068 Midwood Drive.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Sept. 12 Navy pilots reported today that two enemy surface-to-air missiles exploded yesterday afternoon near three foreign ships anchored about 20 miles from Haiphong.

DUNKIRK, N.Y., Sept. 11 (AP) Wallace A. Brennan, retired editor of The Dunkirk Evening Observer, died last night at his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 71 years old.
Investors were out in force yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and prices started off the week on a firm note.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 11 (AP) The Baltimore Teachers Union and the Baltimore City School Board reached complete agreement tonight, thus averting a strike.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 The Treasury bill rate rose at today's auction from last week's levels, with a particularly large jump for six-month bills, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

The city's school system was disrupted yesterday as nearly 46,000 of the city's 58,000 teachers stayed away from the opening classes of the fall term. So did nearly 400,000 of their one million pupils.

For Mrs. Rose Shapiro, the lone woman on the ninemember Board of Education, a visit yesterday to Public School 40 was part pleasure and part pain.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11--Adam Clayton Powell interrupted his exile on an island in the Bahamas today and spent more than an hour in the grand jury room of the United States District Court here. He and his lawyers refused to say why he was there.
DETROIT, Sept. 11 The Chrysler Corporation announced today that prices of its 1968 automobiles would be raised an average of $133 a car, or 4.6 per cent, from the cost of its 1967 models.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 11 (AP) I Am Slipping, ridden by Paul Kallai, charged from off the pace today and won the Malta Purse by a length and a quarter at Atlantic City race track.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 Richard H. Nolte, who recently resigned as United States Ambassador to the United Arab Republic, said today that he felt the Soviet Union "had connived in triggering" President Gamal Abdel Nasser's challenge to Israel that led to war last June.
MSL Industries, Inc., a diversified manufacturing company, announced yesterday in Los Angeles the appointment of Joseph J. Klein as executive vice president.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Sept. 11 Miss Anne Carroll Morgan will become the bride of Russell Lowell Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Llewelyn Jones of Darien. Her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Earl Bliss Morgan Jr. of Riverside, have announced the engagement.

DANNY THOMAS moved this season into the select league of Bob Hope, who has produced several specials starring himself while presenting film dramas on other weeks. The National Broadcasting Company's venture opened at 9 o'clock last night on Channel 4, with Mr. Thomas's fourth edition of his proven success, "The Wonderful World of Burlesque."

UNLIKE most young writers, who follow the sages of creative writing and set their first novels in home territory, Robert Stone has left home for the setting of his first, "A Hall of Mirrors," winner of a Houghton Mifflin Fellowship Award.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (UPI) The American Medical Association called today for changes in procedures for certifying the health of applicants for airplane pilots' licenses.

The stock market shifted direction in midsession yesterday. A broad advance in the first two hours of trading on the New York Stock Exchange faded in the afternoon and closing prices were evenly balanced, with 608 declines and 604 advances.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11(UPI) Everett McKinley Dirksen, the Senate Republican leader, suggested today that Governor Romney talked like an amateur when he accused the Johnson Administration of "brainwashing" him on Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 The Senate approved today a stringent provision against "shaking down" Federal employes for political contributions.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 11 In the wake of the six-day war against the Arabs, Israel has added $17-million to her defense spending, which is already nearly a fourth of her total budget.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) The United States Coast Guard is having trouble attracting Negroes into its ranks particularly at the cadet and officer level.

George Meany yesterday cited membership gains of 1,549,000 in the A.F.L.-C.I.O. in the last four years and said that the figures were at least a partial answer to Walter P. Reuther's charges of complacency in the federation.

William H. Bixby, a partner in G.H. Walker Co., a New York Stock Exchange member firm with its home office in St. Louis, and its main office here, died Saturday of a heart ailment in Glens Falls (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 79 years old. He lived in St. Louis, and had a summer home in Bolton Landing, N.Y.

The Eurobond market--the European market for long-term loans in United States dollars and other convertible currencies--has emerged in recent months as one of the fastest growing sectors of world finance, a top international banker said yesterday.

Few of those who have given their backing have gone down the line for the Johnson package. Most, it seems, just want to put an end to the uncertainty over, tax policy that has prevailed for the last 18 months.
Teachers were forced to withdraw their picket lines at Intermediate School 201 in Harlem yesterday after a brief clash with angry Negro parents.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI)--Senator Joseph S. Clark of Pennsylvania and Mrs. Iris Cole Richey, a former public relations woman, were married this afternoon in All Souls Unitarian Church.
Two ad agencies, new to the auto arena, are both taking their clients up the "value" road.

ROME, Sept. 12--A historic first meeting of a consultative synod of the world's Roman Catholic prelates will cope with the "problem of excesses" arising from the current ferment of change in the church and the "terrible illness" of atheism.

ATLANTA, Sept. 12 (AP)--A group of Negroes and whites held a sit-in today in the Atlanta school superintendent's office in a dispute over school problems that disrupted a Board of Education session last night. A major complaint was double sessions at some schools.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12-- The House approved a $70-billion defense appropriation bill today but insisted on an amendment that would jeopardize a multimillion-dollar arms deal with Britain.
In a session marked by sharp criticisms of Mayor Lindsay, the City Council yesterday repealed a 36-year-old law requiring cabaret entertainers to carry identification cards.
The city agreed yesterday after a two-year court fight to rehire 16 ferryboat officers who were discharged May, 1965, for violating the now defunct Condon-Wadlin Law.

McGUIRE AIR FORCE BASE, N.J., Sept. 12--The Knickerbockers lost the services of Fred Crawford, a guard, for a couple of days today when the former St. Bonaventure star suffered a sprained tendon in his right ankle. X-rays, proved negative and the doctors advised a couple of days rest.
WASHINGTON, Sept.12 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration, citing "formidable difficulties," urged delay today of a controversial proposal aimed at spurring sales of genericname drugs.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--The Senate passed President Johnson's election reform bill by a vote of 87 to 0 today after removing a section that would have permitted rich
NEW DELHI, Wednesday, Sept. 13--A 12-hour lull on the Himalayan frontier was broken early this morning by a clash between Chinese and Indian patrols, the Government said.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 12 (Reuters)--The trial of 37 Africans charged with offenses under a new South African terrorism act was adjourned for three days today to allow the judge to consider whether the court had jurisdiction to try the case.

DETROIT, Sept. 12--School and teachers' union officials foresaw no immediate end today to Detroit's week-long teacher strike, despite a decision from the Michigan Supreme Court that may end some other teacher walkouts around the state.
The city asked yesterday that Albert Shanker and two other high officials of the teachers union be cited for criminal contempt for violating a temporary court order prohibiting a work stoppage.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 12-- "I don't think we had this many units together in Florida during the Cuban missile crisis," CS/2 Larry Johnson said today as he checked the Imposing patrol fleet at the America's Cup yachting opener.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 12--Gov. Ronald Reagan called today for use of the "full technological resources of the United States" in escalating the Vietnam war to win "as quickly as possible."
BALDWIN, L.I, Sept. 12-- Both sides rested their cases tonight on the seventh day of an administrative hearing into charges that a Baldwin high school teacher molested a 16year-old girl student.
Shaking off some of its recent sluggishness, the stock market mounted a fairly broad advance in active trading yesterday.
Two major industrial companies--the Thiokol Chemical Corporation and the WallaceMurray Corporation--reached an agreement yesterday to merge into a new diversified manufacturing and aerospace company.
A technological improvement in the film field has led to a major renovation in a West Side commercial building whose tenants include a number of large film laboratories.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) --The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today President Johnson's nomination of Martin J. Hillenbrand, a career diplomat, to be Ambassador to Hungary.
THE most-discussed deal in the Asbury Park Region als last weekend was the slam shown in the diagram. It was played in the Open Team event, and many NorthSouth pairs reached six notrump.
The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for banking notes at New York. These rates do not apply to regular exchange business transacted by banks.
A new $34,200 Rolls-Royce convertible will be introduced here this fall, Rolls-Royce Inc., the United States affiliate of the parent British company, made known yesterday.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Sept. 12-- Intrasquad competition never hurt a good football team. Bucknell is happy to have some of this healthy battling for starting positions because there was not enough of it a year ago.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 12--Israel reported a soldier slightly injured in shooting across the Suez Canal today.

CAIRO, Wednesday, Sept. 13 (Reuters)--Abbas Radwan, a former Minister of Local Government, has been arrested in connection with a plot by 50 army officers to reinstate Field Marshal Hakim Amer as Deputy Supreme Commander of the United Arab Republic's armed forces, the authoritative Cairo newspaper Al Ahram reported today.
WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 12 --Even before his Holy Cross College football team lined up for the opening kickoff of the 1967 season, Tom Boisture lobbed a bombshell into the coaching fraternity.

Louis Wolfson became concerned about the rising price of the stock of Continental Enterprises, Inc., early in 1960 and sent a memorandum to all his close business associates warning them not to recommend the issue, according to testimony in Federal court here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12-- Gov. George Romney told a Presidential commission investigating urban riots today that an effort of historic proportions by public and private institutions would be necessary to prevent "greater bloodshed and possible destruction of the nation."

Francis I. duPont Co., one of the nation's largest stock brokerage houses, plans to enter the Government bond business as a dealer, a spokesman confirmed last night. It would be "premature" to make a formal announcement, he said, but "we have definitely decided to go ahead."
NEW DELHI, Sept. 12-- When India's Deputy Prime Minister first went to jail in 1930 for participation in the independence movement, he weighed only 130 pounds.
WHOOSH went the polyurethane tree yesterday morning as Piero Gilardi sat on it, stretching his orange-stockinged feet across the brown plastic carpet.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 12 (AP)-- Pete Rose's three-run homer and Vada Pinson's two-run drive marked a barrage of 23 hits as the Cincinnati Reds overpowered the Pittsburgh Pirates, 15-7, tonight.

Paperboard production fell 5.3 per cent with 325,900 tons in the week ended Sept. 9, compared with the corresponding 1966 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 12--Anthony Barber, newly appointed chairman of the Conservative party, said today that an early general election was possible if Labor members of Parliament who disagreed with Prime Minister Wilson's policies "show a few guts."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--Officials in the White House and the Pentagon insist that the air strikes against the Campha docks and against the bridges and warehouse at Haiphong do not indicate any basic change in American bombing policy.

ALBANY, Sept. 12--The Constitutional Convention received a revised Judiciary Article today that would establish a simpler system for creating new judges, provide a plan for abolishing justices of the peace, require the state to assume the costs of the entire court system and set up a new governing body for the system.

The Public Broadcast Laboratory, which will compete against commercial television networks with Sunday evening programing, asked the networks last night for permission to rebroadcast excerpts of news analyses and reports by network correspondents.
Victor Alessandro, rehearsing for his conducting debut with the New York City Opera on Sept. 23, stabbed himself in the hand with his baton yesterday afternoon at the New York State Theater.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12-- Mayor Lindsay said today that proposed limitations on Federal aid to local welfare and medical programs "may have the ultimate effect of converting a deeply troubling situation into a thundering crisis."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12-- A National Labor Relations Board examiner found today that the machinists union had engaged illegally in antiunion activities against staff members who had formed their own labor organization.

The Hoover Ball and Bearing Company improved its results in the final quarter of its fiscal year, but sales and earnings for the full annual period ended July 31 were sharply lower from those of the preceding fiscal year, according to the report issued yesterday from Ann Arbor, Mich.

An 11-hour sit-in demonstration by mothers on the Lower East Side yesterday persuaded officials of antipoverty organizations to keep open three neighborhood service centers and three child-care nurseries.

Pete Seeger, the folk singer who was blacklisted by commercial broadcasting for 17 years, yesterday accused the Columbia Broadcasting System of censoring one of his songs on "The Smothers Brothers Comedy Hour" last Sunday.
MUSCLE SHOALS, Ala., Sept. 12 (UPI)--An explosion in a smelting furnace last night killed four persons and injured 40 at the Reynolds Aluminum Company casting plant here.

New issues of tax-exempt and corporate bonds continued yesterday to be pegged on the high-interest-rate plateau reached in late summer, but sales to investors varied considerably. Some issues sold out swiftly, while others were snubbed.
There may be some corporate bruises in Valley Stream, L.I., starting Monday.

Mrs. Catherine McElligott O'Brien, widow of John J. O'Brien, an advertising salesman for The New York Times, died yesterday in University Hospital after a long illness. She was 56 years old and lived at 1420 Parkchester Road, the Bronx.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 12--India and the United States signed an agreement today for the supply of a million tons of American grains later this year. It raises American food commitments to India for this year to 6.1 million tons.
WATER MILL, L.I., Sept. 12--The engagement of Miss Shirley Hildreth Gay and Lieut. Richard Warren Pershing, U.S.A., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Philip Dumaresque Gay.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 12 --King Constantine of Greece watched today's America's Cup race from Intrepid's tender, a sport-fishing cruiser named Mary Poppins.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--A subpoena served on Adam Clayton Powell in the British island of Bimini, in the Bahamas, brought him before a Federal grand jury here yesterday, informed sources said today.

The tax and law-enforcement officials from sixteen states and the Federal Government who met in New York yesterday at Governor Rockefeller's invitation tackled one of their toughest problems: how to combat cigarette smuggling and recover evaded revenues.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (Reuters)--The State Department lifted a prohibition today on travel by United States citi zens to Iraq, Jordan and Yemen.
Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon said yesterday that the Johnson Administration had allowed the "awesome power" of the United States for world leadership to "succumb to creeping obsolescence."
Bishop James A. Pike has thrown down another gauntlet of nonorthodoxy on the eve of the Episcopal Church General Convention where his alleged past heresies will be a major point of controversy.

The Boston Edison and the New England Electric System, which have been studying the feasibility of an affiliation since early this year, announced yesterday that any move towards amalgamation might include Eastern Utilities Associates.

OWINGS MILLS, Md., Sept. 12--Dr. and Mrs. William G. Marr have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Washington Marr, to Lieut, Charles Watson Newhall 3d, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Newhall Jr. Both families are of Owings Mills.

In unanimously approving the election reform bill the Senate has brought Federal election statutes, first enacted thirty and forty years ago, abreast of contemporary political practice. However, in narrowly defeating an amendment to require members of Congress and candidates to disclose their financial standing, the Senate has voted to leave Congress under a cloud of suspicion.
DEL MAR, Calif., Sept. 12 (UPI)--Baffle survived a claim of foul today to score a halflength victory in the $99,300 Del Mar Futurity, the feature race on the closing day of the Del Mar race track.

LAWRENCE, L.I., Sept. 12-- Leon Kraushar, a partner in the Joseph Held Company, a New York insurance brokerage firm, and a collector of pop art, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home on Barrett Road here. He was 54 years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI) --Frank Bertaina, the winning pitcher, paced a three-run second-inning uprising with a tworun single tonight, leading the Washington Senators to a 5-4 victory over Minnesota and dropping the Twins into a tie for first place with the Boston Red Sox in the American League pennant race.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 12 (UPI)--Frank Sinatra was punched so hard he lost two teeth and got a bruised lip in a one-punch fight with a vice president of the Sands Hotel here Sunday.
A change in senior management was announced yesterday in Minneapolis by the Pillsbury Company, a producer of bakery mixes and flour.

TRENTON, Sept. 12--Assembly Speaker Robert J. Halpin won the Democratic nomination for State Senator in Cumberland and Cape May Counties today. State Senator Thomas J. Hillery, a prominent Morris County Republican, was defeated in the largest legislative primary election in New Jersey's history.

CHATTANOOGA, Sept. 12-- The Mayor of Chattanooga and a band of policemen, supported by a spotter plane circling overhead, captured a famed Civil War locomotive in a daring early morning raid today as it was being transported from Louisville, Ky., to Kennesaw, Ga
A strawberry blond housewife was pulled out of her car by detectives in Queens yesterday morning and charged with strangling her 4-year-old daughter two years ago.
The Damon Runyon Memorial Fund for Cancer Research, Inc., named for the columnist who died in December, 1946, has passed the $30-million mark in contributions, it was announced yesterday.

The performance of music is a year-round thing nowadays Still, the recital by Joao Carlos Martins in Carnegie Hall last night got the local 1967-68 concert season off to a start as the first major event since Labor Day, the traditional dividing line.

BOSTON, Sept. 12 (UPI)--Jim Lonborg drove in the deciding run in the eighth inning with a triple and gained his 20th pitching victory tonight as the Boston Red Sox downed the Kansas City Athletics, 3-1.
DEPARTMENT stores very often operate on the same premise as television: Strike while the iron is hot whether it be cowboys, Cossacks or Cardin.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 12-- Mayor Henry W. Maier, declaring that Milwaukee had reached the verge of civil war, conscripted nine civic and religious leaders today to seek a solution to the turmoil over open housing that has wracked Wisconsin's largest city for 16 days.

The City University yesterday opened its first dormitory facilities for students from poverty areas under the state's Search for Education, Elevation and knowledge (SEEK) program as 100 students moved into the Alamac Hotel, Broadway and 71st Street.

After two days of negotiation, a settlement was reached yesterday in the dispute between Charles O. Finley, the owner of the Kansas City Athletics, and his players, represented by the Major League Players Association and its director, Marvin Miller.

More than half of New York City's one million public school pupils stayed away from their classes yesterday on the second day of a teacher work stoppage in a contract dispute. The 559,000 stay-at-homes meant that 125,000 more pupils joined those who had missed classes on Monday, when the school term opened.
Prices were narrowly irregular on the London stock market yesterday. Trading was slack...
HOUSTON, Sept. 12 (UPI)-- Rusty Staub's single sent home Sonny Jackson with the winning run in the 12th inning tonight as the Houston--Astros defeated the Chicago Cubs, 5-4.

PARIS, Sept. 12--General de Gaulle returned this afternoon from what his associates called a moderately successful voyage. Nonpartisan commentators in the French press tended to agree with the assessment.

MIAMI, Sept. 12 (UPI)--Beulah, a former hurricane that took 18 lives on Caribbean resort islands, lost most of its punch today and drifted back into the open sea.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Sept. 13--Several hundred students walked out of the entrance examinations for the University of Saigon Medical School yesterday to protest what they called the rigging of the Sept. 3 presidential election.

Still more price rises were posted yesterday for a variety off products, among them sugar, chemicals, carpeting and carpet fibers and storage batteries. The sugar advance was new. Most of the others were additional producers following the lead of competitors.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12-- D. Robert Yarnall, a former vice chairman and director of the American Friends Service Committee, who aided victims of both World Wars, died yesterday in his home here. His age was 89.
Bergdorf Goodman, the prestige fashion store on upper Fifth Avenue, has drupped its plans to operate a major store in Chicago, Andrew Goodman, president, announced yesterday,

New car sales fell sharply in the first 10 days of September, according to reports received yesterday from Detroit. The General Motors Corporation, the Chrysler Corporation and the American Motors Corporation each announced declines in sales. The Ford Motor Company is expected to report its sales today.
A New York television station yesterday offered to cancel some of its commercial programing to allow the telecasting of classes during the teachers dispute.
The Long Island Rail Road restored nearly normal service yesterday as all except a few of the engineers who walked out Monday reached for their throttles again.
SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 12--The last of Dame Patties secret weapons for her challenge for the America's Cup was revealed today-- the existence of a "Dame Pattie Blower" corps of Australia.

The Chase International Investment Corporation, an overseas investment subsidiary of the Chase Manhattan Bank, has announced the formation of a new company in Britain to lease vehicles, computers and industrial equipment.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12-- The House approved today legislation that would permit the Small Business Administration to extend the term of its loans up to 15 years. The Senate has approved a similar measure.
SYRACUSE, Sept, 12 (AP) --William Sanford, 28 years old, a freshman crew coach at Syracuse University since 1964, was named head coach today.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 95.5 on Monday from 95.7 on Friday.

Many sugar men--traders, dealers and refinery officials-- took the day off yesterday for their annual golf outing. While they were gone, the American Sugar Company sprang a surprise by announcing plans to increase the wholesale price of refined sugar by 15 cents a hundred pounds.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12-- The Johnson Administration plans to double the number of low-rent housing units to be readied for occupancy in the next year, from 35,000 to 70,000, by adopting new procedures and priorities.

ROME, Sept. 12--Negotiations between the Vatican and Czechoslovakia for the settlement of deep, long-standing disputes, broken off since June, probably will be resumed next month on the initiative of the Prague Government.
Deposits at the nation's mutual savings banks increased by $320-million during August, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks estimated yesterday.

Upper East Side matrons handed out leaflets yesterday at Public School 6, Madison Avenue and 82d Street, that said: "Support our teachers. We urge you to keep your children out of school until the teachers' contract is settled."

Britain, concerned over the steady drain of its top-level management and technical executives and specialists, has opened an information and recruitment center here representing British companies in an effort to turn the "brain drain" into a "brain gain."
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 12--Navy carrier pilots bombed four targets in Haiphong and its suburbs yesterday in a move to isolate the city, North Vietnam's major port.

Marine Transport Lines, Inc., has signed a contract with the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company for the delivery of the nation's first vessel capable of carrying refrigerated anhydrous ammonia, H. Lee White, president of the steamship company, announced yesterday.

CARLSBAD, Calif., Sept. 12 --The strikebound Ford Motor Company has built enough cars to see its dealers through 49 selling days, or about two months, Matthew S. McLaughlin, general manager of the Ford Division, said today at a preview of the 1968 cars at the LaCosta Spa and Country Club.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)--The House Post Office Committee rejected today a subcommittee proposal to charge 25 per cent extra for special expeditious treatment for newspapers and weekly magazines.

The Third Naval District has announced that Rear Adm. Francis D. Foley is scheduled to relieve Rear Adm. Reuben T. Whitaker as District Commandant at ceremonies on the parade ground of the former New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn on Sept. 28.

The Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service, speaking at the first World Conference on Smoking and Health, declared that the nation is at a turning point in the battle to overcome the dangers of cigarettes. He proposed a two-pronged attack: development of a safer cigarette and a stepped-up campaign to inform the public of the hazards of cigarette smoking.

Raymond A. Rich, chairman and chief executive officer of the McCall Corporation, resigned yesterday. No successor was appointed and no reason was offered by the company for his resignation. Mr. Rich remains a director.
Eschewing the usual highfidelity theatricality of visiting folk troupes, the Lyceum Dancers of Greece created the authentic atmosphere of a village dance festival last night at Town Hall.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 12--Once more the America's Cup races are with us, representing the most majestic event in sports. No manmade walls confine the surface of the action. It stretches to the horizon over the tumbling green waters of the boundless ocean, a super-spectacular of breathtaking beauty.

The Rev. Dr. Howard A. Northacker, pastor emeritus of the First United Presbyterian Church of Newtown, Queens Boulevard and 54th Avenue, Elmhurst, Queens, died Sunday in Florida, where he had lived in retirement since 1960. He was 76 years old.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Sept. 12 --Gov. Lester G. Maddox of Georgia made two assaults on the practical, low-keyed tone of the Southern Governors Conference today and got a distinctly cool reception both times.

The American Cyanamid Company announced yesterday in Wayne, N.J., the election of Clifford D. Siverd as president and chief executive officer. He was also named chairman of the management and finance committees and a member of the executive committee.

In a kind of shakedown cruise for the "race of the years," nine horses will go to the post at Aqueduct today in the second oldest stakes race in the United States--the $50,000 added Jerome Handicap.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Sept. 12 (UPI)--Gov. Winthrop Rockefeller of Arkansas made today his strongest statement yet in support of his brother, Nelson, for the Republican Presidential nomination.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)--Pan American World Airways asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today for permission to extend its two routes to Australia on to Hong Kong and Bangkok.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 12 --Iraq is in turmoil over the repercussions of the war in early June between the Arab states and Israel, according to reports published here.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 12-- State District Judge Edward A. Haggerty Jr. said this afternoon he would rule next Monday whether to dismiss an indictment that charged Clay L. Shaw, a retired New Orleans businessman, with plotting the assassination of President Kennedy.

THE custom dressmaking business is hardly a booming area of fashion, but there's plenty of action at Arnold Scaasi's 56th Street salon.

WAYNE, N.J., Sept. 12-- Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood and Mrs. George Guard of. North Jersey shared the medal today in the second annual New Jersey State women's golf championship for the Mrs. James Dorment Trophy.

Stephen E. Weil, vice president and general manager of the Marlborough-Gerson Gallery, one of the country's leading art dealers, has been named to the new post of administrator of the Whitney Museum of American Art.
KITCHENER, Ont.; Sept. 12-- From where Arnie Brown sat today in the Memorial Auditorium, his Ranger teammates be low were a swirl of men and sticks and skates, some trying to get his job.

While splitting a doubleheader with the California Angels at Yankee Stadium last night before a crowd of only 6,505, the New York Yankees showed once again how fine pitching is keeping them out of unimaginable depths.
Dr. Mark H. Barnes, an eye, ear, nose and throat specialist who had practiced here since 1932, died Monday of a heart attack in Lenox Hill Hospital.

EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., Wednesday, Sept. 13--Two Negroes were injured in a firebomb explosion last night on the third successive night of racial disturbances here. The Fire Department was also kept busy putting out 18 small fires, most of which had been set.

The cold war between tightly knit Soviet and NATO blocs has certainly relaxed. The five years since the Cuban missile showdown have been marked by cautious if persistent efforts to improve relations between Washington and Moscow despite tensions in Vietnam and the Middle East.
HONG KONG, Sept. 12 (Reuters)--Three policemen were injured, one seriously, and more dummy bombs were planted in a new wave of leftist activity in this British colony today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12-- State Department officials reported today that Soviet disarmament negotiators had advanced a compromise proposal on international inspection that might help break the long deadlock on a treaty to halt the spread of nuclear arms.

City teachers who are staying away from their posts in the current contract dispute conducted classes in storefronts and churches yesterday. The United Federation of Teachers announced that similar projects would begin today.

ATLANTA, Sept. 12--Jack Fisher was two outs away from his 10th victory tonight when infield hits by Mike Lum and Felipe Alou set the stage for the Atlanta Braves to rally for a 4-3 victory over the New York Mets. Hank Aaron drove in the tying run with a sacrifice fly and Joe Torre followed with a single to end the game.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 12--Secretary General Thant's special representative for Jerusalem has reported that the Arabs of the Old City strongly fear racial and religious oppression from Israelis, who now occupy the area.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 12 (UPI)-- Bob Gibson, rounding into form for World Series duty, pitched 6 1/3 innings tonight as the pennant-bound St. Louis Cardinals gained a 6-0 victory over the Philadelphia Phils.

GENEVA, Sept. 12--The president of the World Federation of United Nations Associations has appealed to the Premiers of the Soviet Union, Britain, India and Poland to meet and work out "a line of common action with a view to securing peace in Vietnam."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- A "country fair" was held on the South Lawn of the White House today for the amusement of 500 children and grandchildren of Congressmen and other leading Government officials.

On a cluttered desk in a cluttered office at the Museum of the City of New York stands an Oscar won by Helen Hayes as best motion picture actress in 1931 and donated to the museum's Theater and Music Collection.

THE City Center Joffrey Ballet opened the second week of its month's season at the New York City Center last night with another wee drop of Balanchine's "Scotch Symphony." The particular interest here was that the leading roles were assigned for the first time to Barbara Remington and Paul Sutherland.

The New York Botanical Garden announced yesterday publication by the McGrawHill Book Company of the second of five illustrated volumes dealing with the country's wild flowers. The book was introduced at the Hallmark Gallery, Fifth Avenue at 56th Street.
WHITE SANDS MISSILE RANGE, N.M., Sept. 12 (UPI) --A 10,000-pound Army Pershing missile fired from Utah went off course today and landed in Mexico.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12-- Morarji R. Desai, Deputy Prime Minister of India, indicated today that his country would accept a treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons without insisting on guarantees of protection by the nuclear powers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI) --The Senate minority leader, Everett McKinley Dirksen, told fellow Republicans today to plan on eating Thanksgiving dinner and doing their Christmas shopping here this year.
