Korean-flag cargo ship service from the United States East and Gulf Coasts to Korean and Japanese ports will begin Friday with the sailing of the South Korean freighter Sae Jong.

Dr. Lev Zetlin, head of the New York consulting engineering firm of Lev Zetlin Associates, has been appointed to the advisory panel of the General Services Administration. Dr. Zetlin is the only structural engineer appointed to the panel, which consists mainly of architects.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 12-- Iran's best-known embroiderer Pouran Darroudi, paused in her labors this week and waved a needle like a scepter at yards of emerald velvet that she is embroidering for Empress Farah's coronation robe.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--A group of economists, carefully chosen to represent all points of view, advised Congress today to ignore current soft spots in the economy and approve a tax increase now. Without one, they said, there will be an inflationary boom and a renewed credit squeeze in 1968.

When the Milwaukee City Council last June rejected an open housing ordinance for the fourth time in two years, the Rev. James E. Groppi, militant leader of a nonviolent civil rights movement, said: "Either we get what we want or we turn this city upside down."

WEIRTON, W. Va., Sept. 12 --Thomas E. Millsop, former board chairman of National Steel Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest producer, died of a heart attack at his home here this morning. He was 68 years old.
The New York University School of Medicine announced yesterday the start of a program aimed at making the transplants of kidneys from one human being to another more available and successful.

John D. Butt, who retired in 1959 as board chairman and president of the Seamen's Bank for Savings, and served for a while thereafter as president of the Downtown-Lower Manhattan Association, died yesterday in his home at 35 Pierpont Street, Brooklyn. His age was 79.
TIPPERARY Land Corporation, an Australian enter prise with all the romantic appeal of a long ocean voyage and vast reaches of cattle pasture, came to Wall Street yesterday seeking the long green.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 12-- Mrs. Vincent Larkin of the home club led the way into the quarter-final round of the 12th Women's Cross County Gol Assocition match-play championship with a 2-and-1 victory over Mrs. Gordon McGrath, Piping Rock, at the Nassau County Club today.

JOHN SURTEES didn't create much more than a rip ple when he announced several months ago that the Japanese-built Honda wouldn't compete on the Formula One world championship circuit until he was sure it was ready. But Surtees made the automobile racing world sit up...
Radio station WBAI was knocked off the air for 20 minutes by a fire last night. The station had resumed broadcasting after having been silent since Sunday as a result of vandalism.
Two Japanese shipyards signed an agreement yesterday to merge by next April to form the world's largest shipbuilding concern.

Organized labor's political education committee is planning extensive use of data processing by computer in half a dozen areas of the country in the political campaign in 1968.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI) Dean Chance, making his second relief appearance of the season, stopped the Washington Senators in the ninth inning tonight and preserved a 3-2 Minnesota victory that kept the Twins in a first-place deadlock with the Boston Red Sox.

MOTHER BELL wore dancing slippers in Wall Street yesterday, waltzing to a 3 1/8-point gain at 54 in heavy trading. The buying wave came mostly in small trades that added up to a stunning 315, 300-share turnover.

The Wall Street community moved uptown last night to honor the outgoing president of the New York Stock Exchange, Keith Funston, and his successor, Robert W. Haack, at a blacktie dinner in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Mr. Gablinger is going to have to battle a blonde, which doesn't sound too bad.

Dr. Edward Teller testified here yesterday that stringent new state air-pollution controls should be adopted for the metropolitan area because "it is a case where one actually will get a lot for very little."
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Sept. 13 H. Rap Brown, the militant black power advocate, was jailed in Virginia today pending the outcome of a court battle by his lawyers to avoid his extradition to Maryland.

WHO was it said that nothing clears the mind like the imminent prospect of death? (I have such a terrible memory for quotations that at times it must seem like an affectation: my apologies.) In any event some such thought seems to be behind Gerald Arpino's "Elegy," given its first performance by the City Center Joffrey Ballet at the New York City Center last night.

The bond market seemed to bog down yesterday. New issues of tax-exempt and corporate bonds were offered publicly at yields close to the highs of the summer, but investors were reluctant to buy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) The intensification of the Vietnam war created more than one million jobs in the United States in the last two years, the Labor Department said today in the first such comprehensive report since the war began.

In rejecting the demand of the United Federation of Teachers that the city schools be closed until a contract settlement can be reached, State Supreme Court Justice Emilio Nunez has underscored the union's impossible position.
MIAMI, Sept. 13 Cuba has indirectly attacked Pablo Neruda, well-known Chilean poet leading member of the Communist party of Chile.
NEWPORT, R.I, Sept. 13 Intrepid continued to gobble up the choice portions of what looks like an America's Cup turkey, but today, at least, Dame Pattie wound up with a leg.

NINETY-SIX salesmen for Broadstreet's, a retail chain of men's clothing stores, assembled Tuesday evening in a smoke-filled banquet room at Gallagher's restaurant to be indoctrinated for the revolution.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 13 (AP) Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the chief of state, said today he was recalling Cambodia's envoys from Peking "to avoid incidents if there is a demonstration against our embassy."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI) The Senate confirmed by voice vote today the nomination of Martin J. Hillenbrand as the first United States Ambassador to Hungary since shortly after World War II.
LONDON, Sept. 13 The United Steelworkers of America has undertaken a quiet campaign to see if steel exports to the United States can be geared to American production levels.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 The United States lost $34million of gold through the operations of the London "gold pool" in the second quarter of this year, a Treasury report indicated today.
CHATTANOOGA, Sept. 13 (AP) Chattanooga won a skirmish today in its battle with Georgia over the final resting place of The General, a famed locomotive stolen by Union soldiers during the Civil War.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 Reversing their previous stand against aid to Appalachia, House Republican leaders said today they would support an extension of the program.
HONG KONG, Sept. 13 The Chinese Communists have formally taken over Britain's consular office in Shanghai according to a radio broadcast that was monitored here.

The head of the International Longshoremen's Association has asked all of its locals to withdraw from any participation in the Maritime Trades Department of the American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Grove Press, the publishing house that since January has bought an Off Broadway theater, an Off Broadway program publishing business and a large rental library of short movies, has further expanded in the entertainment world by acquiring release rights to a feature film, "Passages from James Joyce's Finnegans Wake."

MEYER RIFF of Jersey City, scoring 5 - , captured first place in the recent Brooklyn Junior Chess Championship. In this six-round Swiss system, Gilbert Goon of Manhattan tied the winner in game points, but had to take second place to Riff after a tie-break count. Third place went to Leif Karell of the Bronx.
Although sales of the Campbell Soup Company rose to a new record in fiscal 1967 for the tenth consecutive year, profits declined by 8.9 per cent, it was reported yesterday in Camden, N.J.
DONCASTER, England, Sept. 13 (AP) Ribocco, owned by Charles Engelhard of Newark, won the St. Leger, the last classic of the English race season, today.
MONTAUK, L.I., Sept. 13 Capt. Carl Darenberg and Frank Bann, a Manhattan attorney, returned from a tuna expedition disappointed, but not surprised.

BOSTON, Sept. 13 (AP) Rico Petrocelli's two-run double in the eighth inning carried the Boston Red Sox to a 4-2 victory over the Kansas City Athletics today. It was Boston's fourth triumph in a row in the hot American League pennant race.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 13 Israeli and Egyptian troops shot at each other again this morning along the Suez Canal.
WASHINGTON, Sept.13 (UPI)--Despite warnings that United States espionage may be hampered, the Senate voted today, 79 to 4, to keep the private lives of Federal employees private.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 13 Not far from the $19-million building project that is modernizing the handsome, green campus of Hofstra University, Coach Howard (Howdy) Myers Jr., starting his 18th season as head football coach, is engaged in a "building project" of his own.
Referendum petitions of two groups opposed to the war in Vietnam that sought to put peace questions on the November ballot were rejected yesterday by City Clerk Herman Katz.

Aided and abetted by the California Angels, who found ways to force runs upon them, the New York Yankees moved into eighth place in the American League last night by scoring a 6-4 victory before a crowd of 4,615 at Yankee Stadium.
PARIS, Sept 13 Two leading electronic equipment manufacturers announced today agreement in principle on a merger.

The latest flare-up of fighting between Indian and Chinese troops in Sikkim is cause for some concern but not for alarm. The chances are that China, not her intended victim, will be the heavier loser from this latest expression of Peking's pugnacity in foreign affairs.
ROME, Sept. 13 Pope Paul VI is expected to undergo surgery within a week for relief of a prostatic block of the urinary tract.

NEWPORT, R.I, Sept. 13 Aristocratic Newporters, who are watching America's Cup races from one of the world's most spectacular fleets of privately owned yachts this week, almost never get excited about the royalty that drops in on them. But King Constantine of Greece just may have made a more lasting impression.

People who prefer to keep substantial amounts of cash in savings accounts at banks or invested in savings and loan institutions may rest even easier now. As of Sept. 1, agencies of the Federal Government have raised the insurance limits on such accounts from $10,000 to $15,000.
The Maritime Administration's Maritime Subsidy Board and Prudential Lines, Inc., reached agreement in principle yesterday on the financing of five LASH (Lighter Aboard Ship) vessels for the line.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Sept. 13 The engagement of Miss Marilyn Marie Holschuh of New York to Capt. Robert Gerard Kraus Jr., U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kraus of Stony Brook, L.I., has been made known by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Gage Holschuh.
PANAMA, Sept. 13 This little country of 1.3 million people has become one of the most critical points of United States relations with Latin America.
The Columbia Pictures Corporation came out with a "spectacular" yesterday as directors voted to declare a cash dividend of 25 cents on the common stock, the first cash payment in 10 years.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Sept. 13 Mr. and Mrs. C.B. Welch have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Christina Benning Welch, to Leonard Martin Chazen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Chazen of North Bellmore, L.I.
DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 13 (UPI) The Air Force displayed today a secret material that it said could be used virtually to eliminate explosions and fires in airplane fuel tanks.
Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art has become such a hit that the museum has extended the run for at least five months.

PARIS, Sept. 13 President de Gaulle said today that his trip to Poland had "fulfilled all the hopes" of France.

One of the most important holdouts, the General Electric Company, capitulated yesterday to price rises announced for appliances by its competitors.

The rebuff handed General de Gaulle by Poland's Communist leader, Wladyslaw Gomulka, was simply a reminder of the realities of military power which the French President, lacking it, would like to ignore.

A revival of inflationary fever sent stock prices soaring in heavy trading yesterday. Major blue-chip issues were among the more prominent gainers in the rally, which decisively broke the lackluster trading pattern of recent sessions.

Angelo Pagano, clarinetist, and Steven Stanner, pianist, who have been heard as a duo locally on radio and television, last night made their New York concert debut at Town Hall.

MIAMI, Sept. 12 (AP) Tropical storm Beulah, slowly building back toward hurricane strength, left Jamaica today and moved on across the Caribbean Sea in the direction of Central America.
THE New York Jets have a problem, which is nothing new for them. But this problem the loss of Cornell Gordon for seven or eight weeks with a knee injury may be overwhelming.

The American Broadcasting Company's four-hour telecast of "Africa" last Sunday night received mixed reviews from six African delegates to the United Nations and the Portuguese Ambassador to the United States.

Walter P. Reuther's efforts to get organized labor's top command to accept his proposed reforms and goals appear to have been unavailing to date, raising new doubts as to whether the automobile union will remain in the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Running true to form, the Constitutional Convention has again accepted the second-best when it came to the reapportionment provisions, but the proposal still represents an improvement over past procedures. WASHINGTON, Sept. 13--The chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission offered some harsh words today on the quality and reliability of railroad passenger service throughout the country.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 13 (AP) Larry Jackson who had lost seven straight games to St. Louis, pitched a two-hitter tonight to give the Philadelphia Phillies a 3-0 victory over the Cardinals.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 Total business inventories were essentially stable in July following their decline in June, the Commerce Department reported today.

Fifty years ago the former Mary Pyne stepped lightly down the winding staircase of her home at 680 Park Avenue in her debut to society. The former debutante, now Mrs. C. Suydam Cutting, wife of the retired explorer, was there with 500 others last night for another debut.

British trade figures for August showing a sizable deficit sent prices down on the London stock market yesterday.

NEWPORT, R.I, Sept. 13 The first race of the America's Cup competition holds a somewhat analogous position to the opening game of the World Series. The winner is still a long way from clinching the over-all victory, but he already has seized an edge of considerable proportions.
TOKYO, Sept. 13--Japan's first container-ship facility is to begin operation in the Port of Tokyo Saturday.
LONDON, Sept. 13 (AP) Lord Lambury of Northfield, a pioneer in the British automobile industry, died today at the age of 71.
Governor Rockefeller says he has passed a psychological turning point in his life and is now totally uninterested in striving for the Republican nomination for President in 1968.
A committee formed to back William F. Buckley Jr. in a Republican primary race against Senator Jacob K. Javits announced yesterday that it had disbanded because of Mr. Buckley's refusal to run.

ATLANTA, Sept. 13 (UPI) An all-white jury convicted six members of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee tonight on charges of destroyutg Government property and interfering with administration of the Selective Service Act.

WHEN Ivan Klapper of Gardiner, N.Y., isn't writing movie or TV scripts or books, he's extolling the virtues of the Irish setter. For six years he's been president of the Irish Setter Club of America. Under his leadership that organization has grown from 150 to 600 members.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Leventhal of 177 East 75th Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Terry Leventhal, to Marvin Lerman, son of Mrs. Paul Hitlin of 150 East 69th Street and the late Seymour Lerman.

ADEN, Sept. 13 (Agence France-Presse) The National Liberation Front, leader of a revolution that has swept away traditional rulers from most of South Arabia, announced tonight that it had assumed responsibility for a part of Aden itself.

BERLIN, Sept. 13 (Reuters) Ronald Wiedenhoeft, a 30year-old teacher of art history at Columbia Unversity, was ar- rested in East Berlin last week, a spokesman for the United States Mission said today. He said the reason that Mr. Wiedenhoeft was taken into custody had not yet been de- termined.

NEWPORT, R.I, Sept. 13 The United States defender, Intrepid, had a good look at the ice-blue transom of the Australian challenger, Dame Pattie, today to give rooters something to think about in the early stages of the second match for the America's Cup. But in the end the result was the same as in the first.

Government officials and business executives concerned with the world shortage of food made progress yesterday toward a cooperative plan to export American agricultural skill to developing countries.

RICHMOND, Sept. 13 (AP) The broadcasting industry asked a Federal appeals court today to delay an order of the Federal Communications Commission requiring broadcasters and tobacco interests to provide free time for announcements on the hazards of smoking.

STONY POINT, N.Y., Sept. 13 Four youths were arrested here today for allegedly selling more than ice ceam from a Good Humor truck.
Traders kept the post-Labor Day bustle going again yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, where both volume and prices moved ahead.

Air France expects to invest $1.7-billion for new airplanes in the next decade, Pierre Cot, president of the French airline, told a luncheon meeting of the French Chamber of Commerce here yesterday. "More than half" of that total will be for American-built planes, he said.
Contract talks were under way yesterday in an attempt to avert a strike tomorrow morning by building service workers involving up to 1,800 apartment buildings in the Bronx.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 13 Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Pettingill have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Pettingill, to the Rev. William James Wood, son of Mrs. A.G. Wood of Ramsey and Bayville, Me., and the late Mr. Wood.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 13 Secretary General Thant's office recommended today that the 22d session of the General Assembly due to begin on Tuesday should end Dec. 19.

LONDON, Sept. 13 The Treasury announced today that Britain's international accounts for the year ended June 30 were in balance or "perhaps slightly in surplus." Capital transactions in and out of the country left Britain with a surplus equivalent to $39.2-million for the 12-month period.

Three New York architects will soon begin a project intended to set up new guidelines for contemporary city planning to produce an architecture more livable and workable than that of traditional practice.

Mrs. Alice Crimmins, who was arrested Tuesday on charges of strangling her 4-year-old daughter two years ago, was put under constant police protection yesterday at the request of her lawyer. She is free on $25,000 bail.
