The starting date for threehour train service between Washington and New York was up in the air today.

A black nationalist flag was displayed inside Public School 270 in Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvesant section for several hours Tuesday, replacing the American flag, until school officials spotted the red, green and black banner and removed it.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 14 A blue-hulled Beetle became the first bug in Intrepid's trouble-free mechanism today when it capsized directly in front of the American defender during the third America's Cup race.

Three panes of 50 stamps--of 65 cents, $1.30 and $2.60 denominations--which cost their original owner $227.50 when they were issued in 1930 for use on the first Graf Zeppelin Europe-Pan-American flight, were sold here last night for $21,000.

CAIRO, Sept. 14 (AP) The semiofficial newspaper AlAhram reported today that Secretary General Thant of the United Nations had threatened to resign unless the United States and the Soviet Union made more serious efforts to solve the problems and difficulties confronting the United Nations and the world.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 The House voted tonight to extend the Administration's Appalachian aid program but only after trimming it back $50-million.
The stock market tried to keep Wednesday's rally going yesterday, but the effort fell apart in the afternoon under selling pressure from profit takers.
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I. Sept. 14 Nelson Pessoa of Brazil, the Pan-American Games gold medal winner, won the open jumper competition as the 62d annual Piping Rock horse show got under way today.
ALBANY, Sept. 14 Howard Hilton Spellman today was named Conciliation Commissioner for the State Supreme Court's First Judicial District to help administer the state's recently revised Divorce Law.

The long-discussed need to apply the vast resources of the private economy to the problems of slums has finally been met with action. This is the meaning of the decision of the nation's life insurance companies to invest $1 billion in ghetto real estate.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 A New York cancer research scientist said today that various cancer-producing agents in cigarette smoke could be substantially cut by adding to cigarettes certain chemicals found naturally in tobacco in very small amounts.
IN Holland, a country I love with most of my heart, you don't have to make a mountain out of a molehill. Molehills are what mountains are.
Sidney de Paris, jazz trumpeter, died at St. Vincent's Hospital Wednesday afternoon, after a long illness. He was 62 years, old and lived at 2478 Eighth Avenue.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 14 (AP) The Indonesian Government today ordered two Chinese Communist diplomats out of the country, charging that they were responsible for a shooting Aug. 5 in the embassy courtyard.
The Metropolitan Opera, which begins its second season at its new home in Lincoln Center on Monday night with "La Traviata," has released the names of its opening night boxholders.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (UPI)--Negro youths, mobilized for a black power rally by anonymously-printed leaflets charging the police with brutality, smashed windows and threw stores at passing cars on the South Side tonight.
Alexander's Department Stores, Inc., which has been privately held since its founding 39 years ago, is making plans for a public stock offering.
Unidentified objects from other worlds fly in the face of the laws of physics, a mathematical astronomer said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept.14 (AP) Dr. Halford L. Hoskins, who was instrumental in establishing three university schools of international relations, died today at George Washington University Hospital. His age was 76. He had suffered a heart attack two days ago.

TOKYO, Sept. 14 (AP) The Communist party newspaper in Peking declared today that it would be necessary "to move a mighty army into action" to gain victory over President Liu Shao-chi and his supporters.
Andrew Wyeth will be the subject of "Who, What, When, Where, Why, With Harry Reasoner" on the Columbia Broadcasting System Oct. 3 at 10:30 P.M.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Friday, Sept. 15 (Reuters) The Indonesian Government has ordered its entire embassy staff to leave China, Foreign Minister Adam Malik said today.
For several days, our city, our teachers and our students have been faced with a serious situation. As the Supreme Court said yesterday, "The teachers are on strike and the court so finds."
Issues on the American Stock Exchange ended on the fence yesterday in very active trading.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14--More than five months before the primary in New Hampshire, the White House has assigned a political agent to begin organizing support for President Johnson there. The unusually early timing of the move reflects increasing concern in high Democratic circles over prospective competition to the President from a slate of delegates "favorable" to Senator Robert F. Kennedy.
In his testimony in Washington this week, Mayor Lindsay struck an effective blow at the stereotypes behind the unwise welfare provisions of the Housepassed amendment to the Social Security Act.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) Federal District Judge Alexander Holtzoff ruled today that the Post Office Department's annual Christmas stamp does not violate constitutional guarantees of the separation of church and state.

IN the new fashion mathematics of the nineteen-sixties, little shops catering to the individual multiply into na tional operations. Big department stores, trying to shed their impersonality, divide themselves into small boutiques.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14--Revenue freight traffic generated by carloading on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended Sept. 9, which included the Labor Day Holiday were both under the volume in the corresponding Holiday week of last year.

BOSTON, Sept. 14 (AP) Judge Charles E. Wyzanski Jr. granted today in United States District Court a change of venue to San Francisco for three defendants charged with the $1.5-million Plymouth mail robbery in August of 1962.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI) The Senate Finance Committee approved today a compromise bill to finance election campaigns for President and the Senate with tax dollars appropriated by Congress starting in 1968.
TANNERSVILLE, N.Y. Gov. Rockefeller said today that the Legislature would have to reconsider the section of the state's new Penal Law on the use of deadly force by the police.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 The United States announced plans today to give India $1.3-million to buy contraceptives. It was the first time this country had ever included funds for that purpose in a foreign aid program.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) Secretary of Commerce Alexlander B. Trowbridge announced today the appointment of six members to the National Export Expansion Council.

The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company announced yesterday plans to acquire through one of its international banking subsidiaries a 25 per cent interest in the E.D. Sassoon Banking Company, Ltd., a merchant bank with offices in London and the Bahamas.

A fall-off in the number of teachers at work was reported by the Board of Education yesterday, while student attendance and volunteer assistance further declined in the fourth day of the teacher work stoppage.

The decision of the Federal Communications Commission to modify its ruling on the rates of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company came as good news yesterday to Wall Street and to the huge utility's 3 million shareholders.
The Celanese Plastics Company cut the price of glassreinforced nylon plastic yesterday by 25 cents a pound, in a move to increase sales of the product.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the Cambodian chief of state, appears to United States observers to be veering away from Communist China and assuming a more neutralist position. This, they say, may permit an eventual diplomatic reconciliation with the United States.

THERE were surprises in the starting line-up an nounced yesterday by the New York Giants for their opening game Sunday against the Cardinals in St. Louis. Fullback? Allen Jacobs or Ernie Koy, with a lot of stress on Koy, and not Tucker Frederickson. Right guard?
DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 14 (AP) Representatives of striking city employes accepted a wage proposal by the City Council tonight, apparently ending an eight-day work stoppage.

KITCHENER, Ont., Sept. 14 Camille Henry squirmed, but he couldn't get out of the way, and Reg Fleming barrelled into him. For a brief second, there was a pained expression on Henry's face as he tried to shake off the effect of being boarded by a man 50 pounds heavier.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14--Dr. Paul Edgar Elicker, who retired in 1959 as executive secretary of the National Association of Secondary School Principals, died today in home at Westmoreland Hills, Md. His age was 73.
ALBANY, Friday, Sept. 15 The Constitutional Convention, after the longest debate in its five-month life, voted approval early this morning of an article governing the state court system.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI) The Department of Health, Education and Welfare said today that it would begin a survey of Northern schools to find out if any were discriminating against Negroes.

TRENTON, Sept. 14 United States Attorney David M. Satz Jr. has rejected a New Jersey recommendation that a Federal grand jury be convened to investigate reports of widespread criminal activity by the Mafia in this state.
The long and exacting and, for many, worrisome process by which high school students seek to get into colleges may be hindered by the teachers' walkout here, school experts said yesterday.

One of the fascinating byproducts of the upsurge of activity in the arts has been the effort to build professional theater into educational programs on a number of campuses. It is an obvious and natural development for a graduate school of the drama with art and professionalism as its goal, like the one at Yale.
A reorganization of the administrative structure of New York City's Criminal Court was announced yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Edward R. Dudley, administrative judge of the Criminal Court.
IN the Street of Dreams at Broad and Wall, dim hopes of future bonanzas can play a bigger role than cold hard fact.

Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that the United States should "go ahead at all costs" to build an antimissile system to counter what he called the growing Soviet missile strength and a possible threat from Communist China.

SEWICKLEY, Pa., Sept. 14 Francis G. Gerard has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Stephanie Gerard of Washington, to Peter A. Jay of Gatchellville, New Park, Pa., son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Jay of Havre de Grace. Md.

Another brief, uneasy truce has been arranged in the struggle to save California's finest remaining redwoods. At the behest of the senior members of the Senate Interior Committee, four lumber companies have agreed to extend the existing one-year moratorium on cutting quality redwood trees within the boundaries of proposed national parks. Two firms agreed to hold off until this session of Congress adjourns, another only until Nov. 1, and the fourth for an undefined period.

Mrs. Lois Benjamin was married here yesterday afternoon to Dr. Robert E. Gould, a psychiatrist, of 208 East 16th Street and Quogue, L.I. The ceremony was performed by Judge Justine Wise Polier of the New York State Family Court at the home of the bride's mother, Mrs. Jo Copeland Benson, at 30 East 62d Street. A reception followed.

AREA A Brisk northwest winds kept Barnegat Light fishing fleet idle for a week. A few fluke being taken in Bay, with some striped bass in evidence along the jetties. Dockmasters at Brielle report excellent bluefishing day and night for chummers about 12 miles east northeast of Manasquan Inlet along western edge of the Mud Hole. Bottom fishing spotty but some sea bass and porgies appearing at wrecks in about 70 feet of water.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) The Post Office Department will publish new rules requiring all new large office buildings to provide special facilities to aid mail delivery, a postal official said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI) Crime increased 17 per cent during the first half of this year, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 Capt. Charles S. Robb's engagement to the President's older daughter, Miss Lynda Bird Johnson, has drawn attention to one of the capital's elite miltiary groups, the corps of bachelors who serve as social aides at the White House.
WASHINGTON Sometimes, when regarding our own Vietnamese frustrations, one feels as it seeing for a second time and in a distorted Coney Island mirror the terrible experiences of France.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 14 (UPI)--The United States Court of appeals for the Sixth Circuit denied today a new trial for James R. Hoffa, president of the teamsters' union, who was convicted three years ago of jury tampering.
Industrial issues advanced yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.
BONN, Sept. 14 An authoritative Government source said today that West Germany would make no significant reductions in its armed forces next year.

BOOTHBAY HARBOR, Me., Sept. 14 Richard Matthews Hallet, an author and newsman who had once been law clerk to the late Judge Learned Hand of New York, died today at St. Andrews Hospital. His age was 80.

THERE were those three kids in "The Magic Flute," last night at the New York State Theater, where the City Opera opened its season with Mozart's "Magic Flute." Any impresario will tell you that two things are touched with extreme danger dog acts and kid acts. Nobody knows what will happen. Last night, everything did.

SAIGON, Sept. 14 (AP) Six defeated presidential candidates announced today the formation of a "militant democratic opposition front" to oppose the new Government of Presidentelect Nguyen Van Thieu and Vice President-elect Nguyen Cao Ky.
The Congress of Racial Equality in Harlem started a campaign yesterday to persuade the Constitutional Convention to adopt a proposition enabling Harlem to set up its own public school system.

A 23-year-old part-time engineer at radio station WBAI was charged yesterday with setting two fires Tuesday night in the building at 30 East 39th Street, where the station has its studios. The police said he had a history of mental illness.

The municipal bond market, which is ending a week of relatively slow sales to investors despite the highest interest rates of the year, faces a substantial build-up in noncompetitive sales of new issues from now until the end of October.
Twelve performers will make hteir first appearance with the New York Philharmonic in the 1967-68 season, which begins for the orchestra at Philharmonic Hall on Oct. 5.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) A bill to provide Federal compensation when a state or local law enforcement officer is killed or disabled in helping enforce Federal laws was passed by the Senate today.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 14 (AP)--Charles O. Finley, owner of the Kansas City Athletics, tonight made his first official move toward requesting permission to move the club. He notified City Manager Carleton Sharpe by telegram that he did not intend to exercise his option to renew the lease on Municipal Stadium.

GLEN COVE, L.I. Sept. 14 Mrs. Rundlet Blakemore, Piping Rock, carded a par 4 at the 21st hole to beat Mrs. Allan A. Ryan, the Creek Club, in the semi-finals of the 12th Women's Cross County Golf Association match play championship at the Nassau Country Club today.

"I spent a long and troubled night on Sunday and after due deliberation I decided that it was more important to come in and teach on Monday than to picket," said Victor La Place, who once helped the teacher's union to recruit members at the School for the Deaf.

George C. Scott has bowed out as the director of "Dr. Cook's Garden," a melodrama starring Burl Ives and Keir Dullea. Ira Levin, the play's author, has taken over the direction. He said the opening would take place as planned on Sept. 25 at the Belasco Theater. The production is the Broadway season's first scheduled opening.

Miss Nancy Castro de Graves and John Hawkes Weaver, vice president of the real estate concern of Pease Elliman, were married last evening at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, where the Rev. Wilbur H. Tyte performed the ceremony. A reception was held at the home of Mrs. Colette Woods of 525 Park Avenue.
Opening dates for free professional performances of three plays at the 150-seat New Lafayette Theater, Seventh Avenue at 132d Street, were announced yesterday by Robert Macbeth, artistic director.

OUR carefree life of gaiety and games fell apart the moment my mother died. In the summer of 1933, when we went to Zubalovo, I found that the playground in the woods with its hoops and swings and its Robinson Crusoe tree house had vanished. The only things left were traces of sand in the woods.
Miss Irene McIntyre passed out coffee and doughnuts again yesterday morning to some of the same men she served refreshments to in the World War I trenches of France.
PALERMO, Italy, Sept. 14 Carlo Bazan, former president of the Bank of Sicily, and 27 other people were ordered today to stand trial on charges of embezzlement involving at least $1.6-million.
LONDON, Sept. 14 (AP)--Persecution of Christians in the Soviet Union is charged by a Ukrainian Baptist in a letter to be published in The Church Times Friday.

The foreclosure rate for all mortgage lenders in the second quarter declined to an annual rate of 4.77 for each 1,000 structures from a rate of 5.12 in the April-June quarter in 1966, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday.

ATLANTA, Sept. 14 A case of ninth-inning jitters caught up with the Mets tonight and the result was the dissipation of a one-run lead and an eventual 5-4 victory for the Atlanta Braves on an unearned run.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Sept. 14 Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Schleifer have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sue Barbara Schleifer, to Stephen A. Levy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Levy of Brooklyn, New York.
The Cerro Corporation, a producer and fabricator of nonferrous metals, announced here yesterday the election of Thomas F. Creamer as a director.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 14--Halfway through Dame Pattie's third straight America's Cup ordeal today, a skywriting plane urged everybody to "See It On Channel 6."
THERE were two simultaneous fashion shows at the St. Regis Roof yesterday. One was given by Bonwit Teller and had the usual complement of models.

GENEVA, Sept. 14 William C. Foster, the United States representative at the disarmament conference here, arguing in favor of a proposed treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons, said today that the pact would impose burdens on the nuclear powers and would confer economic advantages on the nonnuclear powers.
SHIMODA, Japan, Sept. 14 Senator Edmund S. Muskie warned Japanese critics of American policy in Asia today that they were helping to breed a new generation of "isolationists" in the United States.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 14--President Johnson flew to midcountry today to plead with the American people for help in passing his programs to fight crime and limit the sales of firearms.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Sept. 15-United States Army units and supporting aircraft and artillery killed 134 Vietcong on Wednesday in a 12-hour sweep 47 miles southwest of here, a military spokesman announced today.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 14 (UPI) The president of the New Orleans Metropolitan Crime Commission urged today that District Attorney Jim Garrison and District Judge Malcolm W. O'Hara be barred from participating in a grand jury's investigation of organized crime.

AGHIRDA, Sept. 14 Five miles north of Nicosia, on the road that leads to this village in the foothills of the Kyrenia Mountains, there is a large white sign that reads: "Welcome to the Turkish sectorthe economically blockaded area."

A bill that would permit taxicabs to carry one more passenger than present law allows provided the rider is under 7 years old and sits on the lap of an adult in the rear seat was approved yesterday by a City Council committee.
"THE trouble with grits in the North is," a Southern voice was saying, "nobody knows if it's singular or plural. It's plural."

TALCA, Chile, Sept. 14 The men were meeting in executive session last weekend under the grape arbor in the courtyard of the ramshackle Spanish colonial house that just a few days previously became the new headquarters in Talca Province for the National Confederation of Campesinos.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI) The Pentagon has on its drawing boards a new, dual purpose, superfighter to follow the controversial F-111, officials said today.
LONDON, Sept. 14 (AP) Air Vice Marshal Sir Robert George died in a hospital yesterday after being hit by an automobile, the police announced. He was 71 years old.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold Klein of 205 West End Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane W. Klein, to James Frederick Parver, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore S. Parver of 203 East 72d Street.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Sept. 14 Bloomingdale's gave a preview today of its new store that will open here at 9:30 A.M. tomorrow at the Mall, an elegant shopping center in this fashionable and affluent community.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 14 When the defender, Intrepid, boiled across the finish line at the end of the third match for the America's Cup today, the challenger, Dame Pattie, still was laboring three-quarters of a mile in her wake, throwing white spray from her bows and beaten decisively again.

The Triangle Conduit Cable Co., Inc., Newark, is planning its first major diversification into the consumer field through the proposed acquisition yesterday of the business and assets of the Rowe Manufacturing Division of the Canteen Corporation, Chicago. Canteen would receive about $25-million in cash and Triangle securities for the division.
It looks as if the New York Mets have it sewed up in the National League. But it's still touch-and-go in the American League for the New York Yankees.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI) Indiana lawmakers introduced legislation today to let the estate of the late Joseiah K. Lilly turn over his gold coin collection to the Smithsonian Institution in return for a Federal tax credit equal to its $5.5-million appraised value.

TRENTON, Sept. 14 A special legislative investigating committee accused Assemblyman Vito A. Albanese of McCarthyism today and declared that his charges of bribery were "wholly without support or corroboration."
The British Petroleum Company, Ltd., reported lower earnings for the first half this year despite higher sales and also announced yesterday deferred action on its interim dividend for 1967.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 14 The United States mission here and representatives of American volunteer agencies are locked in a dispute that has grown increasingly bitter.
The women's committee of the Japan International Christian University Foundation will hold its 11th annual luncheon Oct. 20 at the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14, The Federal Communications commission modified its stand today and told the Ameri- can Telephone and Telegraph company that it could defer until next spring $20-million of the $120-million in long-dis- tance rate cuts that the commission had ordered.

Michael Cacoyannis and Irene Pappas, who have interpreted Greek life onstage and in film, are preparing to give New Yorkers a 2,000-year-old Greek tragedy that they feel has things to say about the present Greek Government.

The Brooklyn chapter of CORE has compared the status of the Negro in America to that of the Jews in Hitler Germany in a document explaining why the civil rights group plans to leave the ghetto to "establish a new world."

SANDS POINT, L.I., Sept. 14 Mr. and Mrs. Louis F. Lauck have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss June Patrice Lauck, to Michael P. Elzay, son of Col. William O. Elzay, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Elzay.
The Handel Medallion, the city's highest cultural award, was presented yesterday to Richard Tucker, the Metropolitan Opera tenor.
A new round in maritime labor's demands for money benefits under the so-called "me too" procedure got under way yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, William McChesney Martin Jr., warned Congress today that the nation was in the grip of an "inflationary psychology." This, he said, is demonstrated by the "unwarranted spree" in stock prices, among other things.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler indicated today that he was confident that the voting provisions of the plan for creating new international monetary assets would not lead European nations to paralyze the plan by vetoes.
A city official disagreed yesterday with Federal recommendations that further cuts in the sulphur content of fuels be made now to curb growing air pollution.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Sept. 14 Joe Scannella, the coach of the C.W. Post Pioneers, is not a member of the life-is-rottenand-so-is-my-football-team fraternity, whose members tend to be pessimistic about everything from the weather to pre-game coin flips.

The deadline for a strike by 7,500 apartment building service workers in the Bronx was postponed from midnight to 8 A.M. today, but negotiations on a new contract were still deadlocked late last night.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI) The Interstate Commerce Commission today asked a Federal court in New York to authorize prompt consummation of the longdelayed merger of the Pennsylvania and New York Central railroads.

Armand Basile's recital program at Town Hall last night made stern demands on his technical and intellectual equipment. Besides two Scarlatti sonatas for a warmup, the Pennsylvania-born pianist took on the man-eating Liszt Sonata, which sprawls over half an hour in its one movement; the first ...
The mystery of who has been a big buyer of stock in the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company was partially solved yesterday.

KNOWING when to depart from the normal principles of bidding and play is one of the marks of an expert. Most players never open with a one-bid holding less than 10 high-card points, but there are exceptional cases.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 14 Dr. George Vlases Jr., director of technical services for the Bureau of Customs since 1956, died Tuesday night at the Johns Hopkins Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in New Carrollton.
George Lois, the often creative and sometimes explosive first vice president of Papert, Koenig, Lois, is leaving the agency to set up his own shop. The rumor has been in the wind for a while.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 14 Gov. George Romney moved briskly through Rochester last night and today telling everyone he encountered that private effort on the local level was the best means of achieving racial peace in the United States.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 14 Shelling by Chinese Communist troops in Tibet across the border into Sikkim was so light and ineffective today that Indian forces were instructed to hold their fire, the Defense Ministry announced.
BOSTON, Sept. 14 When Warren Schmakel became the football coach at Boston University in 1964, the Terriers had suffered through six consecutive losing seasons.
A program to arouse the interest of slum children in architecture as a profession was announced yesterday by the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects.

COLDWATER, Mich., Sept. 14 (UPI) The chairman and secretary of the Branch County Draft Board announced their resignations today, charging that four youths had escaped the draft through intervention by "state officials on the national level."

PASSAIC, N.J., Sept. 14 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Louis H. Brint of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Brint, to Eric Paul Juditz, son of Mr. and Mrs. David L. Juditz of Whitestone, Queens, New York.
FREEHOLD, N.J., Sept. 14 A New Jersey Roman Catholic priest defied his Bishop here today and declared he would continue to improvise masses, despite the threat of excommunication.
New York State, which recently suffered its first failure in attempting to borrow money for state university construction, negotiated a loan of almost $27-million yesterday.
FRUNZE, U.S.S.R., Sept. 12. Bacigalupo has swept through Uzbekistan and Kirghizia, and it is doubtful that any of them will ever he quite the same.
Bicyclists may now use the footbridge from Manhattan to Wards Island to ride in the traffic-free park there, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday at a City Hall news conference.
Teamster locals and major trucking companies in the metropolitan New York and New Jersey area agreed yesterday to a week's extension of their present contracts.
EMPIRE, Colo., Sept. 14 "The molybdenum shortage is over," H.A. Sawyer Jr., president of the Climax Molybdenum Co., declared here today.
The Rev. Francis J. Fuchs, pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Martin of Tours in Amityville, L.I., died in Brunswick Hospital there Wednesday after a long illness. He was 63 years old.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP) Don Buford hit a grand-slam home run with two out in the 10th inning tonight to give the Chicago White Sox a 4-0 victory over the Cleveland Indians behind Cisco Carlos's five-hitter.

ATLANTA, Sept. 14 Leaders of the National Council of Churhches committed a minimum of 10 per cent of the ecumenical organization's unrestricted capital funds tonight to "high-risk, low-return" investments in urban ghettos and called upon others to do likewise.

The State University of New York's Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn announced yesterday that Gordon M. Derzon had been named director of its new $25-million State University Hospital at 445 Lenox Road, Brooklyn.

A TELEVISION spin-off from the motion picture "Iron side" was introduced at 8:30 last night on Channel 4 with Raymond Burr playing the role of the detective in a wheelchair. The hour was a tepid whodunit of very modest interest over the network of the National Broadcasting Company.
MOSCOW, Sept. 14 (Reuters) A Soviet investigating commission was reported today to have rejected charges that Yuli M. Daniel, a Russian writer, was being mistreated at a labor camp.
The Federal Maritime Commission, for the first time in 51 years of regulating the nation's foreign ocean trade, ordered yesterday the dissolution of a steamship conference.

WHITEMARSH, Pa., Sept. 14 Bruce Devlin of Australia, found this a perfect golfing day. Scoring a 65, his best round of the year, the slim explumber from Canberra led the opening round of the $110,000 Philadelphia Classic by two strokes.

ALBANY, Sept. 14 Ten Democratic delegates at the Constitutional Convention are threatening to bolt from their party's position favoring the controversial proposal for establishing a system of free higher education in the state.
A top Democratic policy maker of the City Council told Republican Mayor Lindsay yesterday: Get the city out of the junked-automobile business.
HAZEL PARK, Mich., Sept. 14 (AP) Romulus Hanover won the $25,350 Little Brown Jug Trial at Hazel Park Raceway tonight in 1:58 2/5, the fastest mile of the 1967 Michigan season.

Dr. Frederick Lawson Hovde, the president of Purdue University, was the guest of honor yesterday at a reception at the Racquet and Tennis Club tendered by the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame.

GREENFIELD, Ind., Sept. 14 (AP) The Greenfield monthly Meeting of Friends, representing 282 Quakers in this eastern Indiana community, condemned today such actions as sending medical supplies to North Vietnam, opposing defense taxes and fighting the draft.

ROME, Sept. 14 Surgery for Pope Paul VI to correct a prostatic block may be put off for as long as two months if treatment with drugs keeps the condition in a nonacute state, according to Vatican sources.

TENAFLY, N.J., Sept. 14 The New Jersey Americans of the new American Basketball Association today announced a schedule of 78 games at a press luncheon in The Forge restaurant. The team will play 39 home contests in the Teaneck (N.J.) Armory.
Jacques Brel, the Belgian chansonnier who quit as a solo singer last winter to concentrate on ballad writing and recordings, will return to performing in Paris next fall as an actor.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 14 (AP) One of the leading backers of a proposed harness track in Secaucus, N.J., said today that there would be no conflict of interest if his group continued to hold stock in Roosevelt Raceway at Westbury, L.I.
James H. Binger, chairman of Honeywell, Inc., said yesterday that the company did not intend "to engage" in any additional sale and leaseback financing of computers for the foreseeable future."

LONDON, Sept. 14 The Earl of Iveagh, who cleared slums and financed scientific research with the vast fortune that he inherited as head of the Guinness brewery, was found dead today in bed at his home, Pyrford Court, Woking, near London. He was 93 years old.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 14 Kentucky's 47-year-old sedition law was ruled unconstitutional in United States District Court here today.
LONDON, Sept. 14 (Reuters) Prime Minister Wilson's Labor administration is the most unpopular British government since World War II, the Gallup Poll said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14Administration officials voiced skepticism tonight at the report of Agence France-Presse from Hanoi indicating a shift in North Vietnam's terms for beginning peace talks.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 14 (UPI) Sonny Randle, a split end who has caught 328 passes for 5,438 yards and 60 touchdowns in a career dating from 1959, was traded by the St. Louis Cardinals today to the San Francisco 49ers for a high draft choice.
With sugar prices on the rise in this country, the sugar quota is very much on traders' minds. Yesterday, Ramon Nolan, sugar quota administrator of the Philippines, spoke before the Sugar Club here.

WHEN Buster Mathis outpointed Joe Frazier to win the heavyweight designation in the 1964 final Olym pic tryout tournament, Buster weighed 315 pounds. He was astonishingly nimble at that displacement but he had it nonetheless. Now he is only a shadow of what he once was, a comparatively delicate and attenuated 245 pounds.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 14 Gripping pencils and sketch pads, dozens of soldiers and civilians are trudging into combat zones to re-create the moments of war.
MIAMI, Sept. 14 (UPI) The tropical storm Beulah swung free from a lid of cold air today to regain hurricane strength on its way toward western Cuba and possibly the Gulf Coast of the United States.

ROME, Sept. 14 (AP) Paul Roberts, a former United States professor of linguistics and author of textbooks, died today at the Santo Spirito Hospital. He had an accidental fall in his bathroom last night and did not regain conciousness. He was 49 years old.

SEWICKLEY, Pa., Sept. 14 Mr. and Mrs. Bernd Phelps Rose have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Chapin Rose, to William James King, son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. King of Wethersfield, Conn.

SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 14 Defense Minister Kim Sung Eun disclosed today that South Korea was considering building, with American help, an anti-infiltration barrier along Korea's 151-mile demilitarized zone. It would be similar to the barrier the United States plans to erect below the demilitarized zone in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 "It sure don't look like a museum," a sixth grader said today as she stood in front of the old Carver Theater, a movie house that has been transformed into the Anacostia Neighborhood Museum, which officially opens tomorrow night. "It's nice," she said after making a brief tour. "I think it'll be a real food thing."

The engagement of Miss Enid Weinberg to Ronald E. Groves has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Julie Weinberg of Kew Gardens Hills, Queens. Mr. Groves is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Groves of New Haven.
The Board of Education turned down a union bid for new negotiations yesterday as a massive teachers walkout crippled the city school system for the fourth day.

LONDON, Sep. 14 Denis Healey, the British Defense Secretary, and Eugene V. Rostow, third ranking man in the United States State Department, sought today to calm the storm that has been raised here by a Congressional vote banning the purchase of minesweepers from Britain.

The Brooklyn Lyric Opera Association plans new productions of three operas at the Brooklyn Academy of Music this season. The first, Nicolai's "The Merry Wives of Windsor," will be given Nov. 30. Ethel Green will design the production, Richard Flusser will be the stage director, and Siegfried Landau will conduct.

OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 14 Senator E. L. Bartlett asserted today that the transportation industry could be revolutionized through development of the widely accepted container concept. But he warned that it might be stifled by overregulation, for which he blamed both Government and industry.
FISHKILL, N.Y., Sept. 14 (AP) A one-third interest in President, a champion Black Angus bull, has been sold for $333,000, making him worth about $1-million, one of the owners said today.
DUBUQUE( Iowa, Sept. 14 (AP) Seven and one-quarter inches of rain fell on this eastern Iowa city during a 24-hour period, resulting in one death and minor property damage.
The Geigy Chemical Corporation has leased one of several buildings planned in the Cross Westchester Corporate Park, which is under construction on a 102-acre site off Haviland Lane in Harrison, N.Y.

LAKELAND, Fla., Sept. 14 Henry S. Manley, former Solicitor General of the State of New York and an authority on Indian affairs and constitutional law, died today in Lakeland General Hospital after a long illness. He was 75 years old and lived here and at Green Valley Farm in Strykersville, N.Y.
Alexander Rittmaster, a longtime investment counselor to Louis E. Wolfson, took the witness stand in Federal court here yesterday as a key prosecution witness against the millionaire industrialist.

An unbelievably wonderful performance by Fortune Ryan's Quick Pitch thrilled and delighted the crowd of 26,974 at Aqueduct yesterday. The 7-year-old gelding carried the awesome burden of 172 pounds to victory in the $11,650 Rouge Dragon Hurdle Handicap for his sixth straight success.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14--Dr. Edward Hirsch Levi, a native of Chicago who attended classes from kindergarten through law school at the University of Chicago, was elected today as the university's new president.
ALBANY, Sept. 14 (AP) Two Nobel Prize winners and a leading economist have been appointed to the State University faculty, the university's trustees announced today.

Standing outside the main office of the New York Public Library and gazing dreamily at a young girl in a miniskirt, Raymond Fields decided at 1 P.M. yesterday to buy his first New York state lottery ticket.

An extradition hearing for Harold (Hal) C. Banks, former head of the seafarers International Union of Canada, was adjourned yesterday until next Wednesday after heated argument in Federal Court in Brooklyn.

Directors of the Alleghany Corporation, the big holding company that controls the New York Central Railroad and Investers Diversified Corporation, the mutual fund and insurance company group, yesterday elected Fred M. Kirby as chairman.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14The Johnson Administration mounted a concerted attack today on a proposal by Senator Robert F. Kennedy to build more and better low-cost housing in the slums through private enterprise.

The duties of chief executive officer of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company were transferred yesterday to Alexander H. Galloway, the 59-year-old president, from Bowman Gray, the chairman. Mr. Gray is 60.
TOKYO, Sept. 14 (Reuters) Ratna Sari Dewi, the third wife of deposed President Sukarno of Indonesia, left here today to stay with a New York author to escape "slanders and insults."
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 96.1 on Wednesday, from 95.6 on Tuesday. A year earlier it was 108.3.

Money continued to be readily available during the week ended Wednesday, banking statistics released yesterday indicated. But, as has been the case for the last few weeks, there were signs that the pace of monetary expansion has moderated since midsummer.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 14 Mayor Henry W. Maier today denounced white rioters who have attacked the police with bricks and bottles for the last two nights.

HANOI, North Vietnam, Sept. 14 Reliable sources here indicated today that if the United States stopped bombing North Vietnam, talks between Hanoi and Washington could begin three or four weeks afterward.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) A program of Government-subsidized insurance for property owners in flood-prone areas was approved today by the Senate by a voice vote.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 14 With song and cele bration, Macy's New York opened a new department store here today, starting what resi dents hope will he a vast comercial revival in this proud but blight-marked city on Long Island Sound.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 14 The Most Rev. Fulton J. Sheen, Bishop of Rochester, has ordered broad reforms for the diocesan seminary, including the appointment of seven lay persons to consider the fitness of aspirants to the Roman Catholic priesthood.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 Opposition mounted today to the plan of Representative Patman to require auditing of the Federal Reserve System by the General Accounting Office.

KINSHASA, the Congo, Sept. 14 Secretary General Thant of the United Nations told the Organization of African Unity today that Africans ought not to be discouraged by slow progress in overcoming their problems, nor should they think they could solve the problems without outside help.

The Signal Oil and Gas Company, which acquired Mack Trucks, Inc., last month, announced yesterday a preliminary agreement of merger with Dunham-Bush, Inc., in an exchange of stock involving almost $19-million.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 15 The resident aristocrats who give this patrician old seaside resort its vitality are not likely to starve. Besides breakfast, lunch and dinner, they regularly have afternoon tea.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (ap) President Johnson clipped a blue and white Pleiku Province ribbon to the battle flag of the First Cavalry Division (Airmobile) today and paid tribute to the unit for proving "the enemy can never win Vietnam by armed conquest."

The Nassau County Health Department will begin a series of tests next week to determine if jets flying in and out of Kennedy International Airport are causing air pollution that is hazardous to health in nearby communities.
Loans to Thailand, Iran and Israel totaling an equivalent of $63-million were announced yesterday by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank).
The Public Service Commission said yesterday it had given final approval for a third gas transmission line under the Hudson River between Cortlandt in Westchester County and Stony Point in Rockland.
Prices bid for silver moved higher yesterday at the weekly General Services Administration auction in Washington.

Four men who were seized in a series of raids Aug. 23 that netted a large arsenal were indicted yesterday by a Bronx grand jury on a charge of attempted murder. A fifth member of the group was charged with attempting to transport weapons into the state.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 15 (AP) Steve Carlton shut out the Cincinnati Reds on two hits tonight and Mike Shannon's three-run homer carried the St. Louis Cardinals to a 4-0 victory.

BONN, Sept. 15 Albert Widmann, a chemist who helped design and test mobile gas chambers, left a Stuttgart court a free man today despite a six-and-a-half-year prison sentence for having abetted the murder of more than 4,000 Jews and mentally ill people in eastern Europe.
Columbia University announced yesterday that Sidney Berengarten, professor of social work at the university's School of Social Work, had been named acting dean of the school.

SEATTLE, Sept. 15 (UPI)--The Executive Council of the Episcopal Church in the United States overwhelmingly adopted today a major policy change designed to put the power of the church behind efforts to alleviate conditions of ghetto Negroes.

Net earnings of the United States Shoe Corporation and its subsidiaries for the nine months ended July 31 were reported yesterday at $6,068,000, equal to $1.60 a share on the average of 3,790,000 shares outstanding. This compares with $5,894,000 or $1.56 a share on 3,768,000 shares in the corresponding 1966 period.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 15 The oMst Rev. Fulton J. Sheen, Bishop of Rochester, and the president of the Rochester Area Council of Churches announced tonight the establishment of a Roman aCtholic-Protestant Office of Urban Ministry "to help solve the basic problems of the first citizen of the church the poor man."

BONN, Sept. 15 Shouting students broke through the locked doors of West Berlin's City Hall today as the city's Mayor, Heinrich Albertz, was preparing to defend himself against charges of misgovernment.

NEW DELHI Why does the United States, in view of its many domestic burdens, provide loans, grants and technical assistance to promote economic development in Asia, Africa and Latin America? What can the United States reasonably expect in return for such assistance?

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 Senator Robert F. Kennedy's plan to rebuild the nation's slums, assailed yesterday by Administration officials, received today the unqualified endorsement of two former members of the Government. Both suggested that the Administration's present attitude toward the bill was unnecessarily narrow.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI) The Government is trying to keep contractors who refuse to hire Negroes for better-paying jobs from getting any part of the $4-billion allocated for highway construction.
Briskly, efficiently and somewhat out of recent character, the Yankees whipped the Cleveland Indians last night, 5-1, before a paying crowd of 7,605.

ROME, Sept. 15 Twentyfour delegates of the eight-nation Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries met behind closed doors today to begin discussions on the oil situation following the ArabIsraeli war of last June.

WNYC-TV (Channel 31) will carry live and in color Tuesday the opening of the 22d General Assembly of the United Nadons. The telecast, which will begin at 3 P.M., will be the first time the event has been transmitted in color by the United Nations.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 15 Everyone on the University of Pittsburgh football staff is pleased with the way things are going for the Panthers. But this optimism has little bearing on the season's prospects, which seem as hopeless as they were a year ago when Pitt went through a season with only one victory in 10 games.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) The White House denied today a published report that a political agent had been assigned to start organizing support for President Johnson in New Hampshire's 1968 Presidential primary.
SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 15 The United States Army is building an anti-infiltration barrier along the 18 -mile-long American-held sector of Korea's demilitarized zone, a spokesman said today.

PRAGUE, Sept. 15--Thomas G. Masaryk, who founded--some say invented--modern Czechoslovakia and whose memory has been first condemned and then ignored in the Czech press for the last 19 years, was paid an extraordinary tribute on the front page of a leading periodical here today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 15 Lieut. Gen. James M. Gavin renewed his attack today on the conduct of the Vietnam war and avoided removing himself as a possible Presidential contender in 1968.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 15 The Organization of African Unity backs Nigeria's federal military Government and is sending a mission of African heads of state to Lagos next month as a "public expression" of support, the head of Nigeria's delegation to the O.A.U. said here today.

The pound sterling eased somewhat in light trading here yesterday, closing at $2.7836 against $2.7845 on Thursday. Forward rates for delivery in 90 days narrowed slightly to $2.7782 for a discount of 54 points, against 56 a day earlier.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Sept. 16 A state of emergency has been declared in Danang, apparently in an attempt to avert threatened antiGovernment demonstrations by militant Buddhist monks and their followers, The Saigon Post reported today.
ROME, Sept. 15 (UPI) Pope Paul VI has resumed his daily desk work, although a urinarytract infection may require surgery later, a Vatican source said tonight.

WOMEN over 30 who have been feeling melancholy about the generation gap in fashion may want to take note of the opening Monday of the Sara Fredericks Salon at 11 West 57th Street, formerly the home of Revillon Freres.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 15 Assagai of the Cragwood Stable will seek to make it two in a row in the United Nations Handicap tomorrow. The Kentucky-bred, owned by Charles Engelhard, will compete against eight rivals and the overnight line gives him the favorite's chance at 3-1 of duplicating his 1966 victory in the 1 3-16-mile grass race.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 15 The engagement of Miss Margaret Rose Appelbaum of New York to Sanford Harold Levine of Albany has been announced by Mrs. Samuel Appelbaum, mother of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Levine of Troy.

One sign of a peppy futures market is rising prices for mem berships on a commodity exchange. Yesterday, the New York Cocoa Exchange announced sale of a membership for $21,000, up $500 from the previous transaction, and the highest seat price sale in the exchange's 42-year-old history.

Gov. George Romney toured ghetto areas in Brooklyn yesterday, brushing off a delegation of Democratic officials who flew here from Michigan to urge that he return to the "urgent problems" in his home state.
New York University will bar artists in the Greenwich Village outdoor art show next spring from displaying their work in front of seven houses the school owns on Washington Square North.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 15 (AP) Gov. Ronald Reagan's administration was prohibited today from imposing its planned $210-million cutback in California's medical care program for the poor.
SEATTLE, Sept. 15 Senator Warren G. Magnuson told a delegation of maritime officials today that the largest merchant marine expansion program "in decades" would be enacted by the 90th Congress.
A union of building service workers and a major Bronx realty group reached agreement early yesterday on a new three-year contract and averted a threatened strike at 1,800 apartment buildings.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that over-the-counter trading in the common stock of Tel-A-Sign, Inc., of Chicago may resume on Sept. 20. But it cautioned investors that the company was involved in a bankruptcy case. The American Stock Exchange, which also suspended advised the S.E.C. it would continue its suspension.

Okinawa, the largest island of the Ryukyu chain, was captured by American forces in June, 1945, in one of the bloodiest campaigns of World War II. The Ryukyus were left under United States jurisdiction by the 1952 peace treaty, with the promise of eventual return to Japanese rule.

DETROIT, Sept. 15 (UPI) Willie Horton, given life when Paul Casanova dropped his foul pop-up, singled in the winning run in the ninth inning to give Detroit a 5-4 victory over the Washington Senators tonight and move the Tigers into a three-way tie for first place.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 15 The first three cars, of a Haifabound freight train were derailed early today when the engine detonated two of four mines placed on an Israeli rail line at a point where it runs near the Jordanian town of Tulkarm. No one was injured.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 15 United States infantrymen rushed ashore from armored assault boats today and came under heavy fire from a battalion of Vietcong troops in the Mekong Delta, about 45 miles southwest of Saigon.

WHITEMARSH, Pa., Sept. 15 George Archer played into the rough purposely today yet scored a 66 to lead the $110,000 Philadelphia Classic with a 36-hole total of 134. The former ranch hand from Gilroy, Calif., recovered so well from the tall grass at seven holes that he established a three-stroke advantage with his six-under-par round.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 15 Ambassador Arthur J. Goldberg will discuss a United Nations role in ending the war in Vietnam with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union, Senator Joseph S. Clark said today.

ON certain subjects there is simply no arguing, and Gilbert and Sullivan is one. You are either a G. S. fan, and totally, unabashed about it, whatever your other cravings and commitments; or you're not.

Superintendent of Schools Bernard E. Donovan nominated two long-time city educators as top aides yesterday, including a woman who would become the highest ranking Negro and the first woman deputy superintendent of the school system.

GENEVA, Sept. 15 William C. Foster, director of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, said today that he believed that an agreement could be reached with the Soviet Union on Article III, the missing inspection article, of the proposed treaty, barring the further spread of nuclear weapons.
Three major lumber associations reported an increase of 1 per cent in production for the week ended Sept. 9, compared with the level in the corresponding 1966 week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) Commissioner of Education Harold Howe 2d said today that there was no conflict of interest involved in the proposed financing of a Westinghouse Corporation project by an Office of Education Bureau headed by a former Westinghouse official.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI) The Defense Department identified today 55 United States servicemen killed in action in Vietnam, including: ...
It was elementary, Watson. The 25-year-old jockey from Puerto Rico, Angel Cordero Jr., went to the post seven times at Aqueduct yesterday and simply rode four winners.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 Industrial production rose nearly one per cent in August, adding further to the picture of an economy that is rebounding from the sluggishness shown in the first half of this year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The United States has decided to deploy a limited missile defense around the country.
THE National Football League opens its regular season tomorrow, and the New York Giants are expected to start the new year the way they ended the old by losing.
STOCKHOLM, Sept. 15 (Reuters) The World Bank will float a 75 million krona ($14.5-million) bond issue on the Swedish capital market in mid-October.
HONG KONG, Sept. 15 (UPI) The yacht Phoenix, with an American crew, arrived today from Japan on its way to North Vietnam with a cargo of medical supplies.

SHIMODA, Japan, Sept. 15 Mike Mansfield, the majority leader of the Senate, proposed tonight that Japan, the United States and possibly the Soviet Union should open "a joint consideration of the security questions of the western Pacific."
The Chase Manhattan Bank, New York's largest bank, announced yesterday a reshuffle of its two senior management that gives broad new responsibility to its two youngest executive vice presidents.
ALBANY, Sept. 15 Judges attending the Constitutional Convention took the floor today to attack one another personally, mock one another's names and gestures and question one another's intelligence.
For the first time in its 102year history, the Salvation Army will intensively recruit students on college campuses, offering $45 to $85 a week to work among the world's "down and out."

BAY SHORE, L.I,, Sept. 15 Mike Ryan of Southward Ho scored 74-79 153 to win the Long Island Senior Golf Association championship for the second time in three years at the Southward Ho Country Club today.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 15 Richard M. and James W. Sykes of. Manhasset Bay Y.C., Ports Washington, L.I., alternating at the helm of Dixie, won the first two races of the third annual national championship of the Shields Class on Long Island Sound today. The three-day regatta opened with rails-down sailing in a stiff northeast Wind off American Y.C.
"Whatever I succeed in doing will be meaningful to other Negroes and help them to identify with society."
The sale of Israel bonds soared to a record of $171,256, 000 between Jan. 1 and Sept. 12 this year, more than three times the amount sold in the same period last year.
CHICAGO, Sept. 15 A rotting black ghetto of shabby buildings and trash-littered streets on Chicago's South Side was tense but generally calm tonight after outbreaks of racial violence yesterday.
IT was certainly one of the most unusual things to happen in Wall Street in some time. And it happened to the Responsive Environments Corporation.
TRENTON, Sept. 15 The special effort to recruit Negroes for the New Jersey National Guard has brought in 87 new men so far, the State Department of Defense reported today.

QUEBEC, Sept. 15 (AP)--France and the Province of Quebec announced today wide agreement on further cooperation in educational and cultural fields after five days of talks between France's Education Minister, Alain Peyrefitte, and provincial officials.
TRENTON, Sept. 15 The Republican state chairman urged State Attorney General Arthur J. Sills today to supersede the prosecutors in counties where widespread organized crime has been reported.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that he had no evidence to confirm press reports that North Vietnam was showing renewed interest in peace talks or new flexibility in its bargaining position.

ISLIP, L.I., Sept. 15 The engagement of Miss Barbara Forman and Peter M. Weinstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Moses M. Weinstein of Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Morris Forman.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 Secretary of State Dean Rusk today deflected the suggestion from Senator Mansfield for joint United states-JapaneseSoviet consideration of security problems of the western Pacific area.
Robert 35X Smith, a Black Muslim on trial for the attempted murder of three detectives, was gagged and handcuffed yesterday after disrupting the court's proceedings.

ATLANTA, Sept. 15 Dr. Arthur S. Flemming, former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, joined fellow leaders of the National Council of Churches today in a sharp attack on proposed limitations of Federal aid to local welfare programs.

The New York City Opera's production of "La Traviata," new last year, turned up at the State Theater last night as a reminder of what good theater the Verdi work can be in the hands of an imaginative director and a cast of actor-singers. As director, Frank Corsaro was responsible for constant touches in the staging that made the opera seem fresh, the characters natural, their motivation understandable.

SAIGON, Sept. 15 (AP) Although they would not comment publicly, many United States officials here made it clear today that they felt it was unfortunate that the Government had decided to press the charges against Mr. Dzu at this time.
Prices were generally firm yesterday in moderate trading on the London Stock Exchange.

A STRONG and urgent television editorial de manding that society either correct the legitimate grievances of desparing and oppressed Negroes or face the prospect of violent civil war was presented last night by the National Broadcasting Company in a documentary produced by Fred Freed.

Morris Klaif, an authority on imperial Russian coins and Canadian coins and the owner of a rare-coin shop in Brooklyn for about 10 years till 1966, died yesterday in the Masonic Home, Utica, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 76 years old.
A choice selection of Mozart's sonatas for piano and violin were played at Town Hall last night by Mario Miranda, pianist, and Gabriel Banat, Violinist.

LANSING, Mich., Sept. 15 (AP) The Rev. James J. Kavanaugh, author of "A Modern Priest Looks At His Outdated Church," has been termed "a disobedient priest" by his bishop, the Most Rev. Alexander Zaleski of the Lansing Roman Catholic Diocese.

MONTREAL, Sept. 15 The Soviet Union flew in new intercontinental jet, the 186passenger Ilyushin-62, 6,000 miles from Moscow to Montreal today in 9 hours 20 minutes, cutting 1 hours off the scheduled time.
ALLENTOWN, N.J., Sept. 15 (UPI) One 18-year-old airman was killed and three were injured today, when their car crashed into a utility pole on Allentown-Crosswicks road in nearby Hamilton Township.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 15 Mrs. Joseph Gallagher has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Margaret M. Gallagher, to Thomas R. Ryan, son of Mrs. Frank Ryan of Somerville and the late Mr. Ryan.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 (AP) Bill Singer, a rookie, and Don Drysdale pitched the Los Angeles Dodgers to a pair of 1-0 victories over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight.
A FEW days before he became president of the city's Board of Education last May, Alfred Anthony Giardino, a barber's son, calmly told an acquaintance that he knew it was a "hot seat."

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (AP) A Treasury Department official said tonight in a talk that the Government would be forced to borrow an extra $2-billion by the end of December if Congress fails to approve higher taxes this year.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 15 Gale-force winds today, the prospect of more of the same tomorrow and the threat of Hurricane Doria's big fist in the background led to a postponement this afternoon of tomorrow's fourth sailing match for the America's Cup.
OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 15 (UPI) An Army private who says his war is being fought in the ghettos of Philadelphia was arrested today for refusing to board a troop plane to Vietnam.

The Metropolitan Opera, which opens its 1967-68 season on Monday, will give the season's first performance of Puccini's "Manon Lescaut" on Saturday, Oct. 21, with Renata Tebaldi in the title role and Richard Tucker appearing as Des Grieux. On Thursday of the same week, the fifth of the Metropolitan's season, Jeannette Pilou will make her first appearance here as Violetta in "La Traviata."
A 3-year-old boy was killed by a hit-and-run driver yesterday.
Vice Adm. Andrew M. Jackson Jr., U.S.N., will be guest of honor at a regimenta review at the United States Merchant Marine Academy today at 10:30 A.M.
BALDWIN, L. I., Sept. 15--The school board here voted today to dismiss charges that the only Negro teacher at Baldwin High School had molested a 16-year-old white student.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 15 The border between Sikkim and Tibet was quiet today after four days of shelling by Indian and Chinese troops.
Higher interest rates and improved business are in prospect for the balance of 1967 and into 1968, a top-level group of bankers, economists and investment men concluded here yesterday.
The construction of a mental hospital designed like a shopping center on Wards Island was announced yesterday by Governor Rockefeller.
The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York has established two experimental parishes where priests will operate as "teams of equals" and not under a pastor.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 President Johnson tried to put still more steam today into his campaign for a gun control law, declaring that "a civilized nation cannot allow this armed terror to continue."
The Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral was the setting yesterday afternoon for the wedding of Miss Virginia Anne Petty to Dr. John Joseph Dorsey. Msgr. Thomas McGovern officiated.
Investors closed out an active week on the trading front but left prices somewhat mixed yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.
The Rockettes will be kicking up their heels outside rather than inside Radio City Music Hall today on a picket line.

JOEL M. REED used to be in public relations, but he got tired of it. He was always being asked to think up unusual ideas for parties to introduce products or people. Last March, he decided it would be more fun (and probably more profitable) to introduced himself instead in the party business.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) The Internal Revenue Service is seeking $14,485.32 in back income taxes from the estate of Thomas (Three Finger Brown) Luchese, papers on file at the United States Tax Court showed today.
LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 15--Grey Ghost, an 8-year-old gelding, survived a jumpoff to win the amateur-owner jumping championship at the Piping Rock horse show today.
When is a woman not a woman? When her chromosomes don't add up.

AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 15 Prospects for further drastic cuts in Texas oil production were heightened today when both the United States Bureau of Mines and crude-oil buyers recommended that October production be cut further.

ALBANY, Sept. 15 The sale of state lottery tickets climbed to $5,987,201 in August, a gain of nearly $1.9-million from July but still $465,510 below the initial sales in June, the State Tax Department reported today.
CAIRO, Sept. 15 Aside from sandbags cluttering the en- trances to public buildings, banks and, for some reason, newspaper offices, Cairo is a most unwarlike city.
DETROIT, Sept. 15 (AP) For the first time since they strike at the Ford Motor Company began nine days ago, bargaining teams from Ford and the United Auto Workers resumed contract negotiations today.

Robert Payne, biographer, political analyst, historian, novelist, translator, poet and travel writer, roughly calculates that within three years the 100th book with his name on the cover will be published. Meantime, he has become general editor of The Russian Library, issued by Washington Square Press, which could be a career in itself.

The executive sales and services offices of the Mergenthaler Linotype Company in Brooklyn, will be transferred to Plainview, L,I., in November. Mergenthaler, maker of Linotype machines and graphic arts equipment, is a division of the Eltra Corporation, a diversified industrial concern.

DETROIT, Sept. 15 (AP)--The Chryslyer Corporation said today that it was recalling 957 Rootes Arrow sedans and station wagons because of a possible defect in the mounting bracket of a rod in the front suspension brake reaction apparatus.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 Joe Horlen, who pitched a no-hit game last Sunday against the Detroit Tigers, limited the Minnesota Twins to three hits tonight in a 7-3 victory that moved the fourth-place Chicago White Sox to within 1 games of a triple tie for the American League lead.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 Diplomatic sources said today that President Gamal Abdel Nasser had told other Arab leaders that he knew the United States had not participated militarily in the war between Israel and the Arabs in June.
Organized attempts were made to fan and guide the violence of the Detroit riot, a televised news special reported last night.

GREAT RIVER, L.I., Sept. 15 Hartland St. Clair West, who retired in 1958 as a vice president of J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., the year before the banking company's merger into the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, died here yesterday in his home. His age was 74.

ADEN, Sept. 15 (Agence France-Presse) Egyptian and Yemeni republican forces killed 250 tribesmen and suffered 160 casualties in a clash at Ibb, 20 miles north of Taiz, the Aden radio reported tonight.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., the world's largest nickel producer, announced yesterday that it was increasing the price of regular electrolytic nickel in the United States by 8 cents a pound, to 94 cents.
DETROIT, Sept. 15 Striking Detroit teachers will vote Sunday on a proposal to end their strike and put a wage dispute to binding arbitration.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 15 Truong Dinh Dzu, who ran second in the South Vietnamese presidential election was convicted today an charges of having issued a bad check and of having illegally transferred $11,500 to a bank in the United States.

Sydney Hogerton, former general manager in charge of operations for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Long Lines Department died Tuesday in Brunswick, Ga. He was 91 years old and had lived in Garden City, L.I.
Mrs. Mollie Fein Abrahamson, widow of Alexander Abrahamson, vice president and sales manager of the Chunky Chocolate Corporation, died of cancer Thursday in WilkesBarre (Pa.) She was 76 years old.
LANSING, Mich., Sept. 15 (UPI) The Michigan director of Selective Service denied charges today that four youths from prominent families escaped the draft because "state officials" intervened.
LAST February's customs law, which changed the definition of an antique, seems to have had less effect on the market than has the taste of collectors.
A new method of communication is developing in our society the technique of multi media.
HOUSTON, Tex., Sept. 15 (AP) The University of Houston, led by the running of Paul Gipson and Warren McVea, opened its football season tonight by crushing Florida State, 33-13, in the Astrodome.

NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 15 The Rev. James Nelson Zeigler, former pastor of the Community Baptist Church here, died today in Providence Hospital, Holyoke, Mass. He suffered a heart attack while en route to Vermont with his wife. He was 63 years old and lived here at 11 Bedford Avenue.

ATLANTA, Sept. 15 (AP) Ferguson Jenkins broke a club season strike-out record that had stood for more than half a century tonight as he pitched the Chicago Cubs to a 7-1 victory over the Atlanta Braves.
Jess Krueger, a former reporter, columnist and promotion editor for the Hearst newspaper chain, died on Thursday at Le Roy Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 33 East 22d Street.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15 A $2.4-million medical clinic, aimed at alleviating one of the most serious deficiencies in the Negro district of Watts, will be dedicated tomorrow.

Shareholders of American Telephone Telegraph, the nation's most widely held common stock, were the chief beneficiaries of the Federal Communications Commission's decision to modify its demand for interstate rate reductions. Dr. Ludwig T. Graham, a gynecologist and anesthetist, died yesterday at Montefiore Hospital, the Bronx. He was 65 years old and lived at 11 Riverside Drive. His office was at 35 West 81st Street.
TOULON, France, Sept. 17 (AP)--Two French scientists who were poisoned early this month while doing research on an insect-killer gas died this weekend. A third is still being treated.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17--The editor and writer Harry S. Ash- more reported today that he relayed a peace message to Ho Chi Minh on behalf of the State Department last February.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 17 (AP) --Members of the Cleveland Orchestra voted today to accept a new three-year contract, but bitterness between one group of musicians and their union officers continued.
The Rockettes, members of the ballet corps and singers at the Radio City Music Hall, continued picketing yesterday in their strike, which began midnight Friday.
The municipal bond market this week again will provide the best evidence of what is happening to interest rates.
The first woman to be appointed to a New York State draft board says she hopes to bring a more "compassionate" approach to draft problems.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17-- Attorney General Ramsey Clark accused the Republicans today of jeopardizing the drive against organized crime through "partisan, political distortions."

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 17-- A gang of motorcyclists wearing black leather jackets and swastikas stormed into a tavern here early today, smashed the windows and furniture, beat several customers, stabbed the bar owner in the back and fled with $200 from his cash register.
SUMMIT, N.J., Sept. 17-- Diane Ward rode Smoke Rise Stable's Southern Comfort to the open jumper championship at the Watchung Hunter Horse Show today.

Following, as made public yesterday by the Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions in Santa Barbara, Calif., is the text of a letter sent to Ho Chi Minh last February by Harry S. Ashmore, the editor:
Ralph Lao, president of the Metropolitan Cycle Club, Inc., was on hand in the bright noonday sunshine in Union Square yesterday to improve the image of motorcycling.
Mayor Lindsay has asked the Board of Education to add one school day at the end of the spring term for each day of the teacher work stoppage. The stoppage goes into its sixth school day today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17-- Gov. George Romney's Presidential stock dropped sharply tonight in the first report of the effect on voters of his charge that he had been "brainwashed" by the military and diplomatic corps in Vietnam in 1965.

ADEN, Sept. 17 (Reuters)-- The militant National Liberation Front said today that it was willing to govern the South Arabian Federation in partnership with the rival nationalist group it has been battling for months--the Egyptian-backed Front for the Liberation of South Yemen.
RIVERSIDE, Calif., Sept. 17 (UPI)--David Pearson of Spartanburg, S.C., drove his Cougar to victory today in the 250-mile Mission Bell TransAmerican sedan race at Riverside Raceway.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Sept. 17 --Malcolm S. Forbes, a prosperous Republican of Scottish descent, celebrated the 50th anniversary of his family's Forbes business magazine by giving a party last night that may be described as one of the country's largest single assemblies of working tycoons.
SEATTLE, Supt. 17 (AP)-- Raymond E. Daughters, swimming coach who developed three Olympic medalists, died yesterday after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

Daniel D. Strohmeier, vice president of Bethlehem Steel Corporation in charge of shipbuilding, announced the appointment yesterday of John M. Asphar as assistant to the vice president, shipbuilding department.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 17 --Mrs. Joy Gatchell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Fields of New York, was married this afternoon in the Princeton Jewish Center to Edward Frieman, professor of astrophysical science at Princeton University. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Frieman of Brooklyn. Rabbi Everett Gendler performed the ceremony.

Miss Patricia Lou Edgar, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Robert A. Edgar of 131 East 69th Street, was married here yesterday to Ronald D. Garrison, son of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Garrison of Turlock, Calif. The Rev. Richard Pease performed the ceremony in the Central Presbyterian Church, of which the bride's father is pastor.

Buster Mathis is scheduled to make his first appearance as a main-event fighter in Madison Square Garden tonight, against an opponent about 3 inches shorter, 50 pounds lighter and infinitely less valuable. His name is Ron Marsh.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17-- Ambassador-at-Large Henry Cabot Lodge denied today that anyone had been brainwashed while he was Ambassador to South Vietnam.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Sept. 17 --President Kenneth D. Kuanda said today that a formula for release of white mercenaries in the Congo to a European country was agreed on last week at the Kinshasa meeting of the Organization of African Unity.

The International Longshoremen's Association has announced that several hundred longshoremen from the Manhattan locals will stay away from their jobs today and stage a protest at City Hall against the city's failure to develop the waterfront in the borough.
Several teachers who stayed away from work in city schools last week are due to appear before a Brooklyn draft board tonight for interviews involving their Selective Service Status.
Governor Rockefeller praised the new Jonah B. Wise Community Center as "another home for rich humanism" at dedication ceremonies yesterday

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 17--Jim Hart threw four interceptions and Fran Tarkenton threw three touchdown passes. That was the story behind the New York Giants' decisive victory over the St. Louis Cardinals at Busch Memorial Stadium today in one of the eight opening games of the National Football League's 48th season.
The Israel Bond Organization announced yesterday the start of a sale of a new issue of $500-million in State of Israel bonds to help open "a new era of economic development and progress" for Israel.

The conductor and two sopranos were new to the staff and cast of Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro" in the performance given by the New York City Opera at the New York State Theater on Saturday night, but things went so smoothly and entertainingly that one would not have guessed that any newcomers were present.

Oliver O. Ostier, president of Ostier, Inc., custom jewelers at 5 East 57th Street, died after a brief illness Saturday in his some at 40 Central Park South. He was 65 years old and also had a summer home in Woodblock, N.Y.
DETROIT, Sept. 17--Parke, Davis Co., last week began marketing a new pain reliever in the United States, its second drug to be cleared by the Food and Drug Administration this year.

SUMMIT, N.J., Sept. 17-- Maurice R. McKenney of 24 Sunset Drive, a general patent attorney for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company from 1945 to 1952, died today at Overlook Hospital. He was 76 years old, and had retired in 1955.
FASHION society is playing a new game. It hasn't been named yet but it could be called "spokesman."
More fuel was added last week to the raging controversy over industrial aid financing amid reports that several huge new issues are being prepared for market.
BRIDGEHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 17--The no-vacancy signs were lighted this weekend all over this Eastern Long Island resort area.

KIEV, U.S.S.R., Sept. 17 (AP) --Viktor Saneyev won the triple jump with a leap of 54 feet 8 inches today and clinched the gold Bruno Zauli Cup for the European men's track championship for the Soviet Union.
STOURBRIDGE, England, Sept. 17 (AP)--The life of a trainee skydiver was saved by his instructor today.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 17--Denis Hulme and Bruce McLaren of New Zealand finished one, two today in a 200-mile Canadian-American Challenge Cup sports car race. It was the second race of they rich six-race series and the second straight victory for Hulme, who, incidentally, is the current leader for the world driver championship in Formula One cars.

ROME, Sept. 17--Pope Paul VI, appearing in better health today than last Sunday and speaking with a far stronger, surer voice, thanked all those who had shown an interest in his illness and offered a prayer for the sick, "to whom, in these days, we feel particularly close."

The National Bank of North America and the Security National Bank, two major long Island-based banks, announced yesterday agreements under which mercants who accept the Uni-Card credit card will be able to get immediate cash for sales made under the credit card plan.
