HIGHLAND PARK, N.J., Sept. 17--The Rev. George J. Hafner moved forward on the sofa and carefully emptied a bottle of St. Emilion 1959 into 16 wine glasses on the marble coffee table before him.

CAIRO, Sept. 17--President Gamal Abdel Nasser outlined plans tonight for a diplomatic offensive at the coming session of the United Nations General Assembly to offset the Arab defeat in June in the war with Israel.

Jay Stanwyck, an Off Broadway producer and the director of research for the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company, died at the New York Hospital on Friday. She lived at 353 East 50th Street and would have been 58 years old today.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn,, Sept. 17 (AP)--Doug Cunningham, a rookie, and Kermit Alexander ignited a San Francisco firsthalf offensive that produced a commanding lead today, but the 49ers had to fend off a threetouchdown fourth-quarter rally by Minnesota to beat the Vikings, 27-21.

RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 16-- North Carolina Republicans, convinced they have a chance to elect their first Governor in this century, are caught up in a major struggle for the party's gubernatorial nomination.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 17-- Labor problems made the steel outlook hazy last week.
SEATTLE, Sept. 17--The Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church placed the weight of his office today behind efforts to unite 10 major Protestant bodies, including his own.

The impact of technological development on employment conditions and vocational traininging at sea will be discussed by the Joint Maritime Commission of the International Labor Organization meeting Sept. 25Oct. 6 in Geneva.

HARRISON, N.Y., Sept. 17-- Stuart Feick scored three goals and Adie von Gontard two today as the Blind Brook team won the William Westerlund Memorial Trophy with a 5-1 victory over New Haven at the Blind Brook Polo Club.

ARMSTRONG, Ont., Sept. 17 (AP)--Two officials of a Cleveland-based mining company were among five persons presumed dead in the crash of a plane in Whitewater Lake, about 40 miles north of this village of the Canadian Pacific Railroad line.

Joseph Gluck, founder and president of Joseph Gluck Fabrics, Inc., and chairman of the board of Jo-Glo Textiles, Inc., and Pagoda Textiles, Inc., died Saturday at New York University Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 80 Park Avenue.

Controller Mario A. Procaccino said yesterday he was preparing recommendations for Governor Rockefeller and the Legislature to end the new restrictions against policemen's firing at felony and burglary suspects.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 17--It is now illegal for an Arab in the Israeli-occupied west bank of the Jordan River to engage in anti-Israeli sedition.

NOVA LISBOA, Angola-- Protestant missions are gradually facing extinction in Portugal's western African possession of Angola. The number of Protestant missions in Angola has dwindled to about 65 today from over 250 in 1961, at the time of the nationalist uprising.

"South Pacific" will be next summer's attraction at Jones Beach. The show will open June 27 and run until Labor Day. Guy Lombardo, producer, said yesterday that the show would mark the begining of a new policy of presenting a new production each year.
There's a small "city" edging its way across the Lower Bay these days between Long Beach on Long Island and the Raritan Bay in New Jersey.
The Port of New York for the second month in a row played host to more than a million international travelers in August, Michael Stramiello Jr., Regional Commissioner of Customs, reported yesterday.
GLASGOW, Scotland, Sept. 17 (Reuters)--Bookies were taking bets today on the name of the new Cunard transAtlantic liner to be launched here Wednesday.

Local 1814 of the International Longshoremen's Association has won a representative election of workers at the Yonkers plant of Refined Syrup and Sugars, Inc., according to Anthony Scotto, president of the 10,000-member local. He said they would form an autonomous sugar workers' division.

SACKETS HARBOR, N.Y., Sept. 17--Ch. Reggen's Madas-I of Marydane, a Great Dane known as Maddo, was named best in show in a field of 521 dogs today at the North Country Kennel Club's all-breed event. The winner is owned by Mrs. Mary K. Johnston.
WASHINGTON, Sept.17 (AP) --The drug industry unveiled a new "Code of Fair Practices" today, covering the advertising and promotion of prescription drug products.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept.17 (AP) --Norm Snead threw two firsthalf touchdown passes to Gary Ballman and scored once himself today to lead the Philadelphia Eagles to a 35-24 victory over the Washington Redskins in a National Football League opener.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UPI)--Mr. and Mrs. James S. Robb of Milwaukee, whose son will marry President Johnson's daughter next December, met the bride-tobe and her parents for the first time last week, the White House said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) --Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson's four-day trip to the Midwest, starting Wednesday, now includes stops in seven states, the White House announced today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17-- After allowing for both population growth and inflation, Federal Government spending fog the "social" purposes has multiplied by seven times in the last 20 years, a new study disclosed today.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 17-- John Turner Rohr, who rose in 60 years from bank messenger to the presidency of the city's oldest bank, died Sunday of cancer in Toledo Hospital. He was 78 years old.

American Negroes have until this generation lived predominantly in rural areas, but they have never shared in farm prosperity. As mechanization has intensified during the past thirty years, Negro sharecroppers and laborers have been crowded off the land because they are no longer needed on the big farms and plantations.

BONN, Sept. 17--Hans Christoph Seebohm, former Transportation Minister of West Germany and a leader of the country's Sudetenland refugees, died here today. He was 64 years old. A spokesman for the Christian Democratic party said that Mr. Seebohm had died of a lung embolism after an operation at the Bonn University clinic.

The appointment of Harold P. Bock as vice president and general manager of the Carlyle Hotel, at Madison Avenue and 76th Street, has been announced by Peter Sharp, president of the Carlyle Corporation.

New ORLEANS, Sept. 17-- The Los Angeles Rams defeated the New Orleans Saints, 27-13. today in a National Football League game played in an almost steady torrent of French Quarter jazz.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 17-- Intrepid, reaching for a successful defense of the America's Cup, and Dame Pattie, her people confident that the wind conditions were right for a first victory were beset by heavy fog today and the fourth race of the classic sailing series was postponed.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Mon- day, Sept. 18--Air Force bombers attacking in North Vietnam struck a bridge seven miles from Communist China yesterday in the closest raid to the border so far, a United States spokesman announced today.

HILLSBOROUGH, N.C., Sept. 17 (AP)--Richard Petty of Randleman, N.C., won the Hillsborough 150 Grand National stock car race today for his 25th triumph of the season.
The City Center Joffrey Ballet over the weekend reached the half-way mark of its month's season at the New York City Center.

STEWART MANOR, L.I., Sept. 17--William Allen, former Judge of the New York Court of General Sessions, died today at his home here, 168 Dover Parkway. He was 97 years old.

WHITEMARCH, Pa., Sept. 17 --Dan Sikes, the lawyer-golfer, won the Philadelphia Golf Classic by two strokes with a 72hole total of 276 today. Finishing with a four-under-par 68, Sikes overtook George Archer, the pacesetter after 54 holes, who drove one ball out of bounds and another into a creek before he finished with a 74 and 278 for second place.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 17Catherine M. Dunegan, who played a major role in establishing New York City's pioneering daycare program for children, died at St. Mary's Hospital here Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17--Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll calls in Congress during the week ended yesterday.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Sept. 17 (AP)--The resurgent Detroit Lions intercepted four passes by Bart Starr in gaining a 17point first-half lead, then fought off a furious Green Bay Packer second-half rally today to earn a 17-17 tie in a National Football League game.

SHIMODA, Japan, Sept. 17-- A conference of leading business and professional men, scholars and legislators from Japan and the United States agreed today that Okinawa, a key American military base in the Western Pacific, should be restored to Japanese jurisdiction "in the nearest possible future" to improve relations between the two countries.
Two major publishers--Macmillan and Harcourt, Brace World--are requiring employes to sign statements that several denounced as "company loyalty oaths."
CARROLL, N.H., Sept. 17-- Eight persons were killed and more than 70 injured today when an excursion train fell off the historic cog railway on Mount Washington and plunged into a rocky gorge.
Part of the tail section of the light plane that crashed in a South Bronx park Saturday fell off just before the plane hit the ground, a Federal investigator reported yesterday.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 17-- A spokesman for the Yemeni royalists said today that orders had been issued to "all fronts" to protect Egyptian forces as they withdraw from the embattled country.

GENERALS ordinarily don't have to handle hot potatoes. Their aides or the kitchen police take care of that chore for them. But Gen. William Dole Eckert, the commanding officer of the baseball brigade in his role as the commissioner, escaped last week without even scorched fingers when the most sizzling spud of his new duty tour was thrust at him. This one was so hot it might have exploded and spattered a lot of people.
BETHPAGE, L.I., Sept. 17-- The Jericho polo team defeated Brookville, 6-5, today in the quarter-final round of the Autumn Polo League tournament its Bethpage State Park.
The Traphagen School of Fashion, situated for the last 40 years at 1680 Broadway, will move in January to new quarters at 257 Park Avenue South, at the southeast corner of 21st Street.
ROLF MARTENS of Malmo, in his first attempt to do so, won the Swedish chess championship at Stockholm, scoring 11 -3 in a strong 16-man round-robin.

KINGS POINT, L.I., Sept. 17--The marriage of Miss Roberta Alice Marx to Eric Delson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Delson of New York, took place this afternoon. Rabbi M. Tokayer performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Marx.

The Fluor Corporation, Ltd., had a net income of $3,077,842, equal to $1.31 a share for the third fiscal quarter ended July 31, the Los Angeles engineering and construction concern reported yesterday. For the corresponding three months last year the restated net income was $2,139,983, or 88 cents a share. Sales totaled $94,323,626 compared with $79,707,928.

PORT JEFFERSON, L. I., Sept. 18--An eagle 3 at the final hole helped Doug Ford of Vernon Hills gain a two-stroke lead in the Port Jefferson open with a 34, 33--67 at the Harbor Hills Country Club today. Par for the 6,708-yard course is 36, 36--72.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- Secretary McNamara, in announcing the Administration's decision to build a limited missile defense system, provided an unusual glimpse into the grisly, Strangelovish world of megatonnage and "assured destruction," where it makes no sense to "over-destroy" a target, but where one calculates how many millions of people must be incinerated before the damage becomes "unacceptable" to a society that wants to remain "viable."

In illegally striking New York City's schools, the United Federation of Teachers has knowingly and openly flouted the Taylor Act. This is not a mere local issue, but a direct challenge to a new state law expressly designed to prevent civil service strikes while assuring fair treatment of public employes. This is the law which, it was hoped, would set a nationwide pattern for the future handling of such disputes.

BOSTON, Sept. 18 (AP)-- Chief Judge Charles E. Wyzanski, who had picked San Francisco for the Federal Court trial of three persons accused in the Plymouth mail robbery, reversed himself today and chose New York City as the trial site.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- Following is the text of a statement issued by the State Department today regarding a report that President Johnson had undermined a peace approach to North Vietnam:

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 18--The engagement of Miss Anne Cammann Fairchild to Russell Adams Gilmore 3d has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. deLancey Cammann Fairchild, parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilmore Jr. of Dayton, Ohio.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- Personal income and house building continued to rise in August, the former very substantially, the Commerce Department reported today.

LONDON, Sept. 18--The Soviet physicist who was forcibly removed from a Soviet airline by British policemen Saturday was turned back to the Soviet Embassy today.

Members of a Brooklyn draft board said last evening that they had summoned some 30 teachers for a routine check of their deferment status, but denied that the interviews had anything to do with the current school dispute.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 18 (Reuters)--Cambodia has reversed a decision to withdraw her diplomatic staff from Peking, the Chief of State, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, announced today. He said the decision followed the arrival of a message from the Chinese Premier, Chou En-lai.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 18--The fifth emergency session of the General Assembly voted unanimously today to place the Middle East issue on the agenda of the 22d regular session, which opens tomorrow, "as a matter of high priority."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- Following is the text of Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara's address today to editors of United Press International in San Francisco, as issued by the Pentagon:

Matt Snell, the New York Jets fullback who is as adept at pass-receiving as he is at running, will be out of action for at least two weeks. The Jets put him on waivers yesterday because of injuries, which means he will miss next Sunday's game at Denver and the local opener on Oct. 1 against the Miami Dolphins.
The election of Charles B. McCoy as vice chairman of the executive committee of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., was announced yesterday.
AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Sept. 18 --Patrick Britell, industrialist and big game hunter, died Saturday at his home here. He was 60 years old.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Sept. 19--A bomb shattered the Chinese Nationalist Embassy this morning, wounding 12 persons, seven of them seriously.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 18 --In a word-association test, the casual response to "12Meter" might be America's Cup or sailboat or even Newport.
Robert Kaufman, a pianist who is obviously happiest when the density of notes is greatest, came to Town Hall last night prepared to play several knuckle-cracking pieces and to play them very well.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UPI)--The president of the National Guard Association of the United States indicated today that the Guard's drive to recruit Negroes was moving slowly, partly because Negroes were not interested in joining.
Legislative hearings here next week will touch off a drive for overhauling New York State's laws governing campaign spending.
Sales of the nation's leading chain stores and mail order houses rose 9.5 per cent in August from the level of the 1966 month, according to a survey yesterday by The New York Times.
Ground was broken yesterday for the first nursing home to be built under a $100-million loan program recently approved by the State Legislature.

About 20 Harlem youths staged a sit-in for several hours at Senator Robert F. Kennedy's New York offices yesterday to protest the termination of the summer antipoverty job program. They gained more than ordinary attention.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18 (AP)--The St. Louis Cardinals clinched their 11th National League pennant tonight with a 5-1 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies behind the threehit pitching of Bob Gibson.

TORONTO, Sept. 18--Canada was reminded yesterday that although she is a vast and sparsely settled country, she faces the problems of rapid urbanization and big metropolitan areas that beset her neighbor to the south.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 18 (AP) --Ted Uhlaender's tie-breaking single in the 10th inning and six-hit pitching by Jim Kaat led the Minnesota Twins to a 2-0 victory over the Kansas City Athletics tonight.

In the campaigns in North Africa and Sicily, General Keyes served as deputy commander to Gen. George S. Patton Jr. In September, 1943, he took command of the Second Corps, which paced the Fifth Army's advance from the Gergliano River to Rome.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) --The National Science Foundation denied today reports that it had rejected the application of a California mathematician and Vietnam war critic for a $247,000 research grant.
DETROIT, Sept. 18--Detroit school teachers ended a two-week strike today, accepting a contract with pay increases of $1,700 over two years.
Hundreds of nicotine-stained men and women eager to overcome the cigarette habit jammed a midtown auditorium last night at the start of a Stop Smoking Clinic sponsored by the city.

LONDON, Sept. 18--At least 14 paintings sold to a prominent London gallery by a biographer of John Singer Sargent --and authenticated by him as genuine Sargents--have been termed fakes by art experts, The Sunday Times reported yesterday.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 18-- Three youths, one of them the son of the Suffolk County Health Commissioner, Dr. George E. Leone, were indicted here today on charges of possession and sales of narcotics.

The Ford Foundation asked the Federal Communications Commission yesterday to withhold approval of the Communication Satellite Corporation's proposed pilot program for the creation of a domestic communications satellite system.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Sept. 18 (UPI)--The Government has agreed to extend unused 1967 oil import quotas into 1968 or even 1969, Jim C. Langdon, chairman of the Texas Railroad Commission, reported today.
HONG KONG, Sept. 18-- Army efforts to restore order in the chaotic city of Canton appear to have precipitated a full-scale battle in which tanks and artillery are reported to be in use.

BOSTON, Sept. 18--An internationally known expert on mind-expanding drugs testified today that marijuana was no more harmful than alcohol and that the harsh criminal penalties imposed for its use encouraged rather than deterred criminality among young people.
LONDON, Sept. 18--Britain is to have a "university of the air" called the Open University by the autumn of 1970, Jennie Lee, Minister responsible for the arts, announced today.

THERE have been many tactical twists and turns in the political life of President Giuseppe Saragat of Italy, but even his detractors concede that he has not wavered in his devotion to liberty and democracy.

TAMPICO, Mexico, Sept. 18 (UPI)--Fringe winds from Hurricane Beulah forced thousands of persons to evacuate this port city tonight. Then the storm began to stall in the Gulf of Mexico and its final destination was still in doubt.
RUSSELL, Iowa, Sept. 18 (AP)--Four men were killed today when one bank of a 15foot ditch in which they were working collapsed on top of them. Two others were removed.

With 35 New York City public and Catholic schools preparing for the opening of they football season, selecting Bob Ehrhardt as the outstanding individual player appears to be an easier chore than predicting the league champions.
The Navy has awarded a $3.8-million contract to the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation of Needham, Mass., for miniature twoway rescue radios for downed airmen.
The bond market continued in a stale of "uneasy stability" yesterday but interest rates rose in the, short-term sector of the credit markets.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 18 --The drama of a successful America's Cup defense was enacted for the 20th time today. Intrepid and a crew working with machinelike precision kept the symbol of world sailing supremacy in the United States, delivering a fourth straight thrashing to Australia's inadequate challenger, Dame Pattie. It was dull drama.

LONDON, Sept. 18--Sir John Cockcroft, who won a Nobel Prize in 1951 for splitting an atom by mechanical means, was found dead at his home at Churchill College, Cambridge, early today. He was 70 years old.
Far from the pennant races he once dominated, Sandy Koufax was honored last night by the team he once dominated like nobody else in baseball, The New York Mets.

The Chicago North Western Railway reached an agreement yesterday to acquire the Philadelphia Reading Corporation, a diversified manufacturing concern. The deal would be handled through a newly formed holding company, Chicago North Western Industries, Inc., a Delaware corporation.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 18 (AP)--The police here reported today that Calvin C. Cobb, disbarred Long Island lawyer, was arrested Saturday in Dares Salaam, capital of neighboring Tanzania.

VANCOUVER, B.C.--Arthur Erickson, whose design for the Canadian Pavilion at Expo 70 in Osaka, Japan, was chosen last June from among 208 entries, decided recently to get some help on the color scheme for its exotic roof from Gordon Smith, the hard-edge painter and sculptor.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange moved up in moderately active trading yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 18 (AP)--Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara allayed official British fears today that United States Congressional pressures would compel the Administration to cancel certain defense obligations to Britain.

New York City went on a 24-hour air pollution watch at 2 P.M. yesterday because of the existence of a body of stagnant air in the area, Austin A. Heller, City Air Pollution Control Commissioner, announced.
Efforts to end the walkout of city teachers, now in its second week, resumed last night with new signs of optimism but with several major issues still unresolved.
URBANA, Ill., Sept. 18 (AP) --Mrs. Helen Stevick, president of The Champaign News-Gazette and its radio station, WDWS, died early today in an Urbana nursing home. She was 77 years old.

ALBANY, Tuesday, Sept. 19-- The Constitutional Convention approved early this morning a Democratic proposal to eliminate the need for a voter referendum on each new state bond issue and to impose a ceiling on state borrowing.
CHICAGO, Sept. 18 (AP)--A group of 20 Chicago Negroes, describing themselves as "Hebrew Israelites," boarded an airliner to Liberia today to take up permanent residence.

NARROWSBURG, N.Y., Sept.18--Although trout are biting on the nearby Beaverkill and bass are looking for trouble at such Sullivan County lakes as Pleasure, Wolff and Yankee, Joe Purcell was on his familiar Delaware River shad bandwagon today.
HONG KONG, Sept. 16( Reuters)--China today declared that a recent Moscow international fashion festival showed how far tire Soviet leaders "have gone in their degradation as revisionists."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- The Pentagon has defended its role in helping foreign countries purchase arms on the grounds of aiding this nation's economy and indirectly improving national security.
LAKE GEORGE, Sept. 18-- Men staggered under armloads of muskets wheeled heavy muzzle-loaded cannons to safety today as fire swept the logs of Fort William Henry.

OMAHA, Sept. 18 (UPI)--Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman said today that he had been authorized by President Johnson to open negotiations with "a number of countries" for additional sales of American wheat and feed grains.

DETROIT, Sept. 18--By beating the Detroit Tigers, 6-5, tonight on a 10th-inning home run by Dalton Jones and the relief pitching of Josh Santiago, the Boston Red Sox moved the American League pennant race one step closer to some sort of playoff.

BOSTON, Sept. 18 (AP) --Ernest Henderson 3d, president of the Sheraton Corporation of America, was elected today as chief executive of the hotel system to succeed his late father, Ernest Henderson, co-founder and chairman.
ANDREW GOLDSTEIN has 17 friends. Most of them are 2 years old. They are not always the neatest people in the world. Especially at birthday parties.

Mining companies that strip the topsoil and gouge the land are still laying waste the American countryside. More than two million acres of land, the equivalent of a mile-wide strip stretching from Times Square to the Golden Gate, now lie eroded and ruined. Every year another 150,000 acres are surface-mined, and the rate of these operations is growing, not diminishing.
BONN, Sept. 18--Premier Willi Stoph of East Germany, in a letter to Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger, called today for immediate negotiations to normalize relations between the two Germanys.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 18 (AP)--Mrs. Dorothy G. Ford, the mother of Representative Gerald R. Ford Jr., died yesterday at Butterworth Hospital of a heart ailment. She was 75 years old.

Mr. Spence, who had served in the House continuously since 1931, announced in March, 1962, that he would not seek "re-election because he was physically "unable to make the kind of campaign I would like to make." He would have faced a contest because Kentucky lost one House seat as a result of redistricting after the Census of 1960.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 18--"This book," the priest said, clasping his worn Bible to his chest, "is tired."
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 18--Four Roman Catholic slates have been elected to the South vietnamese Senate, according to official figures made public tonight.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 18 --Rioting continued today in the town of Sivas, in Central Turkey, a day after 42 people were killed following a dispute at a soccer game in Kayseri, 110 miles to the south.

Marshall McLuhan gave his first lecture at Fordham University yesterday, explaining to students that war is total education, television is an Xray machine, and the British drive on the left because Napoleon never reached England.

ON the word of no less an authority than Arthur Godfrey, one of the dwindling survivors of the economics of network radio, yesterday morning marked the 40th anniversary of the founding of the Columbia Broadcasting System's radio network.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 18-- Gov. George Romney visited today the nation's most successful experiment to provide home ownership for the poor and said later that it should be extended nationwide.

Weeks before the first snowfall is expected to whiten Central Park, supporters of the United States Ski Team are planning the first of what they hope will become the annual Ski Ball. It will be held on Oct. 19 at the Tavern-on-the-Green.

Falconbridge Nickel Mines, Ltd., announced yesterday an increase in nickel prices effective Oct. 1, to offset "rising production costs, including the higher wages being paid under the three-year labor contracts now in effect."

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 18 --Champagne corks popped, Jock Sturrock doffed his yachting cap and the Dame Pattie crew, keeping its sense of humor, hoisted the "negative" code flag that means "we do not wish to race tomorrow."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP)--Six New York City residents protesting the Vietnam war and the military draft were arrested-today after blocking the entrance to the national headquarters of the Selective Service System.

The United Federation of Teachers has been insisting that money is not the only thing blocking settlement of the city's longest teacher strike. The union's slogan, "Teachers Want What Children Need," underlines its nonsalary demands.
Robert Bennett, sales manager for national accounts of the Container Corporation of America, died Saturday at St. Clare's Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 23 Pierce Road, Riverside, Conn.

It wouldn't have surprised baseball insiders if the St. Louis Cardinals had emerged on top in a typical National League scramble. But what astounded everyone--including the Cardinals--was their runaway victory.
Bond Stores, Inc., has elected Lawrence L. Shapiro vice president for real estate and construction.
FAYETTEVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 18 (AP)--Broderick Crawford, the movie and television actor, was injured last night in an automobile accident in this village near Syracuse.

Trading in propane futures began yesterday on the Commodity Exchange, Inc., and with a shout of "5.75," Henry Mintz won the opening contract for a Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith customer named G.H. Billue of Conway, Kan., who owns a propane storage facility.
CARROLL, N.H., Sept. 18 (UPI)--An open switch may have caused the derailing of an excursion train yesterday on Mount Washington's cog railway that killed at least 8 persons and injured 73.
The Marine Midland Trust Company of Southern New York, a subsidiary of the Marine Midland Corporation, announced yesterday the election of Eli G. White to its board.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 18 --A challenge for an America's Cup match in 1970 was delivered to Commodore Percy Chubb 2d of the New York Yacht Club immediately after today's final race of the 1967 series. It was from the Royal Dorset Y.C. of Weymouth, England, and was signed by Dr. Gordon Wallace, the club's vice commodore.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Sept. 18 --Willard D. Morgan, head of the photographic publishing company of Morgan Morgan, 25 Main Street, Hastings-onHudson, died today at Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, of lung cancer. He was 67 years old and lived here at 120 High Point Road.

The United States was urged yesterday by 80 prominent Americans, including 16 Nobel Prize winners, to pursue a policy "inside the United Nations and outside of it" to bring about direct peace negotiations between Israel and the Arab states.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) --President Johnson sent these nominations to the Senate today for confirmation:
The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced last night that its agents had arrested three men from Queens--two charged with possession of stolen ham and the other with possession of stolen eggs.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- Rear Adm. William J. Keester, who retired from the Coast Guard in 1949, died on Thursday at Salisbury, Md. His age was 78. He was buried today in Arlington National Cemetery.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- Barry Goldwater said tonight that his followers had been prepared to black out any radio or television network covering the Republican National Convention in 1964 "if anybody got a little too obnoxious."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- Several hundred business executives, opposed to the war in Vietnam on "moral and practical grounds," have set up an organization to press for a reduction in the American military effort and to seek peace negotiations among all parties involved in the fighting.
The election of Charles Curtis Smith as senior vice president for market development was announced here yesterday by the Bankers Trust Company.
About 2,500 Manhattan dock workers walked off their jobs yesterday and more than 1,000 of them picketed City Hall to demand prompt action to revive the borough's declining waterfront.
NEW HAVEN, Sept. 18 (UPI) --A group of teen-age boys and girls went on a windowbreaking spree in the downtown and Dixwell Avenue section early today. One girl was arrested.

Consolidated Foods Corporation is going into the women's apparel business through the proposed acquisition of Country Set, Inc., in exchange for about 143,000 shares of Consolidated common stock with a market value exceeding $7.2million.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- The Administration today denied charges that President Johnson had "effectively and brutally" sabotaged a peace approach to Hanoi through private channels.

BEIRUT, Sept. 18--The threenation commission on a Yemeni peace has decided to ask the Government of the United Arab Republic to liberate more than 100 Yemeni republicans who have been imprisoned in Cairo for a year, a member of the commission said tonight.

ALEKSEI KAPLER is all right now and is living in Moscow. He's writing film scripts, giving seminars and teaching at the Institute of Cinematography. He is one of the older, recognized masters of filmmaking. After 10 years of exile and prison camps he's leading a normal life again.
WILTON, Conn., Sept. 18 --Miss Elizabeth Beryl Fuller and David Holt Boshart plan to marry in November.

The pressure on manufacturing plants is continuing to decline and the number of companies planning to expand production facilities is dropping. This was disclosed yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board in a survey spon sored by Newsweek magazine.

A special three-judge Federal court listened here yesterday for more than four hours to the pros and cons of whether the Pennsylvania and New York Central railroads should be allowed to put their merger into effect shortly.
Governor Rockefeller said yesterday he would not attend an eight-state conference called by Governor Ronald Reagan of California.
There is no such thing as a predictable hurricane. That is the frustrated conclusion of those whose job it is to predict the courses of hurricanes.
THE European Championships in Dublin, Ireland, ended Friday in a convincing victory for Italy.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 18--An unidentified African tribesman testified today that he had received terrorist training in Egypt and in South-West Africa, the mandate territory governed by South Africa.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 18-- State District Judge Edward A. Haggerty Jr. refused today to dismiss an indictment against Clay L. Shaw, New Orleans businessman, who has been charged with plotting the assassination of President Kennedy.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) --Lieut. Gen. Geoffrey Keyes, who commanded the Second Corps in the Italian campaign of World War II, died yesterday at Walter Reed Hospital. He was 78 years old.
ALBANY, Sept. 18--The third drawing in the state lottery began today with the selection of 1,437 winners who will share about $1.8 million in prizes.

Mrs. Alice Crimmins, who has been charged with the 1965 murder of her 4-year-old daughter, remained free in $25,000 bail after the Queens District Attorney's office relinquished its request yesterday to have her bond revoked.
It was active and upward for prices on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.
The Committee American Steamship Lines announced yesterday that its trade expansion program calls for nine workshop programs this fall to develop and expand markets for the nation's foreign traders.

THE usual: crowds outside, crowds inside, people frankly sizing up other people, enough jewels to pay off the national debt, enough heirlooms to stock the Metropolitan Museum, enough intermission parties to float the Queen Mary in champagne, enough society to add quite a few numerals to the original 400. It was, in short, the opening night of the Metropolitan Opera, the second such in its new house in Lincoln Center.

With the showing tomorrow night of "The Battle of Algiers," the Italian film that won the top award at last year's Venice Film Festival, the fifth annual New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center will start its 10-day run in 2,600-seat Philharmonic Hall.
DETROIT, Sept. 18--The General Motors Corporation announced today an average price increase on its 1968 model cars of $110, or 3.6 per cent above the prices for 1967.
The Bronx Zoo closed its reptile house to the public yesterday for its annual "weighing in and measuring" of large and small crocodiles and alligators and giant snakes.

SEATTLE, Sept. 18--The Right Rev. James A. Pike, resigned bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of California, was overwhelmingly accorded today the right to sit and to speak, although not to vote, in the church's House of Bishops.

A lease of four tower floors, involving aggregate rents of more than $20-million, in the 44-story skyscraper under construction at 345 Park Avenue, has been signed by Peat, Marwick, Mitchell Co., certified public accountants.
SHARON, Conn., Sept. 18-- Joseph M. Stevens, who retired in June as Eastern advertising manager of The New Yorker, died yesterday in Sharon Hospital of a heart ailment. He lived here. His age was 61.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- The leadership of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters has invited striking steel haulers to meet with it this week to discuss walkouts that are beginning to crimp the nation's steel production.
The major need in today's dynamic marketplace is for more sophisticated consumer research during the test-marketing phase of new products.

Prinkipo and Pincay the Panamanian proved the winning combination in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. The former, a 3-year-old Kentucky-bred, raced in front virtually all the way under the guidance of the popular Laffit Pincay Jr. to take the feature race by three-quarters of a length over the Harbor View Farm's First and Finest.

PARIS, Sept. 18--The august couture house of Christian Dior, now celebrating its 20th anniversary, created a real rumpus last week in Paris. It opened a readyto-wear boutique at No. 11 bis Rue Francois I called Miss Dior, the same name as its perfume.
Buster Mathis continued his ponderous climb through the heavyweight bush leagues last night with a fourth-round knockout of Ron Marsh at Madison Square Garden.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 18--Israeli authorities encountered stiff Arab resistance today when they attempted to open seven public elementary schools in the former Jordanian sector of the city.

DETROIT, Sept. 18 (AP)-- Even with the strike-bound Ford Motor Company at a standstill, United States auto makers last week turned in their highest car production figures since July, the trade publication Automotive News said today.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 18--The New York Yankees got only five singles and a game-opening double by Horace Clarke off three Baltimore Oriole pitchers tonight and lost, 2-0, in the first game of a two-game series at Memorial Stadium.

GENEVA, Sept. 18--Radio experts of 52 countries met here today to adopt international regulations to meet the expansion in ship-to-ship and ship-to-shore communications while avoiding further jamming of the airwaves.
Twelve members of Brooklyn CORE were arrested yesterday after refusing to obey police orders to end a two-and-a-halfhour sit-in in the office of the Superintendent of Schools.

Wall Street was buzzing yesterday with talk about the Responsive Environments Corporation "omelet," while the lawyer for the investment banking house that brought out the issue said the eggs were never scrambled.

Steel production moved upward last week, still showing no adverse effect from the auto strike that began nearly two weeks ago, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. Steel production gains recently have not been large, but output has been up for the last four weeks in a row.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 18 --Fifteen leading Christian clergymen of Syria have notified the Government in Damascus that schools operated by their organizations will not reopen this year unless it repeals a new decree giving full control of all private schools to the Ministry of Education.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- How quickly things drop from sight, become forgotten and vanish from public thought. The consensus, for example. Who remembers the consensus?
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) --The Federal Reserve said today its Open Market Committee voted unanimously in June to maintain credit ease in the economy.
CUAVIET, South Vietnam, Sept. 18--A heavy-shouldered Marine major stood atop an amphibious tractor this morning on a beach five miles south of the demilitarized zone.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- More than 100 militant students and a scattering of professors at Howard University walked out today during an address in which the president strongly endorsed many goals --but not the methods--of the university's growing black power movement.
ATHENS, Sept. 18--The Interior Minister of Greece's five-month-old military regime declared today that although "traitors like Andreas Papandreou should be shot," the regime would kill no one.

Arthur J. Krauss, executive editor of The Import Bulletin, an affiliated publication of The Journal of Commerce, died of a heart attack Saturday afternoon at John F. Kennedy International Airport while seeing a relative off by plane. He was 67 years old.
A transit system to link Staten Island, Bayonne, Jersey City and Hoboken was proposed yesterday by a new transportation group.

YONKERS, Sept. 18--Dr. and Mrs. James F.X. O'Rourke have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Colleen Elena O'Rourke, to Loren Len Kensinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. McCawley Kensinger of Long Beach, Calif.
Stock prices moved upward yesterday although persistent profit taking limited the extent of the advance.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 18-- The city of San Francisco was ordered by the California Supreme Court today to put on its ballot Nov. 7 the question of whether the United States should withdraw immediately from Vietnam.
CARSON CITY, Nev., Sept. 19 (UPI) Jack Fenkell was dismissed today as enforcement chief of the Nevada Gaming Control Board, which policies Nevada casinos for cheating.
The New Jersey Americans of the American Basketball Association sued today to enjoin Leroy Ellis from playing for the Baltimore Bullets and force him to play for the Americans for the 1967-68 season.
GOUNOD composed "Romeo et Juliette" as a five-act opera. But no opera house, in this speeded-up age, can go for five acts, especially when at the magic stroke of midnight overtime occurs.

FASTON, Conn., Sept. 19 Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Patterson have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Harley Jane Patterson, to William Charles Seabrook 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seabrook of New York.

Dr. Oliver H. Jones has been appointed economic consultant to the Federal National Mortgage Association. He has been been director of research for the Mortgage Bankers Association of America since 1962.
Czechoslovakia's moral and intellectual degradation these past two decades was vividly highlighted the other day by the sensation in Prague when Thomas G. Masaryk ceased to be an unperson.

Had breakfast with Democratic Congressional leaders; saw George Jessel; saw President Giuseppe Saragat of Italy; met with Defense Secretary McNamara, Under Secretary of State Katzenbach and special assistants Rostow and Christian; gave White House dinner for President Saragat.

ATLANTA, Sept. 19 (AP) Leo Cardenas hit a tie-breaking single and then scored on Tommy Helms's sacrifice fly in the eighth inning tonight, enabling the Cincinnati Reds to register a 3-1 victory over the Atlanta Braves.
The American Stock Exchange was hit with its worst setback in several weeks yesterday as the list declined in active trading.

Chesebrough-Pond's, Inc., producer of cosmetics, drugs, toiletries and hospital products, announced plans yesterday to broaden its activities through a merger with William H. Rorer, Inc., a producer of prescription drugs. The deal involves an estimated $203million.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 19 Mr. and Mrs. John D. Barclay have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Margaret Anne Barclay, to Robert Austin Ittner, son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Martin Hill Ittner of Jersey City.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19 Gov. Ronald Reagan told a group of editors today that "we run the very real risk of tryanny by the courts."
The Brotherhood of Railway and Airline Clerks defied a court order early this morning by calling a strike against Pan American World Airways throughout the country and in Puerto Rico.

The Union Carbide Corporation said yesterday it would increase the price of low-density polyethylene resins by 2 cents a pound, following an increase announced last week by the Rexall Drug and Chemical Company. The rise will be effective Oct. 4. Industry sources say the rise is likely to spread to other producers.

Directors of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., raised the quarterly dividend for the second time in 15 months, with the declaration of 30 cents a share on 5,756,351 shares of common stock. In addition, a 5 per cent stock dividend was voted, both payable Oct. 16 to record Sept. 29.
Stock prices tumbled yesterday afternoon, wiping out a modest advance that had been posted in morning trading.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI)--A group of Negro demonstrators, protesting Housepassed welfare restrictions, conducted a brief sit-in today at a Senate hearing room. They left quietly after being threatened with six months in jail.
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 19 Del Insko registered his 200th success tonight for the third straight year as a "catch" driver behind Constant Byrd in the ninth race at Roosevelt Raceway.

BROWNSVILLE, Tex., Wednesday, Sept. 20 (AP)--Winds gusting up to 70 miles an hour uprooted giant palms and raised havoc across the Lower Rio Grande Valley as Hurricane Beulah kept edging toward shore early today.
Dr. Harold G. Noyes, and ophthalmologist at 67 Park Avenue, died on Sunday in the New York Infirmary. He was 73 years old and lived at 15 Park Avenue.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 19 Martin Block, whose "MakeBelieve Ballroom" was a radio institution for 20 years, died here today in Englewood Hospital following surgery. His age was given as 64. He lived in Horizon House in Fort Lee.

MARIO ANDRETTI, the United States Auto Club national champion of 1965 and 1966, has a chance to overtake the current point leader, A. J. Foyt, in the 200-mile race for Indianapolis-type cars scheduled by the Trenton International Speedway...

The Federal National Mortgage Association, in a move that appeared to be clearing the way for the Treasury's next financing, disclosed yesterday plans to sell $400-million of three-year debentures Friday.
HOUSTON, Sept. 19 (UPI) Six runs on eight singles off four Houston pitchers in the ninth inning gave the Pittsburgh Pirates an 11-7 victory over the Astros tonight.

Arthur Keller, former president of the First National Bank of Lincolnwood, in Lincolnwood, Ill., pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal court here to manipulating the stock of Hercules Galion Products, Inc., on the American Stock Exchange.

LONDON, Sept. 19 (UPI) Chartchai Chionoi, a 24-yearold Thailand soldier, retained his world flyweight title tonight when Walter McGowan of Scotland was stopped in the seventh round because of a cut above his left eye.

"THE POKER SESSTON," with anything wild and a slew of case jokers, opened at the Martinique Theater last night, beginning the Off Broadway season.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Sept. 19--Resolutions calling for immediate full-scale application in Rhodesia of apartheid laws similar to South Africa's racial separation measures will be presented to the Rhodesian Front's annual congress at the end of September, the independent Daily Times of Zambia said here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 President Guiseppe Saragat expressed to President Johnson today strong Italian reservations about key provisions of the treaty to ban the spread of nuclear weapons proposed by the United States and the Soviet Union.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 19 The honeymoon is over for Tom Cahill, after logging 18,000 miles by car on 90 dinner and 19 clinic engagements, expounding on the amazing success of the 1966 Army football team that made him the coach of the year.
HASTINGS, Neb., Sept. 19 (AP) Kansas-Nebraska Natural Gas Company made a new move today to head off a merger with Kaneb Pipeline Comnany of Houston.

The Association of Assistant Principals called on its members last night to walk out of the city's public schools this morning if the teachers' stoppage is still going on and the schools are kept open.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 19 (AP) Officials of Mexicana de Aviacion, this country's oldest scheduled airline, have called a stockholders meeting for Monday to decide if the company should be liquidated.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI) Plans were announced today to stockpile tear gas, armored vests, searchlights and other riot control equipment in strategic places for use by National Guard troops in an emergency.

CAIRO, Sept. 19 A Government source said today that 181 military officers and civilians had been arrested in the United Arab Republic for security reasons since the outbreak of the war with Israel last June.

Andrew Heiskell, chairman of the board of Time Inc., called on the nation's corporations yesterday to lower employment standards, if necessary, to provide thousands of more jobs of people living in urban slums.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Sept. 19 Mr. and Mrs. Jerome S. Hyams have made known the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Stephanie Roberta Hyams, to Stephen Charles Geller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Geller of Woodmere.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19 San Francisco Opera openings are noted for a go-forbroke spirit that would have delighted the city's flamboyant, big-spending pioneers, and tonight's opening of the 45th season was no exception.
LONDON, Sept. 19 (Canadian Press) Don Marshall, New York Rangers' center, was injured severely tonight as the Rangers bowed to the Boston Bruins, 9-3, in an exhibition game.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Sept. 20 Eight North Vietnamese MIG-17 jets fought a short-range cannon battle with four United States Air Force F-105 Thunderchief fighter-bombers near Hanoi yesterday, a military spokesman reported this morning.

An official spokesman for a revolutionary trans-Atlantic shipping enterprise, Atlantic Container Lines, yesterday appealed to the United States Government to be more understanding of the need for interline cooperation in shipping.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Sept. 19 Miss Marjorie Roeser Myles and Derek Ellis Miller plan to be married on Nov. 17. Mr. and Mrs. John L. Myles have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Glen B. Miller of Bronxville.
The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company is showing that its centennial year is not too late to adopt a new corporate symbol representative of the company's "modern total environment."

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 (UPI) Two Californians contended today that 11 presumed "mistakes" or misspellings in cryptographic lettering on the Kensingstone Runestone found in Alexandria, Minn., were part of a code that proves Norsemen beat Columbus to the New World by hundreds of years.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 19 Lieut, Gen. William W. Momyer, commander of the Seventh Air Force, said today that bombing of North Vietnam could bring the war to a conclusion only in combination with "continuous pressure" on enemy ground forces in the South.
Following is the text of a statement issued yesterday by the Board of Education and the Superintendent of Schools on the teachers' walkout:

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 19 The Soviet Union today protested a meeting scheduled by Latin-American foreign ministers to consider Cuban subversion. It pledged "every support and assistance" to the Cuban regime.
The nonprofit Brooklyn corporation that will direct industrial development of the former Brooklyn Navy Yard has a new president.
LONDON, Sept. 19 The name of the new Cunard liner, Q-4, to be launched tomorrow, was selected today, but it remained secret.
The Goodyear International Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to build a $13-million tire cord fabric mill and processing facility in Colmar-Berg, Luxembourg.
MOSCOW, Sept. 19 Aleksei I. Adzhubei, a son-in-law of former Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev, has been arrested on criminal traffic charges, it was reported today.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 19 The New York Yankees, whose 225 team batting average has warmed the hearts of pitchers all over the American League this season, again showed an inability to hit tonight as they bowed to the Baltimore Orioles, 3-0, at Memorial Stadium.

New York City will face a serious financial crisis if the local finance article approved by the Constitutional Convention is accepted by the voters. Rejecting the whole concept of fiscal home rule, it is completely inadequate to the city's needs.
There are concerts where the most exciting moments come during intermission. Such a one was an electronic-cumaleatoric program called "Music Expanded" last night at Town Hall.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) A Congressional investigator said today that the Office of Economic Opportunity had instructed an Oklahoma Job Corps center to falsify its records to indicate that it had more enrollees than it did.

DETROIT, Sept. 19 (UPI) The United Auto Workers said today that the General Motors Corporation was rushing car production to "steal the market" from its strikebound competitor, the Ford Motor Company.

George Herman, of 3801 Hudson Manor Terrace, Riverdale in the Bronx, pleaded not guilty in Federal court here yesterday to conspiracy in connection with the establishment of a brokerage house that is now defunct.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 United States officials said today that they suspected that North Korean jet pilots have been flying combat missions over North Vietnam against American planes for the last month or two.
Rent Administrator Frederic 5. Berman announced yesterday that his agency would begin collecting immediately civil penalties of up to $500 from landlords it judges guilty of overcharging on rents.

By eliminating the century-old requirement for voter approval for new bond issues, the Constitution would put the state in a much more flexible fiscal position to meet changing social and economic needs. The change will shock conservatives, but neither the Federal Government nor the city has to get popular approval before borrowing, and it is hard to see why the state should be subject to more rigid limitations.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 19 Mr. and Mrs. Alden Revere Loosli have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Hattie Louise Loosli, to James William Carter of Montclair, son of George William Carter of Grafton Regis in Buckinghamshire, England, and the late Mrs. Carter.

Members of the National Association of Broadcast Employes and Technicians have have overwhelmingly rejected new contract proposals of the American Broadcasting Company and the National Broadcasting Company.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept 19 Mr. and Mrs. Paul C. Henshaw have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sydney Parker Henshaw, to Paul Winfried Nordt 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nordt Jr. of North Caldwell, N.J.
The African American Teachers Association, an organization of Negro public school teachers, called yesterday for "self-control, self-determination and selfdefense for schools in the black community."

PLYMOUTH, Mass., Sept. 19 (AP) Albert De Salvo, who says that he strangled 23 women in eastern Massachuset was sentenced today to 7 to 10 years in state prison for escaping last Feb. 24 from Bridgewater State Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 A leader of a citizens' group promoting Senator Robert F. Kennedy for the Democratic Presidential nomination said today that the group would continue its efforts unless the Senator moved "unequivocally" to stop them.

In a detailed report on its negotiations with the United Federation of Teachers, the Board of Education leaves no doubt that the real obstacles to a settlement are demands for higher salaries, shorter teaching hours, extended sick leaves and expansion of the More Effective Schools project.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 A slate of delegates to the Democratic National Convention supporting President Johnson conceivably could lose the California Democratic primary in 1968, according to The State Poll, which appeared today in The Los Angeles Times.

THE individualistic views of Eric Hoffer, the long- shoreman turned author, constituted a fascinatingly pragmatic interview on Eric Severeid's hour-long special on the Columbia Broadcasting System network.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 19 The Elizabeth teachers' union voted today to ask the Board of Education for a new salary scale, including a $350across-the-board increase as part of its 1968-69 wage package.
MONTREAL, Sept. 19 Expo 67 has played host to several large European opera companies, from Stockholm, Hamburg, Moscow and Vienna, with La Scala of Milan still to come.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 Secretary of State Dean Rusk made a previously unannounced trip to the West Coast today, with one of his objectives the crystallizing of more support for the Administration's Vietnam policies.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Early this year I offered to bet one plugged nickel that Gov. Nelson Rockefeller of New York would be the Republican Presidential nominee in 1968. This was greeted, inevitably, with hoots of derision, but now that the right honorable gentleman has passed President Johnson in the popularity polls, the time has come to raise the ante to one thin Rockefeller dime.

Four foundations and the Federal Government are giving almost three-quarters of a million dollars to the Interracial Council for Business Opportunity to help minority groups, primarily Negroes, establish and expand their own businesses.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Robinson of Grymes Hill, S.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rosemary Robinson, to Richard R. Hough Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hough of Morristown, N.J.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 (AP) Dick Hughes pitched the St. Louis Cardinals, the National League champions, to a 1-0 victory over the Philadelphia Phils tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 The Justice Department today charged that officials in Louisiana were using the state laws against unauthorized legal practice to block out-of-state lawyers from representing Negroes in civil rights cases.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 19 (AP) Dave Boswell fired a twohitter and Bob Allison paced Minnesota's 14-hit attack with two singles and a double tonight as the Twins protected their share of the American League lead by pounding the Kansas City Athletics, 8-2.
ALBANY, Sept. 19 (UPI) A hearing will be held Sept. 27 to determine whether the work stoppage by teachers in New York City is a strike under the new Taylor Law and subject to penalty.

The owners of the Torrey Canyon, a tanker that spilled her cargo of 119,000 tons of crude oil on the shores of Britain after being stranded off the Scilly Isles, filed a defensive complaint in the United States District Court here yesterday.

MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 19 Paul H. Douglas said today that unless widespread housing desegregation was accomplished in the nation's suburbs, America "will be torn by the sharp hostility of the affluent white suburbs" and the Negroes living in the cities.

The American Institute of Certified Public Accountants proposed new rules yesterday that would require companies to make full provision for income taxes in the same period that the income is reported, regardless of when the tax may actually be paid.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Betty Furness, President Johnson's Assistant for Consumer Affairs, cautioned bankers today to stop sending out unsolicited credit cards or else face the possibility of being forbidden to by law.
BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Sept. 19 The president of Briarcliff College has resigned in a personal dispute with the chairman of the board of trustees.

DETROIT, Sept. 19 In a masterpiece of self-frustration, the Detroit Tigers managed to lose to the Boston Red Sox, 4-2, before 43,004 at Tiger Stadium tonight, and left first place in the American League to the Red Sox and the Minnesota Twins.
The International Rectifier Corporation of Los Angeles introduced yesterday a new type of semiconductor device that it said marked a major technological breakthrough.
MEMPHIS, Sept. 19 (UPI) The police had two versions today of an argument between Elvis Presley and a former yardman at the entertainer's mansion.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 The House Banking Committee overruled its chairman today and rejected a move to requite an audit of the Federal Reserve System by the General Accounting Office.
INTO each life a little fashion must fall and yesterday it pattered gently into the beige and gold salon at Elizabeth Arden. There was no thunder or lightning.

A pretty, vivacious 25year-old, Maureen Hakker, has a claim to banking fame. She is the first woman officer of the First National City Bank of New York to be assigned to a foreign service post. Just the other day she left by jet to take up her new job in the Central American city of San Salvador.
Even a second hopeful statement from Orville Freeman, the Secretary of Agriculture, did not shake wheat and corn futures out of their low-priced doldrums yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Senator Charles H. Percy's prospects as a Republican Presidential candidate received a push today from his Illinois colleague, Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen.

ALTHOUGH the pro football season has only begun, casualties to quarterbacks are at hand. The Cleveland Browns, scheduled to play the Detroit Lions next, list their passer, Frank Ryan, as doubtful.

OF recent years the National League has taken a vast amount of pride in the closeness of its pennant races. The managers would be quite condescending sometimes almost insufferably so when they'd predict in spring training that "it will be another dog fight and won't be decided until the last day." Seven teams supposedly would be in contention before the clicheridden finale was attained.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Sept. 19 The exhibition of American pop art in the ninth Bienal de Sao Paulo, which opens officially on Friday, is clearly going to be the sensation of this huge exposition of contemporary art representing 60 countries. Called "Enviroment USA: 19571967," and given a spectacular installation, the show is already the focus of much discussion, envy and consternation.

Michael H. Akeroyd has been named managing director and chief executive officer of the Dictaphone Company, Ltd., Wholly owned British subsidary of the Dictaphone Corporation, effective Nov. 1.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) The House Post Office Committee accepted today a bill that would grant postal workers a 6 per cent pay increase and give other Federal employes a 4.5 per cent raise.

The British pound, which has shown a weakening trend recently, closed here yesterday at the same spot rate as on Monday, $2.7835. The forward rate on sterling widened a trifle, the closing quotation for delivery in 90 days at $2.7885 for a discount of 50 points, compared with 48 a day earlier.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Would you believe? Barry Goldwater said today he was just kidding about a plan to black out radio and television coverage of the Republican National Convention in 1964.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 19 Corneliu Manes cu, the first Communist to be President of the General Assembly, is a familiar figure at the United Nations.

Prompted by President Johnson's demand for tax increases, the business forecasting derby is off to an early start. In fact, the Council of Economic Advisers and many other seers are positive that the outcome is already in the bag.

Paperboard production fell 6.6 per cent with 434,700 tons in the week ended Sept. 16, compared with the level in the corresponding 1966 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paperboard Association reported yesterday.

P. Lorillard has voluntarily decided to change the package of its new 100-millimeter cigarette, Century Great Lengths, so that the health warning label will appear on the package itself rather than just on the cellophane overwrap.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Sept. 20 (AP) The New Jersey Turnpike Authority disclosed today that it was raising some of its commercial tolls.

The record division of RCA Victor Distributing Corporation, the phonograph and records unit of the Radio Corporation of America, which has invested in four forthcoming Broadway musicals to get the originalcast album rights, is adapting this procedure to the motionpicture field.

Jacob Baker, chairman of the board of the Economic Forecasting Institute of Mount Vernon, N.Y., a former Government official and deputy to the late Harry Hopkins, the World War II aide of President Franklin D. Roosevelt, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 72 years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 A coalition was shaping up in the Senate today to take the administration of low-income housing projects away from the Federal Housing Administration on the grounds that it is too slow and cumbersome to meet the urgent needs of urban slums.

Prices on the London Stock Exchange continued to advance yesterday.

Bobbie Brooks, Inc., the apparel manufacturer, sustained a net loss of $465,000 in the first fiscal quarter ended July 31, it was announced yesterday in Cleveland. This compares with a net profit of $2,055,300, or 61 cents a share, in the corresponding 1966 quarter.

Theater clubs, a growing Broadway institution, expect to sell $5-million worth of tickets for the 1967-68 season, or about 10 per cent of the theater's anticipated sales.
