Diners' Club, Inc., the credit card service organization, has agreed to acquire Fugazy Travel Bureau, Inc., the world's third largest travel concern after American Express Company and Thomas Cook Sons.
Macy's and Gimbels lately have been behaving, oddly enough, like Macy's and Gimbels.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UPI) The Kennedy family plane, The Caroline, is being retired.

When five platinum futures contracts are traded, it's a good day for that metal on the New York Mercantile Exchange. When 10 change hands, it's a big day. Yesterday, volume shot up to 25 contracts. It was so busy that the brokers on the exchange, who usually spend their time buying and selling potato futures, made an informal ring to facilitate their platinum trading.
DETROIT, Sept. 20 The Ford Motor Company raised its 1968 car prices today an average of $114, or 3.9 per cent, over the prices on 1967 models.

Governor Rockefeller's announcement that he will campaign for the repeal of the constitutional ban on state aid to denominational schools will come as a shock to all who believe in separation of church and state and who thought he did too. Furthermore, repeal of the ban will do untold harm to the public school system that has been a cornerstone in the democratic integration of the variegated population of this city and state.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 President Johnson called today for a comprehensive Govern ment plan to expand and improve the nation's air traffic control system and said he would ask the beneficiaries to pay for it.

George F. Ferris, chairman of the board of Raymond In- ternational, Inc., heavy-construction company, died Tuesday night of a heart attack while on a business trip to Los Angeles. He was 65 years old and resided at 1125 Park Avenue.

Whenever a new superliner takes to the water, as the 58,000-ton Queen Elizabeth II did yesterday on the Clyde, the doubters wag their heads and say she will be the last of the big ships. Larger passenger liners are indeed on the defensive against air competition these days, and there is comfort in the coming of the new queen of the sea, in the long and honorable maritime tradition of her flag.
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 20 Screams of "Fight! Fight! Fight-Fight-Fight!" echoed under the high-vaulted ceiling of the Westchester County Center today.
VASILY was also summoned on March 2, 1953. He, too, spent several hours sitting in the big room that was so crowded with people. But he was drunk
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20--The Senate Juvenile Delinquency subcommittee approved today by one vote the Johnson Administation's, strong bill to control firearms.
Police of the West 20th Street station were investigating yesterday a series of acts of vandalism at the 2,800-tenant Penn Station South Cooperative Houses.
A spokesman for Donaldson, Lufkin Jenrette fielded questions concerning his firm's 410,000-share trade in Harvey Aluminum by refusing to say anything at all. That's par for the course.

MONTREAL, Sept. 20 The Vienna State Opera gave Alban Berg's "Wozzeck" last night in the Salle Wilfrid Pelletier, the last of the five productions it brought to Expo 67. It performed this difficult work with the assurance and ease that most companies bring to "La Boh me" or "La Traviata."

New Yorkers will be glad that the public schools are finally free to get on with their vital educational mission, but the settlement of the teachers' strike insures neither tranquillity for the school system nor a sound foundation for municipal labor relations.
DR. MARTIN HARROW of Hartford, won first prize in the recent 1967 New England Open Championship at Boston.

DUSHANBE, U.S.S.R., Sept. 9 There are only five mosques in Dushanbe, but the imam at Shakh Mansur Mosque said this was no indication of the extent of the Moslem influence in the capital of the Tadzhik Soviet Socialist Republic.
PARIS, Sept. 20 The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation has won an international bidding match to exploit nickel deposits in New Caledonia, it was announced today.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 20 The Yemeni royalists have called for an early, broad-based conference of tribal and political leaders to choose an eightman sovereignty council to head their war-torn country once Egyptian troops withdraw from the little nation on the eastern shore of the Red Sea.

MADRID, Sept. 20 Generalissimo Francisco Franco named today the 65 appointive members of the lower and upper chambers of Parliament in what was widely interpreted as a preview of the political character of the Spanish regime for the rest of his rule and afterward.
DETROIT, Sept. 20 There's nothing like a visit from the New York Yankees to put some life into a struggling pennant contender.
DENVER, Sept. 20 (AP) A kidney of a defendant who mortally wounded himself in a Denver courtroom has been transplanted to a 24-year-old Colorado woman.

CLEVELAND HEIGHTS, Ohio, Sept. 20 The engagement of Miss Judith Ellis Knight to S. Sterling McMillan 3d has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lewis Knight. Mr. McMillan is the son of Mr. and Mrs. McMillan of Mountain Glen Farm in Mentor.
BONN, Sept. 20 (Reuters) A West German doctor has developed an "antisnore harness," the medical magazine Deutsches Aerzteblatt reported today.

Richard Cooper, a public relations man for the Allied Chemical Corporation and a former assistant to the picture editor of The New York Times, died yesterday after a long illness at Parkway Hospital in Forest Hills, Queens. He was 42 years old.
NEWARK, Sept. 20 (AP) The Prudential Insurance Company of America may be struck by 17,000 insurance agents next Monday night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 President Johnson's legislative program for improving living conditions in the slums received a substantial boost today when the Senate voted $537-million for model cities and $40-million for rent supplements.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UPI) John Charles Daly Jr., moderator of the television quiz program "What's My Line?" was sworn today as head of the Voice of America.
VERGENNES, Vt., Sept. 20 Volkswagen, the German car maker, announced today that it was raising prices in America on its beetle cars by $56.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 20 The General Assembly met today and elected its 17 vice presidents for the current 22d session. They included Arthur J. Goldberg of the United States.
The mummified bodies of three infants, all of whom apparently died in the nineteen-twenties, were found in a steamer trunk yesterday.

WHEN Valentina, the fashion designer, scornfully said "mink is for football" back in the nineteen-thirties, it was considered the quintessence of snobbism. This year, with the prices of mink coats down anywhere from 10 to 25 per cent from their highs, mink may be for the subway as well.

The license of a Westchester real estate salesman has been suspended for six months after the New York Secretary of State ruled that the salesman had used "blockbusting" tactics, in which white residents are stampeded into selling homes cheaply by the threat of an influx of Negroes.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 20 The only Negro alderman on the city's Common Council reported today some softening of Milwaukee's opposition to an open housing ordinance.
The city's antipoverty planning organization informed the Board of Education yesterday that it had withdrawn its objection to the board's plans to use Federal funds in disadvantaged areas.

MONTREAL, Thursday, Sept. 21 (Canadian Press) Public transportation came to a halt early today as thousands of Montreal Transportation Commission employes voted at a mass meeting to strike immediately for higher pay.
The New York Central Railroad hopes sport to build a skyscraper, possibly 45 stories tall, surmounting the waiting room of Grand Central Terminal.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Sept. 20 (UPI) A dispute over alleged racial discrimination involving Negro athletes at San Jose State College forced cancellation tonight of the Spartans' home football opener Saturday against the University of Texas at El Paso.

Ring Twice came through with an appropriate and extremely popular victory in the $28,950 Stymie Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. The 4-year-old, Owned by George D. Widener, is a grandson of the famous campaigner of two decades ago for whom the mile-and-a-quarter race is named.
LEIPZIG, East Germany, Sept. 20 (Reuters) Roland Matthes of East Germany broke the world swimming record for the men's 110-yard backstroke today with a time of 1 minute 0.1 seconds.
HARTFORD, Sept. 20--The streets of Hartford's predominantly Negro North End were quiet this evening after two nights of racial violence.
SEATTLE, Sept. 20 (AP) Episcopal bishops endorsed today a charter for sweeping reform of the church's seminary training and voted to set up a nine-member national board to carry it out.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 Secretary McNamara has been so long marinated in the thought of our doomsday philosophers that he now speaks the jargon like a native. His mastery of this bizarre rhetoric was illustrated the other day in his San Francisco speech explaining why we need yet another megamillion-dollar missile program.
TORONTO, Sept. 20 (Canadian Press) Canada's two largest uranium producers announced today they would sell 31 million pounds of uranium concentrates to a group of Japanese electrical utilities.
CARSON CITY, Nev., Sept, 20 The shutdown of the casino at the Riverside Hotel in Reno has led to a shake-up in the state agency that polices the multimillion-dollar Nevada gambling industry.
Walter Kidde Co., Inc., is planning to acquire the Lithonia Lighting, Inc., in a transaction involving more than $18-million in stock, it was announced yesterday.
BOSTON, Sept. 20 A University of London physician and a Boston psychiatrist testified today that the use of marjuana does not lead to mental or physical illness.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Sept. 20 Lehigh's football team has no place to go but up.
Mrs. Wilheim Augustat of Vienna has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ingrid Lisa Augustat, to John Stephen Haskell, son of Mrs. Aileen R. Haskell and Herbert Haskell, both of New York.
They arrived here from almost every state and from about a dozen foreign countries. They swaggered. They stumbled. They put on pale blue beanies and became the class of 1971 at Columbia College.

"I went to school up here," a Negro parent recently told a Negro elementary-school teacher, "and we had white materials storybooks and textbooks showing white children and white families. And we didn't get any inferiority complex."
KINSHASA, the Congo, Sept. 20 (AP) Mercenary gunners at Bukavu downed a Congolese fighter, one of three that had been raiding them daily, today.
Like all hurricanes, Beulah should be reaching its end because it has reached land.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The Department of Transportation said today that the inauguration of the three-hour rail passenger service between Washington and New York had been postponed until the first of the year.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 20 (AP)--Tony Oliva and Bob Allison slammed two-run homers and Harmon Killebrew drove in two runs, with a pair of singles, to pace Minnesota and Dean Chance to a 6-2 victory over Kansas City today.
DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 20 Sporadic disorders including arrests of 20 teen-agers and a $20,000 supermarket fire, marked a second night of violence on Dayton's predominantly Negro West Side tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 A key member of the House Ways and Means Committee has warned President Johnson that he is "living in a dream world" if he thinks Congress will pass a tax increase without a large cut in Government spending first.
CLIFTON, N.J., Sept. 20 Jack Nicklaus was ready today for a sweep of the metropolitan area's three major golf tournaments.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 Either Governor Rockefeller or Gov. George Romney of Michigan would defeat President Johnson in California if there were an election currently, a new statewide opinion survey indicates.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 20 Another attempt to resume the return of Arab refugees to the west bank collapsed tonight when Jordanian officials failed to appear at Allenby Bridge for a meeting with the Israelis.

Harold (Hal) C. Banks, former head of the Seafarers International Union of Canada, cannot be extradited for perjury, it was argued yesterday in court, because "there is no known treaty of extradition made directly between the United States and Canada."
Many issues advanced sharply in active trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.
LONDON, Sept. 20 About 1,500 gold and silver coins from a British fleet that was wrecked off the Scilly Isles 260 years ago were recovered today by treasure-hunting divers.
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said yesterday that it planned to exchange stock worth about $330-million to acquire the Cerro Corporation.

MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 20 Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, announced today the establishment of a new youth movement that will include as one of its major objectives the development of American Jewish youth "into knowledgeable Zionist leaders for future community responsibility."

PROGRAM Field of 125 will play 18 holes today and tomorrow. Low 70 scorers and ties will continue 18 holes on Saturday and 18 holes on Sunday. In event of tie for first, sudden-death playoff will follow completion of final round.
Douglass Campbell was appointed yesterday as chairman of the Bowater Paper Compny, Inc., the New York distribution subsidiary of the Bowater Paper Corporation, Ltd.
A tentative settlement of the school dispute, which has kept most teachers and many pupils out of school for eight days, was announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.
The short interest position of shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange declined sharply in the month ended Sept. 15 from the record level attained in the preceding 30-day period.
The police sought a brief Midtown gun battle early yesterday morning with a 21-yearold man, who described himself as a mercenary soldier. No one was wounded.
PARAMUS, N.J., Sept. 20 Mrs. Percy Pyne 3d of Somerset Hills, the defending champion, was eliminated from the New Jersey state women's matchplay golf championship today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20--The International Voluntary Services plans to continue without interruption its programs of relief to villages, peasants and refugees in South Vietnam, despite the resignations yesterday of four senior field officials.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 Adm. Ullysses S.G. Sharp, commander of United States forces in the Pacific, has warned Congress that a halt in the bombing of North Vietnam would be "a disaster for the United States" and would extend the war indefinitely.

TRENTON, Sept. 20 The Prudential Insurance Company of America announced here today that it would finance a $4.5-million cooperative, middle-income housing project on the edge of the Negro ghetto in Newark.
A 15-foot-square section of brick wall dropped from an East Side building yesterday about a half hour after its 50 tenants were evacuated because construction men had noticed cracks in the structure.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 20 (UPI) Federal and state agents arrested seven men and confiscated Nazi decals and about 100 weapons, including machine guns, in simultaneous raids today that capped a threemonth undercover investigation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 A Federal judge suggested today that a young man who became accustomed to necking and petting while in the military might have a legal right to continue for a while after he returned to civilian life.
An Eastern Airlines executive warned yesterday that rising costs for airport terminals and of air traffic delays were "more than offsetting" the reduced costs of jet flight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) Conversion of poor and abandoned farm lands into public recreation, fish and wildlife areas would be aided by Federal grants under a bill sent to the Senate today by its Agriculture Committee.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Sept. 20 The Rev. Dr. Frank D. Getty of 49 Mountain Avenue, former director of the Presbyterian Synod of New Jersey and the author of textbooks and a hymnal for young people, died yesterday at a nursing home in Summit. His age was 77. He retired in 1956 after having directed the synod since 1945.
MOSCOW, Sept. 20 (AP) A Soviet newspaper today portrayed Baltimore as a sin city under Mafia influence.
The United States Court of Appeals yesterday upheld New York City's dismissal last December of 15 sanitationmen for refusing to answer questions about their conduct on their jobs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The Justice Department has reached an agreement with Eversharp, Inc., and Schick Electric, Inc., that would technically permit the planned merger of the two companies but actually force them to continue as competitors in the shaving-equipment business.
The Ex-Cell-O Corporation, Detroit machine tools and precision equipment manufacturer, reported yesterday lower earnings for the quarter and nine months ended Aug. 31 despite larger sales.
A LOT of women drove up to Alexander's yesterday in limousines and Southampton tans.

Adolf A. Berle Jr., chairman of the board of trustees of the 20th Century Fund, announced yesterday that Murray J. Rossant, a member of the editorial board of The New York Times, would become director of the fund on Oct. 2.

The United States Savings and Loan League reported yesterday that the estimated net savings gain of the nation's savings and loan associations in August amounted to $680million, more than five times the gain registered in August, 1966.
Perry D. Lindholm has been elected vice president for manufacturing of ChesebroughPond's, Inc., drug and cosmetics manufacturer.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Sept. 20 Richard Smith, the 35-year-old British painter, who divides his time between London and New York, has been awarded the $10,000 grand prize by the jury of the ninth Bienal de Sao Paulo.

U Thant's dramatic proposal to invoke a hitherto unused provision of the United Nations Charter to hold secret Security Council meetings at foreign-minister level is a measure of his deep foreboding about the course of events.
CLINTONDALE, N.Y. "You're Now in McIntosh Country Where Apples Grow Best" read the billboard half a mile from the 250-acre fruit farm of William A. Coy in Clintondale, Ulster County, N.Y.
Today began unhappily for the Superintendent of Schools, despite the contract accord with the teachers' union.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 20 Violence broke out again late last night and today in western Pennsylvania and elsewhere in the strike of steel haulers that has spread from Chicago to the East.

Mrs. Anne Willson Bartels, wife of Federal Judge John R. Bartels of the Eastern District of New York, died on Tuesday at the Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. She lived at 24 Monroe Place in Brooklyn.
Dr. Leonard Lief, the new provost of Hunter College's Bronx campus, outlined expansion plans yesterday that will take effect when the school becomes independent.
OTTAWA, Sept. 20 (Canadian Press) The Government will pay 6 per cent interest on nearly half the $525-million worth of new bonds it offered Monday, it was announced today.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 20 The Hudson River Valley Commission has decided to approve the expansion of a garbage dump in Yonkers to which it had previously objected.

The Gannett Company, Inc., the newspaper and broadcasting chain, announced yesterday the filing of a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of 500,000 common shares.
While Wes Westrum was waiting for the other shoe to drop last night, his New York Mets dropped a 4-3 decision to the Los Angeles Dodgers and an old nemesis, Don Drysdale.

EL AMPARO, Venezuela, Sept. 20 (Reuters) President Raul leoni of Venezuela and President Carlos Lleras Restrepo of Colombia met, embraced, ate lunch and signed a new border agreement today all without leaving their countries.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Sept. 20 The United States delegation's efforts to involve the Security Council in Vietnam peace-making have met strong opposition, qualified sources reported today.

CORNWALL, Conn., Sept. 20 Mr. and Mrs. C. Huntington Erhart have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joanna Lee Erhart, to John Barnes Tyson. He is the son of Mrs. Armin Landeck of Cornwall and Mark Tyson of Bernadsville, N.J., and East Hampton, L.I.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 20 Reliable sources here said that Nigerian Army troops recaptured the midwestern capital of Benin tonight.
A steel executive sharply rejected a contention yesterday that domestic industry had not done enough to modernize steel facilities, a failure that opened the gate to more imports from abroad.

As the specter of inflation takes on more substance and casts its reflection on the securities markets, many corporations, labor unions and individuals concerned with pension problems are turning toward noninsured retirement programs.
V. Alexander Polich, a vice president of the Uris Buildings Corporation, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 209 East 56th Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) President Johnson received a report today that the tourist gap is being narrowed and the United States is getting about 30 per cent more visitors from overseas this year, largely because of Canada's Expo 67.
Two men were arrested in a demonstration in the Bronx last night to protest traffic conditions at the corner of Courtlandt Avenue and East 149th Street.
Life magazine has regrouped its advertising sales force and will soon be adding new troops.

HANOI, North Vietnam, Sept. 20 (Agence France-Presse) Official sources here declined to comment today on the current dispute between the United States State Department and Harry S. Ashmore, an American journalist, over Mr. Ashmore's charge that President Johnson "brutally canceled" a secret peace initiative last February.

Sol M. Zweifach, a New York merger consultant, announced yesterday an offer to buy at $25 a share the 57 per cent interest in the American Steel Pump Corporation now owned by B. S. F. Company. American Steel was quoted at $16.50 bid on the over-the-counter market yesterday. The corporate client of Mr. Zweifach was not disclosed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The House voted overwhelmingly today to condition its approval of a $150-million increase in funds for the Inter-American Development Bank in the next three years on a comprehensive audit of its operations by the General Accounting Office.

The new Mount Sinai School of Medicine has been given $25,787,000 for construction costs by the United States public Health Service. The money will be used to put up a build ing on 100th Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 20 Secretary General Thant asked the General Assembly today to work for the release of African diplomats held hostage by the Ivory Coast in an effort to obtain the release of prisoners held by Guinea.
Merger of the Rheem Manufacturing Company, here with the Dillingham Corporation, Honolulu construction company, is under consideration, the companies announced jointly yesterday.

Like the changing of the seasons, the introduction of the new line of automobiles has become a colorful part of autumn Americana. In words and images, the first announcements of the '68 models promise not to disappoint the public educated to buy luxurious fittings, fastback sportiness and masculine conquest by horsepower.

A man who allegedly used an expensively furnished midtown apartment as an "office" to accept $1-million in bets annually on horse races and other sporting events was charged yesterday with failing to purchase the $50 Federal tax stamp and register as a gambler.

Charles M. Parker, vice president of research and technology for the American Iron and Steel Institute, 150 East 42d Street, and a leading consultant to government and industry, died yesterday at his home in Norwalk, Conn. He was 63 years old.

William H. Tucker, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, has indicated to the White House that he will not seek reappointment when his term of office expires on Dec. 31, according to close associates of Mr. Tucker.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept, 20 (AP) Policemen equipped with riot gear moved into a Negro area on the East Side tonight to break up a crowd estimated at several hundred persons that congregated around a group of civil rights pickets.

MURRAY HILL, N.J., Sept. 20 John R. Townsend, who retired seven years ago as dirertor of meterials applications engineering at the Bell Telephone Laboratories here, died Monday at Alexandria, Va. His age was 71.

Students at the city's public schools were told to stay away today, although teachers and other members of school staffs were asked to report for duty following yesterday's tentative settlement of the teachers' stoppage.
WAVERLY, Minn., Sept. 20 Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson came here from Washington today to help contend with the problem of how to keep 'em down on the farm once they've seen Minneapolis.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 20 It took Don Russell three seasons to revive Wesleyan University's football fortunes. His efforts were were capped last year by a 6-2, won-lost record and the Cardinals' first Little Three title in 19 years.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 20 A former grocery store at 169 First Street in the predominantly Negro port section of this city will be converted as Mayor Thomas G. Dunn's Little City Hall next month.
Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that judgments on the bombing of North Vietnam should be made only by those with access to special intelligence information.

The Metropolitan Opera gave its first performance of the season last night of Mozart's "Die Zauberfl te," in the "Flutist on the Roof" production designed by Marc Chagall. The cast brought no new faces to the Met's stage, being largely the second platoon from last season, when Chagall's paintbesplattered show was introduced to the repertory.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept 20 (UPI) More than 3,000 Negroes gathered in the northeast section tonight when a Congress of Racial Equality group protested for more than two hours the refusal by a white landlord to rent them a vacant store.
Price increases were ananounced yesterday for brake linings and other friction products of the World Bestos. Company, a division of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company.

Holiday Inns of America, operator of 858 motels, is planning to add dinner theaters to its chain. How soon they will go into production depends on the outcome of a pilot project to be run from Oct. 17 to 19 in Memphis, the company's headquarters.

France issued a challenge for the America's Cup to the New York Yacht Club yesterday. It was the first time in the 116 years of the international yachting competition that the French had challenged for the mug.

DREXEL HILL, Pa., Sept. 20 Miss Virginia Susan Foster and Everett McMullin Barber Jr. will be married next month. Their engagement has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Foster.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company achieved record revenues and earnings in the three and twelve months ended Aug. 31, according to the report issued yesterday by the world's largest corporation.

SEATTLE, Sept. 20 (UPI)--A 10,000-ton freighter, the Silver Shelton, inbound to Tacoma collided with another cargo ship, the Fairland, in heavy fog on Puget Sound today and was beached 15 miles north of Seattle.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 20 The Oregon state medical examiner said today that he believed the recent deaths of six women might have been caused by certain weight-reducing pills. In addition, the causes of two other deaths are being investigated.
Sterling Hunkins, a cellist, who had performed with many musical groups, died Sunday at his summer home in Phoenicia, N.Y., of a heart ailment. He was 59 years old and lived at 302 Eighth Avenue.

A new shipyard capable of building 50,000-deadweight-ton bulk carriers for service on the Great Lakes will be built at Erie, Pa., John B. Cogan, vice president of the Litton Industrial Transportation Systems Organization, announced yesterday.
ATHENS, Sept. 20 The Greek military regime ousted two East European diplomats today for "engaging in activities endangering the security of Greece."
The Communications Satellite Corporation formally replied yesterday to the Ford Foundation's plea on Monday that Comsat be denied permission to develop a pilot program for domestic satellites.
Thirty-six issues of bonds totaling $105.38-million were sold at competitive bidding yesterday in the most important tax-exempt financing of the week.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Sept. 17 The voters of New Zealand, which elects a singlechamber Parliament every three years, is being asked if they want to extend the term to four years. The country will decide in a national referendum on Saturday.
BROWNSVILLE, Tex., Sept. 20--Hurricane Beulah battered the Texas Gulf Coast today and touched off 27 tornadoes as it moved inland from Brownsville. Its strength was rapidly diminishing.
The New York Jets, attempting to strengthen their kicking game, acquired Booth Lustig on waivers yesterday from the Miami Dolphins.
MATHIS, Tex., Sept. 20 At the Palace Cafe in Fall City between Corpus Christi and San Antonio tonight, a group of cowboys and oil workers was holding a hurricane party.
Insurance Securities, Inc., a San Francisco insurance and investment company, has announced the election of Jerome C. Eppler as chairman.
CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (AP) Gaylord Perry pitched a sevenhitter and gained his fifth straight victory as the San Francisco Giants beat the Chicago Cubs today, 5-1.
The wholesale commodity price index maintained on Tuesday the level it reached on Monday, which was 96.3.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) The Senate passed without dissent today a bill authorizing $500-million in Federal aid for vocational rehabilitation next year. The House had already passed the bill, which now goes to the White House.

HONG KONG, Sept. 20 A yachtsman from Baldwin, L.I., described today how he was at first almost "scared to death" and later almost "bored to death" during a month-long enforced stay in Communist China.

OTTAWA, Sept. 20 (Canadian Press) Labor Minister John Robert Nicholson will send his top labor relations specialist, Bernard Wilson, to Montreal tomorrow to hold separate talks with labor and management negotiators in the Great Lakes shipping dispute.
ALBANY, Sept. 20. The Constitutional Convention voted today to open the books and records of all public authorities, such as the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, to public scrutiny.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) Several thousand workers striking against Pan AmericanWorld Airways ended today a brief walkout that apparently did little to slow the airline's global operations.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 20 If write-in votes are allowed for the All-Star Jockey Handicap here, Hedley Woodhouse may get to the post after all. He deserves it.
Governor Rockefeller and Senator Robert F. Kennedy disagreed yesterday on how much progress was being made in cleaning up pollution in the Hudson River.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 20 Three Egyptian launches ferrying soldiers in the Suez Canal were sunk today by Israeli tank fire, according to a communiqu issued here.
HONG KONG, Sept. 20 Meager at best, the livelihood of the people of Communist China is certain to be further reduced, possibly for a long time, by Mao Tse-tung's Cultural Revolution.

MANHASSET, L.I., Sept. 20 Mr. and Mrs. William Ellis Porter Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Begly Porter, to Capt. Jeffrey Thomas Shea, U.S.M.C., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Martin Shea.
The Brooklyn and the Bronx chapters of CORE announced yesterday that they will demand the establishment of two community-run schools exclusively for the education of disruptive children.
The Earl of Snowdon, husband of Britain's Princess Margaret, is filming a television news documentary for the Columbia Broadcasting System. It is Lord Snowdon's first venture into cinema.
A coalition of New York Democrats opposed to President Johnson's Vietnam policy has taken the decision to run slates of anti-Johnson delegates to the party's national convention.

THE folks running the Thunderbird golf tournament this weekend probably will not appreciate the reminder, but they hardly will need nudging to cast anxious eyes aloft for their four-day show, which starts today at the Upper Montclair Country Club. Much too fresh in memory is the sad fate that befell the Westchester Classic a month ago, the last major money competition in this general area.
EARLY in 1959 Harold George Israelson was ad vising teachers that they had a right to strike in contract disputes with the city. Today he knows what it feels like to be in the middle.

"Both an exciting challenge and a threat" is posed for the European banking system by the new development of medium-term loans across national borders and in different currencies, a Brussels financier said here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 President Johnson's nomination of Walter E. Washington to head the newly streamlined District of Columbia city government was approved unanimously today by the Senate District Committee.

ADEN, Sept. 20 (AP) Heavy fighting is taking place in the South Arabian Federation's State of Dhala between National Liberation Front forces that "liberated" the area, and troops of the rival Front for the Liberation of Occupied South Yemen.

Dr. Paul H. Linehan, former director of the evening session at City College and a member of its mathematics faculty for 46 years, died yesterday at St. Barnabas Hospital in the Bronx. He was 88 years old.
Fred Lazarus Jr., who will be 83 years old on Oct. 29, has relinquished his post as chairman of Federated Department Stores, Inc., in a realignment of top management, the company announced yesterday.
Mr. Smith, who was reached there yesterday at his studio, said, "I'm absolutely delighted to win the prize. I'm sorry I'm not there."
Stock prices bobbed indecisively yesterday and closed with mixed readings.
NEW HAVEN, Sept. 20 Brian Dowling, Yale University's spectacular passing-run ning quarterback, broke his right wrist yesterday afternoon during a no-contact drill.
PARIS, Sept. 20 The Roman Catholic Church of France is taking a compassionate and worried look at the plight of divorced women, described by one of them as virtual pariahs in the Christian community.

STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 20 (Reuters) The Common Market's Executive Commission will report in favor of opening negotiations with Britain and other countries seeking entry into the European Economic Community, the commission chairman, Jean Rey, said today.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 20 (AP) Shareholders of the Getty Oil Company, the Thewater Oil Company and the Mission Development Company agreed to merge today into a new concern known as the Getty Oil Company.

THE late Albert Morehead, who conducted this column for more than 30 years, was an authority on all card games. The last of his 70-odd books in this area is being published this week by Simon and Shuster at $5.95. It is "The Complete Guide to Winning Poker," a masterly treatment of a complex game that certainly will be regarded as the last word on this subject.
Prices continued to advance yesterday on the London stock exchange.
The appointment of M. Lee Rice as a senior vice president was announced here yesterday by the Ogden Corporation, a diversified manufacturing company.
United States air raids on North Vietnam in the last few days have continued a process described by the military as "shouldering out" the port of Haiphong.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 A team of prominent American physicians has returned from a Government-sponsored inspection trip to South Vietnam urging the expansion of American support for the Vietnamese public health program, informed sources said today.

NEWARK, Sept. 20--The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark announced today that it was sponsoring a new housing and rehabilitation program for the slum-dwellers of this and other northern New Jersey cities.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 20 For the third night in a row, the Boston Red Sox won a share of the American League lead tonight by means of ninth-inning heroics centering around Carl Yastrzemski, their left-fielder, who is establishing superstar status more convincingly every day.
CLYDEBANK, Scotland, Sept. 20--Queen Elizabeth II launched Britain's newest luxury liner today and named her Queen Elizabeth II.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 20 A lot of folks who earlier in the day were pointing to Romulus Hanover as a "cinch" to win tomorrow's 22d edition of the Little Brown Jug, learned later today they might have to revise their estimates.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 Gov. George Romney of Michigan, touring the nation's urban areas, met his first serious rebuff today and engaged in a heated argument with a young Puerto Rican leader who prevented him from holding a scheduled conference.

MASSAPEQUA, L.I., Sept. 20 Mrs. Robert W. Gesecus has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jean Marie Gesecus, to Midshipman John W. Feick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert J. Feick of Towson, Md.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 Last July, just after the Newark riot and just before the violent outbreak in Detroit, the House of Representatives rejected with laughter and derision the Johnson Administration's proposed rat-control program. This week, reversing itself rather sheepishly, the House appended the program to a public health bill.

SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 20 North Korean shore batteries sank one of nine South Korean fishing boats operating near the seaward extension of the demilitarized zone off the east coast early this morning, it was reported here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The Smithsonian Institution, which last week opened a minimuseum in a converted movie house here is quietly setting up a major museum in the two block long, old Patent Office Building at F and Eighth Streets.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The House confirmed today its decision to wade a $40-million drive to exterminate rats.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Sept. 21 B-52 bombers struck twice before dawn today in the demilitarized zone in what has so far been an unavailing effort to stop the steady North Vietnamese bombardment of the Marine outposts at Conthien and Giolinh.
HUMOR, Fernando Diaz-Plaja appears to believe, is too serious a business to be left to humorists. He presents his countrymen's foibles as a moralist.
The 99-year-old LockwoodMathews mansion in Norwalk, Conn., will be the setting for an interior design exhibition from Sept. 30 through Oct. 22.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 20 (AP) The Polish journalist who told Russians that Baltimore was a city of sin and run by the Mafia "obviously was too enticed by three blocks of Baltimore to look around him and see a beautiful, wholesome city," Mayor McKeldin said today.
Directors of Fuqua Industries, Inc., a diversified manufacturing company, yesterday approved a recapitalization plan, subject to approval of stockholders at a special meeting on Oct. 27.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UPI)--An Air Force general reported today that space satellites provided the main communication link between the United States and Vietnam for more than a week recently when cable communications were disrupted.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 20 Mrs. Tatiana Holmsen Kelley of this city and New York was married here this evening to Thomas Jackson Oakley Rhinelander 2d of New York.
PRAGUE, Sept. 18 Czechoslovakia's economic reform, begun at the start of the year, has run into serious difficulties.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 (UPI) The city warned contractors, builders and real estate dealers today that they would be barred from doing business with city agencies if they were found guilty of racial discrimi nation, even in private operations.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 20 (UPI) Firemen and workmen were overcome today by potentially deadly chlorine gas fumes that escaped from a ruptured storage tank at the Continental Oil Company plant in south Baltimore.

The legendary House of Rothschild, which amassed one of the world's great fortunes as banker to the crowned heads of 19th century Europe, has decided to broaden substantially the scope of its investment operations in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI) --The House of Representatives approved today President Johnson's plan for creation of a public corporation to give television viewers more alternatives to ordinary commercial programing.

NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 21-- Mrs. Beryl Norman Gardella, who aided her husband, Louis J. Gardella, in operating three of the city's major businesses, died yesterday in Norwalk Hospital. She was 57 years old and lived here on Spar Road.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)--The Senate passed by a vote of 77 to 5 today a bill allocating $10.49-billion for 24 Federal agencies. The measure gives President Johnson what he requested for clearing city slums and helping low-income families pay their rent.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21-- The International Finance Corporation made more and bigger investments than ever before in the fiscal year ended June 30, the annual report disclosed today.
Directors of the American Sterilizer Company and Narco Scientific Industries reached an agreement in principle yesterday to consolidate their oporations into a new corporation.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 20-- Gustav T. Andren, retired executive vice president and mortgage officer of the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn, died today at Nassau Hospital after a brief illness. He was 63 years old and lived at 365 Stewart Avenue, Garden City.

"See Fancies," the second annual luncheon and fashion show of the Shore Chapter of the National Cystic Fibrosis Research Foundation, will be held tomorrow at 12:30 P.M. in the Crystal Brook Inn, Eatontown, N.J.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 21--The United States asked today whether the Soviet Union and other friends of North Vietnam would use their influence toward obtaining a peaceful resolution of the war if the Americans were to halt bombing of the North.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)--Negroes who graduate from college generally do so despite the handicaps of racial discrimination, broken homes, poor school preparation and money problems, a Government report said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)--A Federal pay rise combined with an increase in postal rates was approved today by the House Post Office Committee. Both increases go beyond President Johnson's recommendations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21-- Reyenue freight traffic generated by carloading on United States railroads in intercity truck tonnage in the week ended Sept. 16 were both below the volume in the corresponding 1966 week.

NEW YORK experts should be well to the fore in the International Team Trials that begin tonight in Atlantic City. Alvin Roth and william Root, and Edgar Kaplan teamed with Norman Kay of Philadelphia, will attempt to retain their positions on the international squad.

ROME, Sept. 21--Pope Paul VI is responding well to medical treatment for a urinary infection and no imediate surgery will be needed, his doctors announced today.
CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Sept. 21--Southeast Texas, from Brownsville to San Antonio, slowly turned into a sea of mud and water today as 20 inches of rain fell from the remnants of hurricane Beulah.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)--A bill designed to tighten Government policing of commodity futures markets was approved today by the House Agriculture Committee.
Prices declined in the money and capital markets yesterday as interest rates rose amid concern over the size and terms of the Treasury's next move to borrow billions of dollars.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 21 --In the interests of safety for the horses and the men who were to drive them, the 22d annual Little Brown Jug, scheduled for today at the Delaware County Fair Grounds, was postponed until tomorrow. The 24-your delay in the $84,778,42 event, a segment of the triple crown of pacing, was necessitated by a two-hour
Holders of short positions in world sugar were taken by surprise yesterday, and they ran fast for cover. Their buying raised prices.

FORT WASHINGTON, Pa., Sept. 21--Robert Lincoln McNeil, pharmaceutical manufacturer, founder of the McNeil Laboratories here, and a former president of the American Drug Manufacturers and American Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Associations, died at Chestnut Hill Hospital, Philadelphia, yesterday. His age was 84.
PARAMUS, N.J., Sept. 21-- Mrs. A.S. Hart of Essex County and Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches gained the final of the New Jersey state women's golf championship today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI)--Tim Cullen singled in Ken McMullen from second base with two out in the 11th inning tonight to give the Washington Senators a 4-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles. The loss snapped the Orioles' seven-game winning streak.

CHATTANOOGA, Sept. 21 (AP)--The last jury tampering count pending against the imprisoned head of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, James R. Hoffa, was dismissed today in United States District Court by Judge Frank W. Wilson.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 21--As a soft drizzle fell and a welcoming band played off key, Col. Sanan Yuttasaphrasit stepped down a gangway today and waved to Gen. William C. Westmoreland.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21-- The Presidential election campaign has not only started, but is beginning to influence executive decisions of the most delicate and fundamental nature. The trend is not new-- policy divorced from politics is heresy in Washington--but it is starting early this time and touching the most important issues of the age.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Sept. 22--United States Navy jets bomded two bridges at Haiphong yesterday--one for the first time--in a continuing effort to isolate North Vietnam's main port city. It was the third raid in the city in five days, and the fourth since Sept. 11.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 21--Arthur J. Goldberg, the United States representative, told the United Nations today that the United States considered the exploration and use of the ocean floor comparable in importance to the exploration of space.
ALBANY, Sept. 21--The ninth Constitutional Convention in the state's history opened April 4 amid pledges about nonpartisanship, cooperation and brotherhood.

Murphy Martin, the newscaster, has asked to be released from his contract with the news department of the American Broadcasting Company, and wiil leave the network later this fall. His con tract runs through January, 1969.

AREA A--Few small bluefish being taken along Long Beach Island by surfcasters using mullet and butterfish. There are also some Kingfish and an occasional striped bass. In the Brielle area, bottom fishing booming, with porgies and sea bass going for clams on the wrecks from the Klondike to Seaside. Sizable blues and albacore also responding along the Klondike, only 20 miles east of Manasquan Inlet.

CLINTON, N.Y., Sept. 21 --Mr. and Mrs. Philip V. Rogers of Clinton and Edgartown, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Lane Rogers, to John Bradford Burghardt Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Burghardt of Ridgewood, N.J.
WASHINGTON--On the eve of an extensive foray among our southern neighbors it is comforting to be assured that Washington, despite its preoccupations with Vietnam, has not forgotten Latin America.
Wes Westrum beat the New York Mets to the punch yesterday by resigning as manager.
Two large investment banking concerns announced here yesterday the election of new senior executives.
The discovery of three mummified babies, dead more than 40 years and neatly wrapped in old newspapers in a trunk in a musty basement, remained a bizarre mystery late yesterday.

TRENTON, Sept. 21--State Republicans and Democrats opened their legislative platform conventions here today, and the Republicans promptly broke with United States Senator Clifford P. Case, the party's titular state leader, over what promised to be the major issue in the election campaign.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21-- William G. Phillips, a deputy chairman of the Democratic National Committee, has resigned to join a new firm specializing in public relations, campaign management and opinion polling.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21 (UPI)--The Mexican Davis Cup player, Rafael Osuna, used a smashing service and hard volleys to defeat Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., today, 7-5, 4-6, 6-4, in the third round of the Pacific Southwest tennis championships.
ALTHOUGH the pro football season is young, its tele vision impact will hit hard into homes this Sunday afternoon. The Giants and Jets will both be visible and there is a third game for a warm-up.

The major policy decision of the Constitutional Convention should be presented on the ballot in the form of separate propositions. The Lindsay administration recommended yesterday that all apartment-building owners here be allowed the option of shutting down their incinerators, even though the city estimated it would have to collect 1,100 additional tons of refuse daily.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 21--Neal Shapiro, a member of the United States Equestrian Team, won the open jumper competition at the Eastern States Horse Show today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk, a Georgian who once said he had developed "an elementary liberalism" on racial matters in his youth, was prepared to resign if his daughter's interracial marriage embarrassed the Johnson Administration politically.

WESTPORT, Conn., Sept. 21--Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Miner have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Lee Miner, to Vaughn Everett Clark, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Clark of Fairfield.

Price increases averaging about 7 per cent were posted yesterday for all nickel-bearing grades of stainless steel produced in strip, bar, cold-finished wire and forging billet form by the specialty steel division of the Cyclops Corporation. The rises take effect Oct. 2.
Vincent McDonnell, the chairman of the State Mediation Board, walked into Mayor Lindsay's office in Gracie Mansion at about 2 A.M. last Tuesday and said, "They're interested-they just might buy it."
A two-year labor contract, retroactive to Jan. 1, was signed by the city yesterday afternoon, closing a dispute in which welfare caseworkers halted work twice earlier this year.
HONG KONG, Sept. 21--The Chinese Communist leadership has reinforced the power of the army to deal with the dissension arising from the Cultural Revolution.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 21-- Mrs. Barbara Wilberscheid Bennett, co-director with her husband, Henry G. Bennett, of the Bennett Hearing Aid and Audiometer Center at 175 Main Street, died yesterday of a heart attack. She was 52 years old and lived at Sterling House, Larchmont.

The tentative settlement of the teachers' strike has not disposed of the crucial issues of law the walkout raised. If the community is ever to have enforceable statutory protection against the cutting off of essential public services by illegal strikes, there must be a final court ruling on the validity of the state's new Taylor Law intended to prevent civil service strikes by providing impartial machinery for resolving disputes.
Members of the New York University Medical Center Auxiliary yesterday dedicated the new Auxiliary Pavilion at the center's Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21-- The critics who have warned since last spring that air traffic is outracing the ability to control it are now accusing President Johnson of offering a nonsolution to the problem.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 21--Will success spoil India's drive for increased agricultural production?
Money was easy and demands for business credit were on the low side during the week ended Wednesday, banking statistics published yesterday indicated.

CLIFTON, N.J., Sept. 21-- Bill Collins, a big fellow with a big swing and a light touch on the greens, took a one-stroke lead with a five-under-par 67 as the $150,000 Thunderbird tournament opened today.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21-- Now that Yale's quarterback, Brian Dowling, is sidelined with a broken hand, the Ivy League race takes on a different look from a week ago.
DELRAY BEACH, Fla., Sept. 21--Robert E. Woodruff, retired board chairman of the Erie Railroad, now the ErieLackawanna Railroad, died yesterday at his home here. He was 83 years old.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 21(AP)--Harmon Killebrew and Tony Oliva hit successive home runs in the sixth inning today to help the Minnesota Twins defeat the Kansas City Athletics, 4-0, on Jim Merritt's two-hit pitching.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21-- Father Groppi said today that he had strongly urged President Johnson's riot investigating panel to recommend cutting off all Federal funds to Milwaukee and other cities "which are still promoting segregation" in housing, education and employment.

SYOSSET, L.I., Sept. 21 --Mrs. Stackpole Lord of Syosset and Franklin B. Lord of Chappaqua, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Fordyce Lord, to Alfons M. Leonard, son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Leonard of Decatur, Ill.
This is the story of the Metropolitan Opera's famous turntable that does not turn, and of the red-faced officials who have been going around in circles for more than a year because it doesn't.

TAMWORTH, England--A five-mile stretch of the A-5 highway between Mile Oak and Weeford at Tamworth, Staffordshire, was reopened after a 10 -hour shutdown caused by the crash of a truck carrying radioactive material.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21-- George T. Brown, deputy director of the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Standards and a widely known authority on industrial safety, died of a heart attack early today at his home in Garrett Park, Md., a suburb of Washington. He was 60 years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21-- Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler warned the members of Congress today that they would be playing "political Russian roulette" and risking an election defeat next fall if they refused to vote for a tax increase and if severe inflation followed.
The National Association of Broadcast Employes and Technicians submitted a new set of contract demands yesterday to the National Broadcasting Company and the American Broadcasting Company.
The Rand corporation will join the city administration in "a partnership adventure" in trying to solve long-term city problems, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday.

UPPER MARLBORO, Md., Sept. 21--A juvenile court judge precipitated a major test today of Maryland's laws against illegitimacy by declaring nine children to be neglected solely because their mothers had given birth to more than one illegitimate child.

Amid more charges and countercharges, Schine Enterprises, Inc., and the Realty Equities Corporation said yesterday that they were returning to binding arbitration in their complex $46-million realty dispute.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 20 (AP)--The United States Embassy has received a letter from four defeated South Vietnamese presidential candidates demanding "that the United States Government stop intervening in Vietnamese internal affairs."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 21 (UPI)--Two more American employes of the International Voluntary Services, which conducts a private relief program in Vietnam, quit today in protest against the United States war effort.

Brewster Ives, chairman of the board of the real estate concern of Douglas GibbonsHollyday Ives, Inc., has announced the election of Mrs. John Elliott and Princess Edward J. deLobkowicz as Vice presidents. They are the first women vice presidents in the history of the company and of its predecessors.
The city's approach to developing the waterfront should broaden future planning, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation Herbert B. Halberg said yesterday.

A joint United States-Israeli company will open a $2.5million plant outside Tel Aviv next February to produce Coca-Cola. The plant, now under construction, will have an initial capacity of 75 million bottles a year. Estimated sales in its first year are one-third that volume.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 (UPI) The Los Angeles Rams, playing a fine defensive game, blanked the Minnesota Vikings for three quarters tonight and breezed to a 39-3 victory.

THERE have been stronger and bolder festival en tries than Jerzy Skolimowski's "Le Depart," but none more disarming. LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 22 (AP) The sale to Howard Hughes, the industrialist, of the property on which the Frontier Hotel is located was confirmed yesterday.
Long Island University's decision to negotiate the sale of its Brooklyn Center to the City University was based on advice from Henry T. Heald, former president of the Ford Foundation.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Sept. 23 Au Truong Thanh, the left-wing economist who was jailed yesterday by the National Police, was released this morning after pressure was brought to bear by the American Embassy.
Autumn, "season of mists and mellow fruitfulness" in the words of Keats and more prosaically the work time after summer vacation, begins today at 1:38 P.M.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22 George Romney stood under the ecualyptus trees of Panhandle Park and traded many questions and a few answers with several hundred bemused hippies this afternoon.
AVOCA, Wis., Sept. 22 A plain-spoken young dairy farmer stole the show from Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson's back-tothe-crossroads tour here today.
A 23-year-old man was arrested yesterday and charged with murdering a woman who planned to testify that he had raped and robbed her.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People announced yesterday that it would proceed with plans to set up multiple branches in Philadelphia.
Nationalist China's Ambassador to Washington, Shu-Kai Chow, said yesterday that his country was possibly the only one in the world where the cost of living had declined in the last few years.

MONTREAL, Sept. 22 (AP) Expo 67's attendance was cut in half today by Montreal's two-day-old transit strike and a chilly rain, but the exposition in the St. Lawrence River still broke the attendance mark set by the Brussels World's Fair in 1958.

Dr. V. Raymond Edman, chancellor since 1965 and president from 1941 to 1965 of Wheaton (Ill.) College, a Christian liberal arts college near Chicago, died yesterday of a heart attack while speaking at a chapel service there. He was 67 years old.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., Sept. 22 A white miniature poodle, Ch. Round Table Loramor Yeoman, owned by Mrs. Alden V. Keene of Middletown, Del., today won best-of-breed honors in the Quinnipiac Poodle Club's ninth specialty show on the grounds of the Yale Motor Inn. There were 181 dogs in the fixture.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 22 The president of the Chase Manhattan Bank said today it was wrong to be discouraged at the economic progress of the poor countries and expressed his "profound conviction" that their future could be bright.

JACK SQUICCIARINO, who doesn't have much to smile about, was smiling. At the foot of his bed in New York Veterans Administration Hospital, five women in white uniforms were singing "Happy Birthday" to him.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) The United States and the Philippines signed today two agreements to limit the flow of Philippine exports of cotton textiles to the United States.
DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 22 Best of All carried off the Little Brown Jug and the $42,954 winner's share of a record $84,778 purse today in the second leg of the triple crown of pacing.

BUFFALO, Sept. 22 The engagement of Miss Louise Lord Stevenson to David Gillespie has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Porter Stevenson of Buffalo and Meadowbeach, in Southampton, L.I., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenrick Samson Gillespie of New York and Southampton.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 22--The Boston Red Sox lost their grip on first place in the American League tonight when they were overpowered by the Baltimore Orioles, 10-0, in the opening game of a double-header.

LONDON, Sept. 22--A hospital management board approved tonight the principle that a medical staff should be allowed to choose between which patients it should allow to die and which it should try to resuscitate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UP) Earl Wilson became the first 22-game winner in the major leagues on a seven-hitter and Mickey Lolich pitched a four-hitter tonight as the Detroit Tigers swept a doubleheader from the Washington Senators, 8-3 and 4-0, to move within one game of first place.
The spot rate on the British pound dropped 7 points to $2.7832 in fairly active trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The decline was mainly due to normal weekend considerations.

MOSCOW, Sept. 22 In another step of a swift expansion of the use of natural gas in homes and industry, the Soviet Union, has completed the laying of a 1,300-mile pipeline from the rich fields of central Asia to the Moscow industrial region.
NICOSIA, Cyprus After more than a decade of sporadic violence, Cyprus has grown accustomed to being quietly at war with itself. The island has settled into a somnolent state of siege.

The Edgewater Steel Company, a small producer in Oakmont, Pa., raised prices 2.5 per cent yesterday for rolling, heattreating and machining steel rings.

Jerry Buchek's three-run homer in the bottom of the 10th inning gave the New York Mets an 8-5 victory over the Houston Astros in the second game of a twilight-night double-header at Shea Stadium last night. The victory enabled the Mets to break even after losing, 8-0, to Mike Cuellar and the Astros in the opener.

The First National City Bank has announced that it will guarantee to pay an interest rate of 5 per cent, compounded twice a year, for a period of up to five years on consumer savings certificates, which are a form of time deposit.
Television and radio technicians struck the American Broadcasting Company last night.

DETROIT, Sept. 22 The University of Detroit, led by Jim Bunsey, the quarterback, defeated the Fordham University Club team, 13-6, tonight before 6,100 fans at Titan Stadium. Six interceptions and four fumble recoveries helped Detroit win.

Mayor Lindsay is planning to build a city "war room," lined with charts called issue maps designed to help give him accurate and complete information before he makes major decisions.

CORNWALL, N.Y., Sept. 22 (AP) Lee B. Mailler, former majority leader of the Assembly and chairman of the State Parole Board, died today in Cornwall Hospital. The 69-year-old Republican had been suffering from leukemia.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 22--"Coach, what defense are we going to use? We haven't had much work on that." The query came from an Upsala College football player just before a controlled preseason scrimmage against Montclair State a few seasons back. John Hooper, the Vikings' coach, replied, "Ah, well, you all know the 5-4, we'll start with that."

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 22 (AP) Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, said today that he thought the North Vietnamese would be more willing to bargain with a "new face" in the White House than with President Johnson.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 The "second adventure" is the way the guerrilla operation now under way in Bolivia is described by a man identified as a top Cuban aide of Ernesto Che Guevara.

MONTREAL, Sept. 22 Two operas, born about 250 years apart, made up the English Opera Group's offering in the Maisonneuve Theater last night: Handel's "Acis and Galatea" and Sir William Walton's "The Bear." The double bill was the ensemble's final production at Expo 67.
Trading soared again yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. Prices moved up smartly, too.

Fridel Stoetzner, a Germanborn novelist and short-story writer, died Thursday in Warsaw of a heart attack.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 22 The three annual Rose Balls, aiding the Adoption Service of Westchester, Inc., will be given Oct. 7.

The city's Council Against Poverty has approved the results of an antipoverty election in the South Bronx that attracted a turnout of less than 1 per cent of those eligible to vote. Top staff officials of a city agency that supervised the election had recommended that the election be voided.
MOSCOW, Sept. 22 The United States and the Soviet Union have taken an important step toward agreements to build new embassies in Moscow and Washington.

CLIFTON, N.J., Sept. 22 The biggest scoring jam of the year developed in the $150,000 Thunderbird tournament today as seven golfers tied for the lead. As a cold wind of 20-mile velocity swept the Upper Montclair Country Club Course, an aggregate of 141 proved the lowest 36-hole total.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP) Danny Escobedo, freed in 1964 of a murder conviction by a Supreme Court decision, was held-under $100,000 bond today after he and three other men were seized by Federal agents as members of a narcotics ring.
MOSCOW, Sept. 22 (Reuters) Top Soviet and Polish leaders met for talks here today, the Soviet press agency Tass announced tonight.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 22 (AP) The police indicated today that a woman arrested in connection with the shooting of a Chinese Nationalist intelligence officer might be the so-called "Dragon Lady" who has been gunning down people from the back of a motorcycle.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 22 The leader of the secessionist regime in Nigeria's former Eastern Region has attributed the defeat of his army in the Midwestern State to high-level treachery. He implied that even the army's commander was guilty.

FERNEY-VOLTAIRE, France, Sept. 22 The Investors Overseas Services, a multimillion dollar financial empire put together by a former Philadelphia social worker, officially opened this week on the edge of this French village, the administrative headquarters to which it recently moved from nearby Geneva.
Harrods, Britain's largest department store, will hold a major promotion of Americanmade merchandise for six weeks starting next February, a spokesman for the London store announced here yesterday.

Colette Boky, a Canadian soprano, will make her Metropolitan Opera debut as the Queen of the Night in Mozart's "Die Zauberflote" on Saturday, Oct. 28, at the end of the sixth week of the company's season.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) The Interstate Commerce Commission ordered today at least four simultaneous hearings in connection with its investigation into an increase in freight rates for the nation's railroads.

MURRAY THE K contributed to the redundancy of the new television season last night. Mr. Kaufman's only oversight was a lack of guidance for viewers too weary of eye and ear to embrace either meaning.

ATLANTA, Sept. 22 (UPI) The Georgia Advisory Committee to the United States Civil Rights Commission asked Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman today to defer Federal aid to Georgia's Cooperative Extension Service until the state ends alleged racial discrimination in the farm program.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 The Regents of the University of California ended a seven-month quest for a new president today by dipping into the school's own administative hierarchy and choosing Vice President Charles Johnston Hitch, 57 years old, a former Assistant Secretary of Defense.

Abraham I. Levine, president and founder of the Presto Lock Company of Garfield, N.J., manufacturers of luggage hardware, died Thursday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 1025 Fifth Avenue and in Mendham, N.J.

Reflecting sharply higher sales, the net earnings of the Syntex Corporation registered a substantial increase in the three and 12 months ended July 31 over the corresponding periods a year earlier, it was announced yesterday in Palo Alto Calif.

HONG KONG, Sept. 22--Constant harassment by Maoist Red Guards earlier this year caused Tseng Sheng, Mayor of Canton, to seek refuge by living in a chicken pen in his back yard.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Sept. 22 The ninth Bienal de Sao Paulo was officially inaugurated today by President Artur da Costa a Silva. ALBANY, Sept. 22 A revised formula to give more school aid to the state's larger cities was adopted narrowly today by the Constitutional Convention.

The generally inactive platinum and domestic sugar futures markets showed an unusual amount of life yesterday. Both attracted a substantial amount of buying which pushed prices ahead. In the case of platinum, the interest came mainly from speculators purchasing through brokerage firms, while trade interests dominated the sugar buying.

The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission endorsed yesterday as a guide to public viewing the practice of allowing critics to write reviews of television programs prior to their broadcast.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 The American Civil Liberties Union charged today that recently imposed police restrictions on demonstrations in front of the White House violate rights of assembly and free speech guaranteed by the First Amendment to the Constitution.

Dr. Frederic S. Schleger, a dentist and former president of the New World Club, the governing body of Aufbau, German-language newspaper, died on Thursday while vacationing in Switzerland. He was 68 years old and had an office at 108 East 79th Street and a residence at 185 East 85th Street.
The stock market closed the week with a flourish of strength in late trading yesterday.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 22 Flying Cloud will try to wrap up Roosevelt Raceway's 3-yearold filly trotting championship tomorrow night. The daughter of Florican-Flying Queen, owned by Susan and Joseph Mendelson of Santa Monica, Calif., is expected to be a 6-5 favorite to beat six other fillies in the $35,540 Lady Suffolk Trot. The race honors the memory of the "Old Gray Mare" of the 19th century.

THE Institute of Glass, which was opened Wednesday by the Chrysler Museum in Provincetown, Mass., will be a great source of information for collectors interested in the history and evolution of 19th-century and 20th-century art glass.

DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 22 Lucien Gerdine Henderson, director and former vice president of the Ronald Press Com- pany, New York publishers, died today at Stamford Hospital. His age was 80 and he lived at 44 Goodwives River Road here and Casco, Me.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 22 (Reuters) Indonesia's general election, scheduled for next July 5, will have to be postponed, the Deputy Speaker of Parliament, Maj. Gen. Sajef Thajeb, has announced.
RYE, N.Y., Sept. 22 Mrs. Frances Pratt Hennes was married this afternoon to John Lathrop Gray 3d. The Rev. Joseph P. Bishop performed the ceremony in the Rye Presbyterian Church.
The Cox Broadcasting Corporation is planning to acquire a second film production company to expand its entertainment and communications enterprise.

LONDON, Sept. 22 These are hard times for Harold Wilson and his Labor Government. No one in the Government was pretending otherwise today in the shock of the loss of West Walthamstow in one of two byelections yesterday.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 22 (AP) An F-111 jet fighterbomber developed a malfunction in its afterburner in flight near Nellis Air Force Base today.

About 350 Hunter College High School girls heard a downto-earth discussion of teen-age sex and the use of narcotics yesterday during a performance of a play specially written for young people, "Let's Get Basic."

An elderly woman walked into the Criminal Courts Building at 100 Centre Street yesterday afternoon, tossed a package containing $1,224.02 onto the information desk and said: "Give this to the Mayor." She fled.
The president of the teachers' union said yesterday that teachers would not return to work Monday because the Board of Education was trying to renege on its oral agreement with the union.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) The White House announced today the resignations of the Ambassadors to Algeria, Iraq and the Sudan nations that broke off diplomatic relations with the United States during the Arab-Israeli war.

SEATTLE, Sept. 22 Delegates to the triennial meeting of Episcopal churchwomen turned over today $2,265,917 to the church's presiding bishop, the Right Rev. John E. Hines, to use in helping to alleviate the plight of Negroes in ghetto areas.

Strong, printed in raised letters under the flap on the left side of an envelope, means as much as Porthault towels, DeBusschere shoes and Martin Van Schaak handbags. Anyone who misses the significance obviously hasn't learned to build identity through product use or to climb socially by consumption through association.
The election of Gerald K. Rugger as executive vice president of the Home Life Insurance Company of New York was announced yesterday.

WESTON, Conn., Sept. 22 The engagement of Miss Barbara Mary Mountain to Joseph Charles Ruggiero has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John H. Mountain, parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Ruggiero of Leonia and Seaside Park, N.J.

ABOARD THE QUEEN MARY, off New York, Sept. 22 The Queen Mary, symbol of an era of unparalleled splendor in shipboard travel, sailed from New York today for the last time. She is now pitching slightly in moderate ocean swells on the final leg of her 1,000th and last voyage across the North Atlantic.

College football lets go with a succession of heavy salvos today to sound the opening call to arms for such dreadnought powers as Notre Dame, Alabama, Michigan State, Texas, Georgia and Miami of Florida, as well as Army, Navy, Penn State and Syracuse.

BOSTON, Sept. 22--A California sociologist said today that parents who deceived their children into believing that marijuana was a dangerous drug were responsible for the children's going on to more potent drugs such as heroin.

A race that was once the richest thoroughbred contest in the United States, The Futurity, will have its 78th running today at Aqueduct. Although many races now exceed the Futurity in value, the event still is an attractive one financially.
BOSTON, Sept. 22 Bernard Goldfine, the New England industrialist whose political friendships led to a Congressional investigation, died last night at his home, apparently of a heart attack.
PARAMUS, N.J., Sept. 22 Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches won her sixth New Jersey state women's golf championship today, a title that she captured for the first time in 1924.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) The Defense Department said today that North Vietnamese troops crossed "fairly frequently" between South Vietnam and Cambodia, which professes neutrality in the Vietnam war.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) President Johnson and his daughter Lynda made an unexpected trip tonight to the Marine barracks in southeast Washington to witness the Sunset Parade.

CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 22 (AP) A "human error" was the primary cause of the Mount Washington cog railway derailment, which took the lives of eight persons Sunday, the Public Utilities Commission said today.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Sept. 22 Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Shibe Macfarland have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jill Macfarland, to Jacob Harrison Cooper, son of John Nicholas Cooper of Stamford, Conn., and Mrs. Van Cleve Cooper of Palm Beach.

ADEN, Sept. 22 (Agence France-Presse) The Front for the Liberation of Occupied South Yemen, Cairo-backed nationalist movement, agreed tonight to hold talks with the rival National Liberation Front provided the meetings were under the "personal supervision" of President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic.

Two longshoremen working in the hold of a freighter in Brooklyn were critically injured yesterday when two cylinders of helium ripped apart hurling steel fragments in all directions. Fourteen other longshoremen in the hold of the freighter, the Black Osprey, required treatment at a hospital, but were later released.

FROM the viewpoint not only of partisans, pro and con, but also of anyone interested in the process of modern American politics and the nature of the modern American political personality, Robert F. Kennedy, at the moment Democratic Senator from New York, is easily the most intriguing figure on the current scene.

The arrogance of power was clearly displayed yesterday in the ukase of Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, that the city's strikebound schools will not reopen before the middle of next week at the earliest.

PARIS, Sept. 22 An exhibition of Henry Miller's water-colors and etchings opened at a small Left Bank gallery tonight, but most of the people who crowded in apparently were more interested in seeing the writer than his works.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UPI) Dramatic innovations are needed to upgrade the nation's educational system even to having high school students attend more than one school a day the United States Commissioner of Education, Harold Howe 2d, said today.

Dr. Edson E. Getman, who retired as second vice president and chief medical director of the New York Life Insurance Company last February, died Wednesday in Riverhead Hospital, Riverhead, L.I. He was 65 years old and lived in Old Post Lane Road, Quogue.

THE New York Giants and New York Jets remain on the road for professional football games tomorrow. The Jets are favored by a touchdown, and they should win. The Giants are two-touchdown underdogs and should lose, but then who thought they would win last week?.
DETROIT, Sept. 12 Bargaining between the United Automobile Workers and the struck Ford Motor Company continues at a stalemate, Walter P. Reuther, the union president, said today.

The marriage of Miss Patricia Mahen, daughter of Mrs. Charles E. Mahen of New Orleans and Nashville and the late Mr. Mahen, to Leslie Waller took place here yesterday morning. CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Sept. 22--Texas rivers choked with Hurricane Beulah's rains flooded today for 200 miles along the ravaged southern coast, threatening an area of 400,000 persons.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UPI)--The American Pharmaceutical Association reiterated its support today of a proposal aimed at lowering prescription drug costs and changing the corner drugstore's pricing system.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 President Johnson vigorously defended today the price that the nation is paying to defend South Vietnam, saying this effort mada a greater war and a far heavier price less likely in the years to come.
