Miss Eugenia Lewis Anderson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Ashley Anderson of Stroudsburg, Pa., was married here yesterday afternoon to Howard William Ellis Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ellis of Memphis. The Rev. Joseph Herlihy performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer. There was a reception at the Lotos Club.

A record fleet of 53 yachts is entered in the sixth annual Douglaston Yacht Squadron 27mile distance race around Little Captain Island today. At stake will be the Commodore Douglas Trophy, named for the 1851 America's Cup winner.

ARLINGTON, Tex., Sept. 22 (AP) Mrs. Patrick J. Nugent, President Johnson's younger daughter, wound up a week today at NeimanMarcus's elaborate Greenhouse, where women go to diet and "tone up." Luci slipped into the Greenhouse late Sunday after most other guests had unpacked.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Sept. 22 (AP) Mrs. Owen J. Roberts, widow of the associate justice of the United States Supreme Court, died Tuesday at a nursing home here. The death was not reported until yesterday.

The United States Treasury announced yesterday in Washington that it would borrow $4.5-billion on Oct. 3 by selling tax-anticipation bills and that it would continue to raise $100million of new money each week at the regular Monday auction of three-month bills.
AUCHI, Nigeria, Sept. 19 A symbolic gesture in the northern third of Nigeria's Midwest State these days is the single upraised index finger of the right hand, standing for "one Nigeria."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission ruled today that a broadcaster does not have to provide free time to spokesmen for the cigarette industry to answer antismoking announcements.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 The possibility emerged today of a compromise that would permit Congress to go ahead with prompt consideration of the President's tax increase proposal while still offering assurance that no tax rise would go into effect without major cuts in Government spending.

SALFURRIAS, Tex., Sept. 23 --A house-high crest of water on the Cibola Creek swept into Salfurrias, a south Texas town famous for its butter, between midnight and 3 A.M. today, covering most of the town of 6,515 with five to eight feet of water.

TEL AVIV, Sept. 23--The prospects of an agreement for the merger of three Israeli labor parties have risen as the protracted negotiations reached a decisive phase.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 23-- Efforts by the United States, Belgium, the Vatican, the Organization of African Unity, the International Red Cross and others to evacuate 150 white mercenary soldiers from the Congo appeared to have failed today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI)--The Government is spending $4.8-million to finance a precedent-setting road building team to include psychologists, economists, political scientists and sociologists.
BOLOGNA, Italy, Sept. 23 (AP)--Italy won the world team trap-shooting championship today, outscoring the United States, 732 hits to 719.

Lady Bird Johnson toured the Midwest for four days last week. This was more than a "beautification" tour. Mrs. Johnson was promoting something more complex--a combination of better living, stronger civic will and keener appreciation of the role of government and of the Johnson Administration.
LINDENWOLD, N.J., Sept. 23 Firemen here are expected to approve moving a siren that doctors say is endangering the life of a frail 3-year-old boy. The siren is 500 feet from his home.

A $32-million complex for the production of granular fertilizers and nitrogen fertilizer materials will be built near here in the northeastern North Carolina county of Hertford.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23-- The State Department ex pressed regret today over the newly announced aid agreement between the Soviet Unions and North Vietnam. But officials said they saw nothing alarming in the aid package disclosed by Moscow.

CLIFTON, N.J., Sept. 23-- Bill Collins, who usually spends six hours a day teaching golf, gave some unscheduled putting lessons today. However, Mr. Ison, a retired sawmill operator, owned the houses that Mr. O'Connor had selected.

Several changes in domestic and international operations were announced last week by the Borden Foods Company through its president, Walter R. Olmstead. The changes are a result of the company's plan of restructuring its domestic and international operations.

Once when filling out a security form, Dean Rusk answered. "Yes" to a question whether any member of his family had ever attempted to overthrow the Government. He put down the names of his two grandfathers who had fought on the Confederate side in the Civil War.
A GIRL and a boy stand on an Irish hilltop idly and idiotically planning their futures. At the sides of the stage sit two somber narrators reporting them both quickly dead.
Federal, state and local revenues from distilled spirits increased some $102-million last year, according to the annual report of the Distilled Spirits Institute.

ELKINS, W. Va.--The roads leading to this town go through lustrous countryside, with mountains to awe the most jaded sightseer, lakes and streams to make a fisherman sob in sweet anguish, waterfalls that can be heard before they are seen and ravines deep enough to smother an echo.

Mrs. Aileen Brenon Harrity, a former music critic and movie publicity woman, died yesterday in the Neurological Institute, Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. She was 72 years old and lived at Hyde Park, N.Y., and also at 15 Park Avenue and Campobello Island, N.B. Her husband, Richard Harrity, is an author and playwright.
Antipoverty officials are facing mounting protests from poor neighborhoods over the death of summer programs and a 90 per cent reduction of jobs in the Neighborhood Youth Corps.
CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP)-- Harry Nye of Chicago, taking all three of his races, won the Richardson Trophy Regatta, representing the Great Lakes yachting championship, today.

MORGANTOWN, W.Va., Sept. 23 (AP)--Tom Digon guided West Virginia to an early lead today as the unbeaten Mountaineers rolled to their third victory of the football season with a 21-9 Southern Conference decision over Virginia Military Institute.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 23 --Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Wheeler Dewart have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elinore Irwin Dewert, to David Sterling Killebrew, son of Sterling Earl Killebrew of New Canaan and the late Mrs. Killebrew.

NEW DELHI. "YOU are introducing a bull into a china shop," an unhappy supporter of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi complained to one of the Congress party politicians who had forced "the lady," as the lady is often called with overtones of affronted male pride, to take Morarji Desai into her Cabinet as Deputy Prime Minister.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Sept. 23--Lawrenceville School pushed over two touchdowns in the fourth quarter, but the rally fell short as Penn Charter won 15-13, today. It was the season opener for both elevens.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23--The engagement of Miss Fern Evelyn Bendall to Alfred Johnson Elbrick has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. David Bendall. Mr. Elbrick is the son of C. Burke Elbrick, Ambassador to Yugoslavia, and Mrs. Elbrick of Washington and Gilbertsville, N.Y.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 23 --Ecumenical Patriarch Athenagoras, leader of the Eastern Orthodox Church, has postponed indefinitely his visit to the Soviet Union and other East European countries, where he had planned to meet with other Orthodox churchmen.
ROME, Sept. 23--Years of borrowing to meet deficits have left Rome with an accumulated debt whose interest payment alone absorbs over four-fifths of the city's annual tax re venue.

HOLLYWOOD. IN television programing the continuing axiom has been to let a hit series go virtually unchanged for its average life expectancy of five years; in the sixth year a show's producer and its network, to save a tired format, busily begin to bring in a new character or two, a new location, a dramatic plot twist, or, if all else fails, a new show--based, of course, on the old theme.
SWANTON, Vt., Sept. 23-- The soft green hills now beginning to flame with autumn foliage and the neat, quiet villages with towering elms make an unlikely setting for a constitutionality battle.

New York's Secretary of State, John P. Lomenzo, declared yesterday he thought it would be unconstitutional and politically immoral to ask the people to vote on the proposed new State Constitution as a single package.

DALLAS, Sept. 23--It will be Fran Tarkenton against the Wolves in the Cotton Bowl tomorrow. The Wolves, wearing silver pants and a helmet with a single star upon it, have names: Willie Townes, Jethro Pugh, Bob Lilly and George Andrie.
All power corrupts--but Communist power corrupts more completely.

Unless a purchaser comes forth soon, Utah will be without a brewery by the year's end, for the first time since pioneer days. The General Brewing Corporation of San Francisco, which has manufactured Fisher Beer and Lucky Lager in Salt Lake's sole surviving brewery for the last decade, has announced it will shut off the valves and seek a purchaser for the plant on Salt Lake's west side.
at Sea, Sept. 23 (AP)--Two stowaways have been found aboard the Queen Mary, now on her last Atlantic crossing.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 23--The engagement of Miss Carol Alexandra Kriloff to Colin Ross Bradfield has been announced by Comdr. Herbert Kriloff, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Kriloff of Port Washington and Old Chatham, N.Y., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. Robin B. Charlton of Brisbane, Australia,and the late Colin A. Bradfield.

NARRAGANSETT, R.I.--Mergers and acquisitions, currently a major preoccupation of businessmen, may seem agreeably remote from this tranquil, thinly populated little community on the shore of Rhode Island Sound.
Deputy Mayor Timothy W. Costello warned yesterday that any attempt to solve racial frictions by concentrating solely on "riot control" would fail.

"When I'm calling you-oooooo-ooo, ooo-ooo-ooo . . ." THIS song ("Indian Love Call") and other love duets by Jeanette MacDonald and Nelson Eddy are, in a roundabout way, responsible for some of the most imaginative theatrical sets being designed in Manhattan these days.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23-- Despite bipartisan sponsorship, election reform legislation has encountered a potentially deadly crossfire from snipers in the House Administration Committee.
Television and radio announcers, newsmen and performers began saying away from their jobs at the American Broadcasting Company yesterday in support of a strike by engineers and technicians.
LEVERKUSEN, Germany, Sept. 23 (AP)--The New Zealand women's field hockey team defeated the United States, 3-0, in the world tournament today.
A Consolidated Edison mechanic was killed and another was injured yesterday morning by an explosion and fire in an electrical panel box at the Sherman Creek substation, 415 West 201st Street.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 23 (AP)--Frank Titas, a sophomore, kicked a 27-yard field goal with 18 seconds to play today, to give Michigan a 10-7 victory over Duke before 79,492 fans.

DEVOTEES of the short fiction of Nathanael West will be captivated by the recent manner of William Melvin Kelley. They have waited 30 years for a bitter fabulist entirely worthy of the West tradition. Now, in Kelley's latest novel, they may savor something of the gift for satire, the corrosive style and the surreal grotesqueries that we associate with the author of "Miss Lonelyhearts."
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 23--American International College upset the University of Vermont, 37-25, today at A.I.C. Park.

Off the old whaling coast at Gloucester, Mass., scientists have put their most versatile workhorse, the atom, on shipboard and harnessed it for service to the fishing industry in preservation of the catch.

Tom Seaver, the rookie righthanded pitcher, who has proved in his first season to be the most effective hurler in the short history of the New York Mets, turned in one of his most effective performances last night as New York beat the Houston Astros, 1-0, at chilly Shea Stadium.
MOSPORT PARK, Ont., Sept. 23--"If Mark is happy, let's take off his tail and give it to George."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23-- The United States was accused today in a study by the staff of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee of neglect of the political development of LatinAmerican countries by emphasizing social and economic progress.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 23--Tolstoy probably did not have the New York Mets in mind when he wrote that all happy households seem happy in the same way, while all unhappy households seem unhappy in their many separate ways. But the description fits the Mets splendidly.

KENNEWICK, Wash., Sept. 23 (AP)--The Washington Public Power Supply System announced today that it was prepared to join with the Pacific Northwest Power Company in building the controversial High Mountain Sheep Dam on the Snake River.
So far as Israel is concerned, the 22d session of the United Nations General Assembly represents the third stage of its current war with the Arabs.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Sept. 23 --The engagement of Janice Patricia Havens to Chilton Barry Greer has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Hershman Havens. Mr. Greer is the son of Mrs. Chilton Dewey Greer of Houston and the late Mr. Greer.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 23--Matt Coney's Nine Seas beat Dr. Al Field's Songbird for Lightning Class honors today as 63 boats sailed with the Knickerbocker Yacht Club in the Cow Bay Area, Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association competition.
COLUMBIA, S.C. Sept, 23 (UPI)--South Carolina rallied for two quick touchdowns in the third period tonight and hung on for a 16-10 victory over its Atlantic Coast Conference rival, North Carolina.

STOCKTON, Calif., Sept. 23 (UPI)--Jim Curtice, the son of the coach of the University of California at Santa Barbara, scored the deciding touchdown today on a 15-yard run to give the Gauchos an upset 24-20 victory over the University of Pacific Tigers.

Tentative settlement of New York's longest teacher walkout finally came last Wednesday, ten days after the schools should have opened. But after verbal agreement, the United Federation of Teachers questioned the terms as understood by the Board of Education and Mayor Lindsay and the final contract remained in doubt yesterday.

ONE of the first principles of criticism, I take it, is that the critic should not quarrel with the writer's subject. That is entirely his affair. The reviewer's, surely, is to discuss what the writer does with it. All the same, I can't help entering a caveat against the central situation of "Debris." I believe it hinders what is in many ways an admirable novel.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 23--A pint-sized outfielder named Tom Shopay, who expected to be hip-deep in physical education classes at Suffolk University in Boston by now, threw a king-sized complication in the American League pennant race this morning.
DENVER, Sept. 23-- The mining industry is concerned about its image.
Last Monday at an impressive ceremony, Governor Rockefeller, Cardinal Spellman and many other notables gathered at East 71st Street and York Avenue to lay a cornerstone that was really a milestone.

LIDO BEACH; L.I., Sept. 23 --Mr. and Mrs. Samuel J. Zucker have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Phyllis Ellen Zucker, to Richard Neil Granat, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Granat of Cedarhurst.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 23--One significant fact in Ambassador Arthur Goldberg's latest Vietnam peace proposal before the United Nations is that he was still around to make it. His intention had been to resign before this session of the General Assembly started. His decision to stay on is evidence of his confidence in the good faith of the peace terms his Government has approved.

SAIGON--In teeming Asia, who alone can halt the march of the Communist Chinese Red Guards, silence the choirs chanting strophes from Mao Tsetung's little Red Book, and wring an apology from Chinese Premier Chou En-lai? Prince Norodom Sihanouk hereditary ruler, chief of state, spiritual director and armed forces commander in chief of the little kingdom of Cambodia, that's who.

MADRID, Sept. 23--The Moroccan Foreign Minister, Ahmed Laraki, arrived here today on a 24-hour visit that is expected to lead soon to a formal agreement for the cession by Spain to Morocco of the enclave of Ifni.
SEATTLE, Sept. 23--One of the most controversial issues to confront administrators of the Seattle public schools apparently is going the way of the proponents.

A benchmark of the 1967 stock mark has been a sizzling atmosphere for new issues the stocks that are offered when a corporation leaves the palm of privacy for the first time and becomes publicly owned.

The first of the nine million persons who eventually will buy 1968 cars already have received an unpleasant, but not unexpected surprise. Prices are up. General Motors Corporation and Ford Motor Company raised prices about 4 per cent on their 1968 models, or an average of $115. Chrysler Corporation increased prices over 1967 close to 5 per cent, or $133 by the company's own figures.

FORT LEE, N.J., Sept. 23-- The engagement of Miss Judith Ellen Leibert to Norman S. Solomon has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jack Leibert. Mr. Solomon is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph K. Solomon of Cleveland.

A CLUSTER of former townhouses now occupied by offices on Madison Avenue, a new housing complex in Greenwich Village and a bank headquarters on East 42d Street are among 38 Manhattan architectural jewels being highlighted by the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects.
The extraordinary growth that European economies have experienced since 1950 will come to an end because of a pronounced decline in labor force expansion, the Chase Manhattan Bank said last week.

Harold Oldak's Pilot Class sloop Windborne III from the Knickerbocker Yacht Club won the Commodore Douglas Trophy as the over-all winner of the Douglaston Yacht Squadron's annual Little Captain's Island distance race yesterday on Long Island Sound.

A TWO-DAY course for horticultural judges and exhibitors will be conducted by The Garden Club of New Jersey on Oct. 3d and 5th. Classes will be held at Rutgers University, New Brunswick. Instructors include Dr. Benjamin Blackburn, Louis Politi, Donald Lacey and Malcolm R. Harrison. Box lunches will be available if applicants specify when making arrangements. Registration forms may be obtained from Mrs. Frank Fedowitz, 1625 Martine Avenue, Scotch Plains, N.J. 07076.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 23. (AP) --Phil Hagen's brilliant passing swept Minnesota 88 yards in the final three minutes for a 13-12 intersectional football victory over Utah today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 23 --A 23-page booklet on psychedelic drugs written by 12 Princeton University upperclassmen has been distributed to Princeton's 3,200 undergraduates in an effort to acquaint students with the legal, social and medical aspects of drug use.

EARLY Irish art provides designs for the first regular-issue Eire stamps in 20 years. It is art that may not be familiar to those unacquainted with its distinct character. The new definitives will be issued early in 1968.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 23 --Melvin Greene scored his second touchdown on a pass from Harold Granderson with 42 seconds left in the first half to snap a 7-7 tie and Montclair High went on to defeat Paterson Eastside at Woodman Field today, 13-7.
The West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company is considering converting a portion of the forest properties it owns to uses other than timber production to capitalize on the growing value of the lands.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23-- Miss Lois Helen Alterman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Jay Alterman of Sherman Oaks, was married this evening to Butler Wright Lampson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Tudor Lampson of Washington. IOWA CITY, Sept. 23 (AP)-- Ed Podolak led underdog Iowa to a convincing 24-9 victory over Texas Christian University today in an intersectional football opener for both teams.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 23-- Representative Richard L. Ottinger has criticized the Hudson River Valley Commission for failing to take a stronger stand against a garbage dump and proposed expressway along, the river above Yonkers.

SOMERS POINT, N.J., Sept. 23 (AP)--The City Council of this South Jersey resort believes that a city official should be penalized if he fails to attend city meetings.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 23-- In a madly exciting fourth quarter that had the 20,101 onlookers hysterical with suspense as the lead switched again and again, Navy snatched victory from Penn State today with a touchdown pass 57 seconds before the end.

Charles W. Morton, journalist, essayist, humorist and one of the best-known editors of The Atlantic Monthly for a quarter of a century, died of a heart attack yesterday in Lon don. He was 68 years old.
The Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest will celebrate its 100th anniversary with a ball on Oct. 27 in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza.
The man on whom millions of American merchant seamen have depended for more than 20 years for a touch of home in foreign ports, Otho J. Hicks, is leaving the shipping scene.

ART, they used to say, mirrors life, and I kept repeating that to myself at the U.S. Pavilion in Expo 67 while looking at the enormous paintings hanging in that equally enormous structure. But are they paintings, or sociology, or social commentary, those works by Jim Dine, Andy Warhol and the others? Certainly the brush work is not very accomplished (brush work? or electric paint sprayers?), the compositions not very interesting, the draftsmanship distinctly minorleague.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 23 (AP)--Kim Hammond passed inspired Florida State to a 37-37 tie with second-ranked Alabama tonight and ended the Tide's winning streak at 17-- a string begun at F.S.U.'s expense in 1965.

THE ninth annual Grand Prix of the United States, a 248-mile, 108-lap race for Formula One cars counting toward the world championship for drivers, will be run next Sunday afternoon at Watkins Glen, N.Y. A field of 20 of the world's foremost road circuit drivers will face the starter.

LA PAZ, Bolivia--The next act of the Bolivian guerrilla drama, which has already produced enough material for a dozen spy thrillers, begins in the fly-specked oil town of Camiri next week when a pale, bookish French intellectual named Jules Regis Debray goes on trial for murder.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. de Maar of Vereeniging, South Africa, formerly of Pittsburgh, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Ann de Maar, to Jan P.C. de Bruin, son of Mr, and Mrs. Nicholas de Bruin of Amsterdam, the Netherlands.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept 23--Miss Doreen Slater Mortola, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward J. Mortola of New Rochelle, was married this afternoon to Michael Allen LeMoult son of Mr. and Mrs. Adolph LeMoult of Port Chester.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23--A London clothing designer named Clive plans to have his models show his latest line at 10 A.M. Oct. 4 in Piccadilly, at 4 P.M. the same day aboard an airplane bound for America, and at 8 o'clock that evening aboard the Queen Elizabeth at its 57th Street pier in Manhattan.
ATHENS, Sept. 23--The military Government stepped up its purge of "disloyal" state employes this week and dismissed 370 policemen and 74 teachers.

RALPH HATTERSLEY puts the photographer on a couch and tells him off in a lengthy analysis, "Games Photograghers Play," in "Photography Annual 1968" (New York: ZiffDavis. 208 pp. $1.50). Most photographers are unconscious of their motivations in taking pictures, this photographer-teacher-writer believes, and are therefore unaware that much of their photographic activity actually is an attempt to hoodwink people.

TEL AVIV, Sept. 23 (AP)-- An Israeli spokesman said tonight that Arab gunmen had opened fire on two Israeli border patrol jeeps in the west-bank town of Nabtus. In the ensuing gunfight, he said, one Arab was killed and another captured.

TRUMBULL, Conn., Sept. 23 --Stamford Catholic ran its unbeaten streak over a three-year period to 23 games today when it romped to a 60-0 victory over Trumbull. It was the second triumph of the season for the winners while the home team has yet to win in two starts.

ATLANTA, Sept. 23--Peter Libassi, director of the Office of Civil Rights in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, believes that the rate of school desegregation in the South, after doubling in each of the last two years, advanced more slowly this fall.

A bill was filed in Congress Sept. 14 by all of Indiana's Senators and Representatives to authorize the United States Government to acquire the magnificent collection of gold coins assembled by the late Josiah K. Lilly of Indianapolis.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 23-- Miss Helene Elsbeth Henning, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Henning of Syosset, was married here at noon today in St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church to Edward F. Cavanagh, 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cavanagh Jr. of Glen Cove.

A minor fire forced the evacuation of 300 passengers from a New York Central train in the Bronx yesterday afternoon as it was proceeding from White Plains to Grand Central--Terminal.

MONTREAL, Sept. 23 (AP)-- About 5,400 Canadian Great Lakes seamen are voting this weekend on a proposed settlement of their 37-day strike. Minister of Labor John R. Nicholson said some ships could be sailing again by Monday.
NEW MILFORD, N.J., Sept. 23--Dale Faust scored three touchdowns today as New Milford High School walloped Rutherford, the defending Bergen County Scholastic League champion, 40-0.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 23--The cereal harvest in the European Common Market set a record this summer and exceeded last year's by 13 per cent. The yield, including rice, of 66.6 million tons was 5.5 million tons more than the previous Common Market record reached in 1965.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP)--The nation's first system designed to intercept missile-carried nuclear bombs will consist of 15 to 20 antimissile complexes throughout the United States.

SARK, Channel Islands--Just a dot on most maps; the last feudal tenure in Europe is an island about three and one-half miles long and one and one-half miles wide. Within these Lilliputian confines is a world apart, a land of pristine beauty without industries, automobiles, airports or taxes.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 23--Mr. and Mrs. Russ Van Vleck Bradley have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Josephine Colwell Bradley, to Jonathan James Bush, son of Mr. and Mrs. Prescott Bush of Greenwich. Mr. Bush is the former Senator from Connecticut.

MANHASSET, L.I., Sept. 23 --Mrs. Cynthia Gummins Hall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rowan Cummins, was married here this morning to William Henry Gish 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gish Jr. of Westport, Conn. CHAOUEN, Morocco--This town, although tucked away in a crevice of the Rif Mountains of northern Morocco, ranks as one of the most attractive places in all of this splendidly scenic country. Chaouen is only 75 miles from the resort center of Tangier, from which it is a two-hour ride over an uncrowded highway, but the drive itself is worth the venture.

Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that there could be direct violence between Negroes and whites next year or the year after if slum problems were not effectively dealt with.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 24 Supported with seven runs in the first two innings, Dean Chance was able "to relax and save myself" in his 20th victory as the Minnesota Twins retained their half-game lead over Boston today in the American League pennant race.
ALBANY, Sept. 24 A divided Constitutional Convention com mittee moved tonight toward recommending that the proposed new basic charter be submitted to the voters on Nov. 7 as a single package.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24 (UPI) Johnny Unitas topped the 30,000-yard mark in passing today, netting 267 yards as the Baltimore Colts routed the Philadelphia Eagles, 38-6.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24 (UPI)--Jim Bakken set two National Football League records today by making seven of nine field-goal attempts and Pat Fischer led a powerful defense as the St. Louis Cardinals beat...

"Liquidity" was a chief item of business social business as 10,000 bankers assembled here yesterday for the 93d annual convention of the American Bankers Association, which gets into full swing today.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 24 The Boston Red Sox put it up to Jim Lonborg today, and the symphony-loving, history-reading biologist with the hard fastball pitched the Red Sox back into second place as the American League pennant race turned into its final, tumultuous week.

DETROIT, Sept. 24 (UPI) Tommy Watkins of the Detroit Lions scored two touchdowns his first in three years as the Lions rallied in the second half for a 31-14 National Football League victory over the Cleveland Browns.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 (AP) Rick Wise pitched a three hitter today as the Philadelphia Phils defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 3-1.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 The Americans for Democratic Action today endorsed work stoppages by the American Federation of Teachers in New York and Detroit.
Britain's current political picture is about as confusing as the American scene little more than a year from a Presidential election.
Madison Square Garden, which owes some of its patrons $100,000 to $200,000 because of double billing for season tickets, has been sued for 60 cents by an irate hockey fan.

ALBANY, Sept. 24 The Assembly parlor in the Capitol, normally the smoke-filled scene of party strategy meeting by delegates to the Constitutional Convention, became a place of worship over the weekend.

SAN DIEGO, Sept. 24 (UPI) John Hadl hit Lance Alworth on a 44-yard fourthquarter touchdown pass that led the San Diego Chargers to a 13-3 American Football League triumph today over the Houston Oilers.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., Sept. 24 One necessary ingredient was missing from Emile Griffith's victory party after he fought Nino Benvenuti last April. It was victory. The handsome Italian had just upset Griffith to win the middleweight championship of the world. Hence the postfight celebration that Emile's camp followers had so confidently planned came up empty.

WAY back in 1948 George Balanchine prepared a "Pas de Trois" from the Petipa-Minkus ballet "Paquita." Mounted for the De Cuevas Ballet and danced originally by Rosella Hightower, Marjorie Tallchief and Andr Eglevsky, it caused some stir, a stir repeated when it was given, also with Mr. Eglevsky, by the New York City Ballet three years later.

ROCKLEDGE, Fla., Sept. 24 (AP) A young newspaper reporter, an amateur skydiver whose wife died exactly five weeks earlier in a parachuting accident, plunged 2,500 feet to his death today at the same airport.

MADRID, Sept. 24--A Roman Catholic priest in the Basque Province of Vizcaya has been fined the equivalent of $625 by the government for preaching a sermon last Sunday critical of fines applied earlier to three other priests.

The New York City League of Women Voters is circulating a four-page "Voters Facts" handbook, available in either Spanish or English, that stresses the importance of the 1967 election and the need for registering to vote.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 24 Harry T. Danker of 214 Marsh Place, president of Danker Danker, Inc., a real-estate and insurance company in Westfield, died Friday at his home. His age was 56.

ORADELL, N.J., Sept. 24 St. Cecilia of Englewood halted Bergen Catholic's 19-game winning streak today when Joe Gismo scored from the 1-yard line in the fourth quarter for a 7-0 victory. The victory was the first for Cecilia over its arch-rival in four years.
General Mills, Inc., achieved record earnings in the 13 weeks ended Aug. 27 despite a decline in sales, the Minneapolis-based company reported over the weekend.

FEW people are happier at the thought that the Bos ton Red Sox may end up in the World Series this year than Archbishop Iakovos, the tall, gray-bearded Greek Orthodox Primate of North and South America.
EL PASO, Sept. 24 The natural gas industry is spending many millions of dollars more these days in an effort to keep customers' rates steady.

Mrs. Agnes McEvoy Laurino, treasurer and a director of Scholastic Magazines, Inc., died Saturday at the Medical Arts Center here. She was 65 years old and lived at 2252 Linwood Avenue in Fort Lee, N.J.
Shades of the 1900's were revived yesterday as Herandis, a Murray-Peterson designed clipper-bowed schooner owned by Henry C. Hock, won the Douglaston Yacht Squadron's third annual windjammer's race.
An Episcopal clergyman charged yesterday that leaders of his church had "deliberately managed the news" to assure the success of merger talks with other Protestant denominations.
New or increased taxes adopted by state legislatures so far this year will increase tax collections by almost $2.5-billion annually, a record rise, the Tax Foundation, Inc., estimated yesterday.

BERLIN, Sept. 24 The governing Social Democrats of West Berlin moved today to urge the West Germans to accept the postwar boundaries of Germany, including Poland's border along the Oder and Neisse Rivers.

Earl G. Talbott, who ended a 44-year career as a newspaperman as a rewriteman for The New York Herald Tribune, died Saturday of cancer in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived at 34 Gramercy Park East.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (UPI) Twenty-one persons 11 of them white were arrested tonight as the police clamped a 9 o'clock curfew on the western suburb of Maywood to prevent a third straight night of violence in a Negro neighborhood.

The pending retirement of Gottlieb Hammer from the presidency of the American Israeli Shipping Co., Inc., North American representatives of Zim Lines of Haifa, Israel, has been announced by the company.

TEL AVIV, Sept. 24 (AP) David Ben-Gurion and his prot g , Defense Minister Moshe Dayan, differed tonight at a political meeting when the 81year-old former Premier tried to block a merger of his Rafi party with the ruling Mapai party.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 24 Miss Anne Rauh Scherck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Joseph Scherck Jr., was married today to Alan Butler Morrison, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joshua Morrison of Larchmont, N.Y.
A four-hour effort to settle the two-week-old teachers' walkout ended early this morning with reports that some progress had been made.
Vulcan Materials Company of Birmingham announced over the weekend an agreement to acquire Dolese Shepard Company, Chicago, in an exchange of shares.

ST. MARY'S, Pa., Sept. 24 Miss Meryl Hope Berman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Berman, was married here today to Robert Allen Guzinsky of Pittsburgh. The ceremony was performed in the St. Mary's Country Club by Rabbi Kurt Metzer of Temple Beth-El of Bradford.
The leader of Greek Orthodoxy in the Americas has called for the replacing of Greek ideas that have dominated Christian theology for centuries on the ground that they "no longer speak to modern man."

Four days after Ben Milberg was elected president of L'Aiglon Apparel, Inc., the old-established dress producer ended its fiscal year in June with a reversal from a loss to a gain, almost dollar for dollar.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 24 The militant Buddhists of Thich Tri Quang cast their lot today with the defeated politicians and disgruntled students protesting the conduct of the Sept. 3 elections.

"A flood of complaints" about abuse and threats to teachers and other school personnel in a largely Negro and Puerto Rican district in Brooklyn will be submitted to the City Commission on Human Rights this week.
The assignment of its liners Sagafjord and Bergensfjord to three long summer cruises from here next July and August has been announced by the Norwegian America Line.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 24 Dr. Harbeck Halsted, an obstetrician and gynecologist and a former clinical professor at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, died in his sleep today in his home at 14 Mill Hill Lane. His office was at 47 East 63d Street in New York.

BELGRADE, Sept. 24 A de cision by the United States to downgrade its participation in the annual congress of the International Astronautics Federation opening here tomorrow has bewildered many delegates and embarrassed both the American embassy and the Yugoslav scientists serving as hosts to the gathering.
The head of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association charged yesterday that minority groups in the city were receiving special privileges and often were not being prosecuted for law-breaking.

Matinicus Rock, an unusually bleak little island off the Maine coast near Rockland, has been named a national bird sanctuary to protect a breeding area for two colonies of penguin-like sea birds and a special petrel species of little Mother Carey's chicks.

NEW DELHI--In the mountain jungles of South Assam, sealed off from the outside world by inaccessible terrain and Government restrictions, hillmen clamoring for an independent state or autonomy within the Indian Union are fighting Indian troops.

WASHINGTON With all the ease of a waiter on a train, Donald Stetson Davis carried his tray of wine and cheese across the afterdeck of his gently rolling, 48-foot yacht, The Zephyrus, which is also his home and real estate office.
The capital market, which has seen interest rates drift upward this month, will continue to face a heavy supply of new bond issues for sale this week.

According to Newsweek magazine, New York State Republican leaders have decided privately to support Governor Rockefeller as a favorite son candidate for the Presidential nomination at next year's national convention.

VEGETABLES at every meal are as inevitable as the falling leaves of autumn, and they can be as varied in color, shape and presentation. Many vegetables are at their peak of perfection during the early fall, and a new combination, a different method of preparation or varying the seasoning can do wonders. Below are several suggestions to take the monotony out of vegetables.

IF the good Lord had wanted man to fly he would have given him wings, and if James Augustine Aloysius Joyce had wished to write an autobiographical play, he would not have written it as an autobiographical novel.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 24 A Texan pair held a narrow lead at the end of this afternoon's play in the International Team Trials here, and many New York stars were in danger of failing to qualify for the final stage beginning Wednesday.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 24 Mrs. Mary Chapin Krech, who devoted much of her time to reducing the maternal mortality rate in this country, died yesterday at the age of 71 in her home, Briar Patch. She was the widow of Dr. Shepard Krech.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 24 There are people around who have fond memories of their underprivileged youth when television, discoth que, happening and be-in weren't even words.

LAWRENCE TOWNSHIP, N.J., Sept. 24 (AP) Maj. Gen. Donald W. McGowan, former chief of the National Guard Bureau in Washington, was found dead in his home today of apparently self-inflicted gunshot wounds.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24-- The Johnson Administration, which only last week announced a decision to provide some defense of the continent against missile attack, is seriously considering a total revamping of its defense against enemy bombers.

Marvin Gordon's Ballet Concepts, founded three years ago, has broadened its range to include ethnic, modern and avant-garde trifles to complement the ballet puffery that is currently the mainstay of the company. As a choreographer, Mr. Gordon is guilty of skimming off the froth and throwing away the soup.

The city's public schools are starting their third week of strike-engendered disruption this morning, even though Mayor Lindsay insists that the terms of the agreement reached last week between the Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers are "very clear."
A prominent Roman Catholic priest and sociologist charged yesterday that the parochial schools, especially those in Manhattan and the Bronx, were not educating enough Negroes and Puerto Ricans.

WASHINGTON, Sept 24 The national board of the Americans for Democratic Action voted a sweeping antiAdministration program today that opposed both Mr. Johnson's war policy in Vietnam and his proposal for a 10 per cent surcharge on income taxes.
MIAMI, Sept. 24 (AP) Len Dawson and Mike Garrett led Kansas City to an easy 24-0 victory over outmanned Miami today.

A lawyer who helped negotiate the $2-million deal last July when the American Broadcasting Company bought the movie "Mutiny on the Bounty" from Metro Goldwyn Mayer threaded the epic into a video tape machine last night and flipped a button to put it on the air.
CHATHAM, Mass., Sept. 24 (UPI)--A 64-year-old Chicago man was found today in the 38-foot yawl in which he had been adrift on the Atlantic for 10 weeks.

The Rockettes continued to picket Radio City Music Hall yesterday as the longest-running act in show business (35 years) went into the 10th day of a strike. There was no indication when an impasse in negotiations for a new contract might be broken.
The Maritime Administration has authorized American President Lines to charter two of its Mariner-type vessels to the Military Sea Transportation Service from 12 to 24 months.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Sept. 25 United States B-52 bombers blanketed a mile-long strip just inside the northern boundary of the demilitarized zone this morning with thousand-pound bombs, hitting at rocket, artillery and mortar positions.
The president of the American Bankers Association predicted yesterday that the economy would turn upward in 1968 and that interest rates, including bank lending rates, would rise also.

TORONTO, Sept. 24 The name of Louis Riel may mean little outside Canada, but as a fascinating and complex figure in this country's history, he turns up appropriately as the protagonist of a music drama created for this centennial year.

A 13-year-old boy is to appear in court this morning on charges of having taken part in the beating of a 79-year-old lawyer. He is also accused of having taken part in an assault on two women near Bryant Park.

SEATTLE, Sept. 24--The nation's 3.5 million Episcopalians will be given an opportunity beginning Nov. 1 to try out a new liturgy for holy communion that seeks to "speak in modern language to the modern world."

BONSALL, Calif., Sept. 24 (UPI)--Sandra Haynie of Fort Worth won the $11,500 Mickey Wright invitation golf tournament at the San Luis Rey course today when she defeated Kathy Whitworth of Jal, N.M., in a sudden-death playoff.

PORTSMOUTH, Va., Sept. 24 (AP) Miss Minnie Mangum, the spinster whose million-dollar embezzlements ruined a Norfolk savings and loan association 12 years ago, died today in a hospital. She was 71 years old.

John Harllee, chairman of the Federal Maritime Commission, has explicitly disavowed charges that the agency was seeking to introduce utility-type rate regulation in the nation's foreign ocean commerce.

GOSHEN, Conn., Sept. 24 Shalfleet Starlight of Foxden, a 3-year-old gray brindle and white greyhound owned by Mr. and Mrs. James A. Farrell Jr. of Darien, captured her third best-in-show award at the 22d annual Northwestern Connecticut dog show and obedience trials today on the Goshen Agricultural Fairgrounds. There were 1,051 dogs entered.

Melina Mercouri, the actress who was deprived of her Greek citizenship for her opposition to the ruling military regime, yesterday announced the formation of a committee to oppose the junta "outlaws."

The American Institute of Certified Public Accountants has drafted a statement urging conglomerated companies to give stockholders more financial information but not enough detail to give competitors an undue advantage.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 The Washington Senators scored three runs in the ninth inning today for a 5-4 victory and dealt the Detroit Tigers a possibly mortal wound in the race for the American League pennant.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Arthur J. Goldberg, Chief United States delegate to the United Nations, said today that he did not regard as final the Soviet Union's rejection of the latest American inquiry on place in Vietnam.

The New York City Opera's colorful production of Rossini's "Barber of Seville" was shown for the first time this season at the New York State Theater on Saturday night. The high-style peerformance was full of fun from start to finish.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 24--The flow of aid from the rich to the poor countries showed almost no increase last year for the sixth consecutive year and the per capita economic growth of the poor countries remained less than 2 per cent a year, the World Bank reported today.

CLINTON, N.J., Sept. 24 Msgr. Michael J. Mulligan, who was the subject of a book, "The Making of a Priest," written in 1950 by Jim Bishop, died here today in his family's home. His age was 89.

Miss Judith Ann Schiffer and Richard Brooks were married yesterday afternoon in the Baroque Suite of the Plaza. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jacques M. Schiffer of Rockville Centre, L.I. PARIS, Sept. 24 Communists appeared likely to increase their number of representatives in France's General Councils, or regional assemblies, as a result of local elections today.
PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 24 (AP) Surveyor 5 was shut down today for the two-weeklong lunar night after televising 18,006 pictures more than the combined output of two previous Surveyor spacecraft.

The press corps arrived early in the 19th floor dining room of Kenyon Eckhardt in the Pan Am Building. On the table were dainty Danish, orange and tomato juice and coffee. There were top agency people there, too, and everyone sipped, nibbled and talked.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 24 Iranians, preparing to celebrate the coronation of their ruler, have learned that the nation has fresh cause for joy: Oil production, which pays much of the bill to overhaul Iranian society, is heading for a record this year.

An agreement was signed earlier this month between Robert E. Simon Jr., developer of the new town of Reston, Va., and the Gulf Oil Corporation, creating Gulf-Reston, Inc. On that day, this country's most closely watched new community changed from one man's dream to a corporate subsidiary.

ONE gets used to things so quickly. All the same, how astonishing it is that in 1967 the daughter of Stalin should be alive and in this country! How astonishing, in part because we do not think of people like her as really existing. Stalin's daughter? No, not real; a nearly forgotten factor in history's imagination.
DURBAN, South Africa, Sept. 24 (Reuters) Fifty Yugoslav seamen, some severely burned, were taken aboard a Dutch freighter today after a night in lifeboats in heavy seas off the South African coast.
TRENTON, Sept. 24 A.J. Foyt moved from 23d place to the lead in a spectacular 158mile run and won the United States Auto Club's 200-mile championship race today.
HONG KONG, Monday, Sept. 25--Mao Tse-tung has taken a tour from Peking through central and eastern China in what appears to be a major effort toward consolidating the Cultural Revolution.

HONG KONG, Sept. 24 (AP) Sir David Trench, the Governor of Hong Kong, returned today from home leave in Britain. He said he would be far too busy working to worry about attempts on his life by Communist terrorists.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 Gov. Ronald Reagan of California and Gov. George Romney of Michigan met today over a luncheon of cold salmon and mixed vegetables, then told reporters that they had purposely skirted political matters.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 24 (AP) Five commercial banks in the United States and one in the Netherlands have agreed to provide $375,000 as part of a $40-million loan agreement signed Saturday between Brazil and the World Bank.
The appointment of Rabbi Walter S. Wurzburger as spiritual leader of Congregation Shaaray Tefila of Far Rockaway, Queens, was announced yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 24 The Home Office has ordered the burning of birches and cat-o'nine-tails and the destruction of all related equipment by Oct. 1. A new criminal justice act, barring any form of corporal punishment, goes into effect then.

The barker's spiel is taperecorded. The advance man travels by private plane. The help watches television in house trailers after work. The "snake charmer" spouts fluent herpetology. Some chorus girls have had to quit for the new college year.

IPSWICH, Mass., Sept. 24 Miss Jenny Leeds Reed was married here this afternoon to Michael Anthony Slote. The bride's parents are Mrs. Stephen Vernon of Hamilton and Walter Reed of New York. Mr. Slote is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Slote of New York and Pound Ridge, N.Y.

ROME, Sept. 24 Pope Paul VI, looking well although speaking with a slight tremor, appealed anew today for peace but said that recent events showed that it could not be achieved without the help of God.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the weep ended yesterday:
Mack Trucks, Inc., announced yesterday in Allentown, Pa., the election of Roger W. Mullin Jr. as executive vice president for administration.
A new, tougher definition of an amateur golfer including a lower acceptable prize value was announced yesterday by the United States Golfers Association.

HARLINGEN, Tex., Sept. 25 (UPI)--The Rio Grande, bloated with the rains of hurricane Beulah, smashed diversion dams today, flooding this south Texas city, and rolled on toward its mouth at the Gulf of Mexico.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 25 (AP) Navy Strut broke last in a field of nine 3-year-olds today, but at the end of six furlongs he was three lengths in front of Laurel Mark in the Harvey Purse before 9,773 fans at Atlantic City Race Course.

The colors of Capt. Harry F. Gugeenheim's Cain Hoy Stable made another visit to the winner's circle after the main race at Aqueduct yesterday. That stable's excellent 3-year-old filly, Too Bald, was an easy winner of the 1 1-16-mile turf event, scoring by 6 lengths over Who Called, with Cassino Vail next. Last Saturday, Cain Hoy won the rich and important Futurity with Captain's Gig.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 The House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly today to give back to the District of Columbia a portion of the local suffrage it took away in 1874.
Alcoholics are seven times as likely as nonalcoholics to be the victims of fatal accidents, according to a survey published yesterday.
The Council of the African-American Institute has expressed "dissatisfaction and disappointment" with the fourhour documentary on Africa the American Broadcasting Company televised on Sept. 10.
The American Stock Exchange rolled along in high gear again yesterday.

The director of a district board of education that is experimentally operating eight schools in a predominantly Negro and Puerto Rican area in Brooklyn charged yesterday that the Council of Supervisory Associations was "out to sabotage this program."
A New York financial trust agreed yesterday to buy Grosset Dunlap, one of the nation's oldest and largest paperback reprint houses, for $46million in cash.

BENIN, Nigeria, Sept. 24 Nigeria's civil war has washed over this small, drab city and flowed on, but the bitter divisions that brought federal and Eastern soldiers here in the first place have not died away.

The Hooker Chemical Corporation reported yesterday lower earnings for the three and nine months ended Aug. 31 and also announced plans to acquire the Udylite Corporation, Warren, Mich., a machinery and chemicals manufacturer.
CAMIRI, Bolivia, Sept. 25 The military trial of Regis Debray, a young French philosopher accused of guerrilla activities in the Bolivian interior, begins tomorrow in this dusty frontier town.

NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 25 The engagement of Miss Cathie Gail Layman to William Maurice Leete Jr. has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Layman. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leete of Williamstown, Mass.

HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 25 Mrs. F.B. Washburn and Mrs. Robert R. Livingston are co-chairmen of the tour of homes in the Germantown and Clermont areas on Saturday. Mrs. Edward E. Ekert and Mrs. Aldo Francescott are assisting them.
Bruno Sammartino wrestled to a draw with Hans Mortier of Germany last night before 9,351 fans at Madison Square Garden. Mortier was billed as the German champion.

HOUSTON, Sept. 25 (AP) Joe Morgan doubled home the tying run with two out in the ninth inning tonight and then scored on Jim Wynn's single, giving the Houston Astros a 4-3 victory over the Philadelphia Phils.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Sept. 26--United States planes have dropped 250,000 out-of-date propaganda leaflets on a North Vietnamese village in what an American source described as a "monumental foul-up."

Marlene Dietrich, who during the last 10 years has circled the world singing her deepthroated brooding ballads, will appear on a New York stage for the first time on Oct. 9. ALBANY, Tuesday, Sept. 26 A Constitutional Convention committee, acting on the final crucial question of the nearly six-month-old meeting, voted last night to submit their proposed state constitution to the voters in a one-lump package instead of in separate segments.
AN elegant sinous chaise and a chair that looks like chocolate pudding represents two extremes in the Museum of Modern Art's additions to its permanent collection of objects.

A movement to name Governor Rockefeller New York's "favorite son" candidate for President at next year's Republican convention has gained wide support, with the Governor himself acquiescing, according to well-placed political sources.
ALGIERS, Sept. 25--The Congo and Algeria have agreed to resume diplomatic relations, it was reported here today.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 25 Jesse H. Lide., who retired in 1957 as a vice president of McCann-Erickson, Inc., New York advertising agency, died yesterday in Greenwich Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 300 North Street.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 House Democrats refused today to agree to transfer the Job Corps unit of the antipoverty program to the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

SEATTLE, Sept. 25 The Right Rev. James A. Pike, Resigned Bishop of California, dramatically challenged the House of Bishops of the Episcopal Church late today to put him on trial on charges of heresy.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 A 39-year-old theologian has been appointed acting rector of the Catholic University of America.

KINGMAN, Ariz., Sept. 25 (AP) The Rolls-Royce of George Hamilton, a former escort of Miss Johnson, was found in Kingman today by the police. Four mink coats belonging to Miss Johnson were in it, the police said.
BOSTON, Sept. 25--A New York psychiatrist described marijuana today as a "harmful and dangerous substance" that should be prohibited as a "hazard to public health."

WESTFIELD, Mass., Sept. 25 Dr. and Mrs. Oscar Rodin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Ann Rodin, to Arthur Stephen Fromer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin A. Fromer of Great Neck, L.I.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept 25 (AP) Crewmen of a freighter from Cyprus, which was laid over in Haiphong harbor for 36 days this summer, have told Allied officials that an acute labor shortage in Haiphong had resulted in lengthy delays in unloading ships and that the city's residents were short of food and were hungry.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla.,Sept. 25(UPI) Sunny Florida grabbed its second winter professional football plum from California today with the announcement that the American Football League would hold its All-Star game here Jan. 21.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 Richard B. Walbert, a vice president and director of Blyth Co. Inc., the investment banking concern, was elected president of the National Association of Securities Dealers today.

"The People rest" said Felix G. Restaino, an assistant district attorney, yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court, completing his case.

OTTAWA, Sept. 25 Parliament reconvened today with 25 "essential" bills before it and with most members preoccupied with a 26th question the future relationship of Quebec Province to the Federal Government.

HONG KONG, Sept. 25 Information reaching Hong Kong indicates that the Peking regime has made progress in reducing the violence and political squabbling that have been widespread in many cities of Communist China in recent months.

REMEMBER that Lake Charles, La., refinery fire last Aug.8 that claimed several lives? It also rated as a catastrophe, in terms of casualty insurance losses as reported yesterday by the insurance Information Institute.
RAPID CITY. S.D., Sept. 25 (AP)--The wife in a divorce proceeding and her attorney were shot to death and the presiding judge was seriously wounded today at the Pennington County Courthouse here.
Interest rates continued to climb yesterday as the money and capital markets headed into a nine-day period of heavy activity.

An attempt to protect 800 square miles of open spaces in New York State and New Jersey from "indiscriminate urban sprawl" was announced yesterday by its supporters and immediately endorsed by Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall.

When they explain the rising costs of television commercial production, agency men mention the increased use of color and higher union minimums. But mostly they point to the extra money now needed to create a more sophisticated commercial that will break through the viewer's everthickening shell.

A retrospective showing of all of Rouben Mamoulian's films will be held at the Gallery of Modern Art in Columbus Circle from Oct. 10 through Oct. 29. The tribute to the stage and screen director coincides with the 40th anniversary of the opening of his first Broadway play, "Porgy."

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25 California Republicans have forcefully projected Gov. Ronald Reagan into the Presidential campaign just as a poll has disclosed that his popularity with California voters has declined.
WASHINGTON. Sept. 25 (AP) Corporate profits fell slightly in the April-June period for the third consecutive quarter, revised figures published by the Commerce Department showed today.

LONDON, Sept. 25 Prime Minister Wilson told the British people tonight that it was "going to be a hard winter" for the economy. But he predicted that the Labor Government's "tough policies" were leading toward a "much more hopeful era."

Radio City Music Hall again will present an all musical stage program to accompany "The Bobo," the film comedy starring Peter Sellers, which opens Thursday. A 30-minute musical program was substituted for the regular stage show when the Rockettes, ballet dancers and singers went on strike on Sept. 16.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 25 (AP) Judge John R. Schwartz, who retired as a Dutchess County Court judge two years ago, died today in Vassar Hospital. He was 72 years old.

The Detroit Tigers gave more evidence last night that they had become the first of the four American League pennant contenders to falter seriously. They lost to the New York Yankees, 2-0, and slipped more firmly into fourth place.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 Sol. M. Linowitz, United States representative at the Organization of American States, said today that the Hemisphere nations had reached "virtual unanimity" on the nature of Cuban Communist subversion and how to deal with it.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 25 Edgar Kaplan of New York and Norman Kay of Philadelphia moved into the lead in today's play in the international team trials at the Traymore Hotel here, and several other New York experts improved their positions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) A sharp drop in August imports gave the United States its best trade surplus in 17 months, the Commerce Department reported today. Imports declined 5.4 per cent from July to a seasonally adjusted August total of $2,114,800,000, the lowest since August, 1966, the department said.

As the Constitutional Convention struggles toward its close it must be acknowledged that it has effected minor improvements in many articles and substantial improvements in some. But it has failed to accomplish some badly needed reforms and has taken at least one highly retrogressive step repeal of the ban on state aid to denominational schools.

BELGRADE, Sept. 25--The Soviet Union, which has in the past been cool to suggestions for international collaboration on space projects, hinted today that such collaboration would be necessary for the major projects of the future.
BONN, Sept. 25 The West German authorities are perplexed about what to do with a group of 46 Asians, camping since last Friday in the no man's land of the West GermanCzechoslovak border near F rth.

NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 25 John E. Sutton, a leading local sports figure, collapsed and died yesterday afternoon white playing golf at the Shorehaven Golf Club, of which he was president. His age was 49 and lived on Pine Hill Road here.

The Board of Education made public yesterday a report in the long controversy over improving th racial balance in Queens high schools. The consultants who prepared the report said they preferred two of four different plans.

A NEW genre of war book has appeared in recent years, the book that reconstructs, with actual dialogue and such fiction techniques as flashbacks, major battles of World War II, such as Cornelius Ryan's "The Longest Day" and "The Last Battle" and John Toland's '"The Last Hundred Days." Now we have "The Fall of Japan" by William Craig.

Hurricane Beulah has presented the nation's insurers with a bill of $36-million for damage to fixed property in Texas thus far. This preliminary estimate of insured property losses, which does not include damages to automobiles and boats, was reported yesterday by the American Insurance Association.
HONG KONG, Sept. 25 (Reuters) Communist China today ordered the expulsion of two top Indonesian diplomats and accused Jakarta of trying to force a break in relations between the two countries.
DACCA, East Pakistan, Sept. 25 (Reuters) About 150 people were believed to have drowned in the sinking of a launch near Faridpur in the Ganges Delta south of here Friday night.
DETROIT, Sept. 25 The General Motors Corporation said today it would not change its executive line-up at its board meeting next Monday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 Gov. Raymond P. Shafer of Pennsylvania began efforts today to resolve a trucking dispute that is hampering the nation's steel production.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 25 (AP) Jim Nash is the third Kansas City Athletics' pitcher to say he wants to be traded.

Mrs. Elizabeth Lambert Schrafft of 50 Sutton Place South and Gordon MacRae, the singer and actor, were married here yesterday afternoon in St. Peter's Lutheran Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Ralph Peterson, the pastor.

New Yorkers and their suburban cousins donned topcoats, changed to fall suits and dresses, disconnected their airconditioners and started up their furnaces yesterday as temperatures dropped into the low 50's and 40's around the metropolitan area.
BONN, Sept. 25 Membership in West Germany's extreme right-wing National Democratic party has been dwindling steadily in recent months, the interior Ministry reported today.

Charles F. Krauss, managing editor of Mart Magazine, a monthly magazine for the home appliance and electronics trade, published by the Buttenheim Publishing Corporation, 757 Third Avenue, died Saturday of a heart attack on a plane near Albuquerque on which he was returning from California. He was 43 years old and lived at 162 West 13th Street.

TRENTON, Sept. 25 The New Jersey Supreme Court nullified the death sentences of two convicted murderers today because the judge at their trial improperly told the jury that it could not impose life imprisonment without hope of parole.
William H. Houghton was elected president yesterday of Professional and Technical Programs, Inc., the technical book club subsidiary of Crowell Collier and Macmillan, Inc., publishers.

BELPRE, Ohio, Sept. 25 (UPI) A Sunday school teacher, described as a quiet and religious woman, was arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation today on charges of embezzling nearly a halfmillion dollars.

If good taste, good musicianship and good intentions were all that counted, Antonia Lavanne's Town Hall recital last night would score high. The Israeli-born soprano chose a particularly appealing program of songs by Haydn, Liszt, Mahler and Bartok, and offered them in a clear, pleasing voice whose best feature was a few flutey headtones.

AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 25 Texas oil production was trimmed 109,071 barrels more a day, effective Oct. 1, when the Texas Railroad Commission today found demand falling as the Middle East oil crisis eases.

The Reader's Digest Association took the initiative in setting up an agreement to sell Loomis-Sayles Mutual Fund, Inc., shares in West Germany, Maurice T. Freeman, president of the Boston-based fund declared yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 25 An informed source said today that Maj. Gen. Nguyen Duc Thang, South Vietnam's vigorous young Minister of Construction and Development would attempt to revitalize the armed forces while retaining control of rural pacification efforts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 Lower rates for many longdistance telephone calls but higher rates for some shortdistance calls that cross state boundaries were proposed to the Government today by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

Received presentation of credentials by the new Ambassadors of Greece and Malawi; met with U.S. Advisory Commission on International Educational and Cultural Affairs; issued proclamation designating Nov. 11 as Veterans Day; sent to Congress the annual report of the St. Lawrence Seaway Development Corporation.
CHICAGO, Sept. 25 Sir William Haley, longtime editor of The Times of London, has been named editor in chief of the Encyclopaedia Britannica.

MONTREAL, Sept. 25 (AP) Most of the 5,400 seamen who have been on strike since Aug. 17 have agreed to return to work immediately pending a formal vote on a new contract offer, the Seafarers' International Union announced today.

A first novel about a 16year-old girl who experiments with mod styles, pot-smoking and men has brought to its 33year-old author guarantees totaling at least $100,000 in advance of publication. Patricia Welles, the novelist, said recently that the bonanza was completely unexpected.
TETERBORO, N.J., Sept. 25 Carey Transportation, Inc., opened an experimental bus service today between Teterboro Airport and Manhattan. But passengers were few and far between.

A well-known California clothing manufacturer in a full-page advertisement in The New York Times today asks President Johnson not to seek renomination in hopes that a successor could end the war in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25--A bipartisan group of 52 House members proposed today that Congress re-examine the Administration's policies in Vietnam in order to determine if there was sufficient authorization for the deepening American involvement in the war.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 Politicians find it hard to believe Governor Rockefeller's statement that he has lost his appetite for the Presidency. This was to be anticipated of the politicians. It is their nature to believe not only that public utterances are contrived to be misleading, but also that everybody wants to be President.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Sept. 25 (AP)--New York State's economic development program has resulted in more than 5,000 new plants and plant expansions since 1959, State Com merce Commissioner Ronald B. Peterson said today.
Hunt Foods and Industries, Inc., announced yesterday the resignation of Raymond A. Rich as chairman of Knox Glass, Inc., a subsidiary.
NEWARK, Sept. 25--Twenty-seven persons indicted for crimes during the July race riots here went on trial today in four unexpectedly quiet Essex County courtrooms.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 The International Union of Electrical Workers removed today two New York area officials from their elected posts on charges of financial abuses.
Boys' apparel producers opened their spring 1968 lines this week with the spotlight on fashion.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept 25 George F. Kerrigan of San Rafael, Calif., and Ray Palmer of Lincoln Park, Mich., were tied with 74's today after the first round of qualifying play in the United States Golf Association's senior amateur championship at the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP)--As Illinois's potential favorite son, Senator Charles H. Percy says he will go to extraordinary lengths to keep from becoming an active participant in the preconvention campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1968.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 Treasury bill rates rose to their highest levels since last winter at today's auction. Today's issue of 91-day bills sold at discounts averaging 4.629 per cent, compared to 4.490 per cent on the issue sold last Monday. This was the highest rate since the issue sold on Jan. 23, 1967.

Despite a union dispute that tied up about 90 per cent of steel shipments by truck last week, production dropped by only 1.2 per cent from that of the previous week.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25 (AP) Gene Alley's single in the 11th inning scored a pinch-runner, Manny Mota, and gave the Pittsburgh Pirates a 2-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight.

Edward N. Wendell, a retired engineer, who served the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation from 1925 to 1955, died Sunday of cancer in New England Baptist Hospital in Boston. He was 64 years old and lived at Boca Raton, Fla., and in Rockport, Mass.

Plans to provide hundreds of jobs for Negroes and Puerto Ricans on the site of the old Brooklyn Navy Yard should get a major push forward tomorrow when the city tries to complete negotiations to buy the yard from the Federal Government.

Herbert Adler, a 49-year old certified public accountant and management adviser, has been elected president of Bobbie Brooks, Inc., the second largest company in the women's apparel industry.

Prices eased yesterday on the London stock exchange. Brokers said investors showed concern over the prospect of higher interest rates.

Scandinavian Airlines' first all-cargo jet has flown more than 6,000 tons of freight across the North Atlantic since entering service a year ago, it was announced yesterday.

The election of Lawrence L. Carter as a vice president of the Irving Trust Company was announced here yesterday.

The "light" antimissile system recently authorized by the Administration might save the lives of five million to ten million Americans, Secretary ef Defense Robert S. McNamara said in an interview published this week in Life magazine.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 25 Mrs. Florence Chilton Wheeler, wife of Walter H. Wheeler Jr., chairman of the board of Pitney-Bowes, Inc., meter and stamping machine manufacturer, died today at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. She was 73 years old. Her home was Bishop Meadows, near Sound View Avenue.

IT'S a witches' brew that the American League concocted for its pennant race this year and the pot is bubbling toil and trouble as it comes to a full boil this week. These are the final days of a season that ends on Sunday or will it? The four contenders have been performing so tantalizingly of recent weeks that the possibility of a playoff extension grows ever more likely.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25 Gov. George Romney discovered today that the discontent that touched off the first major race riots two summers ago was still burning in the grimy streets of Watts.
LINDENWOLD, N.J., Sept. 25 The 80 members of the Lindenwold Volunteer Fireman's Association approved tonight the relocation of a siren that was said to endanger the life of a 3-year-old boy.

Fifteen steamship lines said yesterday that the Federal Maritime Commission's hearing counsel had failed to prove that eastbound ocean freight rates between Britain and the United States were higher than westbound tariffs. The lines serve the westbound route.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25 The New York Mets opened their final road trip of the season by bowing to the Giants, 2-1, in 10 innings today despite no-hit pitching by Danny Frisella, a rookie, through the first six innings.
PARIS, Sept. 25 The Communists, for the first time in French history, have won control of a General Council, or regional assembly.

The Asian-Development Bank announced yesterday that Kuhn, Loeb Co. and the First Boston Corporation had been appointed managing underwriters in the United States for dollar bond issues that may be offered here.
ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Sept. 25 (Reuters) Guinea and the Ivory Coast released today groups of each other's nationals. The prisoners' detention had led to a bitter conflict between the two countries.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) The Commerce Department said today American businessmen were expected to exceed the goal set for this year in the voluntary program to stem the flow of dollars overseas. Secretary of Commerce Alexander B. Trowbridge said revised projections by 625 companies in the program suggest an over-all improvement this year of $2.4-billion, compared with the original $2-billion goal.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Sept. 25 (AP) An excitable lineman and a misread clock contributed to Houston's 37-7 rout of Michigan State last Saturday, Coach Duffy Daugherty of the Spartans said today.

THE furrier doth protest too much. Jacques Kaplan, the art collector, motorcyclist, graduate student in psychology and major-domo of the fur salon that bears his father's name (Georges Kaplan) at 730 Fifth Avenue, introduced his fall collection yesterday by proclaiming "The NeoTender Look."
SAN DIEGO, Sept. 25 (UPI) Bill Schumacher of Seattle piloted Miss Bardahl to victory in the fourth running of the San Diego Cup unlimited hydroplane race yesterday on Mission Bay.

MOSCOW, Sept. 25 Business initiative outside the planned economy won resounding approval from the Soviet Government today.
FRAMINGHAM, Mass., Sept., 25 (UPI) Eighteen players were named today, to an American international hockey squad that will play nine exhibition games in Europe from Oct.1 to 15.
LONDON, Sept. 25--After months of negotiation, Britain, France and West Germany will sign an agreement tomorrow for the joint construction of a 300-passenger subsonic airliner.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 25 Robert Hall, star of "The Green Hornet" radio program from 1944 to 1947 and in recent years host of the C.B.S. Radio "Music 'Til Dawn" show, died of cancer today at New Rochelle Hospital. He was 42 years old and lived at 34 Normandie Lane.

The New York City Council has begun consideration of a bill that has the same aim as one that has been shot at and wounded in the United States Congress: How to control the easy traffic in deadly weapons.
Directors of the Ex-Cell-O Corporation proposed yesterday a two-for-one stock split of the company's common shares, to be followed by an increased quarterly dividend on the current stock.

Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands, already wearing rows of decorations on his lapel and the orange and blue medal of Order of Wilhelms around his neck, received the gold medal of the Holland Society of New York at the society's annual dinner last night at the Biltmore Hotel.
BERLIN, Sept. 25 (UPI) East Germany rejected today a new West Berlin plan for improving relations and urged West Berlin to cut its ties with West Germany.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 25 (AP) Duke Maronic, coach and general manager of the Harrisburg Capitols, said today he was resigning from the Atlantic Coast Football League team.

PARIS, Sept. 25 (AP) Frankie Narvaez of New York outpointed Nigeria's Ray Adigun in a 10-round lightweight bout at the Palais des Sports tonight.

The Broadway theater bus service, which carried 13,544 passengers last season, will resume Oct. 9 and continue until the end of the year. Columbia Records is again subsidizing the service, with a guarantee of any deficit up to $15,000. The service lost $7,500 in its first run, which ended June 24.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 The National Transportation Safety Board today blamed the pilot, an air traffic controller and the jumpers themselves for the deaths of 16 sky divers in Lake Erie last month.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 25 "I have no idea who won in our village," said Tran Van Moi, "but I think it was Dzu. We had nothing to do with the voting process and no control over it."
Prices for a number of spring lines of footwear will be marked up 3 to 4 per cent.

Channel 13 (WNDT) began last night a week-long celebration of its fifth year as the city's educational station. The "Birthday" festival, which runs from 8 to 10 o'clock each night, is also part of the station's fundraising campaign, with volunteers receiving telephone contributions.

TEANECK, N.J., Sept. 25 Mr. and Mrs. Julian Ernest Silverberg have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Ruth Silverberg, to Robert Howard Sunshine, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Sunshine of Roslyn. L.I.

Teledyne, Inc., is making a tender offer for 2.5 million shares of United Insurance Company of America at $35 a share, the West Coast manufacturer of electronic and aviation control systems announced yesterday. The stock would total $87.5-million.

Dr. G. Milton Shy, professor of neurology and chairman of the department of neurology of the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, died yesterday, apparently of a coronary attack, at the Neurological Institute of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.
