Charles Edison, the former Governor of New Jersey and Secretary of the Navy, has privately published a book that discloses that he once was a Greenwich Village poet who wrote under the name Tom Sleeper.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 The decisive events in the Presidential election of 1968 took place away back at the end of September of 1967. At that time the criticism of President Johnson on the Vietnam war took a vicious turn leading to unforeseen consequences.

EMANUEL UNGARO, the French designer who has been called a master of "tough chic," arrived in New York yesterday on his first visit and promptly announced that his clothes were not all that tough--but rather "nouveau romantic."
The cathedrallike room resounded with the chatter of 300 students as Ravi Shankar, the Indian sitar player, entered.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 Radiologists described today a combination method for detecting the early stages of breast cancer, which they say can reduce the death toll from the disease.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 Representative Joseph R. Resnick charged today that farmer cooperatives had issued to their members $4-billion to $6-billion in "worthless certificates" instead of issuing cash from profits.
At 4:35 yesterday afternoon, a chartered Eastern Electra touched down at Kennedy with a load of top creative-agency people fresh from the wonders of Expo 67.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 The United States chided Israel today for her announced plans to send settlers into territories seized from the Arabs during the war in June.

Theodore W. Kheel, chief mediator in the protracted newspaper contract negotiations, announced last night that a sixth union, Stereotypers Local 1, and the publishers had reached agreement on a threeyear contract.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI) The first manned Apollo space shot scheduled for the early part of next year may be delayed until mid-summer, the nation's space agency said tonight.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 26 A spokesman for the Israeli delegation here was questioned yesterday about reports that Nahal, the armysponsored youth organization, planned to establish settlements in territory captured by Israel in her war with the Arabs in June.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 Richard M. Nixon said today that the nation's "judicial and legal system" must share in the blame for the "shocking crime and disorder" in the cities. He implied that the Supreme Court was included in his charge.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26--Yields on the new monthly issues of nine-month and one year Treasury bills rose to their highest levels in several months at today's auction, the Treasury announced tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI) --The United States Court of Military Appeals upheld today the court-martial conviction of three Army privates who refused to go to Vietnam.

ROME, Sept. 26 Pope Paul VI celebrated his 70th birthday today without fanfare. He devoted his time to reading, answering hundreds of congratulatory messages, preparing for the forthcoming Synod of Bishops and resting. He is still recovering from an infection of the urinary tract.

ATHENS, Sept. 26 (UPI) Greece's Interior Minister, Brig. Stylianos Patakos, who once forbade miniskirts as immoral, sat in the front row at a miniskirt contest today when 20 girls paraded before a large crowd at an open-air cafe.

ALBANY, Sept. 26 The philosophical disagreements, the rivalries and the bitterness of the 167 Constitutional Convention seemed forgotten tonight when the delegates gathered for one last time to praise and be praised.

Familiar music by Bach, Mozart and and Chopin on the program of David Bean, pianist, who played at Carnegie Hall last night, acted as excellent garnish for the real substance of the evening: Two formidably difficult, rarely heard works.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 26 The menu that Secretary General Thant chose for his dinner for the foreign ministers of the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union was typically American but the wines were French.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 26 (AP) Milt Woodard, president of the American Football League, announced tonight that Cincinnati had been awarded an A.F.L. franchise beginning in 1968 and that the franchise went to Paul Brown and his associates.
James W. Davant, managing partner of Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis, was renominated yesterday for a one-year term as chairman of the board of governors of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms.
LONDON, Sept. 26 Walter Neurath, the art book publisher who brought scholarly, well-illustrated books within reach of a wide public, died today at the age of 63.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 Walston Co., Inc., a New York Stock Exchange member concern, was found today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to have "willfully violated" the antifraud provisions of the Securities Act in connection with the sale of some California development district bonds.
A public offering of 1 million shares of United States Plywood-Champion Papers, Inc., common stock was made yesterday at $50.50 a share.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 26 James M. Walton today was named president of Carnegie Institute and Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh, effective Jan. 1, 1968. He will succeed James M. Bovard, president for 20 years, who plans to retire.

A half-century ago The Times editorialized: "The movement represented by the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City is of broader import than its immediate important purpose, that of raising $2 million by annual subscrip tions to meet the needs of the Jewish philanthropic institutions of the city. It is an organized step to put giving for charity on a true ethical basis."
ABOARD THE QUEEN MARY, at Sea, Sept. 26 (Reuters) The second of the Queen Mary's two trans-Atlantic stowaways became a passenger today when friends paid his fare.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 26 With most of last year's offensive backs in the graduate ranks, and retarded in its development by a succession of injuries to top personnel, Princeton approaches its opening football game against Rutgers here Saturday, with some degree of apprehension.

Miss Patricia Bertrand, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Bertrand of Brussels, and Don Belth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Caro Belth of 15 West 81st Street, plan to be married on Sunday at the Belth home.

ADEN, Sept. 26 (Reuters) Political tension dropped sharply here today following agreement by two rival nationalist groups to end their warfare and hold talks on South Arabia, due to become independent in January.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 26 The Pennsylvania Supreme Court ruled today that the state's Human Relations Commission has the authority to order a school district to end de facto segregation of public schools.
New York lottery tickets went on sale at Aqueduct for the first time yesterday, and hard-pressed horseplayers greeted their arrival with shouts of "Here's the dollar window!"

BEDFORD, N.Y., Sept. 26 The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Willis Hargate have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Miriam Jane Hargate, to Richard Jeffrey McMonagle, son of Judge George Joseph McMonagle of the Common Pleas Court of Cuyahoga County, Ohio, and Mrs. McMonagle of Shaker Heights, Ohio.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 House Republicans scored another victory tonight in their running battle to give states a major share of control over Federal-aid funds.

Fourteen members of the Action Committee on American-Arab Relations picketed yesterday near the Israeli consulate and mission to the United Nations, at 11 East 70th Street. They were protesting "Zionist atrocities against Arabs" in territory occupied by Israel after the brief war in June.

HONG KONG, Sept. 26 Fresh evidence of the drastic damage done to the economy of Communist China by its internal turmoil was provided by figures on its August trade with Hong Kong, made public here today.

National Educational Television has acquired the broadcast rights to "Olympiad," Leni Riefenstahl's film classic about the 1936 Olympic Games in Berlin. The educational network plans to televise the film before the opening of the summer Olympics in Mexico City next year.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Sept. 26 (AP) An attorney for a 26year-old man sentenced to 90 years in prison for a series of breaks into Alexandria homes and businesses said today that he planned to ask the Virgina Supreme Court of Appeals to overturn the sentence.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 26 The final qualifying ses sion of the International Team Trials began at the Traymore Hotel here tonight with six pairs battling for four places in the final stages.

HERRICKS, L.I., Sept. 26 Cazzie Russell's 2-pointer for the New York Knicks tied the score at the end of regulation time and set the stage for the Knicks to gain a 117-107 overtime National Basketball Association exhibition game victory over the Chicago Bulls at Herricks High School tonight.

VIENNA, Sept. 26--Dr. Sigvard Ecklund, Director General of the International Atomic Energy Agency, asserted today that the agency could provide all the inspection that would be needed under the proposed treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons.
CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (AP) Randy Hundley's single with two out in the ninth inning scored Al Spangler and gave the Chicago Cubs an 8-7 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals today.

Louis E. Wolfson, the Florida industrialist, took the witness stand in Federal court here yesterday in his own defense and testified that he had little knowledge of the Securities Act of 1933, which the Government contends he violated.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Sept. 26 Oscar T. Straub of the East Orange Golf Club took a twostroke lead in the opening round of the 46th annual New Jersey Golf Association seniors championship today at the Baltusrol Golf Club.

The manuscript of "I'm Just Wild About Harry," the 1921 hit that became the official song of Harry S. Truman's victorious Presidential campaign in 1948, was presented here yesterday to the Truman Memorial Library in Independence, Mo.

The premiere of an exhibition by the Burr Artists, a group of painters and sculptors, will be held Sunday at the Thomson Gallery, 19 East 75th Street, to benefit the Blue Curtain Youth Foundation. The exhibition will be open to the public through Oct. 14, daily except Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI)--A spokesman for the Chase Manhattan Bank contended today that proposals to keep the New Haven Railroad operable through a loan or lease arrangement would be ineffective unless the Penn-Central merger were approved by January.

PROUTS NECK, Me., Sept. 26 Langdon Savage Simons of Round Hill Road, Greenwich, Conn., former chief of the iron and steel branch in the industry division of the Economic Cooperation Administration, died today in his summer home here. His age was 72.
SEAFORD, L.I., Sept. 26 The Nassau County police said that a 58-year-old man suffered a heart attack today after notifying them that he had just killed his wife.
ALBANY, Sept. 26 Following are highlights of the proposed new state constitution adopted by the Constitutional Convention.

BOSTON, Sept. 26 Mrs. Louise Day Hicks, symbol of Northern white resistance to Negro demands, easily led a field of 10 candidates tonight in the preliminary race for Mayor of Boston. She will oppose the runner-up, Kevin H. White, in the nonpartisan municipal election Nov. 7.
WHEN Luigi Raimondi was named apostolic delegate to Mexico in 1957, his superiors in the Vatican diplomatic corps sent him off with only one instruction: "Stay."
SAO PAULO, Brazil, Sept. 26 A few days ago in Sao Paulo a Brazilian journalist asked a European art historian, in town for the big Bienal, what he thought of the Brazilian section of the exhibition.
The Seafarers International Union, Atlantic and Gulf District, announced yesterday that it had negotiated a $40-a-month across-the-board increase for rated seamen on oceangoing vessels.
TORONTO, Sept. 26 (AP) The Royal Canadian Golf Association rejected the new code defining an amateur today.
The American Stock Exchange was hit with its worst setback in weeks yesterday as the prices of most stocks fell in active trading.

Teams of plainclothes men and policewomen will ride some Harlem buses in an attempt to catch two young holdup men who robbed and wounded bus drivers twice within a week, the Transit Authority said yesterday.
A study of 19 automobile repair garages here has shown that only five accurately diagnosed a minor engine defect and that the repair cost estimates ranged from no charge to $40.

The election of Frank G. Shattuck 2d as president and chief executive officer of the Frank G. Shattuck Company was announced yesterday. The company operates the Schrafft's chain of restaurants and motor inns.

GENEVA, Sept. 26 Shipowners and seamen met here today under the auspices of the International Labor Organization to discuss the effect of technological developments on working conditions in the world's merchant navies.

Specialists in international affairs, scientists, authors, publishers and broadcasters have organized the International Broadcast Institute to assure that the potential of communications satellites and other technological advances is not thwarted by narrow political, economic or regulatory concerns.

A leader of a union representing 21,000 employes in 21 municipal hospitals here said yesterday that members would walk off their jobs and "close down the entire city hospital system" if the city leased Bellevue Hospital to New York University.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 The State Department indicated today its concern that North Vietnam might be trafficking movie films of captured American prisoners of war for propaganda purposes.
CAMIRI, Bolivia, Sept. 26 Jules Regis Debray appeared in court today under heavy military guard as the Bolivian Government began its trial of the young French philosopher.
The attorney for Mrs. Alice Crimmins, who is accused of murdering her 4-year-old daughter, sought dismissal of the indictment yesterday in Queens Supreme Court.
BONN, Sept. 26 (AP)--Representatives of Britain, France and West Germany signed an agreement today authorizing the first stage of joint development of an air bus.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26 Nearing the last days of what has been his poorest season of an illustrous major league career, Willie Mays smashed two home runs tonight, his 20th and 2lst, to lead the San Francisco Giants to an 8-3 victory over the New York Mets.
The residents of Douglas Manor, Queens, won a victory yesterday when the City Council voted that 25 streets of their community should retain the names by which they have become known.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26--Legislation creating a new type of Federally chartered savings institution with a broad range of loan and investment outlets was approved today by a subcommittee of the House Banking Committee.

Mr. and Mrs. Ernst O. Jo- hansson of Orebro, Sweden, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Berit M. Johansson, to Dr. Richard F. Sabbia, son of Dr. and Mrs. Louis S. Sabbia of Stony Brook, L.I.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI) The State Department indicated today that it would not permit the Rhodesian Prime Minister, Ian D. Smith, to visit the United States to address students at the University of Virginia.
HANOI, North Vietnam, Sept. 26 North Vietnam today rejected as a "new American-style trick" the peace proposal placed before the United Nations General Assembly last week by Arthur J. Goldberg.
Shereholders of Engelhard Industries, Inc., and Minerals and Chemicals Philipp, Inc., voted yesterday to merge the two companies into Engelhard Minerals and Chemicals.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 26 The Foreign Ministers of Chile, Uruguay and Ecuador put strong emphasis today on issues of world trade and development aid, which are as important to half the members of the United Nations as Vietnam or the Middle East.

Glenn Jacobson, pianist of the New York Camerata (a trio that includes a flutist and a cellist), gave a solo recital at Town Hall last night. His program consisted of Beethoven's Sonata in F (Op. 10, No. 2), Schubert's Sonata in B flat, Schumann's "Carnaval" and Calvin Hampton's "Prisms."
SEATTLE, Sept. 26 Bishop Pike withdrew his demand for a heresy trial today at the Episcopal Church's convention here. Only yesterday he had asked for the immediate initiation of judicial proceedings.

CHEEKTOWAGA, N.Y., Sept. 26 Governor Rockefeller said today that he thought public opinion would be against a new state constitution that must be voted on as a package and that he had not yet decided what stand he would take.
THE Ivy League opens its non-league football sea- son on Saturday, and the outcome of some of the games should shed light on the 1967 championship race.
MOSCOW, Sept. 26 The Soviet leadership appeared tonight to have abandoned the final ratification of a five-year economic plan for the 1966-70 period.

AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 26 (AP) Mrs. June Carr Erwin, wife of Frank Erwin Jr., Democratic National Committeeman and University of Texas Regents Chairman, died today at her home after a long illness. She was 48 years old.

The new apostolic delegate to the United States arrived at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday with a friendly grin, an informal manner and, he said later, a message from Pope Paul VI to President Johnson about the Vietnam war.

MOSCOW, Sept. 26 In a year in which every public voice in the Soviet Union is being raised to proclaim that everything has been going steadily upward in the 50 years since the revolution, I. Vishnevetsky has provided the sole discordant note.
A senior official of the Federal Reserve Board expressed deep concern yesterday about the growing trend for smaller banks to withdraw from membership in the Federal Reserve System.

RUMORS that investors might soon have to ante up the full purchase price when they buy stocks were viewed with skepticism yesterday although some observers said 100 per cent margins wouldn't be a bad idea in view of the speculative activity.
A slow retreat in the stock market yesterday turned into a rout late in the session following rumors of a possible increase in margin requirements.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 26 The Farmer-Worker-Soldier party, which scored a resounding triumph in the Senate elections this month, is quietly laying plans to win a commanding voice in the new lower house.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 26 Mayor Thomas J. Whelan of Jersey City charged here tonight that the churches of America, "in their frenzy to repay a century of unconcern with racial inequality, are now toadying to the whims of the lunatic fringe whose goal is racial war."
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 26 The Marine outpost at Conthien was struck by more than 1,000 rounds of North Vietnamese rocket and artillery fire yesterday.

LA JOLLA, Calif. Sept. 26 Ivan Erdos, one of America's leading bridge players, died of a heart attack yesterday after noon while giving a lecture at a country club here. He was 43 years old and lived in Los Angeles.
ALBANY, Sept. 26 It might be said that the proposed state constitution is like a woman who would be a gorgeous creature except that she is a bit cross-eyed and her hair is bleached.

Esso International Inc., the worldwide marketing and marine organization of Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) announced yesterday that it had placed orders for seven additional 240,000-ton tankers in European yards.
Rabbit punches may be illegal in boxing, but their planned use in next Saturday's Woodward Stakes was defended yesterday at Aqueduct as an accepted part of racing.

MODELS many of them wearing ringlets flounced about in front of an ersatz Southern plantation in Franklin Simon Monday night in dresses designed for the modern-day Scarlett O'Hara who frankly wants her man to give a damn.
Madison Fund, Inc., announced yesterday the purchase of 400,000 shares of Denison Mines, Ltd., from Noranda Mines. It put the purchase price "in the vicinity of $30-million,"
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) The Prudential Insurance Company and its insurance agents reached tentative agreement today on a two-year con tract.

WHAT Homer Jones means to the New York Giants their leading scoring threat Charlie Taylor means to the Washington Redskins. The two teams meet in Washington on Sunday and the one that can do the most about containing the other's best weapon will probably be the winner.

TOKYO, Sept. 26 (AP) Communist China announced today that it was suspending diplomatic relations with Tunisia and recalling all its embassy staff because of the North African republic's "hostile attitude."

WHAT has now become almost a conventional television look at modern West Germany was provided last night by the Columbia Broadcasting System in a news special at 10 o'clock on Channel 2. That other networks have covered substantially the same ground did not necessarily detract from the hour's interest, but
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 26--The Syrian Government has denied any connection with the recent wave of Arab terrorist activity against Israel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI) Gen. Earle G. Wheeler, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, believes the Vietnam war could be ended relatively quickly if the American military were allowed to cut off supplies from the Soviet Union and Communist China.
STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 26 In a bitterly contested Re publican primary, Mayor Thomas C. Mayers was nominated today to run for his third term.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 26 Mrs. Pat Cici of Cedar Brook, the medalist in the Women's Long Island Golf Association's match-play championship, won her first-round match today from Mrs. Cutting Cushing, Piping Rock, 6 and 5.
HARLINGEN, Tex., Sept 26 (AP)--The Rio Grande, driving new thousands of evacuees before its record flood, toppled emergency levees and threatend to lap over others today.
ALBANY, Sept. 26 New York's Ninth Constitutional Convention voted tonight to send its proposed new constitution to the voters on Nov. 7 in one package. Then it adjourned.

Paintings from Sweden, Brazil and Norway will be on display for four months starting Friday at the New York Hilton Art Gallery. Half the works shown will be sold to benefit the United Nation's Children's Fund (UNICEF).

The engagement of Miss Josephine Hosac to Matthew Stanzione Jr. has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. James H. Hosac of 425 East 86th Street. Mr. Stanzione is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanzione of Corona, Queens.

VALPARAISO, Ind., Sept. 26 (UPI) Frederick Phillip Seelig, whose two-year confinement in a Federal medical center was under investigation by the office of Representative Gerald R. Ford, died on the way to a hospital today after being found dying in a motel room.
The Right Rev. James A. Pike, resigned Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of California, said yesterday he believed he had been in communication with his dead son.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 President Johnson called on the Senate today to approve quickly a measure allowing the disfranchised citizens of the District of Columbia to elect members of the city school board. The bill passed the House yesterday by a vote of 324 to 3.

The Board of Education said yesterday that the city's 900 public schools would be open for pupils and teachers today, tomorrow and Friday even though the teachers' return to work may be delayed until late tomorrow, or even Friday.
Details of a sex education program that will be introduced in the public schools next November were disclosed yesterday by Dr. Bernard E. Donovan, Superintendent of Schools.

Paperboard production fell 8.1 per cent with 451,400 tons in the week ended Sept. 23, down from 455,100 tons in the corresponding 1966 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paperboard Association reported yesterday.
Radio station WCBS and Time magazine are at odds.
A company in the Bell System borrowed $100-million yesterday, paying the highest interest rate in almost 46 years.

As virtually its final act, the Constitutional Convention decided last night to offer New Yorkers the new Constitution on a take-it-or-leave-it basis. The voter must accept or reject it in its entirety. To our regret, the considerable improvements this document does make in the existing Constitution are insufficient in importance to offset a few features so highly objectionable that we can only recommend that the proposed Constitution be rejected at the polls in November.

After a spirited defense of the legality of the arrests of suspected prostitutes for loitering, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office suddenly switched signals yesterday and moved to dismiss all 11 loitering complaints brought in Criminal Court. They were, indeed, dismissed.

The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service said yesterday it had been in touch with both sides in the technicians strike against the American Broadcasting Company in an effort to bring them back to the bargaining table.

The Supermarkets General Corporation reached an agreement in principle yesterday for a merger with Genung's, Inc., which operates 22 department stores in the East. The companies disclosed earlier this month that discussions were being held.

Dr. Nelson P. Mead, who served for three years as acting president of City College during one of its most turbulent periods, died on Monday at Paul Kimball Hospital in Lakewood, N.J., at the age of 89, the college announced yesterday.

The Southern Railway Company announced yesterday the election of W. Graham Claytor Jr. as president. He succeeds D.W. Brosnan, president since 1962, who was named to the vacant post of chairman and chief executive officer.
Most commodity futures took a breather yesterday and activity lagged generally. Down East in Maine there was another kind of recess time off for school children to help with the potato harvest.

THE 24 drivers in the 248mile Grand Prix of the United States at Watkins Glen, N.Y., on Sunday will be running for a purse of $105,400, the largest in the history of sports car racing. The winner's share will be approximately $20,000.
Counsel for Elliot L. Richardson, Attorney General of Massachusetts, filed papers yesterday in New York Supreme Court to stop the showing of "The Titicut Follies" at the New York Film Festival.

The chaos in Communist China would seem to rule out any early possibility of Peking's orderly participation in the United Nations and in world affairs, whatever happens at this General Assembly. But a new report by a high-level citizens panel argues persuasively that the confusion, doubt and change in China "create an impelling need" to open the U.N. door to Peking now.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 26 France said today that new monetary reserve assets, known as special drawing rights, could not be created until the deficit in the United States balance of payments was eliminated, but West Germany said the deficit must only be "diminished."

MADRID, Sept. 26 Spain was not expected to cut off her trade with Cuba despite the resolution by the foreign ministers of the Organization of American States urging friendly nations to halt aid to Havana.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 The Judicial Conference of the United States threw its weight yesterday behind an effort in Congress to legalize court-approved wiretapping and electronic eavesdropping by state and Federal policemen.
R.H. Macy Co., announced yesterday record results for the fiscal year ended July 29 and also a proposal for a two-forone split in the common stock.

CARACAS, Venezuela For six years Fidel Castro has been trying hard to communize Venezuela Cuban style. But, to use the vernacular of Havana University's erstwhile star pitcher, he hasn't reached first base.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 Senator Clifford P. Case provoked an acerbic Senate debate on Vietnam policy today with an outspoken attack on President Johnson's handling of the war.

Rosalind Russell will depict Coco Chanel, the French couturier, in "Coco," a musical by Alan Jay Lerner (librettist and lyricist) and Andre Previn (composer). It will be presented on Broadway in the fall of 1968 by Miss Russell's husband, Frederick Brisson.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 26 (UPI) Bryan (Bitsy) Grant of Atlanta led the way into the third round of the national clay-court tennis championships for men 55 years old and over with a 6-2, 6-2 victory today over Donald Grey of Ridgewood, N.J. Grant is seeking his third straight title.

ROCKLEDGE, Fla., Sept. 26 (AP) John Wasik, a skydiver who died in a 3,200-foot suicide plunge Sunday near the spot where his wife was killed five weeks earlier in a parachuting accident, was buried today beside her grave.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 26 Jewish leaders, representing B'nai B'rith in 45 countries, reported marked improvement today in Roman Catholic-Jewish relations in many parts of the world as a result of the Vatican Council's declaration on Jews.
A new agreement to end the two-and-a-half-week teachers' walkout, this time backed by a signed "memorandum of understanding," was announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

The 5-by-5-foot red plastic apple that Celine Chalem brought from Paris for the opening last night of her oneman show at the Martha Jackson Gallery is really a piece of furniture. It opens to disclose a mirror-lined bar with shelves for bottles and glasses and a step-in space
WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 26 Leland Lyon, former chairman, president and director of the Atlas Powder Company, now Atlas Chemical Industries, Inc., died here Sunday. His age was 86.

Robert A. Wallace, an assistant Secretary of the Treasury, disclosed yesterday that the Government had removed its deposits from some of the nation's banks because they had not complied with its requirements on equal employment practices.
DENVER, Sept. 26 (UPI) The Denver Broncos dropped Gene Sykes, a defensive safetyman and one of their three captains, and made line-up shifts today in an effort to correct the team's weak defense.
The Maritime Administration and the Maritime Subsidy Board announced yesterday approval of the proposed merger of American Export Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., and Dragor Shipping Corporation.
An angry architectural firm is refusing to turn over to the city plans for Lincoln Center's long-delayed Damrosch Park unless it receives $50,000 in fees it contends are long overdue.
By the narrowest of margins a 1-0 victory over the Yankees the Detroit Tigers managed last night to keep barely within hailing distance of the American League leaders, the Minnesota Twins.

TIJUANA, Mexico, Sept. 26 (AP) The federal district attorney for the Tijuana district of Mexico said late today that the death toll from a mysterious mass poisoning had risen to 34. The police said 100 others had been hospitalized.
KINGMAN, Ariz., Sept. 26 The Rolls-Royce of George Hamilton, the actor, was found unlocked and unattended behind an all-night restaurant here early yesterday and was taken into custody by the police.

WES WESTRUM was a victim of circumstances. He found himself in the wrong place at the wrong time and was swept by an unkind fate into the tormenting task of managing the New York Mets, an appalling assignment for even the world's greatest manager. And no baseball man ever accused Wes of being the world's greatest manager.
The rash of price increases now taking place is stirring a heated debate over whether it is the portent of things to come or the product of things past.

The Society for the Family of Man will honor Jean Monnet, chairman of the Action Committee for the United States of Europe and a prime creator of the European Common Market, at a dinner Nov. 29 in the New York Hilton.

Mr. and Mrs. Jose Procupez of 435 East 70th Street and Buenos Aires have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Teresa Lia Procupez, to Myron Burton Silberman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Silberman of Kew Garden Hills, Queens.
A financial news service combining the resources of Reuters, the leading British foreign news agency, and the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation will make its debut on Jan. 1, 1968.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) The Federal Power Commission reversed an examiner's decision today and granted authority to the Tennessee Gas Pipeline Company instead of the Red Snapper Pipeline Company to build an offshore-toonshore pipeline system in the Gulf of Mexico.

MIAMI, Sept. 26 Cuba announced today that 9,600 tons of rice from Communist China had been distributed in Oriente Province. Havana has rarely mentioned any Communist country as a supplier of a staple consumed in Cuba.
ALBANY, Sept. 26 The state's proposed new Constitution will be the fourth and last item listed on the ballot when it is submitted to the voters Nov. 7.

More than 1,200 faculty members and students at Long Island University decried yesterday what they called "steamroller tactics" by the administration in negotiating to sell its Brooklyn Center to the City University.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange were irregular in quiet trading yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 26 The Government suspended indefinitely today the newspaper Thoi Dai. It was the fourth Vietnamese-language newspaper suspended this month, although the new constitution forbids all forms of press censorship.
Negotiators for the teamsters and major trucking companies in the area agreed on a new contract early this morning, thereby averting a threatened strike.
The Crucible Steel Company of America announced yesterday in Pittsburgh that it would raise the price of stainless steel in bar, sheet and strip form.
Cheetah, a new magazine named after the nightclub organization to which it will pay royalties, goes on sale for the first time today with a press run of 300,000 copies.
A realignment of Texas Instruments, Inc., from five divisions into three groups, each under a group vice president, was announced yesterday in Dallas.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 26 George MacGovern, senior vice president and director of research of the William Esty Company, advertising agency at 100 East 42d Street, died yesterday at the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He lived here at 4 Midland Gardens.
ALBANY, Sept. 26 If the voters turn down the proposed new state constitution on Nov. 7, the present Constitution would simply remain in effect.
HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 26 When John Wayne, a Hollywood patriot, first became interested in filming "The Green Berets" about a year ago, he couldn't find a studio to finance the project.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) The nomination of Carl E. Bagge, former Chicago lawyer and railroad official, for a new six-year term on the Federal Power Commission was approved today by the Senate Commerce Committee after more than a month's delay.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 President Johnson asked Congress today to pledge but not yet appropriate a further contribution of $200-million for the Asian Development Bank.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Sept. 26 Mrs. Nellie M. Berninger has made known the engagement of her daughter, Miss Suzanne M. Berninger, to Dr. Stephen A. Heller, son of Dr. and Mrs. Martin R. Heller of South Orange, N.J.

Eastern Air Lines, Inc. raised its net profit to $3.6-million or 32 cents a share in August, bringing net earnings to $24,475,000 or $2.31 a common share for the first eight months this year, a report issued by the company disclosed yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 26 The British Foreign Secretary, George Brown, gave his support today to United States efforts to bring about a political solution of the war in Vietnam. He criticized North Vietnam as having failed to respond to peace feelers.
BERLIN, Sept. 26--Mayor Heinrich Albertz of West Berlin and his city government resigned today as a result of a smoldering domestic crisis and increasing strife within the Social Democratic party.
AUBURN, N.Y., Sept. 26 Executives of 35 upstate counties told today how enormous Medicaid bills had often forced them to reduce such essential government services as public safety.
A group of 320 professors, writers, ministers and other professionals has signed a statement pledging to raise funds to aid youths who resist the draft and the Vietnam war.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara was to fly to Ankara tomorrow to deal with the uneasiness of some allies over the decision to deploy a missile defense system in the United States and an insistent proposal by Turkey that small nuclear weapons be put at her disposal in the event of an invasion.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, Sept. 27 The Queen Mary, her decks still festooned with streamers, confetti and colored balloons the remains of a happy all-night party aboard returned to her home port here this evening. She had completed her 1,000th and final transAtlantic voyage.

TRENTON, Sept. 27-- The chairman of the Governor's Migrant Labor Task Force said today that his group would probably recommend that Negro migrant farmworkers be accorded the same income guarantees now given to Puerto Ricans.
MAMARONECK, N. Y. Sept. 27--Jerry Courville, the amateur who led by two strokes yesterday, had a four-stroke margin after the second round of the metropolitan open golf championship today.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 26 Premier Souvanna Phouma said today that he would oppose any United States project to extend an anti-infiltration barrier from South Vietnam across Laos.

James Scully, 30-year-old assistant professor of English at the University of Connecticut, was named yesterday as the winner of the 1967 Lamont Poetry Selection for his first book of poems, "The Marshes."
Fourteen Bronx neighborhood associations and religious institutions of the three major faiths formed an association yesterday to sponsor new housing in the Bronx Park WestTremont area.

C.R. Bard, Inc., sold 200,000 common shares and certain of its stockholders sold an additional 100,000 in a public offering yesterday that was priced at 31 a share. The First Boston Corporation, underwriting manager, said that the shares of the Murray Hill, N. J., producer of medical equipment were oversubscribed.
Abraham N. Rosen, a coowner and director of the Metropolitan News Company, died yesterday in University Hospital at the age of 72.

The Consolidated Edison Company said yesterday that it would accept a site a short distance from the original Storm King Mountain location for its controversial hydroelectric plant on the Hudson River.
Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd. achieved record sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended July 31, according to a report issued yesterday by Samuel Bronfman, president.

In the course of a news conference at Philharmonic Hall earlier this week, a, young woman, her voice quivering with the kind of intensity that identifies the occasional contributor to a little magazine, addressed a question to Jerzy Skolimowski, the 31-year-old Polish director of "Barrier."
CHICAGO, Sept. 27 The Chicago Teachers Union and the Board of Education agreed today on a number of new benefits for teachers that in- clude a paid Christmas vacation.

ALBANY, Sept. 27 Anthony J. Travia, the president of the Constitutional Convention, charged today that the proposed new constitution's lastplace position on the Nov. 7 ballot was "strictly a Republican maneuver."

SAN JUAN, P.R., Thursday, Sept. 28 (UPI) Some 500 students arguing over statehood or independence for this United States commonwealth battled each other and hundreds of policemen last night in a riot that still raged early today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 The Revolutionary Action Movement, a Negro extremist group, was charged today with planning to poison hundreds of policemen and some top city officials in the event of a riot here.
AS the television cameras rolled, The Rev. Dr. Ar- thur A. Ford blindfolded himself, started his yogi breathing exercises, and visualized the face of a deceased childhood playmate named Fletcher.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Sept. 27 Mr. and Mrs. Philip Cohen have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Michaele Gerry Cohen, to Burton Paul Drayer, son of Mrs. Victor Silber of Woodmere and the late Al Drayer of New York.
The American Can Company is planning to move into the commercial printing field through the proposed acquisition of the Printing Corporation of America, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP)--The Defense Department today listed 15 servicemen killed in Vietnam.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 27 Play began this after- noon in the finals of the International Team Trials at the Traymore Hotel here, with 20 top experts nine from New York, five from California and three each from Texas and Philadelphia fighting for positions on the 1968 United States world championship team.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 27--The United States is discussing with the Soviet Union the possibility of reaching an unwritten agreement aimed at limiting arms shipments to Israel and the Arab nations.

The engagement of Miss Susan Kilbon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Kenyon Kilbon of 118 East 60th Street, to William Bruce Stiles has been announced by her parents. Mr. States is the son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Edmund Stiles of Laurel. Md.
The National Association of Broadcast Employes and Technicians will resume bargaining with the National Broadcasting Company today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 27 Cuba and Argentina clashed in the General Assembly today over the condemnation of Cuba by the Organization of American States as the backer of subversive guerrilla movements in Latin America.

EVELYN ROAMAN does not believe in compromising with her customers. They may wear sizes up to 26 , but this season they are going to be offered big-square plaids, capes and a lot of other things usually restricted to the wispiest of figures.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 Sixteen faculty members from Harvard University were understood to have urged President Johnson yesterday to deescalate the Vietnam war and to press the South Vietnam regime for "nation-building" reforms for the day when peace comes.
OTTAWA, Sept. 27 (Canadian Press) Canada's payments deficit at midyear totaled $555-million, down sharply from the $771-million deficit at mid-1966, the Government said today.

The most important single cause for the disappointing result of the Constitutional Convention was the intense political rivalry between the two parties, which affected most of the major decisions in the deliberations. Both parties must share the blame for this excessive partisanship.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 Representative Paul Fino, Republican of New York, charged here today that Mayor Lindsay had named a man "identified in 1962 as a card-carrying Communist" as head of a city antipoverty unit.

A former official of the Securities and Exchange Commission testified in Federal court here yesterday that he and another S.E.C. official held a two-hour discussion with Louis E. Wolfson in 1950 concerning various provisions of the securities laws.

The small businessman seeking to lure and retain key employee as well as enjoy the substantial tax benefits inherent in pension funds faces a bewildering selection of such plans. He can, for example, choose a noninsured plan involving payments into a savings account at a bank or into a mutual fund. The noninsured plan was discussed last Thursday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The Senate has taken its first major step toward approval of a program to encourage home ownership on a wide scale among the poor.

More than 60 leading figures in the arts and sciences will participate in a symposium next Monday at the New York Cultural Showcase Festival Fortnight symposium, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Randolph C. Guggenheimer, chairman of the festival's executive committee.
Thomas J. Rochford of Edgewater, N. J., was sentenced to two years in prison yesterday for taking part in a nationwide ring of extortionists victimizing homosexuals and other men.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla. Johnny Alford, 177 pounds, Philadelphia, outpointed Angel Oquendo, 179 pounds, Puerto Rico, 10 rounds.
ABOARD U.S.S. INTREPID, in the Gulf of Tonkin, Sept. 26 "We got an 'attaboy,' and that means we did a good job of flak suppression," the Navy commander said with a broad grin.
The Long Island University soccer team downed the University of Vermont, 4-2, in overtime yesterday in the season opener at Zeckendorf Field, Brooklyn.

Avant Garde magazine, the first edition of which has just gone to the printer, is spending $1-million in print ads and direct mail to promote subscriptions. Maybe that's why you keep running into that barefoot young lady in the farout print flanked by sawtoothed totems.
BOSTON, Sept. 27 A campaign to prevent Mrs. Louise Day Hicks from becoming Mayor of Boston was mobilizing today following her strong victory in yesterday's primary election.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 27 A Scottish-Irish trust has been established by Terence M. O'Neil Northern Ireland's Prime Minister, to coordinate restoration work on buildings of historic UlsterAmerican interest, it was announced here today.

A committee of the Board of Higher Education recommended last night that the Bernard M. Baruch School of Business and Public Administration be replaced by a new, strengthened senior college in downtown Brooklyn.

THE roar of the crowd rattled the rafters at Madison Square Garden last April. It soon became an exultant chant, "NEE-no, NEE-no, NEE-no." The rhythmic reverberations were still reechoing when Nino Benvenuti of Italy was declared the new middleweight champion of the world.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 27 Authoritative sources said today that Pope Paul VI had decided to visit Colombia and Brazil next year if he is in good health.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 27 Canada proposed to the General Assembly today a four-step plan for a return to the cease-fire arrangements worked out for Vietnam at the Geneva conference in 1954.
CAMIRI, Bolivia, Sept. 27 The military trial of Jules Regis Debray was adjourned indefinitely today to await a ruling by the Supreme Military Court in La Paz.
Joel L. Tyler, the city's Commissioner of Licenses, said yesterday he would recommend that the state, license and regulate automobile repair shops and mechanics.

The Robert and Kim Weintraub Central Park West Urban Renewal and Beautification Project is nowhere to be found among the blueprints and maps of the City Planning Commission. Shuffle through the records as you will, it is not there.

STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 27 (Reuters) The consultative assembly of the 18-nation Council of Europe called today for immediate negotiations between the Common Market and Britain and other countries applying for membership in the community.
A 15-year-old girl whose father was giving her driving lessons drove the family car off a Bronx pier last night. The police said the car sank into deep water.

Four sets of prospective merger partners have announced they have called off talks or rejected offers. Negotiations that would have led to mergers or acquisitions were terminated by the following concerns:
GLENEAGLES, Scotland, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Sunset Country Club of St. Louis and a team of golfers from Scotland set the pace today in the international pro-amateur fourball tournament.

SEATTLE, Sept. 27 The Episcopal Church, in the closing hours today of its triennial general convention, turned down a resolution calling for an end to the bombing of North Vietnam and approved in its place a compromise proposal asking the Administration to conduct the war with "restraint."

President Johnson has made a modest but marred proposal for strengthening the infant Asian Development Bank, the new multilateral institution that is slated to play a major financing role when peace returns to Southeast Asia.
MOSCOW, Sept. 27 (Reuters) Color television broadcasts in the Soviet Union will begin on Sunday, but they will not be seen in private homes, Tass, the official press agency, said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The Senate Appropriations Committee voted unanimously today to add $50-million in air safety funds to the Federal Aviation Administration's budget.

The trading pace slowed a bit yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. Prices were somewhat mixed but there were slightly more gainers than losers. At the close, the exchange's index of stock prices stood at $22.47, up 6 cents. Its high for the day was $22.50 and its low $22.42.
State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz and Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo clashed yesterday over the extent of their responsibilities in investigating election frauds.
"Bike Boy," the latest film written, produced, directed, photographed and released by Andy Warhol, the 39-year-old painter and underground moviemaker, will open Oct. 5 at the Hudson Theater.
The possibility of a fourway tie in the American League at the end of the regulation season was ended yesterday when Boston and Minnesota lost.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI) President Johnson will make an aerial inspection of flood and hurricane damage in Texas and Mexico tomorrow afternoon, the White House announced.

Panayotis Canellopoulos, Premier of a Government that held power for 22 days in 1945, was called upon to form a Cabinet on April 3 by King Constantine, whose monarchy was under heavy assault from a left-wing movement led by former Premier George Papandreou.

So what's new in Anatevka? Well, business is still great. Anatevka, in case someone doesn't know, is the Sholom Aleichem village in "Fiddler on the Roof." Yesterday afternoon at the Majestic Theater it reached its 1,259th New York performance. It was great. All Broadway shows should be as fresh--especially at their premieres.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 A new dog is in favor at the White House.

Plans for the construction of Manhattan's first full containership berth-- a $16-million terminal on the East River-- were revealed here yesterday by Commissioner of Marine and Aviation Herbert B. Halberg.

WHEN Emeric Partos was a young man growing up in Hungary, he often spent his weekends skiing in the Austrian Alps. Yesterday Mr. Partos, who is now Bergdorf Goodman's custom fur designer, showed a collection that included what may become this season's status symbol at swanky ski resorts?the mink ski sweater.
Directors of the Delaware Hudson Company have recommended stockholder approval of the inclusion of the D..H. into the Norfolk Western Railway.

MERIDIAN, Miss., Sept. 27 (UPI) Federal District Judge Dan Russell today ordered seven Noxubee County school officials, including a Negro principal, held in contempt of court for failure to comply with a school desegregation order.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 President Johnson and Britain's Foreign Secretary compared assessments of Vietnam diplomacy today and found no prospect of a break in the deadlock between Washington and Hanoi.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 27 Colombia's representative at the United Nations, Julio Cesar Turbay Alaya, was elected tonight to the post of designate, roughly equivalent to a vice president.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The Office of Economic Opportunity is divided over a project to rehabilitate gang youths. Opponents of the project are prevailing at the moment.

Stock prices moved indecisively yesterday in the wake of Tuesday's broad retreat on rumors of a possible increase in margin requirements. Advances and declines moved in a narrow range on the New York Stock Exchange in relatively quiet trading. Closing prices showed a few more losers than winners, with 637 declines against 599 advances.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Sept. 27 A November wedding is planned by Miss Ernestine Sabrina Coffey, a doctoral candidate in sociology at Pennsylvania State University, and Hugh Harding Chapman Jr., a professor of Romance languages at Penn State.

Disgruntled dock workers seeking employment at the Army's Military Ocean Terminal in Bayonne, N. J., are interfering with the hiring of longshoremen to work on vessels carrying military cargo, port agencies reported yesterday. Vessels loading cargo for Vietnam have been delayed, according to the base's information office.
PARIS, Sept. 27 Abba Eban, the Israeli Foreign Minister, outlined today the concessions that Israel might be willing to make toward a settlement in the Middle East.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 27 The Mets' experiment with what Casey Stengel used to refer to as "the youth of America" continued to falter today when Tug McGraw served a grand-slam home run to Willie McCovey in a six-run third inning that paved the way for a 7-2 victory for the San Francisco Giants.
HAMILTON, N.Y., Sept. 27 Dr. Richard M. Strauss of nearby Earlville, who had been on the staff of the Colgate University library for the last 10 years, died Monday in Cooperstown. His age was 80.

The engagement of Miss Rochelle Enid Sobota of Bayside, Queens, to Marc David Shatz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Shatz of Bayside, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leo Sobota.

MONTREAL, Sept. 27 (AP) Great Lakes ships, idle since Aug. 17 as a result of a strike of 5,400 seamen, probably will not be able to handle all the backlog of shipping orders for "quite some time," a spokesman for the Seafarers International Union said yesterday.
The wholesale commodity price index maintained on Tuesday the level it reached on Monday, which was 95.9.
Consumer prices in the New York-Northeastern New Jersey area rose in August by 0.3 per cent, the regional office of the Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics' reported yesterday.
CAIRO, Sept. 27 A Cabinet official said yesterday that a "heroic mobilization of 1.5 million men, women and children had saved Egypt's crucial cotton crop from devastation by leaf worm.

VIENNA, Sept. 27 Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said today that the United States was planning a "nuclear agro-industrial complex" for India that would provide tens of millions of people with enough grain for a daily diet of 2,400 calories.

STOCK market historians seeking explanations for current speculation in computer-based stocks need only consider a few choice statistics relating International Business Machines' market price to those of some of the most revered companies of all time.

A new building code that has been proposed for the city is New York's opportunity to throw off the conventions, restraints and sibboleths of the past and allow 20th-century thinking to take over," Jason R. Nathan, the Housing and Redevelopment Administrator; declared yesterday.

Walter Winchell, dean of Broadway columnists, will discuss contracts today with McCall's magazine and Doubleday Co. that he expects will bring him $170,000 for his memoirs. The magazine has already taken an option on the serialization of his proposed book, "The Private Papers of Walter Winchell."
HONG KONG, Sept. 27 (Reuters) A man identified as a special agent, for the United States was reported to have been executed in Communist China today after a court found him Guilty of "grave crimes."

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 27 Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, James Callaghan, said today that Britain had received no proposal for a transfer of its large sterling liabilities to the European countries, adding that Britain was not going to make any such proposals herself.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 A political struggle with Kennedyvs.-Johnson overtones is being waged in and around the White House over the choice of a Marine Corps commandant.
CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (AP) A Miami-New York-Chicago endurance run by an 18-foot fiberglass boat powered by two 100horsepower outboard motors ended safely at a dock on the Chicago River doday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 A Republican attempt to transfer Project Head Start from the Office of Economic Opportunity to the Office of Education was beaten in the Senate today with the help of Southern Democrats. The vote was 54 to 35.
HOUSTON, Sept. 27 (AP) Chuck Harrison's single scored Rusty Staub with two out in the 11th inning and gave the Houston Astros a 1-0 victory over the Philadelphia today.

Klaus Heitz, a 26-year-old Swiss cellist of significant talent and skill, made his New York debut at Town Hall last night playing a program of 20thcentury music. Mr. Heitz is not a stranger to the United States. He spent the summers of 1965 and 1967 at Tanglewood (where he won the Piatigorsky Prize the first year) and the summer of 1966 he took part in the Marlboro Music Festival.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) The Soviet Union was reported today to be planning to build its new embassy in Washington on the site of the abandoned Mount Alto Veterans Hospital on Wisconsin Avenue north of Georgetown.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. 27 Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr.'s privately financed "war on crime" all but died today as the Florida Bureau of Investigation was activated.
Nino Benvenuti is scheduled to make the first defense of his middleweight championship tonight, against Emile Griffith, at Shea Stadium.

IN Colombia, Saulo Gallego Vasquez is known as "Mr. Irish Setter." He has the top kennel in the country of the red sporting dogs. His setters have been undefeated for five years in the South American republic.
"ROBBERY" comes out very well indeed, con sidering-and there is plenty to consider.
Prices finished strong after moderate trading on the London stock exchange yesterday.

The Johnson Administration makes a good case for the President's proposed 10 per cent income tax surcharge, but so far it has not won much backing in Congress. This led Arthur W. Okun, a member of the Council of Economic Advisers, to raise a point that, in the long run, might be even more important than the immediate economic outlook.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 27 (Reuters)-- Foreign Ministry sources said today that the Indonesian Government has confined Chinese diplomats to Jakarta in retaliation for restrictions imposed on the movements of Indonesian diplomats in Peking.
BRUSSELS, Sept. 27 Big improvements are being made in Western European roads as countries that warred through a good part of this century discover that good highways make good neighbors.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27-A rebellious House of Representatives put pressure on President Johnson today to slash nondefense spending by at least $5-billion.
WASHINGTON Sept. 27 Senator Clifford D. Case said today that the Air Force had "brushed aside" proposals that McGuire Air Force Base in New Jersey be partly used for commercial jet traffic.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) President Johnson announced today the resignation of former Gov. Farris Bryant of Florida as director of emergency planning and the appointment of former Gov. Price Daniel of Texas as Mr. Bryant's successor.

SUGAR HILL, N.H. Highbutton shoes, kerosene lamps, double-lensed stereopticons and the horse and buggy were in their heyday in 1881 when Marcia Gove Bowles opened the Homestead in a farmhouse that dated back to 1802.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 26 (AP)--Two Navy airplanes with six persons aboard collided late today during a rainstorm near suburban Jacksonville Beach and crashed in flames.
The Gulf Oil Corporation announced yesterday the election of W.C. Brodhead as vice president for transportation of its marine division.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Sept. 27 (UPI) A drum-shaped radio relay station owned by 58 nations soared into orbit tonight to double the capacity of the booming trans-Pacific satellite communications business.

PARIS, Sept. 27 Prince Felix Youssoupoff, the leader of a group of noblemen who assassinated Rasputin 51 years ago, died today in the sedate Auteuil quarter of Paris, after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

It is bitterly disappointing that the Organization of African Unity's peace mission has postponed its arrival in Nigeria for nearly two weeks. This delay could be fatal to the efforts of the six African heads of state to end the war between the Federal Government and the Ibos of secessionist Biafra.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 27-- The State Bureau of Narcotics Control was charged here today with a series of entrapments that led to the indictments of an artist, a dress designer, two advertising executives and a college professor for selling marijuana.
DETROIT, Sept. 27-- The president of the State Bar of Michigan accused an American Bar Association panel today of attempting to exercise "veto power" over the appointment of Federal judges.

A committee of depositors in the defunct San Francisco National Bank, which failed in January of 1965, announced yesterday that protracted negotiations with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to settle their claims against the bank had collapsed, and that pending litigation against the F.D.I.C. would be pressed vigorously.

BONN, Sept. 27--The West German Cabinet approved today the draft of Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger's reply to a letter from Premier Willi Stoph of East Germany. It proposed "instant negotiations" to normalize relations between the two Germanys.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 27 Mrs. Pat Cici of Cedar Brook, the medalist, turned back Mrs. Rundlet Blakemore of the home club, 6 and 5, in the quarter-final round of the Women's Long Island Golf Association matchplay championship at the Piping Rock Club today.

A New York importer calls for the nation to "stand together" in a half-page advertisement in The New York Times today replying to a full page advertisement by a California clothing manufacturer who asked President Johnson not to seek renomination in hopes that a successor could end the war in Vietnam.

Now, of course, the bohemian as romanticized in Puccini's "La Boheme" is the cute little furry toy of conservative music lovers everywhere. That's the way of the world: If you must do something unrespectable, make sure you do it a hundred years ago.

The health industry of the United States, a $50-billion-ayear complex of hospitals, clinics and laboratories responsible for the well-being of every American, is suffering from a shortage of tens of thousands of doctors.

More than 200 letters written by Mrs. Jacqueline Kennedy's paternal grandfather from 1942 to 1947 will be sold at auction at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel tonight at 7:30.

Plans to enter the hotel business were announced yesterday by Eastern Airlines. The company said it had arranged to buy controlling interest in two large report hotels in Puerto Rico and Hawaii from Laurance S. Rockefeller for an estimated $27-million.
BOSTON, Sept. 27 (AP) A physician testified today that marijuana caused no physical damage to 200 users of the drug he studied at Beth Israel Hospital here.

A crowd of 11,000 at a Madison Square Garden rally roared its support last night for public financial aid to parochial and private schools.
A 50-year-old Bronx woman died Tuesday, an apparent suicide, after taking "several tablespoonfuls" of insecticide powder containing parathion, health officials said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27-- Senator Thruston B. Morton of Kentucky, one of the Senate's most influential Republicans, charged today that President Johnson had been "brainwashed" by the "military-industrial complex" into believing that the United States would win a military victory in Vietnam.

The board of directors of The New York Times Company approved yesterday a proposed amendment to the company's certificate of incorporation to create a new class of serial preferred stock consisting of 200,000 shares with a par value of $100 a share.

TEL AVIV, Sept 27 An Israeli spokesman said 14 people were killed on the Israeli side of the Suez Canal today during a nine-hour engagement that began with a machine-gun burst and expanded into a duel by artillery and tanks.

The new contract agreement between the Teamsters union and major trucking companies in the metropolitan area and northern New Jersey will provide for wage increases totaling 55 cents an hour over a period of 31 months.
An earthquake at a coppermining operation in Chile was ignored by futures traders yesterday, but an Australian prediction of a sharply lower wheat crop caught their fancy.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (Reuters)-- Ambassador-at-Large Henry Cabot Lodge tonight denied a report that he had advocated an invasion of North Vietnam.
The 12-story loft building at 140 Lafayette Street has been sold by the realty investing concern of Fischer-Landis to Isaac H. Alper for cash over mortgages of $685,000.

Louella D. Everett, who carved a reputation as a super sleuth of poetry fragments, died last Saturday in Boston. She was 83 years old.

LEONIA, N.J., Sept. 27 The engagement of Miss Janet Louise Snyder to Paul George Rooker has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Snyder. Mr. Rooker is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Rooker of Dallas.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 27 Governor Rockefeller declared here today that adoption of the proposed state constitution would mean higher state taxes but he declined to predict when or how large the increase would be.
