WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (Here comes Peter.) "What do you mean you don't understand the arithmetic, Peter?" (You'd think that out of eight kids we'd have at least one who could understand arithmetic.)
An experienced and successful stakes campaigner, Syrian Sea of the Meadow Stable, won the $29,500 Astarita at Aqueduct yesterday.

ATHENS, Sept. 27 Former Premier Panayotis Canellopoulos, whose conservative Cabinet was toppled by the military coup of April 21, defied martial law today to issue a public appeal for political freedom in Greece.
Robert W. Haack announced yesterday his first staff promotions since stepping into the presidency of the New York Stock Exchange on Sept. 11.
By Frank Whiteley's standards, the statement amounted to a filibuster.
The Freeport Sulphur Company said yesterday it was increasing domestic sulphur prices by $5.50 a ton and was further restricting shipments to domestic and foreign customers.
WILMARTH LEWIS is a cultural revolutionist. He rides shotgun for our new National Portrait Gallery. He advocates four-year terms for college presidents.
Near the turn of the century, on New York's Lower East Side, the Kimpetoran Society was formed to care for indigent and often unmarried Jewish mothers.
A booth that will dispense information on cultural happenings in New York began business yesterday in Macy's Elmhurst store, 88-01 Queens Boulevard.
ISMAILIA, United Arab Republic, Sept. 27 The governor of Ismailia said tonight that a seven-hour shelling of this town today by the Israelis resulted in 36 civilian deaths and 85 serious injuries.

MONTREAL, Sept. 27 About two million residents of the Montreal area and thousands of visitors to Expo 67 moved through streets strangled with traffic today as the city's transit strike went into its eighth day.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Sept. 27 The engagement of Miss Betty Winston to Kenneth A. Weisberger has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs., Benjamin E. Winston. Mr. Weisberger is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert S. Weisberger of New Rochelle.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI) President Johnson has told a dozen Democratic Senators, including several who have critized his Vietnam policy, that North Vietnam shows no indication of talking peace "no matter what we do."

A group of 30 students from the nation's most exclusive prep school for corporate executives, the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, came to New York last Saturday not for a visit to Wall Street or Madison Avenue but to kick and be kicked on the stony turf of Van Cortlandt Park.

New York City, high school students who want to go to college next year should not find their chances jeopardized by the three-week delay in the opening of school, according to college admission officers, high school principals and the director of examinations for the College Entrance Examination Board.

Cemeteries should be removed from New York City, and an eight-block-long slice of Central Park's northern end should be lopped off to provide housing space for middle income families, a United Housing Foundation official said yesterday.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 27--Well-informed sources said today that artillery of Nigeria federal forces began shelling the secessionist capital, Enugu, this afternoon from heights about three miles away.

LAKEVILLE, Conn., Sept. 27 Mr. and Mrs. Rodney Goddard Aller have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Alden Aller, to Cortlandt Cammann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Livingston Cammarin of Rye, N. Y., and Lakeville.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 Dr. James B. Conant, who has helped to shape the course of American education, science and diplomacy for more than three decades, was named today the 1967 winner of an award that has been called the "American Nobel prize."

The suggestion made in Strasbourg yesterday by Abba Eban, Israel's Foreign Minister, that an economic union be formed among Israel, Lebanon and Jordan points to the kind of constructive solution that will eventually have to be seriously sought if long-run peace and prosperity in the Middle East are to be achieved.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 27 (AP) Last-place Kansas City ruined Chiacgo's chances for moving into the American League lead tonight and sent the White Sox skidding instead into fourth place by sweeping a doubleheader 5-2 and 4-0.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Sept. 28 The chief of state, Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Van Thieu, debated publicly and dramatically this morning with Thich Tri Quang, the militantly anti-government Buddhist monk.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Sept. 27 (Reuters) The Santa Barbara City Council has adopted an ordinance outlawing sonic booms. This is believed to be the first such municipal code in the United States.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 27 Dean Chance, starting with only two days' rest, was knocked out in the fourth inning. Harmon Killebrew, representing. the potential tying run, swung on a 3-0 pitch and lifted a harmless fly ball for the final out in the seventh.

Under an agreement reached between New York's theater owners and the major theatrical unions, television may send news cameras inside theaters to film segments of a play's rehearsal without having to pay for the privilege.

Dr. and Mrs. Clifford L. Spingarn of 66 East 80th Street have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alexandra Spingarn, to Laurence Kragen Koff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Koff of 25 Sutton Place South.

TIJUANA, Mexico, Sept. 27 (UPI)--Investigators widened their search today for the source of a highly lethal pesticide mixed in food that has caused at least 17 deaths and violent illness among hundreds of others here.

BERLIN, Sept. 27 West Berlin's Social Democrats, caught in a crisis following the resignation yesterday of Mayor Heinrich Albertz and his city government, turned today to Willy Brandt, the Socialist leader and West German Foreign Minister, for help and advice.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27-- Members of the nation's social elite have been invited to support a Washington charity ball that they can't attend even if they want to.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 27--Israelis moved back today to Kfar Etzion, a collective settlement south of Jerusalem overrun by Arab troops 20 years ago.

DALLAS, Sept. 27 (UPI) An industrial courier plane carrying military officials and apparently classified documents crashed and exploded today against an elementary school building in a Dallas suburb 20 minutes after students had been dismissed early because of a teachers' meeting.

KINGSTREE, S.C., Sept. 27 When Mrs. Elmena Frierson opened the door of her sharecropper cabin today there on the front porch standing on a sack of freshly picked cotton was Gov. George Romney of Michigan.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Kremen of 77 Seventh Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Erica Switzen Kremen, to Douglas Eurico Rosenthal, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Rosenthal of New Haven.

MATT SNELL, the New York Jets' ailing fullback, tested his left knee yesterday in a workout at Shea Stadium. But it wasn't an all-out test, so the Jets don't know yet whether he will be ready for Sunday's American Football League game here against the Miami Dolphins.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Kellar Goldstein of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marilyn Susan Goldstein, to Joseph Bernard Schwartz, son of Mrs. Jack Schwartz of New Haven and the late Mr. Schwartz.

LOS ANGELES, Sept, 27 (UPI) Pittsburgh's Roberto Clemente drove in Matty Alou from third base with a single and Bob Veale pitched a 5-hitter to lead the Pirates to a 1-0 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight.
The National Theater for the Deaf, designed to show that actions can speak louder than words, is on its first tour.
The tax-exempt bond market bustled with activity yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 A further sharp rise in consumer, and wholesale industrial prices was reported today, giving President Johnson's case for a tax increase another lift.
The manuscript of an autobiographical love story by James Joyce has been discovered in a private collection here and will be published next January.

The Right Rev. James A. Pike said last night that he had decided to try to contact his dead son through a medium because of "unexplained physical phenomena" that occurred last year in the apartment the Bishop and his son had shared in Cambridge, England.
The delegate assembly of the United Federation of Teachers voted last night to recommend acceptance of a proposed school contract that would end the two-and-a-half-week teachers' walkout.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 President Johnson announced today that he would name Walter N. Tobriner, retiring president of the three-man District Board of Commissioner, as Ambassador to Jamaica.

About 200 Negroes transformed a Board of Education meeting into bedlam yesterday when they shouted threats at a group of Brooklyn teachers, denounced the Board of Education and drove the president of the teachers' union from the room with heckling outcries.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) The Senate approved without discussion today President Johnson's appointment of Carl E. Bagge, a former Chicago lawyer and railroad official, for a full six-year term on the Federal Power Commission.

Predominantly a junior-sophomore football team, Columbia has brightening prospects for 1968, and an upturn in its fortunes may set in this season if the offensive line develops to furnish the blocking for an exceptional group of backs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) Irish International Airlines, Aer Lingus, disclosed today that it was leading a fight by several European airlines against American plans for limiting the seating capacity of the huge "jumbo jets" scheduled to enter service in 1970.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28 Foreign Minister Maurice Couve de Murville of France charged today that the United States was endangering the peace of the world through its involvement in Vietnam.
Following is the translation from the Latin of the canon of the Roman Catholic mass that will be used in churches in the United States beginning Oct. 22:
Dr. Hugo H. Schaefer, dean emeritus of Long Island University's Brooklyn College of Pharmacy, died Wednesday night at his home, 12 Longspur Road, Yonkers. He was 75 years old.

Bernard Relin has relinquished the active day-to-day management of the Rheingold Corporation to John E. Haigney, who has been Mr. Relin's personal lawyer for 25 years and an attorney for the last 10 years for the company now known as Rheingold.
MADRID, Sept. 28 A Spanish Army court-martial sentenced a Madrid University student today to six months and a day in prison for "insults against the armed forces" during campus riots last April.

HANOI, North Vietnam, Sept. 128 (Agence France-Presse) Hanoi's antiaircraft and civil defenses have been greatly strengthened in the last few weeks to prepare the capital in case of United States bombings like those being mounted against Haiphong.

AREA A Surfcasters, especially in the Brielle, N.J., area, are reporting fine catches of blues, ranging from 12-to-16 pounds, with each man averaging 10 to a dozen catches. Small kings (under six inches), striped bass averaging 12-to-15 pounds in the Atlantic City waters and winter flounder in the back bays are also being taken.

The outcome of the preliminary race for Mayor of Boston is moderately encouraging. Mrs. Louise Day Hicks, the School Committee member who has won a personal following by exploiting racial fears and fantasies arising from the school integration problem, did lead the field. But more than 70 per cent of the voters chose one or another of her nine opponents.

Intercollegiate club football, which has grown impressively in national popularity since Fordham and New York University instituted the revival of the student-run sport in 1964, opens in the metropolitan area tomorrow with three games.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28 Only in Ballet America does anyone pirouette to a banjo or leap to a Western guitar. And in the premiere performance here last night of this country's only professional indigenous folk-dance group, songs like "Shenandoah" and "This Old House" provided the main movements.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Peaceful revolution came today to the normally tranquil and conservative professional association of American career diplomats.

The Metropolitan Opera introduced a new queen of the Night in Mozart's "Die Zauberfl te" last night. She is Christina Deutekom, a Dutch soprano who has sung with the Munich, Stuttgart and Vienna opera companies.
Ask a Dr. Fager fan about those pace-setting "rabbits" in the Woodward Stakes and he'll tell you, "they'll get chewed up fast."

CHIHUAHUA, Mexico, Sept. 28 (AP) A man whom the police identified as a son of Mexico's legendary revolutionist, Pancho Villa, was found shot to death today in circumstances that resembled the assassination of Villa.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 28 The Indian Government has imposed a freeze on new activities of the Asia Foundation, which at one time indirectly received funds from the Central Intelligence Agency.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 28 A leading Soviet Space scientist indicated today that Western observers might in the future be permitted to attend space launchings in the Soviet Union.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Doyle of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Louise Doyle, to Ens. Walter Patrick Donnelly Jr., U.S.N., son of Lieut. Col. Donnelly, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Donnelly also of Brooklyn.
Venezuela, which derives 90 per cent of her foreign exchange from oil produced by foreign companies, took a giant step yesterday toward greater self-sufficiency.
A city antipoverty official, under attack by Representative Paul A. Fino as a Communist, was strongly defended yesterday by Mayor Lindsay as "thoroughly dedicated and responsible."
WARSAW, Sept. 28 The Central Committee of the United Workers (Communist) party, meeting for the first time since the Arab-Israeli war strained party unity, opened its ninth plenary meeting today.

CARACAS, Venezuela It may seem strange but, apart from Israel, Venezuela is the only country to benefit from last June's Palestine war. Nasser's Arab allies stopped sending petroleum to the U.S.A. and West Europe, and the Suez Canal was blocked. Consequently there was heavier dependence on this country's oil output, which jumped more than 10 per cent.

Lucine Amara's recital program at Carnegie Hall last night was unequivocal: no arias, no Italian folk songs, nothing in English; just 25 songs in German and French. A no-nonsense art-song evening, the likes of which you do not hear attempted very often these days.

Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, told teachers yesterterday that it "will take personal heroism" for them to go back in some cases to their schools in slum areas because of community hostility, but he urged them to return.

HONG KONG, Sept. 28 Accumulating evidence indicates that Mao Tse-tong is engaged in an urgent attempt to quell disaffection in Communist China's armed forces and that his recent secret trip from Peking into central and east China was concerned primarily with problems of rebelliousness among military units and commanders.

ATLANTA, Sept. 28 (UPI) Miller Barber and Randy Glover, battling cold and the wind in a race against darkness, shot three-under-par 69's late today to tie the Professional Golfers Association champion, Don January, and Charles Sifford for the first round lead in the $115,000 Atlanta golf classic.
Volume hovered around the six-million share mark again yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. Prices moved up, too.
President Johnson has ordered that a member of the Joint Chiefs of Staff attend all future White House discussions involving the bombing of North Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI) The Soviet Navy has 35 to 40 vessels in the Mediterranean, 5 or 10 more than it had in the area before the Middle Eastern war in June, according to Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, Chief of Naval Operations.
Union Electric Company of St. Louis announced yesterday it would install the nation's first full-scale system to remove sulphur dioxide from the smokestacks of a coal-fired power generating plant.
RHEIMS, France, Sept. 28 (UPI) An army of 10,000 grape pickers today began harvesting what promised to be a good vintage champagne crop perhaps enough for 67 million bottles.

ELMSFORD, N.Y., Sept. 28 The Women's Tri-County Golf Association defeated the Garden State Women's Golf Association team of 20 players, 17 to 12 , in a best-ball match over the 6,083-yard, par74 Fairview Country Club course today.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 28 (AP) Ralph Nader, the critic of the automobile industry, challenged insurance agents today to take the lead in weeding out hazards in the human environment.
WHILE most people have been listening to the roar of the bulls in Wall Street, Eliot Janeway has slipped away to poll the Swiss about our stock markets.

The Senate Appropriations Committee, now considering a public works appropriations bill, decided yesterday to insert a $1-million appropriation into the measure for widening of the Newark Bay channel.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Sept 28-- Dr. and Mrs. Vincent Finiello have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diane Rose Finiello, to Philip Algie McCombs, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth L. McCombs of Freeport, Ill.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Sept. 28 Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Lewy Joseph have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Donna Joseph, to Stephan Harris Goldstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Joseph Goldstein of Denver and Cheyenne, Wyo.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 Gov. George Romney accused the Johnson Administration today of "errors of judgment" in Vietnam, both in prosecuting the war and in attempting to end it.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 28 (UPI) Gov. Roberto S nchez Vilella has been divorced by his wife, it was announced officially today at the Fortaleza, the Governor's official mansion.

I still sometimes suspect that Gerald Arpino is the corporate pseudonym of a gaggle of choreographers instead of just one man. He seems to be without the standard set of readily identifiable and favored movements or patterns. He never does just any one thing.

TUNIS, Sept. 28 (Agence France-Presse) The Tunisian Secretary of State for Information said yesterday that "verbal excess" had become so great in Arab information media that "no one any longer pays more than relative attention to what we have to say."

THE New York Jets lost Matt Snell yesterday while the New York Giants gained Tucker Frederickson in the sense that Coach Al Sherman has decided to put Frederickson in his starting line-up. Spell will undergo surgery here today for the removal of torn cartilage in the
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 28 Almost half of Syria's Cabinet members lost their jobs tonight in the country's first Government reshuffle since the Arab-Israeli war.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 28 United States planes fought nine times with MIG fighters near Hanoi yesterday.
ALBANY, Sept. 28 (AP) The New York Central Railroad cited declining revenues today as it defended its proposal to drop six passenger runs in the Buffalo-New York City section.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 28 (Reuters) Premier Rashid Kasami of Lebanon today described an Israeli proposal for economic cooperation between Lebanon, Jordan and Israel as a propaganda move. He said that Israel's only aims were to "mislead and make propaganda to realize its aggressive plans."
The election of John B. White as vice president for production in the glass division was announced yesterday by the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company.

The New York Jazz Repertory Orchestra, a 21-piece group made up of jazz musicians who have served with Count Basie, Woody Herman, Tommy Dorsey and Gerry Mulligan, gave a debut performance at Town Hall last night that indicated promise and pitfalls.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 28 Jerry Courville, an amateur, did the unusual today as he won the metropolitan open golf championship by four strokes.

LONDON, Sept. 28 (AP)-- British drug companies have been overcharging the National Health Service by millions of dollars in recent years, a Government committee reported today. It recommended stricter control of sales techniques, drug names and ingredients.

The two major American steamship lines that had signed up with the city as tenants in a proposed $22-million containership terminal in the Stapleton section of Staten Island have withdrawn from the project.
Hal W. Hazelrigg, public relations manager of the National Dairy Products Corporation, died of a heart attack Wednesday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 15 Claremont Avenue.

ROME, Sept. 28 Benefits from an over-all 4 per cent increase in the value of world agricultural exports in 1966 bypassed the developing countries, the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) The Interstate Commerce Commission upheld today the merger of the Chicago Great Western Railway into the Chicago North Western Railway, and said the consolidation may take place in 35 days.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28-- Doctors here have discovered abnormal growths of a previously unknown type in some women who have been taking birth control pills.

Miss Ellen Kelly Sheeran, daughter of Mrs. James Parker Haney of Rumson, N.J., and the late Gerard F. Sheeran, was married yesterday at noon to Michael M. Gottlieb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abe Gottlieb of New York. Rabbi William F. Rosenblum and Rabbi Martin J. Zion officiated at Temple Israel.
Roman Catholics in the United States will participate in all-English masses beginning Sunday, Oct. 22-- six weeks earlier than planned.
Autumn's first rainstorm struck the metropolitan area yesterday afternoon, delaying planes, tearing limbs off trees, and knocking out power lines in scattered locations.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28 Tom Seaver of the Mets pitched six innings of shutout ball tonight in quest of his 17th victory only to be beaten, 3-0, when his Dodger pitching rival, Claude Osteen, tripled home two runs in the seventh inning.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 The senatorial tennis math between six Democrats and six Republicans a historic first or, as one observer said, probably a historic last proved, if nothing else, that most of the Senators know how to dress for the game.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 The House Democratic leader ship has moved to shelve labor legislation that would ease re strictions on the picketing of construction sites.
ROME, Sept. 28 Pope Paul VI will open a historic first meeting tomorrow of a synod of prelates elected or appointed to advise him on the government of the Roman Catholic Church.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 President Johnson, apparently replying to his latest Senate critic, said today he had always recognized that there could be no "military solution" to the problems of Southeast Asia.
"AMONG all the editors in Greece, there was one man who turned out to be a woman," an Athenian journalist remarked recently.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28-- The Israeli Embassy informed the United States today that Israel's plans to put settlers on territory seized from the Arabs were necessary for reasons of military security. They do not signal any change in Israeli policy toward these regions, the embassy said.
BELTSVILLE, Md., Sept. 28 An insect hormone may be a possible substitute for the dangerous pesticides and poisons now widely used to control common pests that damage and reduce agricultural crops.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 28 The finals of the International Team Trials continued at the Traymore Hotel here tonight with two Philadelphia experts leading by a substantial margin.

The national shortage of doctors and the rising demand for health services has led to the immigration of thousands of foreign physicians, many of doubtful ability who may arrive to practice, in American medical institutions sight unseen and quality untested.

APPLETON, Wis., Sept. 28 (AP) An 80-year-old woman remained in shock this afternoon as the Appleton police continued to search for additional packages of a butchered body believed to be that of her husband, 85.

New York University has appointed John M. O'Mara vice president for institutional facilities. An assistant vice president of the university for business affairs since 1965, Mr. O'Mara will be responsible in his new post for operation and maintenance of the university plant as well as new construction and real estate.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Caught in a partisan impasse over how to cut Federal spending, more than a score of Government agencies face a temporary shutoff of operating funds after midnight Saturday.

The Lindsay administration's broad program for slum and community improvement received the endorsement last night of the City Council's Finance Committee. The approval, in executive session, came after a day of public hearing on the question.
DETROIT, Sept. 28 Just about everything but profits will be up next year, the nation's leading business economists believe.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) The Senate Appropriations Committee approved today a $4.7-billion public works appropriations bill carrying funds for water projects and the Atomic Energy Commission for the fiscal year 1968 that started last July 1.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) Money to finance the design of a big atom smasher at Weston, Ill., which was the subject of a sharp controversy earlier this year, was approved without debate today by the Senate Appropriations Committee.

There is a curious blend of equanimity, intensity and even suspense on Herbert Adler's face these days. He is a man on the move. On Oct. 10, he will leave the cloistered offices of the accounting profession for the frying-pan of the garment industry.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Sept. 29 President-elect Nguyen Van Thieu today rejected the demands of Thich Tri Quang, the anti-Government Buddhist leader.

THIS promises to be a wild and wonderful weekend, packed with goodies of various descriptions. There are tasty tidbits for everyone and the scope can be widened ever so slightly by also tossing in the middleweight championship fight between Nino Benvenuti and Emile Griffith. It's almost a case of you-name-it-we-got-it.
The San Francisco Contemporary Dancers, which recently decided to settle in New York, is starting rehearsals on a program it will do with Karheinz Stockhausen, the avant-garde German composer.
The election of M. Lamar Muse as president of Universal Airlines, Inc., has been announced by Robert J. Wilson, chairman of the board of the carrier.

The United States Department of Justice has asked the United States District Court for the Southern District Court of New York to grant relief to four European shipping lines who face being shut out of this nation's ocean trade with Brazil.

LONDON, Sept. 28 Sir James Learmonth, an authority on vascular complaints who was a surgeon to King George VI, died yesterday at Biggar, in Scotland. His age was 72, Sir James operated on the King in 1948 to restore circulation in the right foot. The fol-
A break in union solidarity has developed in the week-old technicians' strike against the American Broadcasting Company.

ATHENS, Sept. 28 Mrs. Helen Vlachos, who refuses to resume publication of the two conservative daily newspapers and a weekly picture magazine she owns until freedom of the press is restored in Greece, was charged today with having insulted the military regime.
Cotton futures, which have been attracting much more trading than usual in the past few months, had good reason for a price and volume rise yesterday.
Miss Patricia A. Phipps and Ens. David John Ruth, U.S.N.R., plan to be married in St. Martin's Episcopal Church here on Oct. 14.
A National Association of Police Chaplains was formed here yesterday to improve community attitudes toward the police throughout the country.
Prices turned mixed yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.

In an effort to discourage prolonged automobile parking in Manhattan, the city will raise rates at its public garage on 53d Street and increase to 25 cents the charge for an hour's parking at 322 curbside meters in midtown.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Diplomats here are privately expressing doubt that the recent meeting of the Organization of American States can or will produce any real tightening of security measures against Cuban Communist agents.
It was a two-faced bond market yesterday. Government and corporate securities rose in price, but tax-exempt bonds declined.

On the eve of the opening of the current session of the United Nations General Assembly, Secretary General Thant again urged that the United States stop bombing North Vietnam as an essential first step toward peace. Mr. Thant said he was "convinced" that if the bombing ended unconditionally, peace talks could begin in three or four weeks.

Louis E. Wolfson, the millionaire industrialist, was depicted in Federal court here yesterday as "an innocent tycoon" whose financial advisers failed to give him the proper advice about the securities laws.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 28 The Communist party of Czechoslovakia has moved harshly against that country's rebellious writers and, through them, at liberal forces in the party itself.

ALBANY, Sept. 28 The person who stands to gain, or lose, the most from the vote Nov. 7 on the proposed new state constitution is the man who presided over its nearly six months of gestation Anthony J. Travia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Revenue freight traffic generated by carloadings on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended Sept. 23 were both below the volume in the corresponding week of last year.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 28 Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson accused his Republican opponent today of "an extraordinary piece of political deception" in disseminating a campaign brochure photograph.

Adm. Richard E. Byrd relied on one during long months in the Antarctic. Monarchs past and present have favored them. Yet the latest models are as contemporary as the atomic power that drives many of them.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 The House Education and Labor Committee agreed today to raise women's participation in the Job Corps from 23 per cent to 30 per cent, effective next July.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art is about to embark on a major new construction program and the most comprehensive plan for its growth and expansion in its 97-year history. The construction will be in Central Park, within boundaries previously allotted by the city.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28 The Soviet Union won a partial victory in the General Assembly tonight on its proposal that the United Nations once again seek to define aggression. The item was first placed on the agenda in 1950.
BERLIN, Sept. 28 Now that Heinrich Albertz has resigned as Mayor, West Berliners are taking a more serious view of the radical student movement here.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy said last night that he planned to campaign for the adoption of the proposed state constitution, which will be presented to the voters Nov. 7.

Back where he belongs, in a long hurdle-race, the Harbor View Farm's Duke Cannon won the $14,050 Elkridge Handicap for 3-year-olds at Aqueduct yesterday. It was not easy, for the margin was a mere neck over Mrs. Wallace Whittaker's Sky Epic, but the outcome was gratifying, if a little too exciting, for those in the crowd of 22,763 who made Duke Cannon the favorite.
MIAMI, Friday, Sept. 29 (AP) A hurricane watch was set yesterday in the Lesser Antilles, but Tropical Storm Edith, the cause of the alert, halted about 290 miles off the chain of islands.
HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Sept. 28 A year-long survey of housing on Long Island has found that residential blight is increasing, with municipalities doing relatively little to combat the problem.

Radio officers began a work stoppage yesterday afternoon on six vessels in ports on the East and Gulf Coasts. It was feared that the stoppage might spread to as many as 300 American-flag passenger, cargo and tank ships.

EUREKA, Ill., Sept. 28 Governor Ronald Reagan of California opened a cross-country speaking trip today with the observation that the Vietnam war would be a major issue in next year's Presidential campaign even if the fighting had stopped.
The middleweight championship fight between Nino Benvenuti and Emile Griffith, scheduled for last night in Shea Stadium, was postponed until 10 o'clock tonight.
LONDON, Sept. 28 (Reuters) Sotheby's refused today to auction two paintings by Hitler.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 28 Brazil threw the support of the Latin-American bloc behind the plan for creation of new monetary reserve assets today, thus assuring an all-but-unanimous vote when the plan comes up for approval tomorrow at the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund.
TORONTO, Sept. 28 A sharp jump in short-term and long-term borrowing costs in Canada is putting new pressure on the Government to hold down spending and the size of next year's budget deficit.
Nicholas Bernard, banquet manager of the American Hotel, died yesterday in St. Mary's Hospital of the Mayo Clinic, Rochester, Minn. He was 67 years old and lived at 3 Peter Cooper Road.

President Johnson has appointed nine capable, wellqualified citizens to serve on the new City Council to run the municipal government of Washington, D.C. He has suitably recognized the Negro majority in the city by choosing Negroes for five of the nine places.

Edwin Short, Member of Parliament and British Postmaster General, said here yesterday that he could be the last of Britain's postal chiefs. He noted that British postal operations would be turned over in two years to a private corporation similar to those operating other British utilities.
THE first three days of the final week of the Ameri- can League pennant race were sensational, or something: the four contenders played nine games and lost seven of them.
HARLINGEN, Tex., Sept. 28 President Johnson flew across the familiar but barely recognizable Rio Grande Valley this afternoon to see the havoc that winds and floods had wrought in his native Texas.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 The civilian space program faces "complete havoc" if its current budget is cut any further, James E. Webb, head of the space agency, said today.

Even the most talented political leader would have had trouble in replacing Willy Brandt as Governing Mayor of West Berlin. From the outset last December, Heinrich Albertz found the job difficult; now he has found it impossible and has resigned, along with the rest of the West Berlin government.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 28 Diminutive Del Insko, the South Beloit (Ill.) reinsman who appears to have a stranglehold on another Roosevelt Raceway driving crown, brought home his 58th winner of the meeting tonight at the Nassau County course.

DANANG, South Vietnam Sept. 28 (UPI)-- About twofifths of the Marine helicopters used to carry food, water and ammunition to the outposts along the demilitarized zone have been grounded because of a structural deficiency.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28-- Senator Jacob K. Javits said today that the designation of New York's favorite-son candidate for the Presidential nomination at the 1968 Republican Convention was still an open matter.
State Supreme Court Justice Francis T. Murphy Jr. denied an effort yesterday by the State of Massachusetts to enjoin the showing of a documentary last night at the New York Film Festival.

The legal status of the Police Department's crackdown on midtown prostitution was further confused yesterday when District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office reverted to a defense of the practice of arresting streetwalkers on loitering charges.

Peter J. Brennan, president of the New York Building Trades Council, urged member unions yesterday to cooperate with the Workers Defense League in recruiting qualified Negroes for apprenticeship openings.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 28 (AP) Charles O. Finley made official today his long-reported plans to move the Kansas City Athletics to another city.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) J. Edgar Hoover, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, gibed today at his critics and the paunchiness of his former agents.
The First National City Bank announced yesterday that it had stopped accepting new participations in its commingled investment account "until the legal situation has been further clarified."

Channel 13 will follow its Monday presentation of "A Conversation With Svetlana Alliluyeva," a live network presentation of National Educational television, with an analysis of the interview with Stalin's daughter.

NORTH CANTON, Ohio, Sept. 28 H.W. Hoover Jr. was removed as chairman, president and chief executive officer of the Hoover Company last year for "a multitude of reasons," according to an official of the company's management group.
The Consolidated Edison company's plan to shift the site of a proposed Hudson River power plant has only generated more opposition from conservation groups.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI) Monthly premiums for the Medicare insurance program paying doctor bills may be increased by $1 next April 1.

KYOTO, Japan, Sept. 28 The use of herbs known generically as cannabis including hashish and marijuana is increasing around the world, delegates to the annual convention of Interpol were told here today.

But what it all seems to be degenerating into is a desperate search for gimmicks, and the new double bill of "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" last night at the New York State Theater was a Good example. Baroness Hilla Rebay, the artist who aroused the interest of Solomon R. Guggenheim in nonobjective art and persuaded him to provide money for a museum dedicated to it, died of a heart attack Wednesday night at her home in Franton Court, Greens Farms, Conn. She was 75 years old.

The Federal Reserve's credit policy was essentially easy during the week ended Wednesday, but there were signs as has been the case for the last month that the pace of monetary expansion has slowed somewhat from the high rate prevailing last summer.
WILMINGTON, Calif., Sept. 28 (UPI) Two persons died today and 72 were hospitalized after deadly chlorine gas escaped from a chemical plant here.

France's insistence at the International Monetary Fund meeting in Rio that the new arrangements for monetary reform not become effective until the United States eliminates its balance of payments deficit underlines the fragile nature of the plan to assure adequate liquidity to support continued expansion in world trade and investment. John W. Braun, a vice president of Loew's Hotels, collapsed and died, apparently of a heart attack, Tuesday night after leaving his office at 1540 Broadway. He was 48 years old and lived at the Drake Hotel, Park Avenue and 56th Street.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 President Johnson has agreed to weaken his gun control bill so as to improve its chances of getting through Congress.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 28 (UPI) Hank Bauer will be retained as manager of the Bal timore Orioles despite his club's dismal one-year drop from the top of the American League to the second division. The decision was announced today by Harry Dalton, the team's director of player personnel.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 28 Joseph S. Daltry, professor emeritus of music at Wesleyan University, died yesterday in his home at Haddam. He was 67 years old.
Maurice P. During, a realestate executive, died, of a heart attack last Friday in Spacva, Yugoslavia, where he was on a hunting trip. He was 67 years old and lived at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

A SHOW called the first of the 1968 model year in pleasure boats and their accompanying paraphernalia began yesterday at Chicago's vast International Amphitheatre while rain beat outside. It was the four-day Marine Trade Exhibit and Conference, an annual "trade only."

The Martin Marietta Corporation has appointed Robert M. Newman as its direcfor of real estate. The company manufactures missile and nuclear systems; in addition to industrial and construction materials.

ALBANY, Sept. 28 State Controller Arthur Levitt said tonight that he was reserving judgment on the proposed new state constitution but declared that two of its provisions could increase state costs by $1.1billion.
Three men who spent two weeks sawing their way out of the Dutchess County Jail in Poughkeepsie were captured in New York yesterday only 10 hours after they escaped.
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 28 James F. Cavanagh, a wellknown owner of show horses and hunters, died Monday at the Westchester Division of New York Hospital. He was 81 years old.

COMMACK, L.I., Sept. 28 Governor Rockefeller today directed his special counsel, Robert R. Douglass, to look into charges that Walter M. Conlon, a member of the State Tax Commission, was a "secret business associate" of an exconvict.
A tentative agreement between The Daily News and the New York Newspaper Guild was announced yesterday by Robert Keane, chief negotiator for the guild.

The city's teachers voted overwhelmingly yesterday at Madison Square Garden to ratify the new school contract and end the 14-day walkout that had disrupted education for more than a million public school pupils.

SAI ON, South Vietnam, Friday, Sept. 29 After more than two years of construction work, the new United States Embassy opened today. It has doors of solid teak, shatterproof Plexiglas windows, reinforced concrete walls and a massive terra cotta sun screen that will double as a blast shield.

ALMOST on the day of publication, Nathan Silver's "Lost New York," was proving its point. Prices were marked up yesterday on metals, chemicals and fibers. Further rises were posted for stainless steel, for alloys using copper or nickel, and for sulphuric acid, which is possibly the most widely used single chemical.

"Song of the Grasshopper" is worse than "Dr. Cook's Garden," which opened on Monday and closes tomorrow. I hope that this may be definitive but whether it is or not, at least we are building up standards of reference.
The Transamerica Corporation, which over the years has often been incorrectly identified as an airline because of its name, may now fill this description.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 95.8 on Wednesday, from 95.9 on Tuesday.
Trans World Airlines with its $18-million in annual advertising billings, is keeping Foote, Cone Belding as its advertising agency.
The election of Francis E. Dalton, formerly vice president and controller, as senior vice president of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation was announced yesterday.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Sept. 28 (UPI) Pacific 2, a $6-million switchboard satellite financed by thousands of investors, was reported in "good transfer orbit" tonight.
A BEAUTIFUL study of the need for heritage is em- bodied in "Father," a Hungarian film presented at the New York Film Festival at philharmonic Hall last evening.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 A pilot program to rehabilitate 1,000 dwelling units in a West Side Negro slum without increasing rents or displacing familes was announced today by Mayor Richard J. Daley and Robert C. Weaver, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.

WASHINGTGN, Sept. 28 (UPI) Americans will smoke 551 billion cigarettes this year, an average of 4,295 cigarettes or about 215 packs for every person of 18 years or older, the Agriculture Department said, today.
AMSTERDAM, Sept. 28 (UPI) Robert Hans van Gulik, a former Dutch Ambassador to Tokyo who used his knowledge of the Orient in writing a series of mystery novels, died here yesterday at the age of 57.

DETROIT, Sept. 28 Consumers are likely to spend more money around Christmas and early in 1968 than they did the year before on "postponable expenditures" such as cars, home appliances and fun according to a University of Michigan survey.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 President Johnson told his guests at the White House the other night that he had given up alcohol and taken up golf. This is alarming, if true, for in the present state of the world and the Presidency it really should be the other way around.
A letter in which George Washington complained of the "arrows of malevolence" aimed at him as the country's President, was sold at auction last night for $25,000.

NEWARK, Sept. 28 (AP) The chairman of President Johnson's commission investigating the summer's racial disorders toured the riot-scarred streets of Newark today and concluded that "there is a feeling of desperation and frustration among shopkeepers."

Proposals for decay in next Tuesday's state scholarship examination, in which high school seniors campete for state aid for college tuition, were turned down yesterday by both State Education Commissioner James E. Allen Jr. and the city Board of Education.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 28 Miss Susan Aronson's engagement to Abner Symons has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Stanley M. Aronson. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lionel Symons of New York and Long Beach, L.I.

The most disturbing note, as schools prepare for a return to normal operations today, is the belligerent and even seditious temper of a small faction in the Negro community. While the bitterness, with its dangerous overtones of anti-white racism, has been intensified by the irresponsible strike of the teacher's union, the trend had been well established long before the walkout.
Stock prices closed lower on balance for the third consecutive session yesterday after a modest display of firmness in early trading faded in an afternoon retreat.

Ed Conlin, the highest scorer in Fordham's basketball history, will replace Johnny Bach as head coach at the conclusion of the 1967-68 season, Dr. Martin J. Meade, the chairman of the athletic board, announced yesterday.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 28 Negotiations for the fusion of Israel's three labor parties broke down tonight. They collapsed with the decision of Rafi, one of the three groups, to break off negotiations.
Richard M. Nixon says he intends to pull out of the race for the Republican Presidential nomination if he is beaten in both the New Hampshire and Wisconsin primaries.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 (AP) Dick Farrell preserved a 2-1 victory today for Philadelphia over San Francisco by getting Willie Mays, a pinchhitter, to ground into a double play with the bases loaded and one out in the ninth inning.
Dr. Marshall McLuhan, the communications theorist, predicted yesterday that the United States wile have an economic depression in about five years because its youth lacks direction.

The Diamond International Corporation, a manufacturer of paperboard, fiber products, metal cans, automated packaging systems, plastics and wood products, reported yesterday increased earnings in the 12 and 36 week periods ended Sept. 10 despite a drop in sales.
GENEVA, Sept. 28 India today denounced as discriminatory and ineffective the draft treaty proposed by the United States and the Soviet Union to halt the spread of nuclear weapons.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 28 The situation at the University of Puerto Rico remained tense today following yesterday's violence.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 Three members of the Revolutionary Action Movement are to be arraigned tomorrow on charges of plotting to poison hundreds of policemen in the event of a riot here
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI) The House Public Works Committee approved today a measure that would ban just about any kind of demonstration on Capitol Hill.
Tomorrow, Monday and Tuesday are registration days in New York City.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 28 Through the imperfect wall of sanctions around Rhodesia, Britain is conducting an increasingly lively trade with her rebellious former colony, according to figures made public today by Rhodesia's Deputy Prime Minister, John Wrathall.

TIJUANA, Mexico, Sept. 28 (AP) The authorities said today that they had traced an insecticide blamed for mass poisonings of children here to a warehouse where bread ingredients are stored. They said that the outbreak was now under control.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 28 (Reuters) Informed sources said today that Indonesia had executed some of the officers who led the Communist-supported attempt to eize power almost exactly two years after the upheaval that plunged the nation into bloodbath.

IF there's anything Seventh Avenue loves, it's a party. Given the slightest excuse, designers and their satellites get dressed up to the teeth and venture out to admire one another's clothes, squeal welcomes to friends they met in garment district elevators a few hours before, and bestow kisses on familiar cheeks.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that construction would start in January on a 1,600-family apartment house complex over the Pennsylvania Railroad tracks on the West Side.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 28 The sculpture gardens at Joseph H. Hirshhorn's home here will be open to the public from 1 P.M. to 5 P.M. on Tuesday for the benefit of the Sarah Lawrence College Scholarship Fund. In case of rain, the tour will be held on Wednesday.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 28 (UPI) Federal troops were reported to have closed the pincers today on Enugu; capital of the breakaway eastern Region, and Maj. Gen. Yakubu Gowon, head of the federal government, appealed to the Easterners to lay down their arms.
A new approach to state transportation financing under which users of specific facilities would not have to bear the whole cost was outlined yesterday by Governor Rockefeller.
The following dispatch is by David Oancia of The Globe and Mail, Toronto.

State Attorney General Louis Lefkowitz said yesterday he had been in error when he testified that he had sought unsuccessfully to obtain from the secretary of State names of election committees that had failed to report campaign receipts and expenditures.
A 24-year-old man arrested early yesterday as a robbery suspect was said by the police to have been identified later by four women as the man who had raped and robbed them.

MIAMI, Sept. 28 (AP) Premier Fidel Castro told a large gathering in Havana's Plaza of the Revolution tonight that Cuba should get a Socialist constitution by 1970. The nation now is without a constitution.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 28-- J. Wolcott Brown of Sea Girt, N.J., played two-over par golf to eliminate Curtis Person of Millington, Tenn., 2 and 1, today in the second round of the 13th senior amateur championship of the United States Golf Association at the Shinnecock Golf Club.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 28 An Israeli proposal for economic cooperation with Arab nations was denounced by the Premier of Lebanon today as "deception and propaganda."

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 28-- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara met today with the defense chiefs of six nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to explain the reasoning behind the United States decision to deploy a "thin" missile defense around the country.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI) Representative Joe Pool called today for an investigation of Students for a Democratic Society, a college-level organization he labeled "a radical left-wing, anti-Vietnam war group."

"When Greek meets Greek," an old saying has it, "they open a restaurant." Nowadays when young American meets young American, they start a rock group. New York is plentifully supplied with "groups" at the moment (and as their teenybopper fans call them, groupies"), but this does not discourage new ones from streaming into town in search of public notice or a recording contract.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 President Johnson named five Negroes today to the new, nine-member District of Columbia City Council.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) A General Electric Company vice president told a House subcommittee today that the company had found all but about 1,000 of the 154,000 color television sets with tubes emitting potentially dangerous Xrays.
PARIS, Sept. 28 The continental sporting world is in an uproar today over the prospect that a bicycle speed record will be disqualified under anti-doping rules.
From inept start to ignominious finish, two would-be robbers bungled a holdup attempt at a Lexington Avenue savings and loan office yesterday.
LONDON, Sept. 28 (AP) David Exall, the administrative manager of Birmingham City, a British soccer team, is going to apply mini-skirted measures to a maximum problem rowdyism at league games.
School officials think that the walkout will cost the city $10million to $12-million in lost state aid.

MEMPHIS, Sept. 28 A Negro candidate for Mayor, said to be the first in modern times for a major Southern city, has mounted an active campaign in the white community only to encounter problems among voters of his own race.

The Sex Information and Education Council of the U.S. (SIECUS) will hold a cocktail reception and dinner in the Baroque Room of the Plaza on Oct. 16. Mrs. J. Noel Macy is chairman of the event, the proceeds of which will go to the council's education, publications and community services.
A pension fund has purchased the block-square receiving station of the Railway Express Agency, Inc., in the West Forties, and the seller took back a 20-year lease on the property.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 29 --President Johnson said this evening that he would halt the bombing of North Vietnam if such action would bring prompt, productive discussions and that he would "of course assume" that Hanoi would not take advantage of the cessation during the talks.
Air freight costs will continue to decline in the next decade as bigger planes with more efficient engines come into service, according to Robert W. Prescott, president of the Flying Tiger Line.

FARMINGTON, Conn., Sept. 29--Miss Judith Appleton Treadway, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Ingraham Treadway of Bristol, was married this afternoon to Philippe Lucien L'Ecuyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Pierre L'Ecuyer of Paris.
The Army announced yesterday it has awarded contracts totaling more than $243-million for ammunition and ordnance to support the war in Vietnam.

New York will have its own yacht race next month when a dozen or more schooners compete in the Mayor's Cup Race. Mayor Lindsay will view the race from the deck of the F. M. Schaefer Brewing Company's reproduction of the famous schooner yacht America and will present the cup to the winner at a dinner after the race.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 29 --A tow-truck operator was indicted today on 40 counts of billing Islip Town officials for towing away nonexistent abandoned cars.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 29--Nelson C. Osborne, who was president of the Osborne Trust Company here, was an early Mayor of the Village of East Hampton and was a supervisor in the nineteen-thirties of East Hampton Town, died yesterday in his home, 135 Main Street. His age was 79.
BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 29 (UP)--A grand jury today indicted Dalton Smith, a Louisiana businessman, for attemped bribery of a former aide of Gov. John J. McKeithen.
Three major lumber associations reported a decrease of 7 tenths of one per cent in production for the week ended Sept. 23, compared with the level in the corresponding 1966 week.

OSAKA, Japan, Sept. 29 (AP) --Ken Walsh, Debbie Meyer and Catie Ball of the United States had their names entered on swimming's world record list three times each today as the International Swimming Federation officially approved 60 world records.

NASHVILLE--The other afternoon several student leaders at Fisk University relaxed in the college's stately old administration building and tried to assess the impact of a riot that swept the campus six months ago.

From the outset, the military men who seized power in Greece last April based their case for support at home and abroad on the contention that they had to act to prevent a Communist takeover. WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 29-- John Chapman, the Canadianborn horseman who now makes his home here, could make a robust livelihood merely by driving Flamboyant. The 3-year-old Florican-Meg's Melody filly who defeated older trotters in 2:04 3/5 before 21,303 fans at Roosevelt Raceway tonight, never has lost with Chappie in the sulky.

BUCKPASSER--A Kentucky-bred son of Tom Fool and Busanda, this 4- year-old owned by Ogden Phipps is the third highest money-winner in history, back of the now retired Kelso and Round Table, with a bankroll of $1,440,454.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI)--Representative Joseph P. Addabbo, Democrat of Queen has appealed to President Johnson to back pending legislation that would set rules and standards to regulate aircraft noise.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 29--Prime Minister Ian D. Smith declared today that Rhodesians would be "stark, staring mad" to accept a settlement with Britain that would alter the political course of this former colony.

PARIS--Early in August, when everybody was supposed to be at the seashore, the moribund Paris bourse began to stir. To the mystification of those brokers still in town prices began to rise, volume picked up and a full-scale rally got under way.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29-- "I suppose it's a matter of semantics," an Army spokesman: said today in discussing the 60 soldiers who Senator Vance Hartke has charged "simply walked away" from Fort Ord in California last year.
Theodore C. Sorensen, counsel and confidant to President Kennedy, called yesterday for a broad expansion of trade between the United States and the Soviet Union.

The Methodist Board of Missions has voted to remove an investment portfolio valued at $10-million from the First National City Bank if the bank renews a credit arrangement with South Africa's apartheid Government.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29-- The Senate accepted an amendment to the antipoverty bill today directing the Controller General, as an agent of Congress, to investigate the programs of the Office of Economic Opportunity.
An English translation of the Roman Catholic Church's controversial new Dutch Catechism will be published here Oct. 31 by Herder Herder even though its American imprimatur has been withdrawn.

FOR some years now the Munich Bach Chorus and Orchestra has been blazing a trail in a new kind of Bach performance, one that tries to put together the best elements of the new and the old style of playing and singing Bach.
Pupil attendance was far below normal at many schools yesterday as regular classes resumed following the l4-day walkout by public school teachers.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 29--A fugitive gambler, whose United States passport had expired, arrived here in July on an Israeli travel permit, a police source revealed today.

ATLANTA, Sept. 29 (UPI)-- J.C. Goosie ignored his ailing back today while shooting a five-under-par 67 to share the lead with former Professional Golfers Association champion, Dave Marr, at the halfway mark of the $115,000 Atlanta golf classic.
MIAMI, Sept. 29 (AP)--Tom Sherman and Bob Campbell sparked Penn State to a 17-8 victory tonight over the University of Miami in the Orange Bowl.

DANVILLE, Va., Sept. 29-- Former Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama said today that he would "probably" agree to be nominated for President in 1968 at a "Wallace party" national convention in Miami immediately following the Republican and Democratic nominating conventions next August.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 29--Mr. and Mrs. E.H. Lederer of Syracuse and Big Moose have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lynn Lederer, to Michael Field Batcheller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robinson Campbell Batcheller of New York.
A 10-member citizens committee was appointed yesterday by Mayor Lindsay to analyze the city's 24-year-old residential rent-control law and its effects on tenants and owners.

The New York Yankees and the Kansas City Athletics, grinding out their final series of the American League baseball season, hustled through a remarkably quick twilight-night double-header last night at Yankee Stadium.
SALAMANCA, N.Y., Sept. 29 (AP)--The Allegany River ebbed today after a 28-hour downpour that touched off floods through western New York.
Negotiations between representatives of a broadcast technicians' union and the National Broadcasting Company continued last night.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 29--The Manhasset Bay Yacht Club defeated the Royal Norwegian Yacht Club, 50 to 35, this afternoon in the first official race of the Skoal Trophy competition.

Egypt bought 860,000 bushels of United States red wheat for October shipment yesterday and paid $1.25-million. It was the first sale by grain exporters here to Egypt since the start of the ArabIsraeli war.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 29--Miss Minette Dill Grand, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Grand, was married here this afternoon to Shepard Krech 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Krech of Easton, Md. The Rev. Dr. Arthur Lee Kinsolving, rector of St. James' Episcopal Church in New York, performed the ceremony in Christ Church. A reception followed at the Field Club.
Rudy Bruner, an industrialist, died of leukemia Wednesday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived at 22 East 10th Street.

Policemen and policewomen, using the teachers' walkout as a blessing in disguise, masqueraded as pickets for the United Federation of Teachers while gathering evidence that led to a raid yesterday on a suspected pornographic film processing plant in Queens.
TAPESTRIES are making a comeback after decades of neglect, and astute collectors are finding that fine 18thcentury examples are turning up on the American market.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 29 (AP)--President Johnson announced today that he had picked Vice Adm. John J. Hyland to replace the retiring. Adm. Roy L. Johnson as commander in chief of the Pacific Fleet.

A horse race that has been awaited with growing interest for the last month, the $107,800 Woodward Stakes will be run today at Aqueduct. Finally, as the thoroughbred aficionados would say, Dr. Fager will run against Damascus, and against Buckpasser and against Handsome Boy. There will be two others in the 1 -mile test, but they are of lesser status in the hippic scheme of things.
NASHVILLE, Sept. 29 (AP)-- Residents of metropolitan Nashville voted yesterday to end "brown bagging" by repealing a 58-year-old ban on restaurant sales of mixed drinks.
BOSTON, Sept. 29 (AP)-- Testimony was completed today in a pretrial hearing on a defense motion to have a Massachusetts ban on marijuana ruled unconstitutional.
The Internal Revenue Service was reported yesterday to be investigating contributions to Mayor Lindsay's and Senator Robert Kennedy's election campaigns.

Marshall E. Newton, assistant metropolitan editor of The New York Times and a member of the newspaper's staff for 44 years, was the guest of honor last night at a reception given by more than 200 fellow newspapermen and friends at The Lambs, 128 West 44th Street.
VIENNA, Sept. 29--West Germany suggested today a drastic limitation on the amount of inspection to be required under the proposed treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons.

PARIS, Sept. 29--Many in many different places will be reminded of Vladimir Ilyich Lenin on the 50th anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution next month. But the most irrelevant reminder of the Russian revolutionist happens to be a piece of clothing here named after him.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP)-- The Washington Senators eliminated Chicago from the American League pennant race tonight by defeating the White Sox, 1-0, behind the four-hit pitching of Phil Ortega and an unearned run in the first inning.
MACHINERY is now in operation to get brokerage houses to unwind transactions in two of the season's most spectacular scandals so that money can be returned to customers.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29-- Three men were held on $25,000 bail each at a preliminary arraignment before Judge Leo Weinrott today on charges of plotting to poison hundreds of policemen in the event of a riot here.
A city-sponsored campaign to raise funds for the establishment of five Youth Opportunities Creative Workshops on a year-round basis is under way.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Sept. 30--A 19-man subcommittee of the Constituent Assembly recommended today that the results of the Sept. 3 presidential election be voided because of "a pattern of fraud."

THE cause of preserving the country's wildlife from dangers of extinction received sensitive and determined support last night in Chet Hagan's first production for the National Broadcasting Company's new series, "American Profiles."
MADRID, Sept. 29--Fernando Arrabal Teran, the controversial Spanish playwright and novelist, was acquitted tonight of charges of blasphemy against God and calumny against Spain.
CUAVIET, South Vietnam, Sept. 28--At dawn five marines slipped quietly out of the camp and trudged in silence toward a muddy road.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29-- Senator Jacob K. Javits urged today that, to restore national unity on the Vietnam issue, a new Congressional resolution be adopted defining American policy and objectives in Southeast Asia.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 29 (AP)--A young man and woman have become the fifth and sixth persons indicted in the fatal stomping of Patrolman John V. Gleason Jr. during the racial disorders in Plainfield last July 16.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) --The Rev. James E. Groppi and five of his Milwaukee Youth Council commandos began a nine-day prayer-in for Federal and Milwaukee open housing laws today, despite a last-minute protest by a Negro leader.

ROME, Sept. 29--Pope Paul VI today warned the prelates he had summoned to advise him on church matters that the Roman Catholic Church confronted "immense dangers" from an irreligious modern mentality, even within its own ranks.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29 (AP)--A man whose wife gives birth to a child as result of artificial insemination may not be prosecuted if he fails to support the child, the California Court of Appeals ruled today.

Grand Central Terminal, recently declared a landmark, is one of the few remaining examples in New York of the noble use of stone and space for a substantial magnificence that our own day can neither match nor replace. WESTON, Conn., Sept. 29 (AP)--State and local police have made 13 arrests--mostly of teen-agers--in nacotics raids in four Fairfield County towns. They said today that more arrests were expected.

NASHVILLE, Sept. 29 (AP)-- The Davidson County grand jury said today that Herman Alvin McDaniel Jr., a Negro, had two other wives when he married a white woman here two months ago in Tennessee's first legal interracial marriage.

LONDON, Sept. 29 (AP)--A salvage expert announced today the finding of a British submarine that sank 42 years ago in the English Channel with the loss of her crew of 69. The Admiralty said it was opposed to any attempt to raise the craft.

The Maldive Islands, eighteen atolls in the Indian Ocean, has a population of 97,000. No disrespect for the 97,000 is intended in saying that their state, independent since 1965, cannot possibly play a full role in the United Nations.
BONN, Sept. 29--Klaus Schutz, State Secretary in the West German Foreign Ministry, will run for Mayor of West Berlin at a convention of the divided city's ruling Social Democratic party on Oct. 15.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 29 --The 106 member nations of the International Monetary Fund approved unanimously today a major reform of the world monetary system.
McCall's magazine signed a contract yesterday with Walter Winchell, the columnist, for a serialization of his memoirs.
The Association of the Bar of the City of New York reported yesterday that the public made--and sustained-- more charges than ever last year against lawyers for professional misconduct.

Angelo, son of Mrs. Arthur Cowen Jr. of New York and Elberon, and the late Harry Angelo 3d. The Rev. George R. Callahan performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church.

IN Merrill Joan Gerber's new novel, a man dies slowly, painfully, pointlessly. Miss Gerber anatomizes this passing in unaffected, realistic terms that blink at neither horror nor sentiment. What AN ANTIQUE MAN (Houghton Mifflin, $4.95) does with chilling effectiveness is to show exactly where the sting of death is: in the heartless bureaucracy of a hospital; in the ghastly commercialism of a cemetery salesman; in the grotesquerie of a funeral eulogy.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 30-- Gov. Ronald Reagan of California said today that he had not yet made a final decision about explicitly removing himself from passive competition in the Republican Presidential primary in Wisconsin next year.

WASHINGTON--Across the poker tables in Washington hotel rooms, in the lobbies of Capitol Hill and now in the back rooms of the Whlte House, a byzantine power struggle is being waged over the nomination of a new commandant of the Marine Corps.

SALTA, Argentina, Sept 28 --Until this year, a young man from the northwestern provinces of Salta and Jujuy who wanted a university education was forced to travel hundreds of miles for it. Usually, he would go to Buenos Aires, where he would fall in love with the city and a girl, marry the girl and never return home.

ISLIP, L.I., Sept. 30--New York City Council President Frank D. O'Connor proposed today that the area's three major airports--Kennedy, La Guardia and Newark--be removed from control of the Port of New York Authority and be run by an agency with less "internal con flict."

Peace-making in the Middle East came to a dead stop in the General Assembly last week. Israel, dug in behind one diplomatic position, confronted the United Arab Republic and its allies, entrenched in their position. Each side, convinced that time was on its side, appeared prepared to fight it out on the present diplomatic line if it takes all winter--as it may.

Mrs. Helen Vlachos was 23 years old when she went to work as a reporter for her father, George, one of Greece's leading newspaper publishers. Like the father, who often was imprisoned for political reasons, the daughter was strongly opinionated and a stanch champion of freedom.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 30--Lord Caradon of Britain conferred with Secretary General Thant today on subjects that he said included the possibility of a new Security Council meeting on the problems of the Middle East.

Soon after he became President in 1901 the story goes, Theodore Roosevelt was on a hunting trip when he sighted a bear guarding her cub. The President, a noted conservationist, was struck by the bear's protective manner, refused to shoot and ordered everyone in his party not to harm the animals.

In staccato fashion last week, Teledyne, Inc., dropped its plan to acquire the United Insurance Company of America through an exchange of shares, and substituted a tender offer to United Insurance stockholders.
