The Hundred Year Association of New York awarded its gold medal for outstanding achievement last night to John A. Coleman, philanthropist and senior partner in Adler, Coleman Co., stock brokers at its 35th annual dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

MOSCOW, Oct. 3 (UPI) The Soviet Union marked the eve of the 10th birthday of the space age tonight by launchng a new type of communications satellite that it hoped would transmit television programs to the Soviet Far East and possibly Paris.
TWO points need to be made at the outset about Harold Pinter's "The Birthday Party," which opened at the Booth Theater last night.
With modern surgical techniques, post-operative scars sometimes cannot be detect
Governor Rockefeller has been quietly letting it be known that he no longer wholeheartedly supports President Johnson's policy in Vietnam. Up to now, Mr. Rockefeller
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 3 Lady Gaitskell of Britain suggested today that knowledge about birth control should be recognized by the United Nations as one of the basic human rights of women.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 3 (UPI) Gov. Raymond P. Shafer of Pennsylvania ordered several units of the National Guard on standby alert tonight and placed all available state police on 16-hour shifts in an effort to put down violence associated with a seven-week strike by owner-operators of steel-hauling trucks.
VIENNA, Oct, 3 Erich RaJakovic returned to Austria to day after having dodged the Yugoslav police.
THE world of tournament bridge suffered a great loss 11 days ago when Alvin Landy died in Atlantic City.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 The Treasury announced the results late today of its sales of two issues of tax-anticipation bills.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP)-- Following is the roll-call vote by which the House approved today a motion to consider an emergency appropriation resolution without an amendment requiring the President to cut Federal spending at least $5-billion:
The sky lit up in brilliant colors southwest of New York City last night but it was not an off-course aurora borealis or Martians it was a scientific probe into the atmosphere.

BOSTON, Oct. 3 Stan Mu- sial, proud and delighted to be the general manager who guided the St. Louis Cardinals into the World Series, received an un- expected bonus today when it developed that he would most likely get into the Baseball Hall of Fame a year earlier than ex- pected.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Oct. 3 (UPI) A woman from Miami, Fla., who lost her husband in a jet crash at Hendersonville, N.C., last July has sued three air travel concerns for $1-million, charging lax operating procedures.

LA PAZ, Bolivia The trial of Regis Debray, an adventurous young French intellectual who sets himself up as an ideologue for Latin-American revolution, has become a cause celebre. Its importance transcends the legal issues at stake.
TRENTON, Oct. 3 The State Racing Commission selected Jersey Downs, Inc., today to bring big-time night harness racing to northern New Jersey.
KYOTO, Japan, Oct. 3 The International Criminal Police Organization, better known as Interpol, voted unanimously today to oppose the legalization marijuana.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 3 Israel called on the Arab countries today for a peace based on the recognition that all past agreements had been shattered and on a renunciation of belligerency by the Arabs.

The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, the nation's largest food chain, showed increased sales and earnings for the three and six months ended Aug. 26, according to the concern's report issued yesterday.

Southern California, which added a 21-17 victory over Michigan State last week to its opening triumph over Texas, moved into first place in both news service listings of the top college football teams this week. Notre Dame, the No. 1 team until upset by Purdue, 2821, fell more than halfway down the lists.

WNEW-TV (Channel 5) has acquired a tape of the Canadian television program on which the Right Rev. James A. Pike, resigned Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of California, participated in a s ance during which he believes he made contact with his dead son.
The appointment of Frank A. Bailey as general, manager of the Puerto Rico division of Sea-Land Service, Inc., has been announced.

The New York Clearing House Association yesterday named John F. Lee as executive vice president. Mr. Lee, who is general counsel of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, succeeds Paul R. Fitchen, who retires Dec. 1 after 10 years in the post.

The 695 yards gained by Houston in its 50-6 football victory over Wake Forest last Friday night has propelled the Cougars into a commanding lead in total offense among the nation's major colleges, according to statistics issued yesterday.

BY his strong play for the Giants last Sunday, Tucker Frederickson has convinced the man who had to be convinced his coach, Al Sherman that he once again is an offensive football player of some magnitude.
The Long Island University soccer team routed C.W. Post yesterday, 4-0, at the L.I.U. field in Brooklyn. It was L.I.U.'s second victory in the Metropolitan Conference and its third over all.

FRANKLIN LAKES, N.J., Oct. 3 John E. Ackerman Jr., president of the Arrow Carrier Corporation of Carlstadt, an interstate trucking concern, died on Sunday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Paterson. He was 45 years old and liked at 744 Paiute Place.
UNITED NATIONS N.Y., Oct. 3 The Netherlands proposed today that the United Nations adopt an international development charter committing rich and poor countries to a global plan against poverty.

The Amphenol Corporation, a Chicago-based producer of electronic components, announced yesterday that it had urged the Securities and Exchange Commission and the New York Stock Exchange to investigate the recent heavy trading in its stock.
A leading retailer urged merchants and manufacturers yesterday to pay greater attention to the changing patterns of consumer shopping. I

Gaetano Bardini, an Italian tenor with a good Italian sound, made his New York City Opera debut last night as Turiddu in Mascagni's "Cavalleria Rusticana." The opera was given at the New York State Theater on a double-bill with Leoncavallo's "Pagliacci."
DETROIT, Oct, 3 The National Traffic Safety Bureau says automobile makers have reported safety-related defects in a possible 31,161 of their 1968 automobiles, it was learned today.

A number of additional petroleum and chemical companies announced yesterday they were cutting the price of benzene by 2 cents a gallon. Benzene, a chemical used widely in the production of rubber plastics and fibers, has an annual volume of nearly 1 billion pounds.
EAST LEVERETT, Mass., Oct. 3 Roger C. Garis, writer of numerous radio and television scripts, died on Saturday in the Norwalk, Conn., General Hospital. He was 66 years old.

WALL STREET pundits copper-stock department were asked to evaluate the outlook yesterday following Senator Mike Mansfield's speech urging action to end the 12-week strike that has virtually halted United States copper production.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) A bill to require a health warning label on alcoholic beverages similar to that required on cigarettes was introduced today in the Senate.

Tennessee Williams, Truman Capote and Janet Flanner, the writers, were among more than 200 people who attended a funeral service here yesterday for Carson McCullers, the author, who died last Friday at the age of 50.

A petition signed by 241 Peace Corps volunteers working in Brazil and calling for the United States to seek "a negotiated settlement instead of a military solution" in Vietnam has been received by The New York Times.
Negro demands during the recent teacher walkout that the slum schools be kept open contrasted with Negro demands less than four years ago that these schools be either integrated or shut.

The Chemical Bank New York Trust Company, one of New York's and the nation's largest banks, reported yesterday record net operating earnings for the third quarter and for the first nine months of 1967.

MEMPHIS, Oct. 3 (AP) Bailey Howell dropped in 4 points in the overtime period tonight and led the Boston Celtics to a 114-112 National Basketball Association exhibition game victory over the St. Louis Hawks.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 3 Columbia has not beaten Princeton in a varsity football game since the "Goal Dust" twins, Gene Rossides and Lou Kesserow, were hitting pay dirt for Lou Little in 1945. But to hear Coach Dick Colman talk, the Tiger will have to come up with a super performance Saturday to keep its winning sequence going.

Interco, Inc., the largest domestic manufacturer of footwear, is planning to enter the men's sportswear business through the acquisition of the Campus Sweater and Sportswear Company of Cleveland for stock with a market value of more than $15-million.
MINEOLA, Oct. 3 The New York State Commission for Human Rights found today that the all-white Glen Cove voluteer fire department had discriminated against two Negro applicants.
DETROIT, Oct. 3 (UPI) The nationwide strike against the Ford Motor Company will probably force closing of all its Canadian operations by this weekend, the company announced today.
BRISBANE, Australia, Oct. 3 (UPI)-- A 43-year-old Dutch woman swam through sharkinfested waters yesterday, supporting her 4-year-old son for three hours without realizing he had died.

HER arms strapped to a highwire, a model in a purple and silver polka dot jumpsuit sailed through the air in the Electric Circus discotheque Monday night and landed in the arms of a man dressed as a gorilla.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 The House Ways and Means Com- mittee abruptly laid aside today the Administration's pro- posal for a 10 per cent tax surcharge until Congress and the President reach an agreement on spending cuts.
DETROIT, Oct. 3 Sales of 1968 automobiles were off to a fast start, the Detroit car makers reported today.
Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year, begins today at sundown.

The State and Defense Departments have made one good case and one bad one in their extraordinary joint appeal to the Senate-House conference committee against restrictions in the foreign aid bill for fiscal 1968.
A State Supreme Court justice sharply criticized the Board of Education yesterday for what he charged was the abandoning of its "responsibilities and prerogatives" to community groups.
Issues on the American Stock Exchange advanced in active trading yesterday. The market opened firmer and increased its gains until the last half-hour when profit taking trimmed some earlier advances.
GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 3 An 11-year-old girl died here last night after inhaling an aerosol spray designed to frost cocktail glasses.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 3 Two green jeeps equipped with loudspeakers are touring the villages of the Anatolian Plateau this fall in an effort to promote the Turkish Government's official policy of birth control.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Oct. 3 "If there ever was a day for scoring this was it," said Terry Wilcox after retaining a threestroke lead in the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship today.

BOSTON, Oct. 3 The last time the Red Sox were in a World Series was 21 years ago and that one also was against the St. Louis Cardinals. It did not end happily for the Boston idolators, because their heroes were nipped just before the end of the seventh game as the hard-running Enos Slaughter ignored the stop sign flashed by the third base coach and hurtled home with the winning run.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 President Johnson nominated Howard J. Samuels, the New York industrialist, as Under Secretary of Commerce today.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 3 (UPI) Impressive, the 1966 sprint champion, showed some of his old form at Atlantic City today, winning the $5,500 feature race by five lengths.

An immediate cease-fire between troops of the Nigerian Government and forces of the secessionist former Eastern Region, which declared its independence as the Republic of Biafra on May 30, was urged yesterday by the Committee for Biafran Refugees, a private American group organized last summer.
John H. Whelen, an international investment banker, died Sunday in London of a heart attack. He was 70 years old and lived at 1 East 62d Street.
"A SCULPTURE was unveiled yesterday afternoon in front of the Law School Building on the campus of Columbia University. To no one's surprise, it was a work of Henry Moore.

TOKYO, Oct. 3 (AP) Gary Player of South Africa fired a three-under-par 33, 36-69 at the Kasumigaseki Country Club course today to win the first of three matches over Arnold Palmer and Jack Nicklaus in the "Big Three of Golf in Japan" series.
LONDON, Oct. 3 Sir Malcolm Sargent, the most popular of British conductors, died at his home here today. His age was 72.
JUST 10 years ago today, on October 4, 1957, the Soviet Union thrust man into the space age.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 Despite serious opposition from the United States, France has achieved an important breakthrough in the export of arms to Latin America with two major sales.

THE popularity of the paintings of Andrew Wyeth was the subject last night of a virtually unqualified television appreciation at 10:30 P.M. over the Columbia Broadcasting System. The comeuppance to the soup-can school of art and the public relish of the Wyeth works that can be comprehended by what is shown were presented on "Who, What, Where, When, Why" over Channel 2, with Harry Reasoner serving as curator.
The American Broadcasting Company filed a $2-million damage suit in State Supreme Court yesterday against Mel Brandt, president of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists.

MOSCOW, Oct. 3 (Reuters) Soviet sources said tonight that the Government was ready to offer large-scale economic aid to Jordan to help the reconstruction efforts of that proWestern Arab kingdom in the wake of the Middle Eastern war.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 3 Brig. Gen. John S. Allard, U.S.A.F., retired, a veteran of both World Wars and a former vice president of the CurtissWright Corporation, died today in Lawrence Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 9 Midland Gardens.

AS a rather lonely explorer of the American dilemmas of poverty amid great wealth and discrimination against Negroes, Karl Gunnar Myrdal looked ahead 23 years ago and predicted this country's racial crisis in terms that today are common language among sociologists.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 Senator J.W. Fulbright indicated today that the Senate Foreign Relations Committee was prepared to recommend approval of a United States subscription of up to $200-million to the special fund of the Asian Development Bank.

SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 3 (Reuters) President Chung Hee Pak today reshuffled the South Korean Cabinet, appointing Pak Chung Hun, the Minister of Commerce and Industry, as Deputy Premier and Economics Minister.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) Col. Robin Olds, top Air Force pilot in the Vietnam war, said today that a simple way to stop the war was to win it and suggested that the United States was going about the job the hard way.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 3 (UPI) Eugene Connor, former Police Commissioner of Birmingham, Ala., said in an interview today that many deaths in Northern riots would have been averted if the police had used dogs, as he did during Birmingham's racial troubles of 1963.
BOSTON, Oct. 3 (AP) The St. Louis Cardinals had their first look at Fenway Park today, but the National League champions weren't talking about the short left-field fence.

A larger turnout on the second day of local registration in New York City added 74,457 Persons to the list of qualified voters for the Nov. 7 election. The two-day total of new registrants was 136,344.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 North Vietnam rejected today the Johnson Administration's offers of peace talks and vowed to continue the combat in the South unabated.
SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 3 (AP) Kim Ki-Soo of South Korea successfully defended his world junior middleweight title tonight, scoring a disputed 15round split decision over Fred Little of New Orleans.

ALBANY, Oct. 3 (AP) The Consolidated Edison Company says the New York City Housing Authority failed to substantiate its charge that the utility's controversial rate increase showed it to be inefficient in its management.
The Civil Aeronautics Board will propose new rules that would permit conbination air carriers to sell blocked space for cargo shipments, an agency spokesman said yesterday.

MUNICH, Germany, Oct. 3 (Reuters) A Munich prosecutor was investigating today a report that a former Nazi SS official, who is now under arrest, shot Stalin's eldest son, Yakov, in a concentration camp during World War II.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct 3--A warning by the Yugoslav police that he was not to leave the seaside town where he was vacationing apparently tipped off Erich Rajakovic, a wartime aide of the late Adolt Eichmann, that arrest was imminent and enabled him to escape. escape.
Geneva, Oct. 3 Sweden expressed concern at the Geneva disarmament conference today over the United States decision to deploy an antiballistic missile system.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 3-- Diplomats here are worried about increasing tensions between the black African nations and the white-dominated states of southern Africa.
Luring a factory into a slum is no easy job. Aside from the hypothetical danger of riots which might destroy or damage the plant, there is a more immedi
Oakland, Calif. Curtis Cokes, 145 pounds, Dallas, knocked out Charlie Shipes, 145 pounds, Oakland, 8 rounds. Cokes retained world welterweight title.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 President Johnson composed his political epitaph today but in a way that suggested he would rather run than retire with it.
Federal funds are to be cut off from Syracuse's antipoverty agency, the Office of Economic Opportunity said through its Northeast regional office here last night.

There were two other agencies invited to present speculative campaigns for the Trans World Airlines account besides the eight agency giants who did compete. The two smaller shops declined to run, but for different reasons.
The excitement of a pennant race helped the Boston Red Sox accumulate the largest increase in attendance in major league baseball this season.

THE American Road Race of Champions, the world's largest sports car event with more than 400 drivers in action, has gained two new sponsors the Newspaper Enterprise Association and Nine Flags International, a manufacturer of shaving colognes and foam. Their participation

Boston has its Beacon Hill; Philadelphia has Society Hill; Washington has Georgetown, and New York has Brooklyn Heights, a fifty-block treasure trove of eighteenth and nineteenth century architecture, brooding over the East River and lower Manhattan from a bluff on the western tip of Long Island.

Seven City College students were suspended yesterday in the second day of student demonstrations to save campus lawns and trees threatened by the construction of temporary prefabricated classrooms and offices. They face possible expulsion.
STEUBENVILLE, Ohio, Oct. 3 (UPI) This Ohio River industrial area was declared today a "traffic and transportation disaster area" by city officials.

WILLIAM STYRON'S new novel, "The Confessions of Nat Turner" (Random House, $6.95), is told entirely through the imagined mind of the historical Nat Turner, a Virginia slave who, in 1831, led the only effective and sustained revolt in the annals of American Negro slavery.
The Markets Department said yesterday that a spot check of 21 milk plants serving the city had turned up short measures in paper containers distributed by 10 of the companies.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 3 The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has been awarded a major contract to supply the nuclear reactor, nuclear fuel and turbine generator for an 800,000 kilowatt nuclear power plant to be built at Shippingport, Pa.
NORTHPORT, L. I., Oct. 3 Dr. Artur Krell, a psychiatrist, died Friday in St. John's Smithtown Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 29 Normandy Drive here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 A spokesman for the nation's railroads told the Interstate Commerce Commission here today that unless the carriers soon can establish a better relationship between their "escalating labor costs" and their declining manpower requirements, "they are going to be in for some real trouble."
EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Oct. 3 (AP) Maj. William J. Knight of the Air Force flew 4,534 miles an hour today in an X-15 rocket plane with a dummy ramjet engine bolted beneath its tail.

Mrs. June Blossom, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Francis Blossom of New York and Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Walter Terence Pawling of 360 East 72d Street and Pawling, N.Y.

The City Council attacked and ridiculed Mayor Lindsay's record on housing for two hours yesterday, then voted 29 to 3 to restore $10-million in housing funds that it "had cut from his capital budget last spring.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ordered a district court today to reconsider a decision that prevented the Overseas Weekly from being circulated on post exchanges in the Pacific.
LUXEMBOURG, Oct. 3-- New delays appear likely in writing an inspection section into the draft treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons.

Mrs. Eleanor Heller of 176 East 71st Street and Herbert C. Heller of New York and Nantucket, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Mary Heller Jaffee, to C. Hugh P. Silk of New York, formerly of Aldwick, Sussex, England. Mr. Silk is assistant to the headmaster and head of the upper school at the Collegiate School.

The board of the McCall Corporation elected Henry Bowes yesterday as president and chief executive officer. He replaces Arthur R. Murphy Jr., who takes the newly created post of chairman of the executive committee.

The old passenger-cargo liner Exochorda, in mothballs in the Government reserve fleet at Jones Point, N.Y., is to start down the Hudson River this morning. But her engine will have no steam, and she will not be going very far.
James King Son, a 67-year-old construction concern based in New York, has elected P.L. Griffith as its president and chief executive officer.

PROPER Bostonians, and it is assumed many are Harvard men, have been shaken to their broad A's by World Series frenzy. Even the Crimson's football team has fallen victim to the upheaval, which will be reflected at the gate in its contest Saturday with Boston University at Harvard
The Arthritis Foundation will present its Floyd B. Odlum award next Tuesday to Mrs. Edward F. Hartung, chairman of the New York chapter's women's division.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 3 Israel asserted today that there were 288,000 fewer refugees under her control than are listed by the United Nations Relief and Works Agency. The figures were based on a census last month in the areas captured during the Israeli-Arab war in June.
An injunction that would have forbidden Leroy Ellis to play with the Baltimore Bullets of the National Basketball Association was denied yesterday in New York State Supreme Court.
An exhibition of "integrated" sculpture to dance through, play music through, read poetry on and simply to look at, got under way yesterday at Bryant Park.

BOSTON, Oct. 3 A politi- cal advertisement in The Boston Globe this morning read: "Carl Yastrzemski for Mayor of Boston." In smaller letters, the ad continued: "In 1975." And below that: "Kevin White Candidate for Mayor of Boston 1967."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 Gunnar Myrdal, the Swedish social philosopher, said today that America must attend to its white as well as its Negro poor or run the risk of a policy of racism comparable to South Africa's.
The New York Telephone Company again will furnish scores of all World Series games. The number is 6371212, the company's time bureau.
The city went on an air-pollution watch yesterday as tem peratures reached into the 80's and a stagnant mass of air set- tled Over the Eastern Seaboard.

The Philadelphia Orchestra's all-Beethoven concert last night at Carnegie Hall did not look particularly exciting on paper. That is the way it turned out. Well-played, interpretatively all of a piece, but exciting, almost never.

Airlift International, Inc., has applied to the Civil Aeronautics Board for authority to provide a new all-cargo service to five cities along the southern transcontinental route, James B. Franklin, president of the carrier, announced yesterday.
Ellen Stewart's Cafe La Mama and Charles Stanley's Caffe Ciho are the first places that come to mind when you hear the phrase "Off-Off Broadway."
Mark McMillan, an engineer for the Shell Oil Company, 50 West 50th Street, died of an apparent heart attack yesterday in Grand Central Station. He was 37 years old and lived in Weston, Conn.
LUCERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 3 Plans for an all-out effort to understand the world's weather, far more ambitious than any hitherto attempted, were presented to the scientific community here today.

AWARE that theater buffs are almost as common as colds in our culture, Bloomingdale's is ringing up the curtain today on a dramatic display of fashion and home furnishings that will run through the middle of the month.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) A physicist displayed an electro-gas-dynamics model here today and said it could solve the growing crisis in electric power needs and reduce air and water pollution.

A collection of more than 500 rare books, manuscripts and drawings, including a first edition of Walt Whitman's "Leaves of Grass" and a letter to Whitman by Ralph Waldo Emerson, has been presented to Columbia University.

The stock market tapped but a modest advance yesterday in a session that was punctuated by sharp gains for several glamour stocks and specialsituation issues. Price advances on the New York Stock, Exchange held a relatively thin lead over declines at the close, with 673 stocks up from Monday's close and 591 down.

PEKING, Oct. 3 (Agence France Presse) Although stripped of power, Liu Shaochi, the nominal chief of state, Teng Hsiao-ping, who was the Communist party General Secretary, before he came under attack, and Tao Chu, who led the Central Committee's Cultural Revolution group, continue to receive their usual salaries and lead an apparently normal life.
The law firm of Delson Gordon has taken a long-term lease carrying an aggregate rental of more than $1.5-million on office space in the New York General Building at 230 Park Avenue.
William McChesney Martin Jr. has been described as the most durable object on the Potomac except for J. Edgar Hoover.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 3 (UPI) District Attorney Jim Gar rison objected today to either a six-month delay or a change in location for the trial of Clay L. Shaw.

Former Criminal Court Judge Benjamin H. Schor was arrested yesterday on a 10-count indictment accusing him of lying to a grand jury last year in an investigation into an alleged liquor-license shakedown.
American Export Isbrandtsen Lines, Inc., has made two changes in its top management, A. Theodore DeSmedt, president of the steamship line, announced yesterday.
The Moscow Circus arrived in town yesterday-eight truckloads of props and animals, a planeful of people, a bundle of ebullience and some small parcels of apprehension.

BLYTHE, Calif., Oct. 3 (UPI) The main highway connecting California and Arizona was closed today when a trailer loaded with a deadly, pesticide, menthyl parathion, overturned and the liquid spilled out.
The life insurance industry has taken on eight rent-subsidy housing projects under its new commitment to invest $1-bil lion in slum housing and industry.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 3 (AP) Gov. Ronald Reagan defended today the use of minimum security convicts to help harvest California crops and said that labor union critics of the action "remind me of a dog sitting on a sharp rock howling with pain who is too stupid to get up."

The state law making it a crime to possess marijuana for one's own use was challenged yesterday on the ground that the state had no power to punish a person for activities that did not harm or interfere with others.

For two decades now the proper Bostonian Red Sox have endured some of the ills besetting the United States including rising urban unrest among onceloyal citizenry and dwindling popularity in games played abroad.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 For the third successive week, a meeting of the House Administration Committee to consider election reform legislation was called off today.
Frank D. O'Connor, the president of the City Council, said last night that the price of settling the 14-day teachers' walkout was $156.1-million-- not $135,4-million, as reported by Mayor Lindsay.

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that he had submitted legislation to the City Council to aid sidewalk newsdealers who were suffering economic losses owing to the death of five major newspapers here in the last four years.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 The Johnson Administration listed five cities and a rural area today as possible sites for the start of its effort to enlist private help to attack "hard core" unemployment.
PARIS, Oct. 3 President de Gaulle and his critics blamed each other today for the violence by farmers that took a heavy toll yesterday.
Longshoremen in scattered areas of the port staged protests yesterday against the industry's insistence on reducing the size of the work gang by one man.
CHICAGO, Oct. 3-- A 35year-old surgeon who has no more fats in his blood than a new-born baby, told the 53d annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons today how he got that way.

MOSCOW, Oct. 3 The Blue Scarf gang of Azerbaijan has been broken up, Izvestia reported today, in an article that treated with unusual humor a major example of what the Soviet Union calls an economic crime.
Sterling traded in New York lost two points on the spot rate against the dollar yesterday. The pound closed at $2.7842, against $2.7844 a day earlier.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 3 State Representative Carl B. Stokes, a Negro, won the Democratic nomination for Mayor tonight over the incumbent, Ralph S. Locher.
Woody Guthrie, the American folk singer and composer, died yesterday at Creedmoor State Hospital, Queens, following a 13-year illness. He was 55 years old.

Willie Shoemaker and Braulio Baeza rode Aqueduct winners yesterday, but the big man at the Big A was a 39-yearold jockey who weighs 132 pounds, goes to work at 6 o'clock in the morning and makes less in a championship year than they pay their agents.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 3 Anti-Government agitation ebbed today following the Con stituent Assembly's ratification last night of the Sept. 3 election.

ROME, Oct. 3 Two prominent European Cardinals maintained today that Roman Catholic Church law should be general and pastoral in nature and should leave room for a kind of ecclesiastical "state's rights" for the individual churches in relation to Rome.

A top official of the Johnson Administration rejected yesterday Congressional demands for a $5-billion cut in Federal spending as the "price" for enactment of the President's proposed 10 per cent surcharge on individual and corporate income taxes.

PIKEVILLE, Ky., Oct. 3 (AP) A Pike, Circuit Judge, Charles Lowe, said today that five persons, must stand trial for sedition this week even though the state sedition law had been ruled unconstitutional.
BROWNSVILLE, Tex., Oct. 3 (AP) Hurricane Fern weakened today as it continued on a course that would bring it to the mainland north of Tampico, Mexico, sparing the Texas coast.

ALBANY, Oct. 3 The appointment of Dr. Wim van Eekeren to the new $27,500a-year post of executive director of the New York State Narcotic Addiction Control Commission was announced today by Lawrence W. Pierce, commission chairman.

A native of Hungary whose hobby of painting has influenced the city's use of art in public buildings has been appointed the city's director of architecture, Public Works Commissioner Eugene E. Hult announced yesterday.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 3 (UPI) Horace Greeley's century-old advice "Go west, young man?" received statistical support from the Midwest Research Institute today.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 4 (AP)-- Highly favored Nevele Pride became the world's fastest 2-year-old trotter today as he won the $8,662 Saul Camp Memorial at the Lexington harness track.

CAIRO, Thursday, Oct. 5 (Agence France-Presse) The former chief of the Egyptian intelligence services, Salah Nasr, has been arrested after questioning in connection with the reported suicide last month of Field Marshal Abdel Hakim Amer, the authoritative newspaper Al Ahram reported today.

NORTHFIELD, N.J., Oct. 4 (UPI) Marge Mason of West Englewood, N.J., fired a fourover-par 77 today to take the first-round lead in the 54-hole United States Golf Association's senior women's amateur tournament at the Atlantic City Country Club.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) Owners of three models of Aero Commander aircraft have been urged to check immediately for wing cracks. The warning followed a Government investigation of a light plane crash at Dallas Sept. 27 in which seven persons were killed.

The engagement of Miss Patricia Ann Boyle to John F. Conroy has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward P. Boyle of Jackson Heights, Queens. Mr. Conroy is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Conroy, also of Jackson Heights.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Oct. 4 (UPI) A Federal grand jury charged 13 bakery corporations, 13 individuals ad a trade association with conspiracy to fix the prices of bread and other baked goods in Michigan today.
PARIS, Oct. 4 Two out of six local assemblies in the Paris region elected Communists as presidents today, and a third may follow suit.

THE game that virtually decided first place in the re cent Dundee (Scotland) Centenary tournament was a bitterly fought Nimzo-Indian Defense between the grand masters Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia and Bent Larsen of Denmark.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 4 Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Gimber have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Frazer Gimber to Stephen Paul O'Neill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold J. O'Neill.
DETROIT, Oct. 4 Detroit Police Commissioner Ray Girardin offered his resignation to Mayor Jerome P. Cavanagh today.
The Military Sea Transportation Service has invited United States ocean carriers to submit bids for moving military cargoes from east coast ports to various Caribbean ports and the Canal Zone.

Governor Rockefeller released yesterday, without comment, some staggering figures on what the new Constitution would cost. The estimated price tag is an important contribution to the debate on the Constitution's acceptance, but its publication falls short of the kind of leadership the state has a right to expect of its Governor.
BOSTON, Oct. 4 The first game of the World Series, won today by the St. Louis Cardinals from the Boston Red Sox, 2-1, turned out to be more soporific than terrific.

RICHMOND, Oct. 4 (AP) H. Rap Brown's attorneys asked a Federal appeals court today to ease travel restrictions imposed on the black power advocate last month by United States District Judge Robert Merhige Jr.
Huntington Hartford took the offensive again yesterday against the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, Inc., and used the pages of his favorite magazine to do it.
MOSCOW, Oct. 4 (Reuters) The Soviet Union and Jordan have signed an agreement on cultural and scientific cooperation, the Soviet press agency Tass announced tonight.
The teachers union and its president were found guilty yesterday of criminal contempt for disobeying a court order prohibiting the recent walkout by city teachers.

JAMESTOWN, N.D. If you drive through this town on an autumn day, there is nothing that seems to distinguish it from a hundred other prairie communities in America. There are low-lying buildings, two-story homes, immaculate, tree-lined streets and a railroad station in the heart of town.

BOSTON, Oct. 4 A stranger wandered in Boston this afternoon, and had he not known that Destiny's Darlings, the Cinderella team of Rico and Yaz, had brought the bunting to Beantown, he might have thought it was just the middle of a week in autumn.

TAPPAN, N.Y., Oct. 4 The engagement of Miss Regina Coen, to George L. Nye Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Nye of Upper Montclair, N.J., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas J. Coen.

If George Wallace is in the 1968 Presidential race as a third-party candidate and if there is more rioting in the cities next summer, white backlash is sure to be a major factor in the 1968 political campaign.

RATNA SARI DEWI SUKARNO fluttered the lashes ("I wear false eyelashes, who doesn't?") that shade her walnut-shaped eyes ("I did not have them fixed there are a lot of round eyes in Tokyo") and said she believed in quality, rather than quantity, in fashion.

NYACK, N.Y., Thursday, Oct. 5 Six persons were arrested and two policemen injured early today when policemen and sheriff's deputies tried to quell firebombing and rock-throwing disturbances on South Franklin Street, in the predominantly Negro section of Nyack.

ATHENS, Oct. 4 Helen Vlachos, a rightist Athens publisher who termed the members of Greece's ruling military junta "mediocrities," was put under house arrest today. Hers was the second defiant voice to be silenced in 48 hours by Athens's 24-week-old military regime.
PARIS, Oct. 4 A study published today indicates that the technological gap between the United States and other advanced Western countries will continue to widen.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 4 State Representative Carl B. Stokes, the Negro who won the Democratic nomination for Mayor last night, emerged today as a slight favorite in the general election on Nov. 7.
An early advance in the stock market yesterday faded in afternoon trading and closing prices on the New York Stock Exchange showed a few more declines than advances.
Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Odin of Laurelton, Queens, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Ellen Odin, to Marcel Grunspan. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Grunspan of New York.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) Americans redeemed more savings bonds than they bought in September the first such monthly activity in a year, the Treasury Department reported today.
Industrial issues declined slightly on the London Stock Exchange yesterday. Dealers attributed the dip to a technical adjustment following recent gains.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 The House rejected a compromise $13.2-billion domestic appropriations bill today as an economy wave continued to sweep through Congress.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission said today that patents for tetracycline were obtained by misrepresentation and the deliberate withholding of data by the American Cyanamid Company and Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI) The House Committee on Un-American Activities approved today a bill providing for public registration of Communists.

A new kind of nightclub act the exorcising of ghosts is taking place twice each evening at the Maisonette of the St. Regis-Sheraton. There, Marni Nixon, a small, vivacious, russet-haired soprano, is trying to divest herself of the ghostly voices of Audrey Hepburn, Natalie Wood, Deborah Kerr, Janet Leigh, even Margaret O'Brien.
The Public Development Corporation, formed by Mayor Lindsay last year to attract new industry to the city, announced yesterday the election of two vice presidents and a secretary.
Gabriella Celin, a blond 8year-old girl who came here from Venice for open-heart surgery, was delighted yesterday to see her first live bison.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 4 (UPI) Negroes joined white homeowners today in protesting plans for a low-rent housing project in a small residential strip in the West End. They said they did not care what color their neighbors were as long as they were not poor.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 The United States and the Soviet Union have finally agreed to end the deadlock over new embassy sites here and in Moscow, the State Department announced today.

The Office of Economic Opportunity yesterday accused Syracuse's citywide antipoverty agency, Crusade for Opportunity, of "flagrant abuses" of the Federal office's "fiscal and administrative rules" and formally halted the agency's funds.
The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it would make a number of selected revisions on its carbon steel and wire rod products.

SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 4 (UPI) A group of 138 American combat soldiers and two Wac's arrived in Sydney from Vietnam today for five days of rest. It was the first time that a group of United States combat troops had been given a furlough in Australia since World War II.
Brooklyn Supreme Court Justice Frank Samansky awarded $225,000 today to the widows of two men killed June 9, 1960, when the scaffolding on which they were working collapsed.
The credit manager of a major Fifth Avenue store stared hard at the sales slip before him, swallowed nervously, and then placed an out-of-town call.

CAMDEN, N.Y., Oct. 4 Charles H. Harden, chairman of the board of the Frank S. Harden Company of McConnellsville, manufacturers of cherrywood Colonial furniture, and owner of a local dairy farm, died in his home here on Monday. His age was 83.

Reginald Webster's one-time formidable stakes campaigner, the 5-year-old Nature, came through with a notable success in the feature event at Aqueduct yesterday, beating William Haggin Perry's sharp filly, Romanticism, in a one-mile test for fillies and mares.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) An effort by Republicans to bring a less restrictive gun control measure before a House Judiciary subcommittee was blocked on a 6-to-6 tie vote today, with all Republicans supporting the proposal and all six Democrats present opposing it.

BONN, Oct. 4 The public prosecutor in Munich said today that the mystery,surrounding the death of Stalin's eldest son, Yakov, might be cleared up by a new war-crimes trial scheduled to open next March.

Princess Alexandra of Britain, resplendent in a cowlnecked, silver-threaded white satin gown, swept into Gracie Mansion last night as guest of honor at a formal dinner given by Mayor and Mrs. Lindsay.

The engagement of Miss Marjorie Levin to Carl Alexander Katz has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Monte L. Levin of 16 Sutton Place. Mr. Katz is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Katz of Rego Park, Queens.

The Little Orchestra Society will celebrate its 20th anniversary on Tuesday night with a supper dance in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza after the American premiere of Busoni's "Turandot" at Philharmonic Hall.

HANOI, North Vietnam, Thursday, Oct. 5 Agence France-Presse) Education Minister Nguyen Van Huyen said at a news conference today that American planes had dropped antipersonnel bombs on a North Vietnamese school Sept. 27, killing 33 children and injuring 28. He said the bombs were of the type that spray hundreds of tiny steel balls.

ROME, Oct. 4 An informed source predicted today that Pope Paul VI would consult with the prelates participating in the first Synod of Bishops, either in or outside their meetings, on the issue of birth control.

NAGOYA, Japan, Ot. 4 (UPI) Gary Player of South Africa shot a 2-under par 68 today, maintaining his six-stroke lead over Jack Nicklaus and taking a seven-stroke lead over Arnold Palmer after the second of three exhibition golf matches in Japan.

ATLANTA, Oct. 4 A renovated version of "Gone With the Wind," the epic Hollywood film set in Civil War Atlanta, had its premiere here tonight, at the same theater that first showed the film on Dec. 15, 1939.

GREENVILLE, S. C., Oct. 4-- John Bolt Culbertson, a selfproclaimed liberal Democrat pledged to support the Johnson-Humphrey ticket, will oppose Senator Ernest F. Hollings in the Democratic primary in South Carolina next year.

The success of State Representative Carl Stokes, a Negro, in winning the Democratic nomination for Mayor of Cleveland, where the population is only 35 per cent Negro, is an impressive tribute to the maturity and good sense of the voters in that Ohio industrial center. Although Mr. Stokes polled heavy majorities in Negro areas, he could not have won without the support of a sizable number of white voters.

Msgr. Peter W. Fox, pastor emeritus of the Blessed Virgin Mary, Help of Christians, Roman Catholic Church in Woodside, Queens, died in his sleep Tuesday at the church rectory, 70-31 48th Avenue. He was 76 years old.
MOSCOW, Oct. 3 (UPI) The Soviet Union celebrated today the 10th anniversary of the space age, and it paid tribute to the only known Russian astronaut victim Col. Vladimir M. Komarov.

Before a crop report, traders tend to even their positions just in case. Yesterday was no exception in the field of potato futures. Prices declined slightly in cautious and relatively slow volume of 1,502 contracts.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 4 Yale's loss of its opening game (to Holy Cross) Saturday, a rare occurrence in Eli football, has left Carmen Cozza with a feeling of depression. But the young coach can still find much from which to take comfort and hope for the future.
The New York State Commission for Human Rights is investigating the first set of charges brought before it alleging discrimination because of sex in the maritime labor field.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 A Senate subcommittee voted today to prohibit the sale of lottery tickets by Federally insured banks the principal sales outlet for New York's lagging lottery.

LONDON, Oct. 4 The London Daily Mirror reported yesterday that Harold Philby, the "third man" of a trio of Soviet agents who defected to the Soviet Union, is now married to Melinda Maclean, the divorced wife of the second defector, Donald Maclean. The other, Guy Burgess, has since died.
WYCKOFF, N.J., Oct. 4 Arthur L. Smith, retired vice president for sales of the Paterson Parchment Paper Company of Bristol, Pa., died at his home here yesterday. He was 67 years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 Gen. John P. McConnell, the Air Force Chief of Staff, has told Congress that the Administration's "gradualist" approach in applying air power against North Vietnam has led to additional American casualties in the war.
The nation's electric power production rose 5.5 per cent in the week ended Sept. 30 from the level in the corresponding 1966 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.
TRENTON, Oct. 4 The Democratic state convention today unanimously adopted a legislative platform advocating the lowering of the voting age to 18 in New Jersey.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Oct. 4 William G. Fennell of 16 Halsey Place, Valhalla, associate general solicitor of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, died of a heart attack today in Northern Westchester Hospital here. He was 59 years old.
The New York Philharmonic and its musicians agreed yesterday on a three-year contract that will make the orchestra the highest-paid symphonic group in the country. At the
The 21-story apartment building with a penthouse on the northeast corner of Park Avenue and 73d Street has been sold to David W. Frankel, real estate investor and builder, by George W. Warnecke.

John F. Wharton, the Broadway lawyer, has retired as board chairman of Theater Incorporated, the nonprofit organization that sponsors the Association of Producing Artists-Phoenix Theater. He held the post for 10 years.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4 (AP) Mia Farrow will fly to India for a month of meditation with the mystic Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, her studio said today.

For the sake of spurious "economy" the Senate has turned its back upon the nation's poor. By a vote of 47 to 42 it rejected the plan for intensified manpower training and job-creating projects offered by Senator Prouty, Republican of Vermont, and Senator Clark, Democrat of Pennsylvania.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Oct. 4-- Mr. and Mrs. Daniel D. Mendelson have announced the engagament of their daughter, Miss Lois Jean Mendelson, to Frank Forester 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Forester Jr. of Plandome.
BOSTON, Oct. 4 (AP) Two college boys attempted to "scalp" World Series tickets today and wound up without tickets or profits.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 "Fear of aircraft noise," not lack of money, is "the main threat to new airport expan sion," the nation's top aviation official said today.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 4 Mr. and Mrs. Philip Crawford Mitchell of Bronxville and Stratton Mountain, Vt., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nan Kerr Mitchell, to Reed Loomis Harman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Page Gerald Harman of West Hartford and Stratton Mountain.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 4 The engagement of Miss Dorothy Marie O'Donnell to Edward Reilly Jr. has been announced by her mother, Mrs. Thomas E. O'Donnell. Mr. Reilly is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Reilly of Ossining.

William S. Gaud, head of the Agency for International Development, said yesterday that the growth rate in the economies of several Asian nations indicated opportunities were opening there for local and foreign industries.
